Brief Description: Minor contact between two vessels. There was no damage to the vessels.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
The vessel came into port and made contact with vessels which resulted in structural damage to the other vessels
The vessel came into port and made contact with vessels which resulted in structural damage to the other vessels
While shifting pallet boxes, the crew member's hand became caught between the box and rail, resulting in a fracture of their left ring finger.
A close quarters situation occurred south of the berth between two vessels which were making for the bunker berth.
A close quarters situation occurred south of the berth between two vessels which were making for the bunker berth.
Passenger felt dizzy and blacked out, falling to the ship deck and sustaining a fractured rib.
The wind pushed the bow towards the pontoon, vessel rested on corner on pontoon aft to mid ships. Damage caused to hull structure.
Several logs fell off vessel in close proximity to stevedore.
The combination pilot ladder boarding arrangement was not secured to the ships hull.
Damage under vessel belting was found upon routine check by skipper. Skipper believed the possible cause was the vessel being pushed into the pier by the wake of a passing boat.

Vessel ordered dead stern Ahead. The engine failed to fire, they tried again from wing control, centre control and engine control, it would still not fire. Tugs were used to arrest astern movement and berth the dead ship.
A log dropped from the trailer onto the wharf.
A log dropped 3 metres onto the deck. The log was retrieved and put back onto the heave.

A passenger started seizing. The vessel parked at a ramp and transported other passengers off the vessel. The passenger stayed onboard with their minders before their condition stabilised and they were able depart the vessel
When berthing the ship the speed did not reduce as expected and came close to berth. Ship backed off the engines and tugs assisted and the vessel berthed as planned.
A log dropped from the deck onto the wharf.
A log dropped from the trailer while taking the weight with the crane, the log landed on the berth behind the trailer.
Vessel suffered a failure of the CCP mechanism in the propeller hub, effectively disabling it. A tow was called to take the vessel back to shore, this took a few days.
A crewmember was pinned between two 40" full reefer boxes. They were taken to hospital for treatment.
The vessel had a trapdoor pilot ladder arrangement. The ladder was not attached to the hull side.
The raft flipped and pulled rafters right ring finger sideways. First aid was applied.
Log handling error resulted in log sliding onto the wharf.
Vessel ran out of fuel, the fuel gauge failure resulted in the vessel not being filled.
Skipper and crew member temporarily blinded after being hit in the eyes by a laser light that was being directed into the vessel wheelhouse.

The luffing wire broke, possibly due to the boom bouncing when coming free after discharging the heave in the side deck. One of the runs came off the spool which in turn caught on the drum brake, cutting the wire.
During a spin a passenger received a minor cut above their eye after bumping into the seat in front of them. First aid was applied and they were taken to a medical centre once on shore.
Vessel experienced loss of starboard shaft propulsion whilst maneuvering into the rail ferry berth, due to failure to start of the starboard gearbox electrically driven lube oil pump.
A log dropped from the trailer.

A spark entered the engine room via a partially opened panel and set fire to either a leather fire blanket or a dust cover over the port auxiliary. Crew emptied a co2 extinguisher through a hole which in turn extinguished the fire.

The skipper was setting up the boat for the spin it started to bounce. The timing of the bounce and the positioning of the boat came together to cause the boat to come down on top of a small submerged rock. This caused damage to the vessel.
A log fell from the deck stow into the sea.
A log fell from the deck into the sea.

A large wave hit the vessel on the starboard side rolling the vessel to port approx. 40 to 50 degrees. A crewmember was thrown across the wheelhouse and landed on their tailbone on the step inside the rear entrance to the wheelhouse.

The vessel was pushed sideways from a large swell and it landed on the rear of the jet unit disabling the forward reverse bucket. Damage sustained to the vessel rear included the destruction of the radio antenna, navigation lamps.

As the cargo of 18 parcels of steel was moved by crane over the edge of the wharf one parcel of three lengths came free and fell on the wharf structure from a height of 5m. One length fell into the harbour and the other two landed on the wharf.

Engineer reported port steam engine had mechanical problems and had to be stopped. Starboard engine and steering gear were in full working order. Vessel berthed without problem at usual position on wharf using one engine only.
Recreational vessel capsized on Raglan bar with three passengers on board. The trio sustained minor facial injuries.
Two incidents of logs falling into the harbour during log loading operations.

The boat proceeded to cover the gap of about 20m under hard acceleration and made impact into the side of another vessel. The station select button did not work so the skipper could not stop the engine. The collision caused damage to both boats.

Internal fitting malfunction resulted in a leak in the vessel. The passenger swam to shore as their vessel ending up sinking. Once on shore, they let emergency services know what had happened. No injuries were sustained.
Log fell approximately 4 metres onto wharf. All personnel were in safe zones. No injuries or damage occurred.
Log fell approx. 4 metres overboard. All personnel were in safe zones. No injuries or damage occurred
The pilot ladder was not up to standard, there were knots and splices throughout the rope.

Lasher was leaning over the safety rail when it gave way due to the bolt having rusted away, narrowly avoiding a 3.5m fall to the vessel deck. The rusted portion of the safety rail had been painted over, disguising the hazard.
The pilot ladders man ropes had knots and splices on the ends and through the lengths of the rope.

On vessel pre-start inspection, several broken strands were noticed on running wire on the drum on Crane 4 on each lay. Crew were advised that work would not start until the wires were changed. The crew changed the running wire and work commenced.
Vessel hit the reef while departing the harbour during a low tide.
Vessel capsized on the bar and four passengers swam to shore safely. Emergency services attended the scene.
Stevedore fell off an open hatch cover and broke both wrists. They were taken to hospital for treatment.

Vessel failed to respond to astern control. Vessel collided with a rock and then slipped back into clear water using centre control. No visible damage occurred with three passengers sustaining minor injuries.
A passenger tripped and fell down the stairs. Conditions were fine and the vessel was slowly approaching its berth. They were helicoptered off the vessel and taken to hospital as a precaution.

Crewmember fell overboard during yacht race. They were picked up by a following race boat following radio communication to fleet. They were in the water for approx. 5 minutes and sustained no injuries.

Whilst loading deck cargo, a log that had previously been loaded rolled off the deck and dropped several metres back on to the wharf. No injuries were sustained and the scene was frozen till crew were approved to work again.

The accommodation ladder was not secured to the ships side. The ladder platform was not level and was obstructing access to the pilot ladder. Crew rigging the arrangement were not wearing lifejackets or safety harness.

Vessel erred while coming alongside another vessel, touching slightly harder than planned. This resulted in the hand rails been bent inwards slightly and the MOB smoke float being activated. No injuries were sustained.

The vessel was knocked down due to a wind gust. Crew climbed over side with one in water. Boat shortly inverted with pivoting centre-board extended. Two crew members were picked up, the other fixed the anchor. No injuries, vessel was towed to shore.
The skipper could not pull the vessel off the concrete ramp before the low tide, and the vessel grounded on the ramp.

Gantry hook become dislodged when crewmember was lifting mussel back bone causing some soreness but no physical damage to skin or bruising. A few hours later they had a seizure, work was stopped immediately and the vessel headed to port.

Skipper turned on the motor in fwd. propulsion to manoeuvre away from another vessel in attempt to prevent a collision. A minor collision occurred between the two vessels, the beltings on the hull of each boat bumped. No damage or injuries occurred.

The crew were changing trawl nets, the Bosun was assisting to push heavy chain weights on to the net-roller and their hard hat became dislodged. While retrieving their hat, the chain slipped and knocked their head.
A drop of wood stain dripped into the workers right eye resulting in immediate pain and discomfort. First aid was carried out until the injured worker arrived at hospital. Corneal burns sustained.
Log truck released their brakes early while onboard resulting with it rolling and hitting the boarding ramp.
Event Location: Butters Landing Ferry, Port of Tauranga

Brief Description: Log fell approx. 4 metres in to the water, all personnel were in safe zones. No injuries or damage occurred.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
The pilot ladder was not secured correctly. It also had knots, splices and shackles in the ropes.
During log lift onto deck, a log slipped out and overboard on the vessel's starboard side into the water.

RCCNZ was advised of a crewmember who had a serious medical condition onboard and required hospital treatment. The crewmember was transferred to a pilot vessel then to shore where an ambulance was waiting.

Crewperson installed a lashing chain onto the right rear section of a car transporter. The vehicle was then motioned forward and the bar where the lashing was attached failed and hit crewperson’s leg, causing them to suffer a broken tibia/fibula.

Skipper accidentally put steering into inactive mode. They could not correct and tried to slow vessel and avoid impact with cardinal maker. The wind was too strong and the vessel made impact with marker with port bow. Marker collapsed on impact.
Stevedore crane driver turned the crane clockwise into the hatch while another crane was in their blind spot, resulting in a minor collision.
One of the stanchion posts was detached at its base due to a forceful impact with logs while deck loading operation was in progress. Loading was ceased, and no injuries were reported.
Two logs were dropped onto the wharf, all personnel were in a safe zone. The scene was not frozen, and was cleaned up with the digger.
The waka began approaching a moored vessel and they tried to correct and pull away, their waka came in contact with the front of the vessel. Vessels sustained minor cosmetic damage only.
Smoke was seen coming from hold no. 5. Cargo onboard. Multi cargo operation called fire services and they commenced dousing hotspots onboard vessel.

600L of molasses cargo overflowed from the cargo tank hatch, spilling on deck and overboard. This was immediately reported to the duty officer and cargo pump was stopped simultaneously. Spilled cargo was contained on deck and crew commenced clean up.
When attaching lines to vessel one broke and hit the helmet off one linesman and had a near miss with another.

All four blocks on the vessel were found with significant corrosion and wastage around some top bolts of the blocks. The swivel on the block of crane 4 was found to be missing 3 of the 4 bolts connecting it to the block. Repairs were arranged.
The pilot ladder was not secured to the ships side above the 1.5m accommodation ladder platform.
The non-coking coal cargo had been smoking while the vessel was at berth. One fire service was  at the scene. Vessel crew were hitting "hot spots" and the situation improved.
Upon climbing the ladder the crewmember held onto the rung which moved and cracked. Operations in this hatch ceased till further notice.
Vessel lost power to half of the main power distribution board as a generator was being brought back on line. Other generator started to take the load.
Logs dropped onto the wharf. All personnel were in safe zones and no injuries were sustained.
The block of No.4 crane was deformed due to rough handling of cargo logs by stevedores, no damage occurred to the ship's strength and seaworthiness.
During log loading, logs fell back into the bunk. All personnel were in safe zones.
The starboard bridge wing main engine rev indicator was faulty.
The main engine stopped. Skipper aborted the approach and turned hard to port away from the entrance. After communication between the bridge and engine room, the engine started working again.
The pilot ladder was non compliant.
Crew member slipped and fell down stairs, sustaining a cracked rib.

Port engine dropped revs, but did not cut out. Further investigation proved there was a partial blockage at exit of fuel tank. All passengers were transferred to another vessel. Fuel tank was cleared.

A faulty O-ring in Raycor Filter lead to loss of fuel to engine, resulting in the engine stopping. The anchor was laid, the filter was removed and a new O-ring was reinstalled. The engine was then restarted.

The crane driver noticed that the crane started to shudder when luffing down towards lower luff limit to place a heave of logs on deck. The luffing wire had jumped off the sheave and was damaged. It was replaced, no injuries occurred.

Passenger attempted jump, slipped, and hit hand rail before landing in water which resulted in a fractured left femur. Patient was transferred to the beach via the tender and transferred to hospital via helicopter.
Five passengers were on-board, the skipper and two people were trapped under the vessel for a short period of time. All were rescued from under the hull. Every passenger had life jackets on.

The main engine alarms went off and the engine needed to be stopped due to high temperatures. A tug was in attendance and made fast C/L aft which then arrested the forward motion. The vessel was dead ship and pulled astern back to the berth safely.
As the anchor was retrieved, the vessel took water through anchor well and foundered. Vessel flipped/capsized and two people were retrieved and returned safely to shore.

A boat was towed back to port after it was reported drifting near Bluff. There were three passengers on board who contacted police to say they could not get their boat started. They were all wearing life jackets, no injuries or damage occurred.

A boat was spotted by kayakers that was capsized and aground on rocks at Cable Bay. The two passengers called police sometime later to advise that they had had an accident in their boat but had self-rescued and were safe and well.
A vessel capsized when crossing the bar, all members on board were rescued by a passing fishing boat.
A fuel leak was detected, the repair was not satisfactory so a call for tow was made. The auto bilge pump was disconnected. At the wharf the bilge water was removed and a fuel filter was refit.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Vessel had a loss of propulsion due to blown hydraulic hose on transmission. The anchor was deployed and a tow was arranged back to Port. Oil in bilge was contained and cleaned and removed from vessel.
Logs were dropped while at berth, they were dropped seaside. The scene was not frozen as they fell away from all personnel.
Logs dropped into the sea, the scene was not frozen as all personnel were in their safe zones.
A vessel with five passengers on board broke down. Assistance was required and the vessel was towed back to shore.
Jetboat engine stopped during testing, the skipper threw the bowline to their colleague who was following behind and the vessel was towed back to shore.
Allegation from boatie that while queued at a boat ramp, their boat was deliberately rammed by another vessel driven by an abusive skipper.
Event Location: Kawakawa Bay Boat Club's Boat Ramp

Brief Description: The vessels main engine failed to start off berth. After two failed attempts, emergency controls were used and the engine worked. Loss of air occurred, no indication of the reason of failure was found.
A vessel was observed powering through an area full of feeding marine animals to get to their next work spot.
Vessel lost situational awareness in thick fog, resulting in a grounding.
The pilot ladder was not compliant, it was joined together under the bottom thread.
Logs dropped port side of vessel to the water. No personnel were close and the scene was not frozen.

Skipper saw smoke coming from the engine room vent. They stopped the vessel and saw a small fire in the engine room. They extinguished the fire and called for assistance. The vessel was towed to berth.
Event Location: Northwest of Silo Park Marine, Auckland

Brief Description: A log fell from deck one from the ship onto the wharf. No personnel were in the area, no damage or harm occurred.

Crane driver was pulling wires out of a heave placed in the well side. While pulling the wires, one caught on a stanchion, lifting the heave up at one end. Three logs slid off the heave and fell over the side of the vessel into the water.

The vessel touched ground on the Reef which caused damage to the propellers and the vessel to ground. All passengers were transferred to other vessels. The vessel was re-floated on the tide and was towed to port.

A pot had become stuck on a break, upon beginning to haul the pot a large wave began to form so the skipper released the pot and turned to head for safer waters. The surge sucked out and the boat struck a rock causing major damage.
Vessel was T boned on its starboard by a yacht and sustained a large hole to its hull. Vessel started taking on water, the engine cut out and vessel was towed back.
Vessel was T boned on its starboard by a yacht and sustained a large hole to its hull. Vessel started taking on water, the engine cut out and vessel was towed back.
A log was dropped into the tide. A crew member was dispatched to locate and retrieve the log. Boat ramp security were informed incase any vessels were heading in the direction of the log.
The locknut on the turnbuckle on the steering chain was found to be loose, and the chain had jumped several links. This caused the turnbuckle to jam against the top steering pinion.
A log slipped off the deck onto the protective rubber barriers between the wharf and vessel.

Coastguard were called to assist a vessel which had not returned. They were located and taken under tow, large waves hit both vessels capsizing the vessel under tow, putting both crew in the water. The tow line was cut free, and they were rescued.
The combination ladder had a hole in the platform and ladder and man ropes hung under the platform.

Smoke was observed from the engine room vents by crew and the alarm sounded in the wheelhouse. A small fire in the 240volt wiring was put out with a fire extinguisher. The system was isolated and the vessel went back to wharf.

Main engine No.3 which was supplying all the ship's power via the port shaft generator malfunctioned. The breaker for the port shaft generator supplying the main switchboard opened, causing momentarily brown out. Steerage was interrupted momentarily.
A log fell into the water while the vessel was being loaded.
Vessel was observed discharging brownish coloured liquid from its portside aft quarter.
A log fell in to the water during log loading.
While commencing lift from trailer, a log slipped out of heave onto the wharf. All personal situated in safety zone approximately 20 metres away. The scene was frozen.
Vessel hit rocks and took on water with one passenger on board. A mayday call was made and another vessel soon responded and towed the boat to safety.
One log fell from a crane and onto the wharf. No one was injured, and the scene was frozen.
Passenger fainted as they were getting out of bed, falling to the floor and sustaining bilateral broken ankles.

While preparing the gangway before ship departure, a crew member lost their balance and fell 2.5 metres from the gangway to the wharf. Emergency services were called and the injured party went to hospital with cuts, bruises and pain in their knee.
A passenger fell over by accident, fracturing their left hip.
A log slipped of the ships deck back onto the wharf whilst another load was being slung on. No one was in close proximity and no one was injured or hurt. The operation was frozen.
The ECDIS displays on the vessel were in error when the vessel was moving. The position on the ECDIS was lagging behind the visual and radar positions, the lag increased as speed increased.

The vessels mainsail had broken, along with their Jib and one engine. Their second engine was operating at 50% power, but was unstable. The vessel requested a tow back to shore. The police assisted with a tow back.
Passenger fell out of their canoe into river and sustained a torn bicep. They made their way to the side of the river and were transferred to hospital via helicopter.

Skipper noticed the steering was getting tight and had started to bind. Assessment from technicians on board ascertained the fault was in the steering column. The boat was returned to the trailer and taken to the workshop to investigate the cause.

Vessel stalled due to fuel problem. Another vessel was contacted via VHF and was able to hook on tow rope and towed them to deeper water. The skipper changed the secondary fuel filters and proceeded to sea.
Crew on watch were not paying attention and the vessel made contact with the sandy seafloor and came to a stop. No damage occurred and the vessel was moved.

The crane driver was pulling wires out of hold and the feral hit a rusted tank fitting, a piece of metal plate come off the tank and landed on the wharf. All personnel were in safe zones, the scene was frozen.
Two passengers on board fell out of their boat and found it difficult to get boat to the side. A jet boat came along and picked them up as they decided not to continue.
A passenger bumped their head on the dashboard during a spin. They were assessed and the injury was minor. An ice pack was applied after trip had returned.
Event Location: Upper Shotover River by Pleasant Creek

Brief Description: A log was dropped from the vessel on to the wharf. No one was injured or harmed, the scene was frozen.
The ladder was secured at the deck level in a manner that caused the steps to be at an angle. The ladder appeared well worn with loose chocks on many steps.
Logs dropped about 8 metres onto wharf. No personnel were in danger, the scene was frozen.
The ladder was secured on deck with shackles and the chocks were loose on numerous steps.

Crew member had a medical emergency which resulted in sudden blindness, numbness of one side of body and they subsequently collapsed. A mayday call was made and a helicopter transferred the patient to hospital.

Vessel made contact with the pontoon. This caused a piercing in the vessel and the impact popped the lid off the dinghy oil. The oil leaked into the water, majority of it was contained by removal of the container.

A canoe was on the river when a jet boat passed them closely. There was an alternative path with more room but the jet boat driver went as close as possible. This occurred twice during the trip, resulting in two near misses.

A canoe was on the river when a jet boat passed them closely. There was an alternative path with more room but the jet boat driver went as close as possible. This occurred twice during the trip, resulting in two near misses.
The vessel had a poorly rigged and well worn ladder on the starboard side when it arrived.
When wires were released on deck, a log slid out and landed in the water, starboard side. It was later retrieved.
The digger operator dropped one log in the water while loading a hatch. It was retrieved safely, no damage or injury occurred.

The skipper got no response from the port main engine, they managed to pull up alongside the wharf with their starboard engine only. The twin disc was replaced and the vessel was tested before it returned for service.

When manoeuvring the vessel into port the main engines failed to start astern. The vessel was stopped, swung and berthed without the use of the main engine. Tugs assisted and the starboard anchor was used.
Whilst berthed at the dock, another vessel came in at high speed and crashed into the berthed vessel. This resulted in damage to both vessels, no injuries were sustained.
Minor swelling/bruising occurred to crew member's hand after being pinched by a cylinder head during repair.
During loading a log fell into the sea; no person was near and no person was injured.
A log dropped onto the wharf from a height of 4 metres. Everyone was in safe zones.
Skipper of fishing vessel acting aggressively towards skippers of other fishing vessels in the area.
Skipper of fishing vessel acting aggressively towards skippers of other fishing vessels in the area.
A worker tripped on a part of the ship structure and collided with another part of shift structure resulting in a broken collarbone.
Two logs slipped from the heave, the scene was frozen.
A log dropped onto the wharf, all personnel were in a safe zone. The log was wet/slippery and had minimal bark, the load was slightly off centre causing the log to slip out.
While putting down the crane, the hook pressed the crews finger, resulting in a fracture. The master was informed and they were taken to hospital.
Sewage valve failed. A temporary repair was made before being replaced with a new valve.
Logs were dropped onto the wharf.
A rope got entangled in the propeller, the vessel was towed to shore.
A log was dropped onto berth. Personnel were in the safe zones and the scene was frozen.

Emergency stop was called while loading due to failure of on board hydraulically activated cargo valves. The engineer checked the valve and added more oil. The bulb had blown and no alarm had sounded.
SLSNZ canoe capsized, three passengers made it to shore, while the other one struggled. The other canoe passengers swam back to assist the passenger, who was then taken to hospital to be monitored.

The back corner of the boat got caught on a rock. Skipper tried to power away but the current of the water pushed the nose of the boat under and rolled over. The boat was recovered the following week once the river dropped.

The pilot ladder had been prepared but the quality did not meet standards. There was tape around all of the chocks in an attempt to hold them in place. Several steps were on an angle and the spreader was loose.
A Yacht headed towards a vessel on a collision course. The vessel had to take evasive actions to avoid a collision and sounded their horn five times. No injuries occurred.
The pilot ladder was incorrectly attached to the vessel.

A wind gust pushed the vessel sideways leaving less room to manoeuvre on the starboard side. When the final turn to port was made the vessel made contact with the stern of another vessel. Minor damage occurred.
Ammonia detection alarms sounded. Crew were evacuated while engineers checked the leak. The leak was not able to be fixed while at sea. The vessel turned back to the port for repairs.
A log fell from deck 3 of the vessel onto the wharf. The log landed in the safe zone, away from crew. No injuries occurred.
A log came out of the grapple on Deck 4 and landed in the water. No damage or injury occurred, the log was retrieved safely.
Rafting guide fell out of vessel and hit the passenger in front of them, resulting in a concussion for the passenger.
A skipper was harassed by three other vessels which were approaching and then turning away in a dangerous manner. The skipper contacted the police as they felt unsafe.
A skipper was harassed by three other vessels which were approaching and then turning away in a dangerous manner. The skipper contacted the police as they felt unsafe.
Port engine stopped during spin at the Jetty. The cause was found to be a wire which had chaffed on an engine part and shorted to earth.
While worker was welding, an ammonia pipe that had not been purged combusted. This resulted in hearing loss and minor facial burns.
A pot became stuck and the rope flung back out, causing buoys to strike a crew member in the chest. The impact knocked the crew member to the ground, resulting in bruising and two broken ribs.

A small fire occurred in the Communications Centre which affected non-statutory equipment. Cabins near Comms Centre were evacuated, majority of smoke was contained in the Comm Centre.  The power was turned off while investigations were made.
Skipper found that all batteries were drained and sent out a PAN PAN text. The vessel had no other issues. A vessel assisted by bringing out batteries.
Vessel grounded on soft mudbank two hours before low tide. A kedge anchor was deployed by a passing vessel and they floated off without damage or spillage.
The approach to berth was misaligned and the vessel made contact with a pile on the wharf at an approx. speed of 2 knots. No injury or damage to the vessel occurred.
As crew were loading the deck with vehicles, a crew member was guiding one of the vehicles back when they tripped on one of the shackles on deck, causing them to fall land on their hand.

The crane lifting block was slightly unscrewed from the swivel. The locking plate that keeps the swivel and hook together had been damaged/dislodged, causing the hook to unscrew from the swivel. Repairs were made to secure the hook.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
The pilot ladder was not attached to the ship's side 1.5m above the accommodation ladder platform, as per international shipping standards.
The vessel filled with water quickly forcing the two passengers to evacuate. The boat stayed afloat and the police were contacted.
The vessel grounded with three passengers on board, it was dark and nothing showed on the radar. No damage or spillage occurred. Two other vessels responded and assisted. All passengers were okay.

During loading, a single log rolled between the stanchions and overboard, wharf side, into the sea. There were no injuries, and no damage to the vessel or equipment. The log was retrieved from the sea.
Fire occurred in the electrical cadet cabin. The electrical power was switched off for accommodation and fire fighting commenced. The main engine was stopped and the fire was extinguished.
While loading logs, two fell from the deck onto the wharf. They then rolled into the water. No injuries occurred. The scene was frozen.
The pilot ladder was secured by shackles to the accommodation ladder.
The man ropes of the ladder were non compliant.
Log slipped out of heave just as it was being lifted off the trailer, the log was retrieved safely.
The vessels engine cut out without warning. The master restarted the vessel instantly, though the engine cut out again 10 mins later. Assistance was required to take the passengers to shore.

The fuel return line broke, causing the motor to stall. The spare anchors were used to hold the vessel. The rope broke on the spare anchor so the main anchor was used until another vessel towed them to shore.

While approaching the bar a wave caught the stern of the vessel and spun it 90 degrees to port with a significant list. The vessel was then spun to starboard again with a significant list. The skipper managed to regain control of the vessel.
While discharging containers, a container caught under the lip of a ballast tank, causing two spreader lifting chains to break.
A wave came over the back and cut out the outboard engines. The boat washed onto the beach. Vessel was salvaged onto trailer immediately and taken in for repairs.
The pilot ladder had uneven gaps between the steps, which were also at an angle.
Stevedore employee's pinkie finger crushed between the spreader and container.

There was a drop in oil pressure. The vessel was placed into idle ahead while crew checked the control unit and engine room. Wind caused vessel to drift and make contact with the channel marker. Minor damage occurred to the starboard side.

Vessel was struck by a large wave on its port side. The vessel was pushed due to the force of the wave, the captain then straighten up the vessel. Crew cleaned up items that had shifted. Damage occurred, no injuries occurred.

On departure the bridge alarm sounded, the vessel had lost main engine power. The tug was instructed to re-attach and steering was maintained using tugs and rudder. The engines were restored after a few minutes. A sensor failure was the cause.
A pole hit a crew member in the jaw, causing them to fall backwards and hit their head. They were rendered unconscious for 30 seconds and sustained a laceration to the chin as well as a concussion.

Steering locked up while boat was proceeding downstream. The skipper manoeuvred the boat to the shore, calling the workshop for assistance. A fault was found within the steering helm assembly. All boats were removed for a fleet wide inspection.
The strapping broke on pallet while being loaded by vessel cranes. Pallet contents fell 1.5m onto wharf, no injuries occurred.
A hydraulic hose burst and approximately 5 litres of hydraulic oil was lost overboard into the harbour. Pump was stopped immediately and the rest was contained on-board.

The skipper did not realise the vessel was in reverse when the sampling equipment was deployed. The gear fouled the starboard propeller, damaging three prop blades. There was no injury to crew, and the vessel returned to shore to assess the damage.
While tying the vessel to the wharf the line jumped from cleat and crew member's hand made contact with metal gate stop resulting in a fractured wrist.

Low coolant alarm on starboard engine sounded, and port generator failed. The engine was switched off and on inspection an open flame was detected in the starboard engine. Starboard generator started and vessel returned to berth on the port engine.
The upper two bolts holding a ladder in place gave way when a stevedore climbed down the ladder. The stevedore was not hurt.

A crew member was in the process of picking up fish off the deck whilst another deckhand was pushing fish into the hold with the pusher. The pusher slipped out of the deckhand's grip, and the handle made contact with the crew member's head.
A pallet of 35 bags of fishmeal, each weighing 30 kg, fell approx. 2 metres onto the deck.
The raft flipped and all passengers ended up overboard. One occupant sustained a dislocated shoulder.
Log fell into water between ship and wharf during loading.
Passenger sustained a back injury following raft capsize. They were transferred to hospital for assessment.
Diver struck by boat's propeller. This resulted in a serious leg injury and they were taken to hospital via a helicopter.
The main engine failed whilst manoeuvring off berth. Vessel proceeded at slow speed towards berth. Vessel continued berthing using engine room control.
Operator was hand stacking side of deck when a log slipped between the stanchion and fell onto berth from deck.
A log was lost over the side of the vessel and landed in the water on the sea side.
While slinging up to lift off the trailer and while the crane was taking the weight, a broken log on top fell on the wharf between the trailer and vessel.
Two log drops occurred at the same time, both into water.
Two log drops occurred, one into water and one onto berth.
The crane operator was pulling out the wires too close to the edge and flicked a log off the ship into the water.
Two vessels collided while approaching berth. One vessel altered their course and this resulted in the vessels colliding, damage occurred to both vessels.
Two vessels collided while approaching berth. One vessel altered their course and this resulted in the vessels colliding, damage occurred to both vessels.
A log was dropped while loading the ship.
A piece of equipment failed, causing logs to drop 3-4 metres onto the deck . The scene was frozen.
A log dropped onto wharf, no personnel were in danger and the scene was frozen.
Log fell onto the wharf when the weight was taken on heave, no personnel were in danger and the scene was frozen.
Log fell when weight taken on heave from wharf. No personnel were in danger.
While the logs were being loaded into the bunk a log slipped and fell into the water. There was no one nearby, except the loader driver.

The motion of the vessel on the wharf caused the starboard side bow cleat to snap off, leaving a small hole in the deck. The vessel was turned round on the wharf and made fast port side to the wharf. The vessel was removed from service.
A crew member hurt themselves while on the vessel and was taken to hospital via an ambulance where they were diagnosed with a herniated disc.

A vessel approached from behind at high speed passing in front of the vessel, missing bow ramp by a couple of metres. The skippers sounded the horn, the driver of the vessel appeared to be startled and not aware of their position.

Vessel was attempting to move off pontoon and remove spring-line when wash from another vessel swung it into a third vessel. The bow of the vessel shattered the other vessel's windows. Both masters were uninjured.
During rafting trip, raft flipped and a passenger's thumb was caught between the rope and raft and dislocated. Following the rafting trip, ice was applied to it to keep the inflammation down.
Log slipped off bunk, landed on berth 30 metres from nearest person. The scene was frozen.
Heavy winds prevented berthing. During this, the vessel made contact with a beacon.
Log drop occurred, no injuries were sustained. The scene was frozen.
Log fell when weight was taken on heave from trailer on wharf the logs had not lifted any distance yet. No injuries or damage to equipment occurred.
Two logs fell when the weight was taken on heave from trailer onto wharf. No damages occurred to the equipment.
While loading the vessel, four logs fell from the heave as the weight was taken off the bunk. The logs were extremely slipper due to rainfall.

There was a small fuel spill onboard that resulted in approx. 15L of diesel being spilled over the side into the water. The ship then immediately placed absorbent pads to stop further fuel spills over the side.

Tug slipped on hull and tug mast came into contact with flare of bow, tug reversed and realigned and continued pushing on until docking operations completed. The top half of the mast bent and top navigation lights were damaged.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
One of the vessels own vehicle tugs exhaust manifolds overheated and caught fire, the fixed drenching system was used then fire parties fully extinguished the fire.

Sailing yacht impeded safe passage of another vessel. They became becalmed in the centre of the channel and did not attempt to motor to safety. The pilot of the other vessel had to stop engines and manoeuvre around the yacht using tugs.

The vessel was brought under control using astern engine power and the assistance of the two tugs, although it made contact with the seabed. Both tugs were damaged during the event and their towlines parted while bringing the vessel under control.

The vessel was brought under control using astern engine power and the assistance of the two tugs, although it made contact with the seabed. Both tugs were damaged during the event and their towlines parted while bringing the vessel under control.

The vessel was brought under control using astern engine power and the assistance of the two tugs, although it made contact with the seabed. Both tugs were damaged during the event and their towlines parted while bringing the vessel under control.
Crew member suffered a laceration while working in the ship fish processing plant.
A log fell onto the wharf while lifting it on to the ship. There were no injuries.

A complete fail of the 108V circuit, resulted in total loss of power to the electric engine. All fuses were checked, the vessel made sail to the harbour entrance and was towed in for berthing. It was due to a failure of controller of electric engine.
While lifting logs, one fell out of the sheath when the weight was taken on the crane.

Propulsion failure occurred when the vessel tried to start back up after stopping for commentary. The vessel was taken ashore and tied up whilst other driver brought second boat to scene to move passengers.
Passenger sustained an injury to their upper back during a rafting trip and were taken to hospital for assessment.
While conducting loading operations some logs were dropped, no injuries occurred and operations were stopped.
Logs were dropped onto wharf while conducting loading operations using ships cranes. No injuries occurred and operations were suspended.
On approach to the mooring the main engine failed. The anchor was dropped and the engine failure was investigated. The engine was able to be restarted and vessel sailed to mooring.
Bridge telegraph potentiometer fault was causing main engine to stop. This was resolved and the vessel departed without incident.
A log was dropped while the vessel was loading logs, no injuries occurred. Operations were suspended.
Logs dropped into water during loading operations.
Cargo ship overtaking a yacht, the vessel got within 200m of the yacht and the yacht had to take last minute action to avoid a collision.
Cargo ship overtaking a yacht, the vessel got within 200m of the yacht and the yacht had to take last minute action to avoid a collision.
Raft flipped during descent down falls, with one passenger sustaining a broken leg. The vessel was brought to shore where the passenger was transferred to an ambulance

The vessel responded to the helm and began to turn, in the final part of the turn the vessel came round with the stern striking the river bank. No passengers or crew were injured and the after peak showed that the hull, while dented was water tight.

Sparks observed emitting from the vessel's battery area. The master switched off the isolating switch which stopped the sparking. The boat was returned to the trailer on the second motor and was pulled in for repairs.
A couple of logs fell off during loading of the vessel, all workers were in a safe area and the site was frozen.

Vessel's gangway bent upon arrival at port, after mooring operation had been completed. The driver pulled the line they tied up on gangway frame abruptly, causing fore part of the gangway to bend & tearing the ladder plate on each side.
One log fell from the heave approx. 1.5 metres. No injuries or damage occurred.
Log fell when weight was taken up on heave, the scene was frozen.
One log fell from the heave as weight was taken up by crane. No injuries or damage occurred.
Log fell when weight was taken up on heave, no damage or injuries occurred.
Two logs dropped onto wharf while the crane was taking on the weight.
A log fell from the vessel onto the wharf during loading. No damage or injuries occurred.
Log dropped from vessel to water, no injuries and log was retrieved.

Vessel's spud leg was not operating correctly causing the other two spud legs to become bound. The vessel was listing as the tide was receding. The vessel was assessed by the barge master and it was not deemed to be in danger.

The port engine high temp alarm sounded; coolant temp had gone up to 100C. The vessel was shut down. The water pump wasn’t working and the impeller was replaced with a spare. Vessel temp came down and engine was restarted.

A tender from a vessel failed to give way to yachts racing under sail. Tender driver sounded their horn and maintained course, across the group of yachts under sail. Vessels ended up very close but no contact.

Crew was passing a cord through the ferry window while at berth. They leaned forward and put their hand on the boat for support, but instead the boat moved further away, resulting in crew member falling into the water between the boat and jetty.
Several logs fell from the heave onto the wharf. No damages or injuries occurred.
The pilot ladder was not up to standard, the chocks on various steps were loose, the ladder was secured to the deck using shackles and chain.
Main engine shut down. Engine was able to be restarted and the vessel then resumed its journey.

Capsized kayaker dislocated their shoulder whilst trying to roll their kayak upright. Their kayak instructor took control of the situation and transported them to a vehicle where they were taken via ambulance to hospital.
Log dropped onto wharf during loading. No injuries or damage occurred.

The vessel was surveying at night when an unlit fishing vessel came into close proximity. The search lights were put onto the fishing vessel and the master correctly assessed the situation and avoided a collision.

The vessel was surveying at night when an unlit fishing vessel came into close proximity. The search lights were put onto the fishing vessel and the master correctly assessed the situation and avoided a collision.

Vessel clipped nozzle on a rock which reduce their steering and reverse. They stopped, threw anchor, radioed other boat, pulled their anchor, beached boat and transferred passengers to other boat, they then boated back to the ramp and trailer.
Propulsion failure occurred while entering the wharf. While berthing was being carried out, the wind blew the vessel into jetty, minimal damage occurred above the belting.

A vessel was laying ropes and the rope snared the foil of a windboard.  They were thrown off their board at speed and fell into their sail. Their windboard was damaged and they received minor injuries.
Lifting wire disconnected from the crank spin resulting in several logs falling 2m onto the wharf. No injuries or damage occurred.

When the dinghy was returning to shore from the main vessel's mooring it filled with water and capsized. All three crew fell overboard, were wearing life jackets and were able to swim to shore. No damage or injuries occurred.
Stevedore slipped on stairs and fell onto deck, resulting in a suspected concussion.
Crane caught wires on raised stanchions which caused 4x stanchions to collapse back into their fold position.
Log dropped onto wharf, no injuries or damage occurred.

Jet Boat ordered the disembarkation of passengers after venturing into water that was too shallow to proceed. The passengers were offloaded onto the bank, where one received a laceration on their foot from a rock on the riverbed.
Passenger missed handrail when walking down stairs and tumbled 2 metres down. First aid was applied onboard and when they got to shore they were taken to hospital to be checked up.

A passenger was pushed overboard as a joke while the passengers were celebrating a function They swam to shore safely and the master and crew informed the passengers the behaviour wasn't appropriate. The vessel docked and all passengers hopped off.
Raft passenger suffered a broken leg after the raft flipped. They were brought ashore and transported them to hospital for further medical assistance.

Vessel was taking on water and they were unable to assess the water ingress. Crew activated their ERIPB, a helicopter and nearby ship went to assist the crew. All three people on board were winched to safety.
When berthing to unload fish at conclusion of fishing trip the boat would not go astern and it hit the wharf.
Rowing skiff bow penetrated a red marker buoy, no injuries occurred. There was minor damage to the boat and buoy.
As the crane started to take the weight of packet off the trailer,  a log slid out. no injuries or damage occurred.
The pilot ladder man ropes were rigged incorrectly, no stanchions or handhold were above the deck for manropes to run through.
While doing testing the on-board fire detection system showed a battery fault.
The accommodation ladder was not secured to the ship's side.
Log slipped between stanchion and wharf, falling 3m. No Injuries or damage occurred.
Log dropped into water, no injuries or damage occurred.

On departure the vessel engines misfired several times. Start air was leaking due to a opened valve, tugs held the vessel off the wharf and the engine eventually started and departed with no further incidents.
The vessel suffered a gyro error of up to 10 degrees. The master and crew were aware and when departing the error reduced to 2 - 3 degrees.
On departure tugs pulled vessel off berth, a loud bang was heard from the forward tug line as a securing shackle fractured under tension.
Log fell from the deck of the ship, landing on the wharf. No injuries or damage occurred.
Log dropped from heave onto wharf. Wet and slippery conditions. No Injuries or damage occurred.
Accommodation ladder was not secured to the ships side, the ladder was not attached to ships side 1.5m above accommodation ladder platform.
Log fell onto the wharf. No injuries or damage occurred.
Log fell onto wharf; it had not been lifted out of the trailer at the time it fell. No injuries or damage occurred.
Vessel lines were in poor condition and not tendered. Surge conditions were minimal and reducing at time. The lines were re-secured.
Log dropped onto the wharf, no injuries or damage occurred.

Watchman fell asleep on shift and the vessel hit a rock. The master pulled the boat out of gear and the vessel rolled off the rock. The vessel was assessed, no water was coming in and they steamed around the wharf and berthed the boat
The pilot ladder was secured with incorrect man ropes.
Pilot Ladder was old and in poor condition. It had excessive gap between chocks and steps
A log was dropped onto berth, no injuries or damage occurred. Wet and slippery conditions
While loading vehicles onto the ferry a logging truck driver was repositioning their vehicle and reversed into a ute, which was forced backwards into another ute causing damage to both vehicles.

Starboard engine shutdown. Both engines were then shutdown, and the mains were turned off. All systems were rebooted, only the port engine worked. Vessel continued on just the port engine, a technician found the fault.
Passenger experiencing headache, numbness in hand and arms, and vomiting. Examined by doctor on board and was then taken to hospital by helicopter.
Accommodation ladder was not secured to ships side.
Ladder was not attached to ships side 1.5m above the accommodation ladder platform.
Passenger sustained minor injuries after vessel flipped.

The vessel was put in forward gear and was still moving slowly astern due to its momentum. At this point the vessel came into very minor contact with another vessel as the stern collided with the stern railing/gunwale of that vessel.
While boarding the vessel, a passenger tripped and broke their ankle. They were transported to hospital for treatment.
During loading operations, a log was dropped. No injuries or damage occurred and the log was recovered.
Accommodation ladder was not secured to ships side, one manrope was also lead incorrectly.
A raft passenger was accidentally struck by another passenger's paddle. They received a small cut just below their lip.
Log dropped over side of vessel into water, no injuries or damage occurred.

Crew member was struck by a grapple below the shoulder blades. The grapple had flicked off the back bone striking the crew member. They were taken ashore for a check up and it was determined they had a closed fractured rib.
A recreational vessel approached from astern and tailgated another vessel. The vessel had to change their course to avoid a collision.
A recreational vessel approached from astern and tailgated another vessel. The vessel had to change their course to avoid a collision.
When departing the berth engine room reported a burst seawater cooling line. The vessel proceeded to anchorage and repairs were made.

The skipper put the vessel on auto-helm and was using binoculars to scan for dolphin activity outside the harbour. The tide took the vessel sideways at an unexpected rate and the vessel made contact with a channel marker briefly.

The pilot ladder was not used as shifting ship from berth to berth with access via the gangway. The pilot ladder's two spreaders bars were separate pieces of wood which had been screwed and nailed to the back of the steps.
Crane limits shut crane down, while stevedores where handling crane wires one smashed a window of the vessel
Two logs dropped onto wharf. No injuries or damaged occurred, conditions were wet and slippery.
Two logs dropped onto wharf. No injuries or damage occurred, wet and slippery conditions.
Log dropped onto berth, no injuries or damage occurred.
Log dropped onto the wharf, no injuries or damage occurred.
Main engine shut down due to the breathing pipe water chamber drain line being blocked. Once cleared, the main engine started up again.
Log dropped onto wharf. No injuries, wet and slippery conditions.
Vessel experienced a high speed overtake by a jet boat at close quarters
Vessel experienced a high speed overtake by a jet boat at close quarters
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Accommodation ladder was not secured, man ropes were rigged incorrectly.
Crew member accidentally stepped into the path of parasailing chute as it deployed from the boat. The parasail webbing struck them on their head, causing an abrasion.
The vessel dragged anchor due to high winds in bay. Vessel made contact with another vessel, and then lost propulsion.
A few logs dropped onto the wharf, no injuries or damage occurred.
A passenger fell overboard, they were retrieved with a life ring.
Person on board was hit in the eye by a snapped fishing line, their glasses were shattered and eyes abraded by debris.
Passenger slipped and hit their head on hand rails in front of them causing a cut and bleeding. The passenger was taken to the medical centre via an ambulance.
Vessel impacted another vessel on starboard hull tearing away part of hull and one stanchion
Vessel impacted another vessel on starboard hull tearing away part of hull and one stanchion

A tyre fender securing system on the starboard shoulder of the tug failed. Tyre fell into the sea and then allowed metal to metal contact with the remaining hanging chain. This resulted in an dent on the hull.

Vessel was found adrift, with no one on board. The yacht had the anchor rope over the bow. A coastal navigation warning had been issued for the drifting yacht. The owner confirmed that the yacht had drifted away.

A fire was caused by sand build up in the manifold over time. The master noticed smoke and could smell fire, they stopped the vessel and fire extinguishers were used to put out the fire and passengers were transferred to another boat.
The pilot ladder was very well-worn with very loose chocks.

The vessel grounded while navigating river and the master was looking out for other jet boats. A passenger was hit by a tree branch but no injury occurred. Passengers were transferred to another vessel.
The crewmember noticed that the hook was unwinding from the crane block. Operations were stopped, repairs were made onboard.

A vessel caught fire with five passengers on board, four passengers rowed in a dinghy to shore. One passenger stayed aboard to try extinguish the fire before swimming to shore, and was treated for smoke inhalation at Auckland Hospital.
The pilot ladder tripping line was fitted on aft side, and was fitted too low. Some of the steps/chocks were loose.

The vessel lost main engines on departure, during this time the vessel had steerage, bow thrusters were on and anchors were ready to let go with forward station manned. Vessel was steered safely, main engine revs were restored.
A performer on board cruise ship fell off the stage, fracturing their foot. They were treated onboard and then taken to hospital.
Bottom section of vessel came apart creating 500mm square hole. Vessel quickly foundered, 5 passengers on board all had life jackets on and abandoned the vessel.
Vessel owner called for assistance after vessel lost its propeller. The vessel was anchored and was assisted to a safe mooring.
Water was flooding into the engine bay from around the flywheel. On inspection it was discovered that a pipe feeding water from the pump to the engine had partially come adrift.

Vessel started rapidly taking on water. Four passengers on board abandoned the boat. The vessel sunk with 50cm of the bow remaining visible. Section of rear underside came away on the port side. The skipper did not remember hitting anything in water.
Pan Pan call was made regarding a vessel that had a dead engine and was taking on water. A tow was sent out to retrieve the vessel.
Event Location: Te Hue Pa, Little Barrier Island

Brief Description: Vessel set off EPIRB and SPOT after hitting rocks and grounding. The two people on board were winched to safety by a helicopter.
A vessel capsized with 6 people on board, all of them were not wearing life jackets. Rescue helicopters and the local surf live saving club were tasked to go and rescue them all.

Vessel ran out of fuel while on their route. The fuel gauge was inaccurate and skipper misjudged vessels running time. The vessel anchored while they awaited assistance before they continued their journey.
A solo yacht sailor fell and sustained a minor injury to their hip. They required escorting by another vessel into the Harbour. They were then taken to hospital.

Both engines unexpectedly rolled back to idle. The driver pulled on the reverse buckets to slow the boat, they kept it mid flow, once stopped they turned around, keyed each engine off and on, the engines restarted and power was restored.
Vessels starboard engine lost power and stalled on two separate trips. The vessel was taken out of the water to find the issue.
Crew member opened oven door. Oven dish slid out and spilt food on crew members foot due to the oven having no grips. Crew member sustained burns.
Multiple logs dropped onto wharf, no injuries were sustained.
Passenger slipped and hit their face on the vessel dashboard. They were taken to the medical centre and the injury was found to be a broken nose.
Vessel had to take evasive action due to secondary vessel not giving the way.

A blocked fuel pipe in the vicinity of the emergency fuel cut off valve caused the vessel to lose power. The skipper anchored the vessel and they waved down another vessel which towed them to get it checked out. They then proceeded once fixed.
A jetski was involved in a T-Bone/Side collision with a personal water craft. Jetski passenger sustained minor injuries, with the jetski sustaining some damage in the incident.
A jetski was involved in a T-Bone/Side collision with a personal water craft. Jetski passenger sustained minor injuries, with the jetski sustaining some damage in the incident.
A vessel was exceeding 5 knots within 50m and failed to keep out of the way of another vessel. The other vessel had to move to avoid a collision.
Vessel was hit by a large wave which broke over top and flipped the vessel. Cabin of vessel was wedged in surrounding rocks, two people sustained injuries.

Recreational vessel capsized trapping the two people on board underneath the submerged cabin for around 20 minutes. The boat washed in close to the shore, and rescuers retrieved the two passengers who sustained minor injuries.
The house battery moved during a bumpy trip and the positive terminal arced out on the battery bracket causing a lot of smoke as the negative wire burnt out.
Container cage swung off top of containers with two stevedore's harnesses attached. Stevedores were pulled back suddenly, there were no injuries.

Starboard side of the vessel contacted with rock when transiting the passage, which caused the vessel to sustain a crack hull plate on starboard side. There were no injuries and the vessel returned to port.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
One jet ski collided with back of another jet ski - all passengers were ejected into water. All three people were injured. Minor damage occurred to the jet skis and the ambulance was called.
One jet ski collided with back of another jet ski - all passengers were ejected into water. All three people were injured. Minor damage occurred to the jet skis and the ambulance was called.

The starboard Genset starter motor failed, this caused smoke in engine room set off fire alarm. The crew investigated and deployed the Co2 extinguisher. The maintenance team replaced the starter motor.
A passenger was head-butted by another passenger due to them sitting opposite each other while going over the falls. This resulted in a split lip and they were advised to go to hospital.
A crew member received a cut to their forehead after an altercation on board.

Batteries in battery box below floor gassed off hydrogen, due to a failed regulator. Gas was trapped below the floor boards of parts of the saloon. Starting the freshwater pump ignited the hydrogen. One crew member sustained hearing loss.
Crew member had right hand jammed in a gantry pulley as they were trying to unjam a hook. This resulted a crushing injury to their hand.
Event Location: Area B Marine Farms, Firth of Thames

Brief Description: Jet boat was spun in the wrong place on the river, vessel grounded on rock and put a dent in the stator which stopped the motor. The boat was driven to the side of the river on the post motor, a backup boat was brought down, customers swapped over.
Log fell between stanchions onto wharf, no injuries were sustained.
Crew member sustained alkaline chemical burn on their right arm, and irritation/abrasion to left eye after prematurely opening a dishwasher.
A kayaker was passed closely by a vessel numerous times throughout their trip. They were verbally abused when they confronted the skipper of the vessel.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Smaller vessel approached from starboard side and the other vessel needed to manoeuvre out of its way to avoid a collision.
Smaller vessel approached from starboard side and the other vessel needed to manoeuvre out of its way to avoid a collision.
Vessel hit submerged log, wood lodged in propellers causing the engine failed to restart. Another boat was sent to retrieve the vessel
Kayak cut across vessels bow, caused vessel to take immediate evasive action. This caused the port engine to be lost for 10 minutes due to the manoeuvre.
A fishing vessel failed to give way, then turned and actively cut off the gear which was being trolled by another vessel.
A fishing vessel failed to give way, then turned and actively cut off the gear which was being trolled by another vessel.

A mayday call was made and the vessel responded, upon arrival they saw that the aquaculture vessel had set up to tow the vessel back to shore. They two vessels assisted the recreational vessel to shore.

The vessel came across approx. 40 people on rubber inner tubes were floating downstream. The people made no attempt to move and the vessel grounded in their attempt to move out the way. The vessel was freed and they waited for the people to pass.
Event Location: Waikato river near Cobham Drive Bridge

Brief Description: While the vessel was anchored, a member onboard had a cardiac arrest. Ambulance coordinated a response and they were transferred to shore by another vessel.
Skipper made an error of negotiating the river, hit a rock and overturned vessel. Two passengers were hospitalised due to injuries.
Vessel were not under command and experienced blackout. After approx. 10 minutes the vessel was fine and resumed their journey.
The crane's swivel bolt of cargo block was removed of its foundation and fell down onto the cargo. No one was injured and the cargo operation was suspended.
A crew member was pierced by the spike of an elephant fish while cleaning the deck.

Vessel dragged anchor across harbour while crew remained sleeping. Insufficient anchor chain/warp had been put out. The anchor alarm failed to sound. The vessel struck the edge of the wharf, slight damage occurred.
The man ropes on port side were slippery.
The pilot ladder steps had uneven gaps and were on angles. The tripping line was fitted too low and the ropes running through the stanchions at the top platform were in poor condition.
The pilot ladder weight was not supported correctly and the length was too short.
The pilot ladder was in poor condition.
A log dropped onto the wharf, no injuries were sustained.
Log dropped onto wharf, no injuries were sustained.
When putting weight on first step, side ropes of pilot ladder parted where the ladder goes over the fish plate. The pilot ladder fell away - no injuries were sustained.
Lift was taken and a lashing chain was caught on the wire. Wire sling broke and one end of steel dropped onto cargo below.
A vessel failed to give way causing the other vessel to take evasive action to avoid a collision.
A vessel failed to give way causing the other vessel to take evasive action to avoid a collision.
A vessel was conducting lifeboat drills and lost propulsion on their lifeboat. 4 passengers were rescued aboard the lifeboat by another vessel after approximately 1 hour.
A log fell from the ship through the stanchions onto the wharf, no injuries were sustained.
Five logs fell from the ship through the stanchions onto the wharf and into the water while the digger was loading the ship.

The battery overheated in the engine room, the vessel dropped their anchor and waited for assistance. The gas in the engine room escaped, the battery was able to be disconnected and the vessel went to shore where a replacement battery was installed.
Lid fell off kettle and cook sustained 1st degree burns on three fingers on their hand. First aid was applied on board.
Vessel had a small fire in the roof of the vessel caused by the exhaust outlet overheating. Fire was put out by the skipper using Co2 and then the deck hose. Minor damage, nil injuries occurred.
Pilot ladder steps were uneven and at an angle.
While singling lines, the main engine accidentally went astern at slow speed. The caused load on the aft back spring line, and resulted in the line parting.
Two vessels were close by as the skippers were chatting, one reversed when leaving and hit the starboard side of the other vessel. There was no apparent damage or injury.
The stern of the vessel went down to the starboard side and hit the bottom, breaking the starboard side skeg off and bending the port side skeg.
Five logs slipped from the heave onto the berth, when the weight was taken off the crane.. No injuries or damage occurred.
Rafting passenger sustained a dislocated right ankle with fractures in 3 places after going down a rapid.

A vessel crossed the lane line and collided with a single sculler which was heading in the opposite direction. The single sculler was capsized by the impact, the crew made it to shore unaided. They received first aid.

A collision occurred between a rowing four and rowing double scull. The four pierced the hull of the double causing the double to capsize. Two crew fell into the water and were retrieved by another vessel.

Three passengers were injured when the vessel went down the falls. One fell out and hit the passenger in front of them, one was injured after being hit and the other one was injured after falling out after the raft flipped.

A passengers fingers were in the doorway when the door was shut on them. The top pf the finger was severed and the skipper immediately pulled back into berth. First aid was applied and they were transported to hospital.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
The main engine stopped while the vessel was heading into berth. The vessel carried on steering aiming for safe anchorage position. The engine restarted after the bow thruster came online.
A log slipped from the heave when the weight was taken. There were no injuries or damage.
The vessel was dragging anchor in the harbour and had a near miss of a grounding. The master was told to berth the vessel as the winds were too high for the vessel to stay anchored overnight.
A passenger on board was injured, they had cuts and a near broken arm. Another vessel was called to assist and transfer the passenger to hospital.
Passenger had sustained a broken rib a week earlier and became seasick and damaged their rib further on board. An ambulance met the vessel at the wharf and they were taken to the medical centre.
Passenger was slid into by other passengers, resulting in them hitting their brow bone on the handrail. First aid was provided.
Vessel ran aground on the rocks as they could not see where they were heading and got the beacons mixed up.
A log slipped from the heave when the weight was taken off. No injuries or damage occurred.
A vessel observed another vessel heading in their course, the vessel slowed down and eventually stopped to avoid a collision.
A vessel observed another vessel heading in their course, the vessel slowed down and eventually stopped to avoid a collision.
Master became distracted and veered vessel off course, hitting a timber pile. One passenger experienced minor whiplash and a crew member sustained bruised ribs.

A capsized vessel was noticed with two people sitting on the hull. The owner of the vessel got some help and went to the capsized vessel to rescue the two crew. One of the crew cut their finger, about 5cm long during the process of helping.
Lifting wire caught on crew member's arm while they were attempting to lift wire from the log bunk, injuring their left wrist and forearm.
Three passengers sustained minor injuries after capsizing in a rapid. They were transported by helicopter to hospital for treatment
Event Location: Ngaporo Rapid, Ngaporo Campsite, Whanganui River

Brief Description: Vessel hit a submerged log, damage occurred to the propeller.
While manoeuvring the vessel in the viaduct marina at the bottom of a spring tide, the vessel struck a known rock at low speed.
Passenger suffered stroke during training exercise on board vessel. They were transferred to hospital by helicopter.
While logs were being loaded onto the vessel, four logs fell from the truck. No injuries or damage occurred.
Passenger slipped and fell on the stairs, this resulted in a fracture of their right clavicle. They were disembarked once the vessel arrived at port.

On departure the skipper heard a noise and the vessel lost drive to their right hand unit. The vessel returned to the jetty on one engine where the vessel was inspected. The H-Bar was broken, all passengers were unloaded.
A person cast the yacht adrift while berthed at the Whitianga wharf.

Passenger disembarked vessel by jumping off a ladder from a height of approximately 2 feet, resulting in the passenger straining their knee. An ambulance was called and they were transferred to the medical centre.
Keyway on no.2 shaft severed causing the centre shaft to dislodge from the gearbox making it unusable.
Vessel came to a stop near the boat ramp, the vessel turned 180 degree and was hit by vessel towing a water-ski in the 5 kt zone
Passenger complained of feeling unwell before collapsing. Passenger was transferred to an ambulance upon the vessel's arrival in Wellington.

Main engine lost fuel pressure & shut down. The shut down was caused by contamination of diesel in the settling tank which was clogging the filters. After re-routing the fuel supply the main was restarted
The vessel came across an unknown cabin top cruiser in distress being helped by Surf Club Rescue. The vessel attached tow line and towed vessel back to the jetty.
Recreational vessel failed to give way to jet boat. This resulted in the jet boat slightly grounding, which lifted some rocks in the grill and stopped the engine.
Passenger slipped and fell on vessel this resulted in them fracturing their ankle. First aid was applied and once ashore they went to hospital.
Evasive action was taken by a vessel to avoid a big collision with a yacht. The yacht keel boom clipped the forestay and the shockwaves through the rig dislodged the vessels boom’s gooseneck.
Evasive action was taken by a vessel to avoid a big collision with a yacht. The yacht keel boom clipped the forestay and the shockwaves through the rig dislodged the vessels boom’s gooseneck.

The hatch above bilge pump came off and water started to push in above the bilge pump. The vessel was taken back to boat ramp, however while waiting the vessel started taking on more water and drifted 100m back into the water. Tow was required.
Crew member carrying heavy pot lost grip and dropped it on other crew member on deck below. Soft tissue injuries occurred to their back and shoulder.
Vessel's engine did not fire when pilot was guiding it to berth. Tugs were used to berth ship, the engine became available to use again after 5 minutes.
Deck crew found a fire in the incinerator room which they extinguished with the deck hose immediately. There was minor damage to internal area of incinerator room and equipment inside.

A vessel noticed another vessel in close quarters, they sounded there horn numerous times to alert the other vessel. There was no change in course from the vessel so they turned hard to starboard to avoid collision.

A vessel noticed another vessel in close quarters, they sounded there horn numerous times to alert the other vessel. There was no change in course from the vessel so they turned hard to starboard to avoid collision.

In the prevailing NE speed could not be reduced in time, and vessel hit the link-span at approximately 1.4kts. This damaged the vessel and the link-span. Relatively high power shaft orders were required to keep the vessel up to the berth.

Vessel grounded after crew member who was steaming home fell asleep. The vessel was grounded on a part of the starboard side. After moving some of the bags to the other side, the vessel was reversed back and they came to shore. No damage occurred.

Starboard motor cut-out while on a trip, vessel still had port motor and went to the side of the river. Passengers were loaded onto another boat to carry on with trip. Fault was investigated with company mechanic and was rectified.
Main engine overheated, high temp alarm failed and engine was extremely hot when noticed. The engine was shut down and cooled for five hours. It was suspected a plastic bag was over the intake valve.

A vessel noticed another vessel in close proximity. They sounded their horn five times to get their attention, the other vessel continued on their course and crossed the vessel at high speed very closely.
A worker sustained burns to their legs and hands after attempting to stomp out a fire. They were helped and taken to hospital.

Vessel was moving to look for an area to anchor. The vessel hit the shelf under motor. Assistance was called and all six passengers were removed from the vessel and taken to shore. Minor damage occurred to the vessel.

A jet boat performed a spin in close proximity to another jet boat. This resulted in contact and slight damage to one vessel. Damage occurred to the non-structural spoiler wing off the main transom of the vessel.

A jet boat performed a spin in close proximity to another jet boat. This resulted in contact and slight damage to one vessel. Damage occurred to the non-structural spoiler wing off the main transom of the vessel.

Passenger locked legs when going down waterfall, on impact they then fell out of the raft, once resurfaced they noticed pain in their knee. They were evacuated on a backboard and taken to the carpark to met an ambulance. They dislocated their knee.

Both boats had just passed each other and then both turned without checking where the other vessel was. Their tuna poles clashed and were torn off both boats, no injuries occurred. The glare of the sun had made it hard for the skippers to see.
Event Location: By Heaphy River Mouth, West Coast

Brief Description: Both boats had just passed each other and then both turned without checking where the other vessel was. Their tuna poles clashed and were torn off both boats, no injuries occurred. The glare of the sun had made it hard for the skippers to see.
Event Location: By Heaphy River Mouth, West Coast

Brief Description: Vessel was unable to anchor due to the Morse cable to the gearbox snapping whilst the vessel was going astern. They moved and managed to drop the anchor but still drifted, they made contact with another vessel.

Engine dropped a valve while returning to port to drop off passengers. The vessel was able to safely make it in alongside the wharf and unload passengers. Vessel was taken out of operation until repairs could be made.

Two vessels collided with each other. One skipper hit their dodge switch on the outside steering helm, this made the other vessel turn to port and collide with the starboard stern quarter. No injuries occurred.

Two vessels collided with each other. One skipper hit their dodge switch on the outside steering helm, this made the other vessel turn to port and collide with the starboard stern quarter. No injuries occurred.
Four craft paddlers ended up capsizing on a wave during race training. One of the paddlers was struck by the canoe on the back of the head. The paddler sustained a severe concussion.
Engine failure occurred due to incorrect fuel being accidentally obtained prior to departure for the days boating.
The accommodation ladder was not secured to the ships side. The ladder was not 1.5 metre above the ships side.
A person was found in the water and recovered by a nearby vessel after their vessel had sunk. They released a distress beacon to try get help.
The skipper took their boat close to the wharf where a lot of people were jumping to load passengers. There were multiple near misses with multiple swimmers and children.
One person was left in a serious condition and was taken to hospital after a collision between a jet ski and a boat.

A passenger became destabilized with one leg inside the boat and one leg on the beach. A surge caused the boat to move and this resulted in the passenger falling out of the boat into knee deep water. This resulted in an injured knee
There was a fire in the engine room of the vessel, the crew extinguished the fire and fire services were involved.

Crew member was reaching for a fish tray and was spiked by a ghost shark spike, which entered the back part of their palm by the wrist and was just touching the index finger bone. First aid was applied on board and the next day they went to hospital.
As the crane was lifting a packet off the trailer, a log slipped out.
Passenger jumped overboard to swim to shore when the vessel was 200m from its final destination. The skipper effected an emergency stop and the crew threw the person a life ring.

The vessel suddenly had a total power failure occur, the vessel then drifted approx. 50 metres. The skipper tied the bow rope to a branch of a tree. There was a crack in the 20amp main powertrain fuse, this was replaced and power was gained.

On approaching the berth, the bow thruster 'tripped out'. The berthing operation was suspended until the bow thruster was re-started. After 5 minutes, the thruster was re-started, tested and used for the berthing operation.
