The starboard engine cut out, the port engine was used to get the vessel to the side of the river. Passengers were swapped over to another boat. Water was found in the component and the map sensor was faulty, fuel was drained and the sensor replaced.

There was a loud bang followed by vibration from the port engine. The driver stopped and radioed for replacement boat to be sent up. No injuries or damage occurred. The engine was replaced, there was a broken crankshaft.

When approaching the basin, the speed dropped inexplicably. The engine RPM indicator showed the engine stopped, the engine then restated and the ship berthed. The incorrect operation of engine in the local control was the cause.
Crew member complained of serious back pain while vessel was out fishing. First aid was applied on board, the vessel steamed to port, and they were taken off the vessel.
Recreational vessel was hit by a wave on its starboard side, resulting in the vessel being flipped on its two occupants. Both managed to swim out from under the boat, and back to shore.

Crew member's foot was tangled in a parasail shroud line. As they hopped into the water their right ankle caught the boat railing and twisted, resulting in minor fracture. They were taken to hospital to checked over and were given a moon boot.
Engine failed to start astern on the approach to the turn into the berth. Turn completed by use of tugs and engine back in operation just prior to coming alongside the wharf.
Vessel blew engine fuse, there was no power to throttle. The fuse was replaced and there was still no power, an electrician checked and the vessel started immediately with no problems.
While reversing the master heard a clunk. The propeller had sheared off shaft resulting in starboard engine having no thrust. The vessel berthed on one engine.
The vessel had difficulty berthing in basin due to large cruise ship berthed at the wharf.

Two young kids jumped off bridge close to the vessel/occupants and got them wet. Master responded in an aggressive manner by trying to reverse the vessel over the kids. Master and crew member were then aggressive to witnesses who approached them.
When boarding the vessel using a combination arrangement the crewmember struck their head on the gangway hoisting arm which was low over the gangway.
While unloading the ship the runner wire on ship's crane failed. No injuries occurred and the scene was frozen.
Ladder was secured incorrectly to the end of the accommodation ladder platform.
Vessel lost steering just after leaving the harbour. Tug assisted back to berth and fault was found with a hydraulic control valve in steering system.
The vessel towed a vessel off a concrete wall and returned the vessel and passengers back to the wharf.
Boat caught fire and was unable to be contained. The vessel was abandoned, and the sole occupant was rescued by helicopter after activating their EPIRB.

The vessel did a hard turn of starboard to indicate a port to port pass with another vessel, they proceeded to turn back so they were bow to bow. 5 short bursts were heard, the skipper turned to starboard to do a port to port pass to avoid contact.

The vessel did a hard turn of starboard to indicate a port to port pass with another vessel, they proceeded to turn back so they were bow to bow. 5 short bursts were heard, the skipper turned to starboard to do a port to port pass to avoid contact.
After vessel had berthed at the wharf a passenger jumped over the side and swam to shore. They made it to shore safely and were met by a security guard.
On arrival the master observed that the AIS data was showing the vessel behind the data presented on the PPU. The GPS setup was incorrect and once they were reset there were no further problems.

When lowering the scaffold that was used for access around the winches a connecting piece of the structure was removed and the supported framework fell coming into contact with the crew member. They sustained a cut to their forearm.

While hauling gear the crew member slipped and sustained knee and head injuries. First aid was administered, the crew members condition deteriorated over the course of the day. They were taken to shore and treated at the hospital.
Crew member attempted to retrieve hanging loop from water, vessel moved due to wind and caught the crew members thumb between the vessel and the wharf causing bruising.
A vessel came right up behind the vessel at speed and then veered off to their starboard side within 40m at speed dragging an excessive wake.
A vessel came right up behind the vessel at speed and then veered off to their starboard side within 40m at speed dragging an excessive wake.
Vessel's motor broke down and stopped operating.
Vessel required assistance from Coastguard after a steering gear failure/dragged anchor. The anchor didn't hold after the steering gear failure and the anchor ran ashore.
Vessel was hit by wash from a ferry which caused the bow to rise, contacting the fender with the wharf fender stringer. This caused the wharf springer to split on the underside.
Observer noted smoke coming out of unused washing machine in wash house. They turned the washing machine off. Issue was repaired 15 hours later by engineers.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Vessel was turning away from sand bar due to outgoing tide, when arriving back at boat ramp the boat was being manoeuvred at a slow pace along the edge of the water course and bottomed out on sand. The boat needed to be man handled back to deep water

Vessel was loading livestock at high tide. The livestock were being difficult, which resulted in the vessel being there longer than intended and the tide went out. Vessel was grounded and a large piece of rail iron punctured the hull.
Vessel grounded on rocks another yacht assisted and took the two passengers on board to land. Vessel was abandoned until it could be re-floated, there was no damage.
Vessel made brief contact with a sandbank. The vessel continued operations and was checked over, no damage occurred to the vessel.

Passenger was thrown from raft. They were able to hold onto the raft as it continued down the river, however this resulted in a dislocated shoulder. They were met by an ambulance when back at shore and taken to hospital.
Engineers ignited an old rag while they were replacing the starboard side belting rail. Fire was immediately extinguished with onboard extinguishers and engineers spoken to about clearing work space.
Vessel was in fishing competition, started taking on water for unknown reasons. Vessel sunk 5 miles outside the breakwater. Two passengers got rescued from passing boats.

Raft was travelling down river. Raft was sucked close to rocks due a cross current, passenger made contact with rock and dislocated their shoulder. Paramedics were called and they looked after the passenger.
The ventilation system was not working, the vessel had a full load of passengers.

Skipper approached the anchored vessel from a stern well hugging the port side marker due to low visibility and strong incoming tide. They didn't see any anchor light on the moored vessel. This resulted in the bow impacting the outboard of the vessel

Skipper approached the anchored vessel from a stern well hugging the port side marker due to low visibility and strong incoming tide. They didn't see any anchor light on the moored vessel. This resulted in the bow impacting the outboard of the vessel

Master was checking on the progress of the lashing of Deck #5 when they slipped and fell. Medical attention was received at hospital. They sustained a small open wound on their eyebrow and a corneal abrasion.
The vessel hit a submerged object, this was believed to be a shallow mud bank that previously held a submerged tree on it. there was no damage found on the vessel.

Vessel's main engine stopped suddenly while prepping to anchor. Engine would not restart, so the vessel anchored quickly. The fault was not found so they sailed back to the marina and were towed into berth by a support vessel.
Passenger slipped whilst embarking on bottom step and fell whilst holding rail.

Vessel started discharging sludge to truck shoreside. Effluent was noticed seeping from strainer on receiving truck.  Vessel hit the emergency stop and ceased discharge operations. Shoreside truck mopped up, the oily water was cleaned up.

Recreational vessel capsized with four passengers. All emergency equipment was in the boat, however one passenger managed to keep a cell phone dry. Passengers were rescued after an hour in the water by a passing vessel.
While in the process of loading operations of cargo logs, the differ machine slipped off a row of logs and was tipped sideways. Crew came and assisted in removing the digger, no injuries occurred.
Vessel grounded on mud whilst attempting to tow another vessel off the same mud. Vessel was anchored where it was and retrieved later on in the day.
Crew member got a fish spike in their finger. Days later the finger was swollen and they were prescribed medication to help with the pain.
Steering gear failure resulted in a collision with a rock/bluff, multiple people overboard.

Vessel hit submerged object going downstream. The skipper noticed the bilges come on and parked the boat on the beach . Passengers were transferred to another vessel. A crack was found in the chine and was welded up.
During rough weather a crew member lost control of the picking hook which started to swing wildly, narrowly missing two other crew members.
Passenger had a serious medical event, they were taken off the vessel and taken to hospital via ambulance.

The vessel got hit by a few waves and got stuck on the rocks. The skipper made a mayday call and while the vessel waited for assistance another wave pushed the vessel off the reef. The vessel lost steering but managed to drive astern and get to shore
Crew member stepped off the aft deck of the vessel from a height of 200mm and rolled their ankle. Medical assistance was given and they were taken to hospital where x-rays revealed a fractured ankle.
A log fell off the deck into the water.
A log fell into the water off starboard side deck.
Main engine was unable to fire due to two of the engine cylinder's having broken piston rings and worn down liners.
When asking for first engine movement, total loss of start air was experienced. Manoeuvre of dead ship was completed with three tugs made fast.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
A fire occurred in the engine bay, the cause was unknown. No passengers were on board.
Steps on the pilot ladder were very loose and the ladder was not up to standard.
The tripping line was fitted on the aft side and it was fitted too low.
Vessel make contact with wharf while under pilotage. Wharf sustained some damage, and ship sustained minor crumpling on bow.
Strong wind caused the boat to rock resulting in elderly passengers to slip off the bench seats while the ferry was berthing, this resulted in them lacerating their knuckles.
During initial set-up of a generator installation, where the connections had been incorrect by the attending technician, a short circuit occurred as the alternator was excited.
Pilot Ladder broke on one side while pilot was climbing ladder to board the ship.

Jet ski engine fault occurred during operation. Inspection of jet ski engine by marine mechanics revealed a number of service discrepancies with non-standard parts being used and alleged poor workmanship by the jet ski retailer

The port engine lost thrust so the skipper anchored the vessel. The gearbox had blown an oil hose and oil was dumped into the engine tray. The hose was bandaged up and the vessel returned to port on one engine.
Vessel corrected their movements to avoid a rock and when they came into shore they nearly collided with a few small boats which had dragged on their anchors.
Crane runner wire broke while heaving logs, resulting in crane driver sustaining a laceration to their head from flying debris.
During berthing, the bow thrust would not fire. The vessel was berthed using tug assistance.
Digger slipped onto side when manoeuvring over slope. A slip occurred, the operator was not injured. they were immediately rectified by pulling digger up right and lifting from the vessel.
A flame out occurred on the vessel due to a fault in the ignition system. Al passengers were safe and the vessel was moored safely. Another boat was used to transfer the passengers.
Two logs fell into the tide, no injuries occurred and the scene was not frozen.

A near miss occurred divers in the water and a fishing vessel. The vessel which had dropped the divers off noticed the vessel was close to the divers and was able to protect the divers. The two vessels used radio to explain where the divers were.

A near miss occurred divers in the water and a fishing vessel. The vessel which had dropped the divers off noticed the vessel was close to the divers and was able to protect the divers. The two vessels used radio to explain where the divers were.

The swell in the harbour increased rapidly. The back of the boat gradually filled with water as the waves caused lots of water to be forced into the boat. The boat eventually took on too much water and disappeared below the surface.
Tender 1 was being craned on to the stern of the vessel. As the tender neared the cradle the winch wire broke and the tender fell back to the water.
When vessel was attempting to pull away from berth, the main engines failed to start. After 1 hour of subsequent work/testing of main engine the vessel sailed without further incident.
Log slipped out of grapple on deck into water on the starboard side. The digger driver recovered it safely.
A passenger complained of feeling unwell, vessel dropped them off to take ferry back to Queenstown. Once dropped off they were still complaining of discomfort and an ambulance was called.

A person fell overboard and a helicopter located the person in the water and recovered them using a rescue swimmer, other boats assisted the remaining crew on-board, who were unable to sail the yacht alone.
Crew member fell overboard and scratched their arm while being aided back on board. They were wearing a lifejacket and first aid was given on board.

The passenger was making their way from the saloon through the port side door on to the deck, they caught their leg on the sea sill and fell over. The wind caught the door and it closed on to the passengers leg causing the leg to fracture.
Contracted electrician had a medical event which resulted in them falling off a ladder and sustaining a concussion and intracranial injury.
Tug deckhand was hit by a ship line that had been caught in the wind. Deckhand sustained minor bruising to the side of their face and a split lip. First aid was applied to them.
Tug deckhand was hit by a ship line that had been caught in the wind. Deckhand sustained minor bruising to the side of their face and a split lip. First aid was applied to them.
The vessel hit a rock and three passengers injured themselves. The trip continued to get everyone off the vessel. A helicopter was called for one of the passengers to be taken to hospital.
During cargo loading into hold #1, crane #1 dropped it's entire heave into the hold with no control from the crane. The crane then cut out completely.
A passenger collapsed due to extreme seasickness. Rescue coordination initiated and the passenger was transferred to hospital by helicopter.

Fire pump hose split and sprayed water over ceiling and genset control box in starboard engine room. Bilge pumps were activated and repairs were made. Once bilge pumps were clear, the vessel carried on with no further problems.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessel had an engine failure and was attempting to navigate out of the way of a container ship, they had a collision with another smaller vessel.
Vessel had an engine failure and was attempting to navigate out of the way of a container ship, they had a collision with another smaller vessel.
Master fell asleep at the navigation station. Vessel hit rocks and they were rescued by Coastguard. Vessel submerged and became broken up on rocks by swells.
Vessel involved in several near misses with swimmers at the wharf.

The flexible joint on the port engine raw water discharge pipe blew. Serious sea water ingress resulted in partial flooding of port engine room. Master shut down port main engine and closed main raw water intake valves, vessel returned on one engine.

While leaving the pontoon, the VHF aerial on the wheelhouse contacted a launch and snapped off, no damage to launch occurred. Vessel also contacted an inflatable tender resulting in a crack in the outboard engine's cowling.
Crewmember fell forward in the boat when it went over a wave. Their foot got stuck in a adjustable foot strap that is used in an evaluation. This resulted in two fractured bones in their foot.

Customer fell overboard and was sandwiched between vessel and rocks. They were lifted back into the vessel and continued the trip after being assessed by crew.  The fall resulted in an upper end closed humerus fracture.
Stanchions holding manropes were so corroded that the pilot launch crew were able to break them. This happened on both port and starboard side ladders.
The driver was driving the boat and lost control, they reduced speed and crashed into rocks, causing serious injuries to themselves.
No.1 crane dropped a load several meters during the lifting of a digger off the ship to refuel it. Crane was put in to hoist to stop any further free fall.
Two Logs slipped out of the grapple and into water while stowing on stanchions.

Vessel lost steering and in a panic the helmsman put the helm hard to port. Pilot managed to coordinate tug assistance to keep vessel in channel and prevent a grounding. The steerage was quickly recovered and no further problems occurred.

When leaving their berth a vessel waited for another vessel to get into their berth. The vessel approached their berth in an unusual way causing the vessel to continue astern more than planned to avoid contact. The vessel made contact with the wharf.
Vessel had a close quarters situation with a yacht. Vessel managed to manoeuvre out of the way of the yacht, the vessel's whistle did not work when the pilot tried to warn the yacht.
Vessel had a close quarters situation with a yacht. Vessel managed to manoeuvre out of the way of the yacht, the vessel's whistle did not work when the pilot tried to warn the yacht.

The steps on the pilot ladder were not firm under foot, they were sloping generally from aft to forward and getting worse as weight was applied to steps higher up the ladder which is not in compliant.
During vessel unload, a stack of bins came loose from the unload chains/ crane and fell back down into the fish hold. No one was injured and no equipment was damaged.

The bilge alarm went off and the skipper discovered water running into the engine room. The skipper called for aid from on site security. The skipper closed the open sea suction and the water stopped. Significant water was in the engine room.
The vessel was returning to port when there was a hydraulic failure which resulted in a second vessel towing the vessel to its berth.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Vessel was anchored on a chartered fishing trip, when a yacht was seen coming towards the vessel. The yacht did not make any efforts to turn away from the vessel and ended up colliding with the vessels beam, doing significant damage. No injuries.

Vessel was anchored on a chartered fishing trip, when a yacht was seen coming towards the vessel. The yacht did not make any efforts to turn away from the vessel and ended up colliding with the vessels beam, doing significant damage. No injuries.
When jacking down the BPC Jack Up Barge a change of leg lock positions occurred. The nearest spud leg to the wharf seemed to punch through the seabed. No injuries occurred.

Researchers were standing in knee deep water when a jet boat came around a blind corner. The jet boat had to quickly move to the other side of the river to avoid a miss. The vessel then stopped to ensure the researchers were okay.

When loading pallets of hay onto the vessel from the wharf using the crane. The pallet clipped the corner of another pallet already in position and tipped over from 2 metres onto the deck. No injuries occurred.
Starboard air bridge and ramp were lowered/extended incorrectly by shore staff, resulting in the vessels fast rescue craft being damaged.
During maintenance while ammonia system was being pumped down there was a leak from the drain valve on the auxiliary tank being used. The valve was closed, plugged and leak isolated.

Worker was unlocking lashing from a man-cage using a small unlock pole, the pole slipped causing the worker to hit their little finger against the cage causing a fracture of their left hand little finger.
Accommodation ladder did not have safety stanchions rigged on bottom platform and ship had only rigged 50% of safety ropes up each side. The top rope was fitted but not the middle one.
Bosun had their hand caught on a chain during hauling. They sustained serious crushing injuries and lacerations to their hand so the vessel headed to shore to take them to hospital.

A vessel was swamped by a wave over the stern. The crew alerted the ERIRB and a passing fishing vessel recovered all three crew. The skipper received a knock to their head and all of the crew suffered mild hypothermia. They were taken to hospital.
While underway vessel had a blackout and main engines stopped, the emergency generator came on immediately. Engineers investigated and system was restored and vessel was underway after one hour.
The trapdoor accommodation ladder did not meet the standards.
A mayday call was made after a fire started on the vessel. The person was in the water and a passing vessel rescued them from the water. The fire caused the vessel to sink.
Vessel had a small on-board oil spill. A hydraulic pipe to hatch #2 lids burst/leaked and spilled.
The skipper was distracted which led their attention towards stern and they did not see yacht crossing until unable to avoid collision. They hit their gunnel near the stern causing minor damage.
Four logs dropped into the hold after the crane operator misjudged distance to edge of hold.
While stowing logs on deck at Hatch 4, a log slid out of a heave and into the harbour.
Chemical dripped onto eye when cleaning meal plant. First aid was given on board the vessel, once the vessel was back to shore they were taken to hospital to be checked out.
A person was lost overboard at while crossing the bar in a small boat. The person was later safely recovered from the water and was checked over by an ambulance.
Chief Mate was found unconscious and vomiting. A helicopter evacuated them to hospital for assessment
Crane started to take lift, one log slipped forward out of the heave. The logs were very slippery, no damage or injuries occurred.
Operator went to take lift 1 and one log slipped from the heave. The logs were very slippery logs and all staff were in safe zones.

The vessel was relocating to another fishing location when the gearbox and stern leg failed. The vessel had no propulsion or steerage. A tow vessel was called and the took the vessel back to shore. A replacement stern leg was installed.
Log slipped between stanchions and fell into water.
Navigational error occurred on vessels AIS/ECDIS position. The pilot was able to fix error using smoothing settings.
One log slipped from the heave while the wires were ready to be lifted.

While one vessel was overtaking other vessels one of the vessels altered their course and this resulted in the vessels passing each other very closely. The vessel then came back up to speed and continued without further incident.

While one vessel was overtaking other vessels one of the vessels altered their course and this resulted in the vessels passing each other very closely. The vessel then came back up to speed and continued without further incident.

The fire alarm sounded and the bow thruster stopped. The sternlines had been made fast the tug was advised to let go aft and help keep the bow in alongside forward. The fire alarm was investigated, there was no fire.
One log slipped out as the heave was being lifted up.
A crew members hand got caught up in rope and bollard on wharf as crew winched rope tight. This caused their hand to be badly crushed.
A helicopter was used to take a sick crew member off the vessel.

Skipper put the bow of the vessel under a waterfall so people could get a cup of fresh water from the waterfall. The boat drifted a little closer to side of fiord and touched side of fiord putting a slight mark/dent in mid section of bow of vessel.
A jet boat ran through a normal obstacle and an over hanging branch made contact and slightly touched passengers forehead. No major injuries sustained, just a small scratch to forehead.

The driver got caught between a couple of larger than normal waves from the side and got flung off their ski, causing them to hit the water and break their leg. First aid was applied and when they returned to shore and ambulance took them to hospital
The chef touched the meat slicer and got a minor shock. They checked the machine and found the plug to look corroded. The plug was replaced and retested and tagged.
The vessel moored off from the boat club sunk and was completely submerged with only the mast showing.
A log was dropped, all staff were in safe zones.
Digger operator knocked one log off the vessel while stacking stanchions on deck one, staff were all in safe zones.
Pilot noticed that the combination ladder was not secure to ship side. Vessel was turned around for corrective actions which entailed securing pilot ladder and gangway with magnets.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
Main engine fuel filters failed due to the vessel drifting in the bay for more than 36 hours awaiting a berth.

When moving off berth ordered dead slow ahead. Engine started without a problem. Slow ahead was ordered again with no response for approx. 30 seconds. Engine room contacted & changed to ER control & slow ahead achieved. No further problems occurred.

Fire on board vessel was extinguished by skipper. Out of concern of fire restarting, the ship was evacuated and passengers transferred to another vessel. Ship was towed back into the harbour. No injuries were sustained.
As the vessel was preparing to berth, it contacted the Starboard Hand Mark knocking off the top mark and light. No damage to the vessel occurred.

While hauling a longline a hook got caught at the hauling station and broke free flying across the working area striking a crew member in the eye. They pulled the hook free and then the vessel headed to port. They were taken to a hospital.
The engine failed many times over a number of dates. The engine was repaired and replaced to fix the problem.
The vessel had an automated emergency shutdown of main engine due to mist detector alarm. The vessel headed to port on auxiliary to inspect the main engine cylinder head as a precautionary measure.
Vessel has non-compliant platform style ladder.

The master had altered course slightly to port to avoid fishing vessel when crew observed a previously not visible boat shine a torch at them from approximately 20m ahead. The vessel was approaching directly towards them and crossing their bow.

The master had altered course slightly to port to avoid fishing vessel when crew observed a previously not visible boat shine a torch at them from approximately 20m ahead. The vessel was approaching directly towards them and crossing their bow.
Digger driver climbing up to their machine on deck No 4 fell several metres and sustained some form of internal injuries.

The refrigeration alarm activated and the chief engineer found smoke was coming from the switch board. Crew members were on standby with a fire extinguisher. The chief turned off the switch board breaker and the crew extinguished the small fire.

Whilst approaching a secure anchorage at dead low tide the skipper misjudged the very narrow entrance and came into contact with the bottom. The vessel continued forward without hesitation and rode over the obstacle into deeper water.
When crossing the calm entrance, the port engine stopped. The vessel cleared entrance with starboard motor, went and checked, opened valve primed engine and resumed trip.
When logs were released one log slipped out of grapple and went into the water.
When Logs were released, two logs went into the water.

The ROT indicator was not functioning, radars on head up were un-stabilised. The display was not displaying heading, all analog gyro repeaters checked were not working, the helmsman was using digital display on console.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

The vessel lost steering, the master slowed the vessel down and informed the passengers. A loss of hydraulic oil from the steering reservoir was found. The vessel went to shore and found a split hydraulic line on the port side in the port tiller flat
The ship prediction shapes on the ship’s ECDIS were disappearing regularly from the screen for one or two seconds.
Boat with one passenger on board begun to sink, the person was rescued.
the port motor water pump drive belt slipped off the drive pulley causing the over heat warning to come on. On closer inspection the idler pulley centre bolt had failed, it was repaired.

The vessels port stabiliser failed to house. Vessel aborted entry to allow issue to be resolved. Engineers managed to fix issue and house the port stabiliser by manually overriding system after a delay of 30 mins. Vessel had no further issues.
The vessels roro rap was lowered prematurely resulting in the vessels ramp finger flaps contacting the concrete landing. Two of the finger flaps were damage and repairs were made.

The throttles were not in neutral before the skipper changed to centre helm so they still had a little astern momentum, as it was dark they didn't realise they were reversing. The vessel made contact with the wharf, there was minor vessel damage.
Whilst operating crane 2 during log loading the crane hydraulics slipped causing load to drop 1 - 1.5 metres. Operations were ceased after another log dropped.
The tripping line was fitted on the aft side.
Crew member misplaced their foot on the edge of the wheelchair ramp and rolled their ankle. First aid was administered.

On departure the main engine failed to fire astern when the pilot ordered dead slow astern. Tugs were informed and told to standby. After a few minutes the main engine fired astern and the vessel departed without further incident.
A small fire was discovered by a crew member in the port side engineer's storeroom. Two crew extinguished the fire. The suspected cause was an electrical fault.
Crew member cut into an air purge pipe in compressor room this released ammonia into the atmosphere triggering ammonia alarms.

Five degrees of port helm was applied and the helm carried on hard over. The rudder was put hard over to starboard but remained to port. Engines were used to maintain steerage. The helm was brought to midships and the vessel berthed using the engines
While inspecting the ballast tank, traces of HFO was found. The oil was contaminated with ballast water and same tank isolated to prevent further contamination.
A canoe became wrapped around a tree while operating on a river.
During final approach to berth engine failed to fire ahead. Motion was arrested by two tugs. The ship berthed. One of two engine air blowers failed and the engine was sent for repairs.
Crew member was injured after opening pressurised door.
Passenger tripped over sea sill and later found to have broken leg. First aid was applied on board and then a helicopter was called to take the passenger to hospital.
Vessel hit the wharf with bow of vessel above water line. No body was hurt, superficial damage to vessel.

The guide was flung forward from their seat but stayed in the boat. This over extended their knee and strained it. Boat stopped on the side and they were carried up to an access 4x4 track and was driven out to base.

Centre strut for foil between hulls came away where it attaches to foil, the skipper noticed a vibration. The skipper disembarked passengers and inspected the strut. The vessel was taken out of the water, the strut was re-fixed to foil.

A passing vessel's wake caused the vessel to surge slightly towards the wharf, a crewmember became caught between the forward davit and the vertical timber of the wharf. They suffered a slight crush to their chest/shoulder area.
A crewmember was found lying on their back after slipping with a suspected broken hip. Paramedics were called and treated them.

Propulsion was lost due to fuel starvation caused by failure of a quick release valve on the forward settling tank. Vessel safely anchored, power restored to the vessel and it was brought back alongside under its own propulsion.
A light on the end of ships crane fell while slinging in to the hold. There were suspected maintenance issues with fittings.
The vessel had a list of 3.5 degrees and declared a pan pan. The cause was a communications fault between valves for the port/starboard tanks allowing more product to go into one side.
The vessel was affected by another vessels thrust and was pushed sideways into berth. All passengers on board were okay.

A swell came from the vessels port side and threw it against the bow rail starboard side light. This touched the starboard window and broke it. The vessel pulled away from the vessel and crew cleaned all the glass away from the helm.
The vessel lost their mast and sails. It took awhile for crew to cut the rigging and mast free. The vessel was met at the harbour entrance and was escorted to the marina.
A contractor fell while on the ship, they got a suspected fractured knee. They were taken to hospital when they arrived at the next port.

Smoke was coming from under the vessel floor. The skipper diverted from the river and shut engine down. They opened the engine bay and extinguished the fire to the best of their ability. Help was called and the vessel was taken to shore.
One of the deckhands slipped while preparing dinner in the galley and sliced their thumb with a kitchen knife. The boat was taken to port so they could receive medical treatment.
Vessel scraped a beacon on return to port.
Some of the pilot ladder steps felt slippery as the pilot disembarked, the steps appeared to have had a sealer or varnish applied.
The starboard bridge wing main engine indicator was not working.

A fire alarm sounded in the starboard engine room, the engineer investigated and found no fire but discovered a coolant hose leak had created heat and steam activating the fire alarm. The vessel was removed from service and the hose repaired.

The electrics completely stopped, the skipper tacked into the harbour. In the process of reefing the boat was driven toward the rocks, The boat was not able to be manoeuvred off the rocks. Assistance pulled the vessel off and towed the vessel back.

The vessel encountered some wake from another boat, they slowed down but not enough and the boat hit hard on the water. This caused the hydraulic struts to brake at the clips and the windscreen fell back. Two passengers injured themselves.
While taking the heave of trailer at ship side, one log on the outside slipped off due to wet conditions, it landed on the berth. All staff were in safe zones.
Crane operator began taking heave, one log slipped out landing on the berth. All staff were in safe zones.
One log slipped out onto the berth just as the heave was being lifted. All staff were in safe zones.
One log slipped off the trailer when the crane took the weight. All staff were in the safe zones.

The helmsman applied full ahead throttle. The vessel rammed the wharf with some force, they then applying full throttle astern. The vessel backed away from wharf, and the helmsman then again applied full power ahead and struck the wharf a second time
During a race, the vessel hit the wake of another vessels. The vessel bounced side to side throwing the driver and crew into the water. The safety boat arrived quickly and gave assistance.

Vessel was drifting with the wind after coming from the wharf, the skipper was retying the dingy to rail when a unnoticed wind gust blew them into a moored vessel damaging the starboard bow rail on the moored vessel.

Vessel was drifting with the wind after coming from the wharf, the skipper was retying the dingy to rail when a unnoticed wind gust blew them into a moored vessel damaging the starboard bow rail on the moored vessel.
A fishing line was not visible and struck the boat causing the pronged sinker to rise and strike the cabin side at head height narrowly missing a passenger.

Master made contact with a port channel marker. The engineer inspected the void spaces with no internal damage found. Vessel returned where passengers were disembarked and the vessel was removed from service pending inspection by surveyor.

A log fell one end first on to the berth. The log came to rest standing upright with one end on the wharf and the other leaning on the trailer bolster. The crane driver instructed the wharf-hands to push the log over to lay it flat on the wharf.
Pilot vessel made contact with a buoy whilst taking a pilot out to a waiting ship. All crew safe and vessel able to return to berth. Minor damage occurred to the starboard propeller.

A vessel off shore hit a submerged rock while doing approx. 10 knots. Visual inspection appeared to show no damage. They continued at very low speed into Whitianga harbour and took boat out of water. Propeller appeared to be damaged.
Customer fell out of kayak, when trying to get back on the other passenger fell in too. The kayaker capsized. They waved down a nearby boat and were taken back to shore. No injuries were sustained.
Vessel made contact to the wharf at side of one of their hatches. Slight damage occurred on the wharf.
Operator sprained their back while trying to move and lift a roll of fire hose.

The vessel developed a mechanical issue with the gearbox. The vessel decided to return to port to repair the gearbox as they were unable to fix the issue at sea. Parts had to be ordered for the repairs.
A kayak capsized causing the passenger to be left in the water for approx. three hours. A helicopter found them and transported them to hospital where they were treated for hypothermia.
The 15HP outboard engine stopped working, the skipper rowed the vessel back to the shore.

While manoeuvring boat to depart, vessel locked in astern. The skipper shut the main engine off to assess. The vessel glided back into the training wall at 1 knot. After drifting off the skipper started the main engine and assessed the vessel.

A sole occupant of a vessel was taken to hospital for serious injuries after they had run aground. The vessel was upturned and above the waterline. Reports were the vessel impacted the shore at high speeds.
When moving logs on the deck with the digger along the stanchions, one log rolled into the water.
The crane operator started taking the weight, a log started to slide. This was noticed and the crane operator stopped, the log fell onto the berth.
While inspecting a rag caught in the drive belt of the banding machine a crew member's middle finger was pulled into the machine. Vessel returned to port to seek medical attention.
A stevedore moved a reefer cord and the reefer plug blew up, water leaked from the connecters.

The vessel grounded on a sandbank, the skipper reversed off and the tidal current pushed the stern. The vessel reversed into rocks puncturing a 300 x 400mm hole in the transom above the waterline. No water entered and no other damage occurred.
Engineer rolled their ankle and broke their foot while stepping on to gangway.
The crew member collapsed for an unknown reason, hitting their head on the breakfast bar. The crew member was treated for concussion. The crew saw a doctor on shore.
The main engine kept starting and then dropping. The vessel was berthed without one main engine, tugs and thrusters were used.
A boat was found off its mooring, and resting at the base of the cliff.
The tripping line was fitted too low.
A boat with a broken rudder ran aground on a boat ramp.
Six fumigation canisters were dropped in the water while being transported from vessel in paint cage to wharf. Canisters were empty and had the lids off.

A vessel was seen heading towards the vessel. The other vessel suddenly turned to starboard and went across their bow at a distance of about 50 metres. Skipper went astern to avoid a collision and then continued on their original course.
A side pulley fell off the ship's crane into the hold. No injuries were sustained.
The propeller touched the bottom, the engine then stalled.  The vessel was able to complete there operation of discharging the vehicles onto the Island. No one was injured.

Vessel grounded on a reef in shallow water while conducting search grids. The vessel was aground for 10 mins and then drove off the reef with the assistance of an off shore swell. No damage occurred and operations continued without further incident.

Passenger was in the process of going back into the cabin from bow deck port side. Whilst they walked through the door their right hand ring finger top knuckle caught in the closing door and was squashed and severed.
Ladder was rigged with a trip line leading aft and below the bottom spreader.
Engine failed to fire astern after letting go. After 1 hour delay engine was tested and worked ok.
Anchored unoccupied craft dragged it impacted one vessel and impacted and lodged against a second vessel.
An unexpected steering failure occurred after the vessel finished a tow.
Ladder shackled to deck through side ropes, crown knots on man ropes.
A wave smashed the starboard porthole on the bridge and flooded the cabin. The general alarm was sounded and the engineer wasn't able to repair it until it arrived back in port.

A lift of logs were being taken into the hold. As the heave went over the hold a single wire came out and the heave fell approx. 10 metres into the hold. Two logs came into contact with the digger and caused damage to the digger.
A vessel was fishing with their fishing lights on when another vessel came approx. 50 metres close of their vessel.
A vessel was fishing with their fishing lights on when another vessel came approx. 50 metres close of their vessel.
A crew member was climbing down a fixed access ladder on the ship to access a lower deck when their foot slipped off a rung, and they fell approximately 5m.
The ladder was replaced with a new one with varnished rungs and was rigged correctly.
Crew member was using their knife to open the oyster when their hand slipped and they cut their finger. First aid was given on board and they went to hospital once on shore to be assessed.

The vessel was involved in a minor collision with another vessel after they went around a turning mark and sailed into the stern of the other vessel. The damage was superficial as the impact was at slow speed.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Trap door combination ladder was not compliant. Man ropes were less than required diameter.

The skipper lost control and overturned, the race was stopped and safety boats went and helped right the vessel.  The boat was pulled back to the ramp. There was no fuel/oil spillages and the boat undamaged, no injuries were sustained.

A yacht blew aground and became stranded near high water. The yacht had an anchor on warp without any chain and the vessel appeared to be abandoned. The vessel was reported to be a hazard to other vessels in the river.
The crane runner wire unravelled whilst loading logs in vessel hold, the operations were ceased immediately until the wire was replaced.
A vessel passed closely to the vessel with excessive speed.
The main engine failed, the engine restarted within 2 minutes. No further issues during passage.
Neither port or starboard boarding combination ladders were available. The master eventually deployed a combination ladder which was not compliant.
The pilot ladder was old and very worn, the side ropes were chafed and flattened.
The ladder was non compliant and they had a lack of ring plates to secure the man ropes for departure.
When hauling the gear after a tow, the PS warp wire parted. The cause of the PS warp parting was due to a rotten wire.

Dingy motor failed and trio drifted out towards the bar on the outgoing tide. Assistance was called, they all fell into the water. All three were rescued after two hours and taken to hospital in serious conditions. The vessel was not recovered.
A crew member has slipped while walking out of a hatch and has injured back. An ambulance was called to asses them.
A stevedore slipped from cross deck fixed ladder and fell down on the deck. They were seen by ambulance staff.
Whilst removing a pulp spreader from hold 4 the stevedore got their right hand caught between the spreader and the hatch lid. They were transported to hospital for treatment.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
A passenger fell down the stairs was found by crew. Crew applied first aid and called an ambulance. An ambulance took them to hospital to be checked over.

Main engine failed to fire astern on two attempts, tugs were used to arrest headway. Once stopped main engine tested ahead and astern and worked correctly. Berthing continued without further incident.
On departure, pilot launch reported that the manropes had not been passed around the side-ropes (above the combination ladder platform).
While departure from the berth, vessel did not respond to first engine movement, several attempts were made. Control was taken on manual and the engine movement was received.
Engine failed to fire ahead on departure. Tugs controlled vessel in the turning basin for approximately 10 minutes until the engine fired ahead.
Skipper put the boat out of gear and tried to adjust course, the vessel impacted a marker. The mark slid down the starboard side making loud noises, no one was injured.
Vessel backed into the marina pile and broke it off at sea level.
The manropes were replaced on the pilot ladder.

A small fire was discovered by a crewmember within a clothes dryer in the ships laundry. The ships fire alarm was sounded and crew mustered while the crewmember unplugged the dryer and immediately extinguished the fire.

The vessel had a jammed steering alarm, the vessel was able to make it to safe water. The starboard steering was not responding. The vessel continued to shore on the port engine and the vessel made minor contact with the wharf.

A passenger was walking onto their vessel and then fell into the water. A life saver ring was thrown into the water and they held onto that which was directed to the ladder. They climbed back onboard the vessel and first aid was applied.

Upon stowing the boat a small rope attached to the bowsing tackle was noted to be stuck in a fall wire block. A seaman climbed over the vessels railing to free the rope but lost their footing and fell about 3m to the deck below.
The ladder is rigged via slots in an angle bar, thus putting strain on the step lashing rather than at the ends of the side ropes. This is non compliant.
Aluminium tender capsized. A vessel passing by offered assistance and retrieved the crew and took them back to the jetty.
One log slid between stanchions and fell onto the berth landing under a empty trailer.
Two logs from the deck into the water.

The vessel suffered from steering failure at the berth and was removed for service. A tug was used to assist the vessel to a maintenance berth and during the tow the vessel made contact with the tug. Minor damage occurred to the vessel.

Jet boat struck a rock which resulted in pierce on the oil sump. The driver noticed a drop in oil pressure and called for assistance. Passengers were transferred to another vessel and the vessel returned to the workshop for inspections.

Main Engine shut down but the vessel returned safely without further incident. The failure was caused by a clip in super charter parting, the passengers were informed throughout the situation and repairs were made once at port.

The vessel rudder angle indicator went hard to starboard, midships were order but there was no change. The rudder angle indicator was not working, the vessel responded to helm and had tugs escort the vessel out.
Vessel broke off mooring and drifted onto the beach due to strong winds. The vessel was secured with the anchor and at low tide the vessel was assessed. There was no damage.

The master requested main engine astern due to the forward winches being too slow. Tugs were used as a precaution, after ten minutes of slow ahead the all clear was given and the tugs followed until the main engine was okay.

Passenger sitting in the front seat felt discomfort while the jetboat was at white sign area, midway through the second gorge and the roughest part of concession of the river, and asked to be removed from the vessel.

Vessel damage above the deck line occurred that resulted in some gantry damage on the port side at the stern of the vessel. The mooring lines remained intact and the measure of force with the undulating surge resulted in gantry damage.
This vessel fishes long line and can only board on the starboard side. The position was well fwd. and there was no gap in the rubbing strake.
Vessel's stern line broke, causing it to drift and collide with another vessel.
Vessel's stern line broke, causing it to drift and collide with another vessel.
A crewmember was evacuated from the vessel via a helicopter due to them feeling unwell and experiencing heart attack like symptoms.
A vessel failed to give way to another vessel, the vessel slowed down and turned on their deck lighting to make themselves more visible. The vessel didn't react and passed with less than 50 metres.
Event Location: Between Dieffenbach Point and Ruaomoko Point

Brief Description: The skipper heard a noise and put the boat in neutral. They experienced a loss of propulsion and called for assistance. They were towed back to the wharf. After investigating it appeared that the coupling had parted from the propeller shaft.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
The guide held on when the raft flipped, while doing this they twisted their arm.
Both the rudder indicators were out of order.

The main line on the forward shore mounted shore tension unit parted. The line was replaced straight away. The line may have suffered fatigue in way of the main snatch block after approximately 5000 hrs of operation.
Log slide off the heave onto the berth. The height from the top of the heave to the wharf was approx. 4 metres.
One of the shaft's went in to full astern. Vessel was not under command (NUC) for a short while. Both shafts became operational again and the vessel restricted their speed to 15kts.
Accommodation ladder was not secured to ships side. The ladder was not attached to ships side 1.5m above accommodation ladder platform
Two logs slipped off the top of the heave onto the berth. The heave was slightly off centre which was a contributing factor.
Four sailors were rescued from a life raft as the ship suffered catastrophic rigging failure and low diesel.
Event Location: Off Great Barrier Island, Pacific Ocean

Brief Description: The vessel had an ammonia leak, general alarm was sounded and all crew were mustered at the evacuation point. The No2 freeze compressor front shaft seal had failed. The boat was ventilated.
When trying to get onto the plane, the wake built up behind the vessel and swamped the vessel.

Engine stalled approximately 100m from shore. Skipper dropped anchor, though vessel continued to drift toward shore, grounding 20m from the beach. With vessel listing, it was abandoned and crew and passengers brought ashore without injury

One of the vessels stabilisers let go from its mountings, and it was slamming against the hull. The engineer advised them to speed up, this caused the stabiliser to be pinned up against the hull. A diver met them and made temporary repairs.

A vessel was found sitting upright with a slight list to port. The aft deck was underwater and the wheelhouse sole was just under. The owner was notified and the vessel was held upright. The vessel re floated after pumping begun.
Deckhand slipped on deck as the vessel was steaming out to start fishing, the ship turned around and took them back to port so they could go to hospital.

The jetboat grounded, all four passengers were assisted off the vessel and the skipper walked downstream to the ramp. They grabbed the other larger boat and picked up the passengers from the shore to take them to the jetty.
A vessel crossed ahead of another vessel. The vessel sounded their whistle and reduced engine revs to dead slow. The other vessel ignored all signals and proceeded to cross the channel.
A vessel crossed ahead of another vessel. The vessel sounded their whistle and reduced engine revs to dead slow. The other vessel ignored all signals and proceeded to cross the channel.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
A vessel required towing assistance after their vessel with seven passengers on board had motor trouble.

Crew member slipped and injured themselves after they stood in the rope bin trying to push the rope down. They put their hand out to steady themselves and their hand went into the rope and rope hauler. This broke their thumb and cut one finger.
Crew member fell overboard while washing down the work deck, they were recovered within 5 minutes via the life ring.
The propeller hit something below the surface, this caused significant damage to the vessel when it was inspected.
Main gearbox failure occurred the boat and crew were safe. The vessel was towed back to anchorage and then towed to port.
When loading against the stanchions on starboard side the wires pulled out a log and it fell into the water.
Accommodation ladder was not secured to the ships side. The ladder was not attached to ships side 1.5m above accommodation ladder platform.
Ladder was secured by passing under a bar without lashings.
A tug boat collided with port shoulder of the vessel they were piloting. No injuries occurred and after assessment the vessel proceed to the next port.
A tug boat collided with port shoulder of the vessel they were piloting. No injuries occurred and after assessment the vessel proceed to the next port.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Skipper had engine overheat and alarm sounded, the engine shut down. Skipper proceeded with basic troubleshooting and could not determine a solution while safely anchored. They requested for mechanical assistance. Assistance of a tug was made

A crewmember when to the incinerator to add some rubbish to it. A spark came out of the incinerator and the crewmember stomped it out. Minutes later the cage next to the incinerator caught fire. Crew extinguished the blaze with  the fire hydrant hose
Accommodation ladder was not secured to ships side.

On un-berthing, when dead slow astern was requested the engine failed to fire astern. It took about 5 minutes to correct fault. On next movement engine fired ahead correctly and the vessel proceeded out without further incident.
A log slipped from the deck between the stanchions and dropped in to the water between the berth and the vessel.
A helicopter was used to transport a sick crewmember from the vessel. They were taken to hospital to be treated.

Digger driver injured knee climbing into vessel ladder well. They stepped backwards into the man hole for the ladder. The second rung broke off while their feet were on it, they had to pull themselves up with the hand rails.

A wave overturned the vessel, one passenger jumped off and the other got stuck under the vessel. The pair then stayed together treading water, while they yelled for help. After two hours they were rescued and taken to hospital to be treated.

Two kayakers were spotted moving on the pass of the vessel. Warning sound signal was given by ship's horn for kayakers to draw their attention. The skipper kept yelling and got their attention, they moved and narrowly missed the kayakers when passing
A piece of the protection bar that stops the crane wires jumping out at the end of the Gib fell approximately 30+ metres landing not far from a stevedore on the wharf.

Skipper had turned on jump switch instead of isolator switch by mistake, which lead to the port engine to cut out. The vessel carried on to a safe stopping point using one remaining engine. The engine was then restarted and proceed with both engines.
Jetboat hit a rock bank and had damage to the steering nozzles and seating and rendered the vessel unusable. All passengers were safely moved to shore. None of the passengers reported any injury.
Ladder was attached to ships side incorrectly.
Crew member while on deck lashing was hit in the mouth by loose swinging wire. This caused a minor cut to their lip and their teeth were bleeding. They were taken to get medical treatment.
The electrician was going though a hatch when it started to close, causing them to fall and land on their arm. They were taken to hospital for treatment and they broke their arm.

On commencement of loading, a digger was placed on top of hatch cover no. 3. When the digger started moving on the hatch lid, digger started to slide and fall into deck no. 3 port side. This caused some damage to the deck and to the digger, no injury
During main engine repairs vessel unexpectedly shifted north along the berth. Mooring lines were tightened. All cargo operations were placed on standby.
Sheave needle bearing fell apart, the crane was stopped and the grab was dropped off and moved to another crane.

The vessel came in contact with a navigational beacon in the harbour, there was no illumination of shore lights so he visibility was poor. The inspection of the vessel revealed only paint damage with no indentations or damage to steel surface.
The pilot ladder steps were uneven and were at an angle.
When manoeuvring the vessel back into the pontoon the ramp of the vessel collided with the hull of the vessel on their portside. It caused the ramp to puncture the hull of the other vessel.
When manoeuvring the vessel back into the pontoon the ramp of the vessel collided with the hull of the vessel on their portside. It caused the ramp to puncture the hull of the other vessel.
Platform of combination pilot ladder was rigged <5m so pilot vessel could not safely manoeuvre under it in the prevailing swell. The steps were also not horizontal.
Master reported loss of control systems. The crew isolated issue to an electrical power failure and issue was resolved in 15-20 minutes with no actual loss of steering reported.

Main engine failed to start on first kick after lifting off berth. The engine room control manually turned over, then after a 10 minute delay control was given back to bridge and the main engine started and operated with no further problems.
As a result of navigational error the vessel struck rocks and grounded. The owner patched up the holes in the hull and tried to retrieve the vessel at high tide.
The steps on the ladder were loose and unsafe.
A person reported a vessel sunk on its mooring

Whilst performing a rescue boat drill, the boat was lowered to the water prior to boarding, with no-one onboard. The lifting strop caught below the steering wheel and when the weight of the boat came on the strops the steering wheel ripped out.
Crane driver climbing up crane slipped on hydraulic oil and fell, they suffered multiple broken bones and internal injuries.
The thruster failed on berthing due to the generator tripping. The generator restarted and the thruster became operational prior to berthing complete. Two tugs were made fast.

The net was bundled on wharf, crew were detangling it as the ground rope was guided on. Crew member went to operate lever mesh grabbed hand and the ground rope went hard around the controls. Crew member degloved their finger.
Vessel made contact with a submerged object. The bump was slight, the vessel was stopped and all void spaces checked and were all watertight. The vessel slowly moved ahead, no apparent vibrations.
Crew untangled the trap and disconnected the grapple pulling it onboard vessel. It was noticed that rope was caught around the rudder of the vessel leaving the skipper unable to engage the gearbox.
The man ropes were rigged incorrectly and the accommodation ladder was not secured to the ships side.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Driver entered the start of a spin at which point the boat failed turn and proceeded to travel straight ahead. Driver put the boat into reverse to minimise the impact of the imminent collision into nearby rocks. The boat subsequently impacted rocks.
The ladder steps were uneven and the distance between the crimps differed.
Vessel had faulty AIS system, Gyro input to the AIS is erratic, resulting in Erratic COG and CMG.
The pilot ladder was not attached to the ships side and it was not extended to the height of the railing above the lower platform of the accommodation ladder.
The man ropes were rigged incorrectly, the ladder was not attached to ship side
The man ropes were rigged incorrectly, there were no stanchions or handhold above the deck for manropes to run through.
The jetboat lost the starboard engine while under power.
A crew member was pierced by a black ray. First aid was applied, and their condition was monitored as the vessel proceeded to port before the crew member was transferred to hospital for treatment.
A passenger was walking up the port stairwell and slipped, sustaining multiple lacerations. They were transferred to the ship's hospital and first aid was administered.

Strong gust of wind pushed ships bow to starboard, causing vessel to be set on to the long arm. This caused some minor damage to the mid ships shell plating. The vessel also made contact with the pontoon causing damage to the pontoon and the ramp.

There was a fire in hold No.1 caused by a led light internally combusting. Engines were turned off and crew used fire extinguishers to put out the fire. Crew started motors and went back to port whilst checking to make sure fire was completely out.
The container auto twist locks partially engaged while removing container. The automatic twist lock then disengaged causing container to fall off starboard side into harbour.
Fishing vessel hit a submerged log, causing skipper to be thrown to the other side of the bench seat and sustaining three fractured ribs.
The ladder was shackled to the deck, and had crown knots on the end of manropes.
The ladder was incorrectly secured to the deck.
Vessel was taking on water while at its berth.
The ladder was secured incorrectly, it was secured with shackles to the deck.
There was no inward tracks on ECDIS, the master had to call second mate up to sort it out.
The combination ladder was overlapping the pilot ladder made it difficult to get around. The manropes were rigged incorrectly and had knots or splices on ends or in the length of the rope.
The man ropes on the pilot ladder were rigged incorrectly. The steps also had uneven gaps and were they were at angles.

Whilst taking a grab out of hold 4 a link in the chain connecting the crane with the grab failed. This caused the full grab to fall back into the hold from height and land on top of the product. No personnel or equipment were in the hold at the time.
A vessel was towed back to shore after the vessel had an engine breakdown and the passengers were in the water.

A person fell overboard and clung to their vessel for six hours before they were rescued. A person on shore heard them yelling and took them a life ring, before a helicopter transported them to hospital to be treated.
Two logs fell from the starboard side of the vessel and landed in the water. One log washed alongside the berth and was recovered. The other log was monitored and was retrieved the next morning.

The main engine failed to operate immediately, the alarm sounded. It was discovered that all the control air ha been lost from the previous manoeuvre. Tugs were used to slow the vessel down and to help berth the vessel.

Whist lifting short logs off a trailer using the ships crane, two logs slid off the packet and fell on to the trailer and berth. No person was in the vicinity when the logs fell and work was stopped immediately.
A crew member was knocked over on the deck by a long line, they fell over on an hit their head on a hatch nut. They were knocked unconscious.
The Gyro Compass failed.
Extreme weather caused the vessel to break its mooring and ground on the beach

While stowing a lift of logs on deck 2 the Cranston nut and split pin have come off causing the bolt to come loose and release the lift approximately 1.5m to the deck below. All logs remained on deck.
The vessel took seven starts and then took a few minutes to refill the air bottles.
Pilot ladder standards - Unresolved
Neither the ladder or the gangway were secured to the ships side.
Raft came over a wave and wiped as it came down, as guide was holding inside rope. This caused them to pull their arm muscles and fracture their carpal bone.
The hatch came down on the observer's hand. The observer sought medical attention once the vessel made land the next day.

Vessel experienced start air pressure issues when testing main engine before departure. When proceeding outbound "reduce rpm" alarms sounded. The main engine then stopped for no reason, after ten minutes it started again.
A passing boat wake caused the exposed starboard navigation housing to rub up against the underside of the tyre and damage the housing.
Event Location: Bluff Port, Western end of Wharf 4

Brief Description: Combination ladder with trapdoor and rope ladder section shackled on the underside of the platform. The ladder to platform distance was not large enough for safe operation.

A crew member fell from a ladder seven metres into a cargo hold. Life flight rendezvoused with the vessel and winched the injured crew member aboard and transported them to hospital with a suspected fractured pelvis.
Stern line passing through a panama fairlead parted during ahead movement of main engine testing procedure.
The engine failed resulting in the vessel needing to be towed.
When putting the pin into forward manhole to test to see if it was going to stay in, the steel of the hatch cover broke.
The ladder was secured with shackles to the deck.
A log slid from the top of a heave as it was being lifted from shuttle trailer on to the ship. The scene was frozen.
A crew member jumped into a slurry tank and slipped causing a minor cut above eye. No first aid was required.
An auto shut down caused reduced propulsion for approximate 2 minutes.

A crewmember cut their scalp on a bracket support screw while removing rubbish. They were assessed by the medic on board, and it was determined that medical attention was needed. They were taken to hospital where they received stitches.

Port engine lost power then stopped, and was unable to be restarted. Vessel was secured into safe location on remaining starboard engine. Assistance was called, a second boat was sent to the scene. Passengers were transferred, the trip was continued.

The vessel ran over the purse net, the skiff was used to hold the boat off the net. The conditions were rough and the skiff dropped, the lugs on the bow punctured the hull above the water line. No injuries occurred.
The crane driver was slewing and pulling at the same time to get the wires out which caused the wire to jump the sheave. No damage or injuries occurred.
Oil was noticed leaking from a crack in the reduction gear box housing. Reduction gearbox failure caused the housing to crack.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Two passenger cabin windows were damaged due to adverse weather conditions. Two passengers sustained small cuts and were treated by the ship's senior doctor.
Wind and tide set the vessel to the north of the channel. Shuddering was heard on the vessel indicating the possibility of touching bottom. Transit continued outbound with no further incident.
Master incorrectly handled a line throwing device and accidentally set it off. Their improper handling caused the discharge of the expired item.

An operator was climbing the housing ladder. The operation was stopped but a gust of wind and the swell of the sea made the load to slightly swing. Their hand was crushed between the spud and housing. They went to hospital to be treated.
The combination arrangement for pilot boarding had the accommodation ladder too low for the pilot launch to safely board the pilot.
The vessel blacked out when using the bow thruster leaving only the main engine to complete the pilotage.

A port side partition inside the factory pond was left open allowing fish and sea water to spill into the factory area. The crew then proceeded to contain what was in the pond from spilling any further into the factory and immediately began to clean.
Vessel's front window smashed by the impact from a large wave.
The helm became unresponsive, the steering was changed to NFU on tillers. The vessel returned to the harbour for testing and no issues or faults were found. The passage was resumed.
The combination ladder was not secured to the vessel, manropes were incorrectly rigged. Chocks were loose on various steps.
The vessel lost pitch control due to a faulty valve limit switch.

Vessel suffered pitch control failure on the starboard shaft approaching the berth in Picton. Emergency pitch control back up was engaged but the pitch still failed to respond. The Starboard ME was shut down and the vessel berthed on the Port ME.
The main engine had to be stopped due to a broken drain pipe on the turbo charger. The broken pipe was blanked off and the vessel was underway in twenty minutes.

While raising collapsible stanchions on starboard side near the cargo hold, one crew member put their foot on the stanchion socket when the stanchion dropped on their left foot. Their foot was crushed and they received surgery.

The RPM did not change after requesting full ahead and excessive exhaust was being emitted from the funnel. The decision was made to proceed outbound and tugs escorted vessel for the remainder of the passage.

On hauling approximately 50 tonnes of cod a strop parted and the winch wire and hook whipped back, smashing the bridge safety glass window. All crew were clear from the deck during this normal operation with no injuries occurring.
Vessel struck submerged object with engine resulting in a damaged skeg on port engine.
The vessel had a control failure of engine and had to anchor for 1 hr while tests were made to fix the fault. The vessel then returned to port with no further incident.
Event Location: Tamaki River by Half Moon Bay

Brief Description: A crew member got their arm stuck in the conveyer belt, resulting in bruising

The main engine was not available due to a lack of start air. Tugs were advised to be close in case of assistance needed. The main engine answered astern the bell order and the manoeuvre continued without further incident.
The Skipper crushed their finger between securing rope and the side of the vessel. Due to medical complications, the finger was required to be amputated
While reversing and pulling a pontoon, the vessel's engine started making loud noises and grinding. Vessel lost propulsion and drifted onto rocks. It was then towed back to the jetty
While the digger operator was stowing logs, a log slipped through on to the gangway where ship's security crew were located. A crew member received a graze to their leg.
Vessel tender overturned by wave. Crew managed to climb on top and rode the vessel until it grounded against the rocky shore.
One log slid of the heave as the crane driver was taking the weight of the logs. The scene was frozen, no injuries occurred.
Port unit was inadvertently de-clutched causing the vessel to slew sideways. Damage occurred to portside upper rail, navigation light housing and housing for rope store vent.

The mooring line failed due to the weather conditions. The bow lines broke causing the vessel to drift across the harbour. The incident was reported to the ports and the vessel was secured by harbour tugs and brought alongside the wharf.

Extreme wind gusts resulted caused the stern line to fail and the vessel swung rapidly out from the pontoon. The deckhand lost control of the fuel hose. The pump was isolated, approx. 10 to 200 litres of diesel oil was lost into the water.
Nylon rope snapped and caught the crew member across the stomach while lifting the fish pump back onto the boat. This resulted in a bruised abdomen.

The pilot vessel and ship rolled, causing a gap between the two vessels as a crewmember was stepping onto the ladder, causing them to fall into the water. They were recovered within two minutes and sustained no injuries.

The pilot vessel and ship rolled, causing a gap between the two vessels as a crewmember was stepping onto the ladder, causing them to fall into the water. They were recovered within two minutes and sustained no injuries.
RCCNZ was contacted due to the skipper having a serious medical event. A crewmember took control of the vessel and took it to the nearest wharf where the skipper was transferred to hospital.
A near miss occurred between two vessels.
A near miss occurred between two vessels.

A crew member stepped out on to the crane platform surrounding the crane to pull the wire in. They temporarily unclipped their harness and the wire jerked/unbalanced them and they fell onto the hatch lid below, suffering serious injuries.
Boat came off its mooring and drifted onto the rocks

A swell lifted the vessel off the trailer to the port side whilst the bow was still attached to the trailer. The bow rails caused damage to the trailer ladder and braking system. The vessel only suffered minor scratches
There was a small fire on the deck of the punt. Sparks from gas cutting determined to be the cause of the fire.
A vessel failed to give way and cut in front of another vessel's bow.
A vessel failed to give way and cut in front of another vessel's bow.
A refrigeration unit was being vented for a pressure test with nitrogen that vented into a confined area. The area was quarantined and cleared of the nitrogen
The vessel slipped its mooring and grounded nearby.
The pilot ladder had a rubber step that split at the rope whipping.
The passenger stood up to change seats and tripped and fell. As a result of the trip they broke their ankle. The passenger was transferred to hospital for treatment.
Event Location: Hole in the Rock at Piercy Island

Brief Description: Fish hook embedded into the finger of passenger. A Coastguard vessel evacuated the patient to be treated at hospital.
The pilot ladder was not compliant, the step gaps were uneven and the man ropes were rigged incorrectly.
Crewmember lost the tips of their index and middle fingers while operating a fish heading machine.
The vessel was heading into a cove when it struck an uncharted rock.  As a result the vessel sustained moderate damage to the bow.
Event Location: Burial Cove, Broad Bay, Stewart Island

Brief Description: Vessel had to stop the main engine to replace a faulty drain valve which was on the cooling system.
The vessel ran out of fuel. Another vessel came out to it and refeulled the vessel.

The pilot ladder was not supported by side ropes. Shackles were fitted over side ropes a few steps above the one taking the load, but the ladder was slack in between. At the bottom spreader and rubber step, chocks were missing.
Skipper operating vessel at low tide noticed shallow water ahead and pulled back on the throttle, decelerating quickly and grounding on the sand bank.

The vessel had three cranes which were unserviceable due to control issues and one failed crane wire. Loading commenced and one crane would not lift the load of logs, Loading stopped and the vessel cranes were inspected.

During vessel manoeuvre off the wall, gust of wind caught other vessel. Bowsprit of other vessel hit the starboard window and smashed it. At the same time, a crew member reached out and got their finger caught between the bowsprit and window frame.
Pallet broke while being lifted onto the vessel and packaging material fell into the hold.
The echo sounder malfunctioned, a technician went on board and assessed the unit, they determined it needed to be replaced.

Crew member was starting the vacuum pump, they positioned the engine and trapped steam turned the flywheel and pushed the engine down. The starting lever came down and hit them on the shoulder, resulting in a suspected broken collar bone.

Skipper heard a bang as they were accelerating and felt a bump. They stopped to check damage and noticed damage to the propeller and shaft. They started the auxiliary motor and slowly headed back and received a tow when they got to the channel.
Vessel ran aground on a mud bank with 21 passengers on board, with the skipper unable to refloat the vessel. They contacted their other vessel and transferred the passengers to shore.
The pilot ladder was secured under the platform and not to the deck.

As the skipper put both throttles astern from neutral, the starboard engine engaged forward gear which turned the boat to portside, the starboard gearbox was locked in forward gear. Both engines were turned off and the vessel headed back to the jetty
The pilot ladder had shackles, knots and splices in the ladder ropes. The tripping line was fitted on the aft side.
Vessel made contact with the flare of another vessel causing the dislodgement of the two upper most Not Under Command Lights.
A vessel came at high speed towards another vessel, they were abusive and the other vessel had to move out of the way to avoid a collision.
A vessel came at high speed towards another vessel, they were abusive and the other vessel had to move out of the way to avoid a collision.
The vessel was entering the harbour and travelling at less than 5 knots. Another boat passed at approximately 20 knots and only 10 metres away.
While departing vessel, vessel's bow thruster failed. Vessel safely departed using tugs/engines.
Crew member suffered a hernia while lifting a bin of fish, they were transferred onto shore.
Mooring failure vessel drifted onto mud bank, at high tide was able to drive vessel off and back to wharf.
The pilot ladder had no stanchions or handhold above the deck for the manropes to run through. The steps also had uneven gaps and were at angles.

While going into the marina, the vessel touched the mud inside the channel while navigating around an out going barge. They reversed off and checked off board discharge. Back at port crew checked the strainers.
The accommodation ladder was not secured to the ships side, the ladder was not attached to ships side 1.5m above the accommodation ladder platform.
The pilot ladder was not secured correctly. As the pilot was transferring across to the gangway, the gangway swung outwards in a roll - slamming back to the hull as the vessel rolled away.
The pilot ladder was observed not hanging vertically. The steps were on an angle from horizontal and possibly stressed.

Vessel was taking on water off the coast off Cape Campbell. A standby call was made, but due to rough weather it was unclear of the location. The vessel activated their beacon and a helicopter was dispatched. All three passengers were rescued.
