Jetboat's steering wheel detached from the steering shaft, resulting in the boat colliding with a cliff face at high speed and both passengers sustaining injuries.

The maintenance engineer was in the engine space, they put one hand on the front panel of the generator to steady themselves and felt a sharp jolt through their hands, sustaining a mild electric shock

During maintenance check, the engineer had isolated the piece of equipment and began removing the injector. When injector was removed hot water from the cooling system discharged and burned their lower leg and forearm.
Pilot ladder was not up to standard. The ladder spreader was at an angle, the chucks at the step were loose and knots were at the bottom of manropes.

Bunding bag on port number one tank breather pipe over flowed into the harbour. Spill soak mats were deployed around the bunding bag and surrounding deck area to contain residue. The estimated quantity of spill was 40-100 litres.
The vessel sustained some minor damage when a number of shelves in the fridge collapsed and a gate was lifted from its hinges due to heavy weather conditions.

The impact of the wave against the boat caused the drivers shoulder to hit the front of the boat and subsequently knock them out of the boat. They were rescued and the vessel was recovered and brought to shore. They sustained a dislocated shoulder.
Pilot ladder not compliant with SOLAS standards
Deckhand slipped on a step and dislocated their shoulder. They were taken to hospital for treatment
The pilot ladder was less than 5 metres above the sea level.
Crew member lost consciousness due to reduced oxygen in an enclosed space. Rescuers on board responded and applied first aid before they were transferred to hospital for treatment
Vessel was discharging full cargo. Brest line at foredeck went under tension and rested on edge of hull which cut the line and it separated. No crew were on deck.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Seaman was stacking frozen cartons as the vessel was steaming. Vessel lurched in rough seas and the front layer of the stack fell, with a 20kg carton hitting their ankle.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

The steering system locked causing the ship to swing to port under pilotage. The chief engineer found that the clutch was not engaging and heat was generated due to slipping. The ship was anchored, and proceeded to berth then next morning.

A crew member was pulled over the lifelines into the water after getting caught in the sails. This caused the kite to get caught in the rudder. Another vessel rescued them as the vessel was unable to move.
Vessel attacked by shark, no injuries were sustained.
The shore-based hiab was slewing an unloading cage onto the stern of the vessel when the hiab wire parted, and the cage dropped into the water, glancing the stern of the vessel. No one was injured.

When backing out of the marina berth an issue with the hydraulic pump inhibited oil supply to the gearbox. This caused the vessel to remain in reverse even after 'ahead' was applied. Power to the engine was cut, the anchor was dropped.
Crew member suffered burns to their leg after it was caught in the rope of a cray pot which had been dropped overboard

When the tow wire was shortened to disconnect and hip up to barge, it was noticed that the barge was down by the stern. The skipper was advised to go to anchor. The dump barge was brought to shore to unload sand and water.

While heading to main vessel the dinghy capsized while trying to board, two crew both wearing lifejackets fell into the water in bad conditions. Both were in water for approx.10 mins before reboarding.
A crew member fell 5m and suffered a deep laceration to their left shin
When the gear was engaged on both engines an abnormal sound started coming from the port engine and the vessel lost power. The vessel transited through the harbour to viaduct with no further issues.

Vessel bow submerged up to windscreen in front wave and the aft wave broached vessel to port. The skipper made a mayday call and then the vessel submerged and overturned. All were able to escape the vessel and were rescued.
Event Location: Freshwater River mouth, Patterson Inlet, Stewart Island

Brief Description: While working on the wharf during the unload of hatch 1 the gang working heard the short spring line creak as it came under tension. They cleared the area before the line snapped at the point at which the line was tied to the vessel
The vessel's main engine shut down and the anchor was then dropped. A tug was organised and towed the vessel back to berth.
A vessel collided with the wharf and the infrastructure sustained considerable damage.

A rope fouled the motor in the boat, leading to flooding of the vessel. The boat then flipped and all three passengers fell into the water. One person was able to call the police and a rescue team was dispatched. All three were rescued
The starboard bow area of the vessel hit a submerged object. There were no visible signs of water ingress. The vessel was checked and hauled for minor repairs.

Vessel drifted at anchorage with one person onboard. A crewmember from shore kayaked out to catch the vessel. The person on board got hold of coastguard and the two passengers dropped the anchor. The crew then carried on as no damage occurred.
The vessel hit a submerged rock with the skegg of the outboard. The engine recoiled and the skipper brought the vessel to a stop. The outboard was still idling, and the cowling came loose.

When shifting vessel from berth to berth the main engine failed to start once pulled off the berth by tugs.  The vessel was contained by tugs until the engine was started. The cause was due to a low tube oil temperature issue.
Log slipped out of heave landing on wharf, no injuries were sustained.

When engine order on bridge telegraph was put to dead slow ahead, the engine turned ahead with revolutions for half ahead. Engine control was given to the engine room and revolutions adjusted to requested settings via telephone.
Vessel lost power to their engine and was towed back to port by a nearby vessel for repairs.

The wind caused the stern of the vessel to be blown away from the wharf. Whilst attempting to put the vessel back alongside, the bow collided with a fender pile of the wharf causing the front pontoon bag to deflate.
Safety glass broke while lifting the vessel up and sideways onto the rubber buffer. The trap deployment was aborted, and the vessel was moved to a sheltered area. No injuries were sustained.
Failure of turbo on main engine led to oil being forced into exhaust which became a potential fire hazard. The main engine was shut down and a tow was organised.
A strong wind gust pushed the vessel on to a sandbar. The skipper phoned for help and they received a tow to get free. No damage occurred and no one was injured.

Two vessels were next to each other when one vessel punctured the port side front pontoon of the other vessel. The damaged vessel returned to the wharf. The pontoon had slipped under the chime, and got hooked on a bolt which caused the puncture.

Two vessels were next to each other when one vessel punctured the port side front pontoon of the other vessel. The damaged vessel returned to the wharf. The pontoon had slipped under the chime, and got hooked on a bolt which caused the puncture.
Whilst taking a lift of logs onto the vessel a piece of steel conduit (approx. 4m) fell from the crane to the wharf below. No injuries were sustained.

The vessel gear box pressure was lower than normal, vessel was slowed and then investigated. The crew found that the starboard gear box Morse cable was broken. The engine was shut down, and the vessel was taken back to port for maintenance.
Hook connected to line under tension broke, causing the line to snap back, hitting thigh of one crew member and the wrist of another.
The pilot ladder was non compliant, it was secured incorrectly.

The main engine RPM was only working at 70% which then increased to 100% after some time. The main engine shutdown oil mist detectors, the covers were opened and after a few hours the main engine started again.

High temperature alarm sounded on the port main engine and the temperature was very high.  The engine was placed into idle speed and then shutdown. The trip was curtailed and the vessel returned to berth on one engine.

A digger driver entered an access hatch to enter hatch 1 and reported a lack of air in the area. The driver reported they felt unwell and took 30 mins off work due to a shortness of breath and headaches.
During a drill the davit for the fast rescue craft did not function.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
The ladder was secured to the deck using shackles which is non compliant.
The crew were lifting Cray pots when another vessel drove past at close quarters and at high speeds. They did this numerous times, each time turning away at the last seconds to avoid a collision.
The crew were lifting Cray pots when another vessel drove past at close quarters and at high speeds. They did this numerous times, each time turning away at the last seconds to avoid a collision.
Log became dislodged and it rolled down the heave and slid between the stanchions, landing on the berth.

The engine failed to operate ahead when pilot ordered dead slow ahead to arrest slight astern motion of ship. The tugs were ordered to stretch their lines and the crew took control of the engine for the remainder of the berth.
Vessel had been anchored overnight, on weighing anchor flukes not on anchor. The sea state was calm, wind light airs throughout however there was no weight on the anchor.
As crane was being stowed, crew lifted crane hook and caught their finger between hook and stowed boarding ladder.
Vessel deviated slightly from its passage. Tugs were used to line the vessel back up in the No.3 Reach.
The vessel was responding to a rescue mission and the boat rolled over. Crew were able to right the vessel and return to shore. No injuries were sustained
Crew member was knocked over by a wave which came over the side of the vessel. They injured their shoulder and went to the medical centre once the vessel was berthed.
During a dredging run the vessel drag head made contact with a beacon which sustained substantial damage. The vessel backed away and then made headway to the east of the beacon.
A crew member was walking around the bow of the boat when they slipped and broke their arm. They were taken to the medical centre.
The pilot ladder was lashed on the deck with shackles which is non compliant.
The pilot ladder was not up to standard, it had loose steps.
The vessel was heading on course when another vessel approached on a direct heading. They had to move out the way to avoid a collision.
Event Location: On route from South East Bay to Havelock

Brief Description: A truck exiting the vessel struck the side and damaged the water tight door of the vessel. No injuries or other damage occurred.
Puncture occurred to the side of the boat, this was due to it being pushed into the barge bow anchor of another vessel.
When backing into the wharf, the vessel made contact with the duckboard. The skipper noticed a puncture in the duckboard, the hole was temporarily taped up and the next day was repaired.
A boat suffered some damage to the hull after it was dragged out of the lake.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
The man ropes on the pilot ladder were very thin.
Boat started taking on water and the bilge pump could not keep up with the intake. The skipper alerted a boat which was passing and they were rescued before the vessel sank.

After a survey on the valve water was taken, a water leak was detected in the lower boiler door. The boiler was shut down and scheduled trips were set up to be conducted one boiler at slightly reduced pressure within harbour limits only

The vessel noticed another vessel on course to hit them, the crew tried to get their attention and put their boat in reverse to move out the way. When reversing the vessel made contact with a channel marker, damaging its hull.
Two kayakers were out fishing when one kayak sprung a leak. A boat was tasked to retrieve the person from the water before they were taken to hospital for treatment for hypothermia
The side ropes of the pilot ladder were secured to the deck head. There was no platform to the side.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
While discharging palm kernel, the grab dropped a load on a generator running the hydraulics which caused a small fire which went out almost immediately. The scene was frozen immediately.

Skipper fell asleep and when they woke up it was to stop the vessel from pushed in the swell onto a sandy part of the beach. The vessel was placed in neutral. The skipper backed the vessel out safely into deeper water. No further damage occurred.
The vessel hit rocks and then started leaking fuel into the harbour.
Lasher fell while climbing onto the hatch cover from the centre ladder, they landed on the side deck on their leg. They went to hospital to receive treatment
A gust of wind knocked a drum loose. The drum fell and hit a crew member, with the crew member sustaining a fractured collarbone.
A helicopter was tasked to evacuate a crew member after they had a medical event on board their vessel. They were taken to hospital for treatment.
The vessel had water ingress from a leaking valve. The ingress was handled by the bilge pump and the vessel sailed to a haul out facility for replacement of faulty valve.
A helicopter was tasked to locate three rafters that had been ejected from their raft. They rescued all three people, one had a minor back injury.
A sick crew member was airlifted off the vessel and taken to hospital.
The manropes were attached to the top of the portable stanchions instead of running through the tops and being attached on deck.
Fault in locker room water cooler caused a small fire. The cooler was isolated and the fire was extinguished immediately.
Medivac was conducted by helicopter to winch an unwell crew member off the vessel.

Vessel was discovered to have water ingress into the fish hold whilst in port. Water was then evacuated by use of bilge pumps. The cause was due to pipework which had been removed for repairs and suction valve not seating properly.
The vessel was on course when another vessel approached on a direct heading. The vessel was forced to stop to avoid a collision.
While departing the gyro compass failed and settled with a 180deg error before re-calibrating.

While in reverse, the controller mechanism sheered off inside while leaving the boat reversing backwards. The engine was quickly shut down but the vessel was unable to stop in time and bumped in a moored vessel.

While in reverse, the controller mechanism sheered off inside while leaving the boat reversing backwards. The engine was quickly shut down but the vessel was unable to stop in time and bumped in a moored vessel.

The vessel lost an inflatable life raft overboard that then inflated. The crew then recovered the life raft and once the raft was partially deflated and hauled onto the bow deck the vessel continued to its destination.
The vessel broke free from its buoy mooring. The mooring line had chafed through after bad weather occurred. The vessel had a broken window and no other damage occurred.
The pilot ladder had an incorrectly rigged retrieval line.
At the Tutea falls waterfall a passenger did not tuck in their chin forward enough resulting in them hitting their face and nose on the helmet of the passenger in front of them.
The ladder was secured with shackles at deck level and the manropes were secured around safety rail stanchions as there were no deck fittings provided.
Whilst underway the port gearbox coupling failed, the vessel returned to port on one engine.

When slewing towards the hopper, crew brought the grab down towards the hopper and due to mechanical failure, the grab "free failed" about 5 m towards the grab. The emergency stop button was used to stop the grab hitting the hopper.
The crane malfunctioned and swung back with the full grab starboard side back towards the hold 2. the emergency button was used to cease operations.
There was no power going to the crane and the fault sign was flashing.
The vessel hit the beacon head on, which broke it off the seabed. The master was injured due to the contact.
While placing 11 metre logs against the port side stanchion with the crane the heave knocked a 3.6 metre log which slid through the stanchion onto the berth.
The skipper lost balance and fell into the water, the kayak began to take on water so they swam approx. 350 metres to shore. The kayak was not found
Crane operator was taking the weight of the heave under crane 1 when a log slid out of the heave onto the berth. The log was re positioned with a digger.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Crew member's fingers were pinched between a gantry hook and the backbone of the mussel line. Whilst pulling their fingers free, a portion of the skin of their left finger tore off.
Event Location: Marine Farms off Wilsons Bay, Firth of Thames

Brief Description: A boat broke down and emergency services were alerted. The vessel had engine trouble and they were towed back to shore. No injuries were sustained.

As the vessel touched the shore the stern swung around and there was a bang. When checking the master found the damaged propeller on the starboard engine. The propeller was replaced with no damage to shaft alignment.
As the crane operator was loading the deck on the port side deck and pulling the wires out,  a log on top of the heave turned and slid onto the berth before the digger operator could secure the log
Vessel engine failed to start whilst in navigable channel with tugs in assistance. The chief engineer fixed the issue and the vessel then proceeded to berth without further incident.
Crane driver was taking the weight of the logs when 6 logs slid off the heave onto the berth.
The boat dragged its mooring in a storm and was close to a cliff edge.
The vessel lost steering, the emergency steering was engaged. Tugs were notified to be on standby, the vessel berthed with no further problems and the engineers found a faulty switch.
A passenger was suffering from pneumonia and they were airlifted off the vessel and taken to hospital.
A crew member cut their finger whilst cleaning fish

The vessel was responding to a boat which had dragged its anchor, as the crew were checking for people on board the boat pitched up and it’s gunwale caught a small 25mm alloy hand rail on the vessel causing it to bend and crack.

Skipper engaged reverse gear on the port engine to straighten vessel in the channel. Port engine stalled. Skipper was able to manoeuvre on to the trailer with starboard engine. Engines annualised to determined cause of stall.
The vessel engine stopped, on investigation there was no fuel in the tank. Other vessels assisted.

On arrival vessel engine was set to dead slow astern then Slow Astern. Engine room called the bridge to request engine be stopped then reset to dead slow astern due to irregular RPM. Vessel assessed to be in a safe position with two tugs made fast.
The ladder was secured incorrectly, shackles were used.
An injury occurred to the crew member when they were casting out fishing gear off the back of the boat and hooked their finger on the gear.
While discharging sulphur from the vessel a small sulphur fire broke out on an excavator working in hold 1. The fire was extinguished quickly as per procedures and work recommenced.
The trapdoor system was not secured to the ships side. The top extended end of the ladder was not made fast on deck.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
The electrical generator power supply failed, a portable diesel generator was used.
The crew member was entering a doorway into the boiler room. They misplaced their foot and rolled their ankle, resulting in a fractured ankle
A rescue helicopter responded to a PLB call and uplifted four people from their kayaks. One person had a minor head injury.
Ladder was lashed using shackles and not ropes to main deck.
The chef was not wearing the appropriate PPE gear and sustained minor burns to their wrist when removing a tray from the oven.

The main engine failed to go astern on three attempts. The vessel re-positioned after tug to right astern and stopped the headway and berthed without incident. The engine fired up at slow astern, five minutes after the initial request.
The vessel capsized with two people on it, they were rescued after hanging onto the upturned vessel. A member of the public onshore saw the flipped boat and launched a boat to rescue the passengers.
A yacht with two people on board broadcast a PAN call as it had lost engines, lost the headsail and was having difficulty with the mainsail. Coastguard directed the yacht into a safe anchorage.
The skipper was removing the last berthing line of the vessel when their hand got caught between the pile and vessel,  lacerating their hand.

During unloading of equipment, the unloading bridle dislodged a valve on the refrigeration coil. The system contained only residual gas which leaked into the hold. The vessel was evacuated as a precaution & the leak was contained and the hold vented.

Crew started calling starboard to another vessel as they had were not changing course and were on course to make contact. They did not alter course and the vessel did not have time to move, contact occurred on the port side at the bulkhead.
The main engine was on local control in the engine room which meant a 10 second delay occurred to get the engines to respond to controls.

When requested to pull aft, the tug commenced with the instruction and whilst doing so witnessed the capstan on the tugged vessel break free. The tug ceased pulling to assess damage to both vessels, but no damage was evident.

When requested to pull aft, the tug commenced with the instruction and whilst doing so witnessed the capstan on the tugged vessel break free. The tug ceased pulling to assess damage to both vessels, but no damage was evident.
Crew member slipped on a patch of spilled detergent and sustained a fractured arm.
Thumb injury occurred to a passenger as the door slammed due to wind. They went to a doctor once they returned to shore.
Passenger hurt their back when the vessel went over a wake at the falls.
Vessel was towed back to shore due to propulsion failure.
The pilot ladder was hung incorrectly, it was hung over a bollard with weight being supported by step of ladder.

The pilot ladder was incorrect, the ladders man ropes were made fast to the ships rails, there were no fittings to welded to the deck. Side ropes of the ladder were secured with shackles, as there were no eyes to secure with rope lashings.
The pilot ladder was secured only by shackles through the side ropes of the ladder.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
The pilot ladder tripping line was hanging from the bottom step.
Crane four had failed prior to shift starting, so the crew informed stevedores not to use the gangway as there was potential for boom to drop which was positioned directly over the gangway.

While racing two vessels were collided with each other due to a wind gust changing one of their paths. The collision caused a large hole in vessel, water flooded the boat quickly, all four crew abandoned the vessel and were rescued, the vessel sunk.
The raft went over the falls, a passenger was propelled forward at bottom of the falls, hitting the helmet of the passenger in front of them. This resulted in a bleeding nose and swelling
The vessels anchor dragged and the vessel made contact with the stanchion of another vessel. Minor damage occurred to both vessels.
The vessels anchor dragged and the vessel made contact with the stanchion of another vessel. Minor damage occurred to both vessels.
The pilot ladder had shackles, knots and slices in the ropes. The tripping line was also fitted too low on the aft side.
The ladder was uneven towards the bottom. The whippings at the chocks were loose.
A crew member had their fingers caught in wire when they were lowering the gangway.
The engine/telegraph/RPM indicator was not working.
While berthed and in strong winds, excess tension on a highly vertical breast line broke a bollard from its moorings .
The boat flipped on an incoming wave and one crew member sustained a spinal injury and was airlifted to Middlemore Hospital.

The vessel was found settling onto the bottom while it was tied up to the pontoon. The vessel sat down completely on the mud as the tide continued to go out. The vessel was left secured in position until the incoming tide caused the boat to re float.
A patient was lying on lower deck after falling downstairs in severe pain with obvious arm, elbow and possibly shoulder injury. A helicopter was requested to transfer the patient to hospital.

Occupants of both crews could see each other and tried to divert their path but could not do so in time. They managed to slow the speed of the boat a little. Both boats collided with each other. Minor injuries occurred, no damage was sustained.
While loading logs on the deck of the ship, two logs dropped in the tide and one on the wharf. The logs were retrieved, no damage or injuries occurred.

Fire was detected in the starboard engine room, the vessel was brought to a stop and the fire was put out with extinguishers. Emergency services were made aware of the situation, the vessel headed back to berth. Crew were treated for smoke inhalation
Two people were rescued after their vessel smashed against rocks
When transferring from one tank to another a tank, the diesel overflowed spilling approximately 100 litres of diesel.
The Starboard bow pontoon came in contact with the rock wall. The vessel retuned to port to inspect the vessel, there was a small scuff mark on the starboard bow pontoon point.

A small leak was discovered around the Starboard Side main winch drum, the source was found to be a hole in the brake oil supply. The hydraulics were turned off and soaker pads used to absorb the leaked oil. The hose was changed.

When pulling the diver back on board, the boat got swamped due to weight shifting. The passengers stayed in the water holding on, they then swam 3 hrs to shore to contact police. The police towed the boat back, no injuries occurred.
A vessel lost power and they deployed their anchor to stop drifting, another vessel towed them before Coastguard arrived to tow them back.
A vessel hit a ski biscuit which had three passengers on it. One of the passengers came off, all three were taken to hospital for treatment.
A vessel hit a ski biscuit which had three passengers on it. One of the passengers came off, all three were taken to hospital for treatment.
A small fire started in the anchor locker, around the windlass. The fire was extinguished, and the anchor locker was flushed and cleaned. One crew member received minor injuries.
The pilot ladder was non compliant due to the shackles and non rope lashings used to secure the ladder to the deck.
A local boat company pulled a kayaker out of the water and headed to shore after the kayak capsized.
The vessel made contact with a large unknown object. The vessel proceeded to berth with one engine. The mater contacted the harbour to let them know about the object.

The boat rolled in the swell and the skipper slipped off their seat, they fell down two steps into the lounge and hit their head on the floor, they became unconscious for about 30 seconds. They were met by ambulance at the wharf.

Both outboard engines stopped on vessel, the skipper dropped the anchor. The vessel was towed the short distance back to the wharf and secured. The passengers were disembarked. An air bubble was found in the fuel system.
The pilot ladder was old and had loose steps. The ladder was attached at deck level with old shackles. ladder

A passenger experienced back pain after vessel travelled though some large waves. The boat stopped and turned around  to decrease the impact of the waves. An ambulance was called for precaution and they were taken to hospital for treatment

The fire alarm for the engine room space sounded, the automatic fire suppression system was activated. A faulty relay/contactor had burnt out and activated the fire suppression canisters in one of the switch boards. The vessel headed back to port.
The ladder and manropes hung below the trapdoor, which is non compliant. The ladder and frame were removed.
The ladder presented was non compliant, there was a trapdoor system with ladder and man ropes secured under the platform.

The jet unit bucket was in more ahead than reverse position causing the vessels bow to slew quickly to starboard. Starboard bow made contact causing damage to the starboard bow. Crew and passengers were unharmed.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

When halfway across the bar wind started to pick up and this caused large waves. The boat tipped over backwards and the three passengers treaded water till they were rescued. The boat sunk, and the next day no debris was found.
Whilst loading cargo of logs onto the deck, a log slipped out of the heave into the water.
While checking the lashings on containers, one turnbuckle became loose from the stowed position and hit an AB on the left side of their hard hat
Skipper issued urgency call to RCCNZ as two vessels collided and their anchor warps became tangled. No damage occurred to the vessels and the skipper managed to rectify the situation by themselves.
Skipper issued urgency call to RCCNZ as two vessels collided and their anchor warps became tangled. No damage occurred to the vessels and the skipper managed to rectify the situation by themselves.

Starboard rudder failed to respond upon leaving. The rudder was then isolated and the emergency tiller arm was used to help get the vessel back into berth. The hydraulic lines were cleaned out and metal shavings were found blocking the control valve.
A kayaker was missing after falling out of their kayak. They were later found by a search and rescue team.
Event Location: Off Great Barrier Island, Karaka Bay

Brief Description: A crew member injured their back while lifting 20 kg inflatable swim buoys. They were taken to hospital.
Pilot ladder not compliant with SOLAS standards

Vessel capsized in rough conditions, the mast broke in two places. They got the rig on board, mounted outboard motor on transom and motored back to marina. A yacht stayed with the vessel until coastguard came along.
The ladder was old and needed to be replaced. Widget seizings were worn and the widgets had gaps so it was getting a bit loose.
A sailor suffered a medical event, an alarm was raised and emergency services were contacted. Search and recue operations were involved and assisted the person off the vessel.
The anchor chain for the buoy tangled in the port side propeller of a vessel causing repairable damage.
Two pilot ladders were used to extend past the platform, they were secured 1.5 metres.
The pilot ladder bottom steps and spreader were not parallel. The steps from the bottom spreader were at a 45 degree angle.
The ladder had shackles, knots and splices in the ladder ropes and it was not secured correctly.

A passenger started hallucinating and became violent. Crew restrained and sedated them in order to calm them. The vessel travelled to port and anchored off the harbour. The passenger and an injured crew member were transported to hospital.
The mast of the waka was damaged due to rough sea.
Skipper had left hatch open momentarily and as the deckhand entered the boat through the window they stepped down and fell into the floor compartment, injuring their leg.

Vessel ran over a stray line which fouled their propulsion. The anchor was deployed and passengers were transferred to a responding vessel. The fouled propellers were cleared and the Pan Pan call was cancelled. The vessel was then returned to mooring
The ladder had shackle, knots and splices in the ladder ropes. The tripping line was incorrectly fitted on the aft side.

One of the lines went through the other side of the rudder and was suspected that it got tangled with the propeller. Crew slowly heaved up the line and saw that the line was moving and not tangled with the propeller.
Two crane remote controls were coded with the same frequency.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Two valves for the shaft brake were left closed, RPM caused an increase in pressure and friction on the brake. An emergency stop was called, tugs attached lines to the ship to keep vessel un position until issue could be resolved
Barge was pushed onto rocks by strong winds
A vessel with three people onboard started taking on water due to rope being stuck around the propeller
The vessel struck a rock, the vessel was then freed, however it immediately hit another rock. The skipper had to get off the boat to push it off.
Event Location: Tinline Bay, Abel Tasman National Park

Brief Description: The pilot ladder had shackles, knots and splices in the ropes. There were also no stanchions or solid handholds.
The pilot ladder had no stanchions or handhold above deck for manropes to run through
A crew member was moving drums on board and they twisted their lower back, requiring medical treatment.
A passenger tripped and fell in the corridor

Deckhand opened starboard engine room hatch and a smell of diesel came out. The starboard engine was shut down.  The engine was found to be covered in diesel, the foam extinguished was used which quelled it. They headed back to port on one engine.
Sun in the coxswains eyes obscured their vision causing the vessel to hit the buoy. No injuries occurred.

The vessel had to turn to starboard to avoid risk of collision with another vessel. The other vessel gybed to port and cut across the bow very fast. Engines were put into reverse to avoid collision, there was approx. 30 metres to spare.
Event Location: South of Devonport Wharf, Waitemata Harbour

Brief Description: A dismasted yacht declared distress. Another vessel offered assistance and picked up the sailor.
Passenger missed their footing on the bottom step of the main companionway and fell. They were taken to hospital with a possible punctured lung.
A small amount of oil was spotted near a floating production, storage and offloading ship off the coast of Taranaki.
The pilot ladder steps were at a slight angle at the bottom of the ladder, with the deck steps horizontal.
The vessel was transiting the river when it touched bottom.
The vessel rowed directly in to the stern of the moored boat stopping the single sculler abruptly. No injuries occurred and minor damage was evident on the moored vessel.
A vessel going at high speeds did not change their course and made contact with a vessel which was stopped to fish.
Skipper dozed off and vessel grounded doing about 7 knots speed. Vessel grounded near low tide with no major damage and was able to be refloated later that day.
Boats collided due to congestion on the river as it was at a time of high activity. No damage was done to either craft but the oars from each boat slammed into the back of the bowman of each boat.
Crewmember was working in the cross bay walkway when the walkway plate gave way underneath them. No injuries occurred.

A vessel was anchored when another vessel started heading in their direction. The vessel got close and passed in front narrowly missing hitting the bow. The port side made contact with the front of the anchored boat causing the boat to swing.
The scupper turned inside out causing water to free flow into the vessel.
Vessel grounded on a rocky area south of Kaikoura. The skipper was not injured and was able to abandon ship onto the rocks the vessel was grounded on.

When entering the port ship's main engine failed to run astern, the main engine remained out of order for 8 mins while manoeuvring in port with tugs. Main engine returned to working order prior to coming alongside.
Pilot report - Resolved - Crew Issue, BRM or Lack of
Vessel with five people on board struck a rock, police and coastguard were contacted and escorted the vessel back to the marina.

Revs were not coming up and sitting in critical range. there was a cylinder leak and the vessel couldn't run at full ahead. Speed reduced to half and proceeded out with tug escort. Vessel cleared port and proceeded to sea to fix the problem.
About 100 litres of diesel spilled onto the wharf and into the water while the vessel was refuelling.

The vessel bumped a submerged rock causing the guide to fall from their seat. When falling they twisted their knee, they were met by an ambulance when they returned to shore and they had a slight tear of their MCL.
The pilot ladder had no stanchions or solid handholds and the ladder was rigged incorrectly.

The movement of the ship caused a crew member to hold onto the moving conveyor, where they caught their hand leading to their arm being broken. The emergency stop button was pressed and first aid was given. They were transferred to hospital.

An abrupt grounding occurred, resulting in two crew members to fall forward. Minor injuries were sustained including bruising and small abrasions. The vessel was checked for damage, no leakage was observed. The master headed the vessel back to berth.

A collision occurred between two yachts during a race. One crew member was badly injured, they sustained two broken ribs and a bruised kidney.  On water medic staff took sailor to shore and an ambulance took them to the hospital.
Vessel was at anchor and dragged anchor in wind change and came into contact with nearby moored boat while crew were ashore.

While walking along aft end of bay, the crew member had the walkway grating collapse under their feet, they kept hold of the handrail to avoid falling and injuring themselves. Master was informed and the area was taped off awaiting repairs.
The mooring line broke under water from a shark bite.
Event Location: 20 miles east of Gable Islet, Gisborne

Brief Description: Crew member fell out of the vessel. They were then backed into by the returning vessel, resulting in the propeller lacerating their arm.
Vessel drifted onto rock during fishing activities. No injuries and cosmetic damage to hull occurred.
Crew member was lifting mooring buoy line when the boat shifted and their finger was caught between boat hook and loop, resulting in a broken finger
The tripping line was fitted too low, spreaders were missing and the man ropes were rigged incorrectly They also had knots and splices throughout the ropes.

A crew member knocked their eye on the conveyor system. After one night the redness worsened and it was decided they should seek medical advice. They were evacuated from the vessel by helicopter and taken to hospital.
Ships crane block came apart and fall into the hold with all log lifting gear attached. No injuries occurred and the scene was frozen.
Crew member lost their balance after the vessel surged forward in heavy seas, slipping and  falling overboard. They climbed back on board with minor grazes.

The outboard cut out, the fuel line had become disconnected. This was re connected but the engine didn't start. Assistance was called and another vessel towed the vessel back to port. The fault was caused due to air intake on fuel tank being closed.
Minimal water entered through window as the tide hit bow of the boat causing front port side window to pop. Nil injuries, nil damage.
The pilot ladder magnets were positioned below the platform instead of above.
The pilot ladder was incorrectly rigged, it was only 0.5 metres above the water instead of 2 metres.
A crew member sustained a fracture after the hydraulics moved, causing the bottom of the dredge to crush their foot.

Vessel hit a submerged rock on our starboard side, damaging the starboard side of hull, prop and rudder. Vessel started taking on water and having difficulty with propulsion and steering. Another vessel towed to shore and repaired.

Crew were welding plates, the acetylene hose ignited approx. 6 metres from where the welding was taking place. This resulted in melting of the oxy-acetylene hoses and some burn marks on the wall near the leak from the hose. No injuries occurred.

Skipper fell and hit their head, then landed awkwardly and broke their arm. They fell due to two large waves causing them to lose their balance. The crew took the vessel to shore where the skipper was met be emergency services.

Cyclone mooring chain twisted over the shackle holding the rope, it then chaffed the eye parting the line. Vessel then ended up drifting onto mud bank where it was retrieved later in the morning on the high tide. No damage to vessel or environment.
The pennant wire parted causing the stanchions to collapse. Once the pennant wire was repaired, the stanchions were raised.

When the owner disembarked the vessel they stood on the unsecured lids and the lid slipped and they fell onto the vessel causing injury to their tail bone. The bins and fishing gear were removed to prevent this happening again.

The bin was about 5m above the ground and the crew were about to lift and slew the scrap bin into the hatch, when the power was lost to the crane. The crane swung back and the brakes failed, the bin slowly lowered to the ground by itself.
The pilot ladder spun to horizontal rubbing strakes and this resulted in the ladder pushing away from the ship's side.

The deckhand was standing in fish ponds knifing fish when the boat rolled and lurched causing them to fall backwards trapping their lower leg on the fall while their body twisted causing an injury to left knee. They were taken to hospital.

A vessel noticed another vessel on the same course as them, they gave 5 shorts blasts to try attain their attention. The other vessel took no avoiding action, so the vessel came to a stop to avoid a collision.

A vessel noticed another vessel on the same course as them, they gave 5 shorts blasts to try attain their attention. The other vessel took no avoiding action, so the vessel came to a stop to avoid a collision.
The pilot ladder did not meet correct standards.
The pilot ladder shackles used to secure it were not varnished correctly.

The vessel struck a rock, it was difficult to see and the skipper had not been in the area before. The vessel was put into neutral and when it was safe enough, the motor was started again and they moved. Significant damage occurred to the keel.
The pilot ladder was shackled to the underside of the trapdoor platform incorrectly.
The pilot ladder did not meet the standards, it was attached by shackles to the underside of the platform, did not extend past 1.5 metres and was not secured to the ships side.
Starboard side had parted at the base and stanchion leaned towards at a small angle.

Ten minutes after shutting the engines down, smoke was noticed coming from the starboard engine bay. A small amount of flames came from the engine room, crew extinguished the fire. All electrical systems were isolated, vessel went back to port.
The chocks on the pilot ladder were all loose and the steps were not held firmly in position.
A fire occurred in the wheelhouse most likely caused by a tea towel on the drying rack above the stove, falling onto the stove.
Power was requested for the thruster, the ship then lost power and the emergency generator started. Vessel steered to port to clear any potential dangers as speed dropped.
The pilot ladder was secured to the deck with a very rudimentary knot.

A faulty fuel gauge on the portside of the fuel tank caused the engine to stop operating as it was starved of fuel. A second vessel was used to bring additional fuel and the vessel was taken to the wharf to transfer the passengers.
Customer started to complain of chest pains mid-way through the trip, they came became unresponsive, but stayed conscious. A helicopter was called to transfer the passenger to the hospital.
As the vessel was reversing into berth they came into contact and caused a scratch on a private yacht while manoeuvring in the marina. No injuries or other damage occurred.

The anchor line parted as the boat resettled after a small swell rolled under the vessel. The crew secured the remaining warp and got the secondary anchor. The crew replaced the warp and changed the splice configuration.
The forward starboard port lite failed allowing water into the forward bedroom. Action started immediately to make repairs, water was pumped out and the vessel continued without further incident.
The steering failed resulting in throwing passengers onboard out of the boat.
Tug impacted the ship’s hull (port quarter) causing indentation to ship's hull.
Tug impacted the ship’s hull (port quarter) causing indentation to ship's hull.

Two passengers jumped off the ferry from the top deck into the water while underway making way into harbour. MOB gear was deployed and retrieved one person while the other person swam under the wharf. Police were called.

Passenger fell into an opening while walking to foredeck as a crew member failed to close hatches. The passenger did not take any medical treatment on board, once off the vessel they were seen at hospital, they had a fractured ankle.

Two boats collided causing one to capsize, the rowers swam to shore and then got back in the boat rowing it back to shore.  A miscommunication between officials and the crew resulted in the collision.

The gyro was drifting slightly over several days by 3 degrees, service was arranged when the vessel was next in port. The technician found that centre pin and support for gyro sphere had suffered damage.
The raft flipped over,  right onto a rock shelf where the customer hit their right arm on the rock. Basic first aid was applied and they passenger went to hospital for further treatment.
Stevedore sustained a crush injury to their left wrist while trying to manoeuvre a container into its stowage position. The scene became frozen and immediate first aid was given.
The ropes were incorrectly running on the deck, and the stanchions were too short.
Vessel had a ladder with loose and uneven steps, the ladder was also incorrectly secured to the deck.

A crew member reported to the doctor aboard with stomach pains, the doctor carried out an examination and decided they should go to hospital. After 48hrs in hospital they were deemed fit to board the ship again.
Vessel moved out of channel to avoid collision as a small fishing vessel was anchored in the middle and did not move despite the vessel blaring their horn multiple times.
A vessel was heading straight towards another without making any sign of moving out the way. The vessels missed by approx. 1 metre.

Bow thruster jammed tripping both ships generators and blacking the ship out while positioning. The prevailing wind then pushed the vessel onto the seawall mud bank adjacent the wall. Generators were started and the vessel was moved to clear water.

A crew member lost their balance after a wave hit the vessel, causing them to slip and land heavily on the vessel. The vessel headed towards shore where the crew member was attended to by medical services.
Vessel found partially sunk.

Crew noticed blue smoke coming from port engine, the engine alarms started to show the oil pressure dropping fast, power on port engine was lost. There was no fire, the boat was turned around and passengers were offload safely. Repairs were made.
Crew member attacked another member of crew before jumping overboard. RCCNZ and HMNZS tasked to render aid to the injured crew member.
Event Location: Beyond Offshore North East of East Cape

Brief Description: The pilot ladder was not continuous for 2 m above the combination ladder but was fixed below a bar on the combination ladder.

The master noticed a smell and saw starboard engine temperature rising and the alarm sounded. The engine was put in idle and the temperatures continued to climb, the engine was then shutdown and continued to port. The impeller was replaced.

While getting the sails down and secured, the wind caught the main halyard line and flung it overboard where it snagged on both propellers which caused the motors to stall and stop. Coastguard was called and towed the vessel back to berth.
A client fell out of the raft and dislocated their right shoulder. An ambulance was called to assist with the passenger transported to hospital.
Vessel touched isolated rock while carrying out hydrographic soundings in shallow water.
The pilot ladder was stretched on one side, with the steps horizontal at deck level, but at approx. 30 degrees from the horizontal at the bottom of the ladder.
A passenger fell out of canoe and ended up on the side of the river. A spot help message was activated and they were collected and returned to shore.

After a wind gust, the vessel manoeuvred upwind. It was then discovered that the anchor warp had parted and the anchor and 2.5 shackles of chain had been lost. Vessel proceeded to sea and dodged in lee land until daylight.
A boat sunk at its mooring overnight.
The starboard pilot ladder bottom 10 steps were not horizontal.
When reversing in the pier the vessel clipped a wooden post, which in turn pushed the other posts horizontally, damaging the lamp post to the point where it broke off.

After the autopilot malfunctioned, the skipper began navigating by sight and became disorientated, before travelling directly toward shore and grounding. Paramedics effected a water rescue to bring passengers to shore, with one sustaining hypothermia
The manropes were found to be excessively long and instead of 2 metres above the water they were dragging significantly in the water.
The gangway portion of the pilot combination ladder was not secured to the hull.

The master smelt burning and saw smoke, the port engine bay was smoky. When the bench seat was lifted up there was smoke and small patch of flames from a 12-230v inverter. A fire extinguisher was used and the vessel returned to shore, no injuries.

The vessel was hit by a very large wave whilst crossing the sandbar. One passenger sustained a back compression injury due to the wave impact. Vessel immediately returned to shore and the passenger was transferred to hospital.
The manropes were non compliant, they were shackled to the top of the stanchions and had splices below the shackles, making the rope thicker than the permitted size.
Crew member injured as their finger got caught between rope of stern line anchor and cleat.
A helicopter was called to lift the skipper from the vessel after they developed an illness
Event Location: Coastal off Ninety Mile Beach, Northland

Brief Description: A vessel was speeding towards an anchored vessel, they did not change course and narrowly avoided colliding
A vessel was speeding towards an anchored vessel, they did not change course and narrowly avoided colliding

During morning trip starboard engine made a loud noise and lost power. Engine was switched off to prevent further damage. Boat was secured using the port engine and passengers transferred to a second boat.

A vessel was anchored and fishing when a speeding yacht operating on autopilot headed toward them on a collision course. The crew tried unsuccessfully to get the attention of the yacht master,  and the yacht collided with the vessel.
Event Location: Between Motuihi island and Waiheke Island

Brief Description: A vessel was anchored and fishing when a speeding yacht operating on autopilot headed toward them on a collision course. The crew tried unsuccessfully to get the attention of the yacht master,  and the yacht collided with the vessel.
Event Location: Between Motuihi island and Waiheke Island

Brief Description: Engine failed during warm up. The boat was restarted and ran, before stopping again. On inspection it was found that the main 10amp fuse had a hair line crack causing loss of power to the engine.

Four kayakers paddled into a tree, one kayak capsized and the operator went to help them. The operator got trapped against the tree, they managed to get out and help the remaining client. However, they suffered minor injuries during the process.

The vessel was leaving the harbour, the skipper was cautious of keeping their distance to avoid any collision with another vessel. The vessel made contact with Starboard Buoy No. 17 causing minimal scratching. No injuries were sustained.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Jet boat hit rock while doing a U - turn, causing the driver's head to hit the windscreen, sustaining a broken nose and fractured orbital socket.

The coastguard was approaching a private vessel on starboard side. The coastguard vessel reversed, due to shallow water they were unable to resist forward motion and made contact with the vessel. Damage was minimal and no injuries occurred.

The coastguard was approaching a private vessel on starboard side. The coastguard vessel reversed, due to shallow water they were unable to resist forward motion and made contact with the vessel. Damage was minimal and no injuries occurred.
Two kayaks capsized due to winds. The passengers were close enough to shore they managed to beach the kayaks
A vessel foundered on rocks due to anchor failure. The reason is unclear whether the anchor failed or the joining of the shackle to the anchor chain broke. The vessel was washed up on the rocks.
Passenger injured onboard as the balcony door slammed from the wind and caught their hand. The doctor on board assessed their hand and the passenger went to hospital once onshore.

The engineer was performing maintenance on machinery and neglected to lock out the equipment whilst making adjustments to the machinery. They inadvertently triggered the machinery and crushed the tip of their index finger. First aid was applied.

During a spin a passenger not holding on slid into the passenger seated next to them, injuring their shoulder. Driver checked on the injured party, and while uncomfortable, they continued on. Onshore they were treated with basic first aid.
Jetboat driver noticed excessive water being pumped from the bilge area of the boat while stationary. Both bilge pumps were activated and the boat taken to the trailer and removed from the river.

Starboard engine lost power, the driver went to the closest stopping area on one engine and transferred their passengers to another boat to complete their trip. A small chafe in a wire to the 5 volt supply protection cover had moved causing the fault

Deck cadet fell from the pier to the water while adjusting the gangway net during a routine gangway watch. The cadet grabbed the messenger line, and a life ring was thrown to them. They were pulled to the ladder to climb up. They were not injured.
Event Location: Ports of Auckland, Fergusson Container Terminal

Brief Description: Crew member caught their arm between the bulwarks and the vessel. The skipper completed the manoeuvre then took the crew member to a medical centre, where they were assessed to have sustained a sprained and bruised wrist.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
Crew member had an ongoing infection in their mouth from a broken tooth, they were picked up by the coastguard for further treatment
Pilot ladder did not extend 2m above the combination ladder but was fast below the combination ladder.
The anchor failed to hold and the skipper of the vessel misjudged the space required to complete a manoeuvre. There was minimal damage between the two vessels which hit each other.

The coastguard vessel came alongside another vessel to attach a towline to the trailer eye. While attempting to slide vessel bow down to mid ship, the wind caught stern of the other vessel pushing it out causing the bowsprit to make contact.

The coastguard vessel came alongside another vessel to attach a towline to the trailer eye. While attempting to slide vessel bow down to mid ship, the wind caught stern of the other vessel pushing it out causing the bowsprit to make contact.
When mooring up the tug a noise was heard coming from aft/drive units. One of the mooring lines was seen getting sucked into the starboard unit.
A large launch failed to give way to a vessel under sail, and vessel had to actively avoid a collision.
Event Location: South  Cavalli Islands, and Rocky point

Brief Description: A large launch failed to give way to a vessel under sail, and vessel had to actively avoid a collision.
Event Location: South  Cavalli Islands, and Rocky point

Brief Description: Yacht was moored in Oneroa Bay with family sitting on the deck, when they noticed a boat sailing at high speed towards them. The vessel was on a collision course. One family member yelled out, and the other vessel heard and changed course.

Yacht was moored in Oneroa Bay with family sitting on the deck, when they noticed a boat sailing at high speed towards them. The vessel was on a collision course. One family member yelled out, and the other vessel heard and changed course.

Vessel lost steering, skipper put more steering oil in and noticed the steering ram connection had corroded and cracked. Passengers were transferred to another vessel. The skipper tightened connections and drove vessel back to wharf for repairs.
The chef on the vessel was cutting vegetables when they sustained a serious cut on their left thumb.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The tripping line was fitted to low.
A large wave washed over the ship, which resulted in one of the vessel's lifebuoys which was located on the vessel main deck being washed overboard.
Raft landed heavily after coming down a waterfall, dislodging a few passengers into the water. One passenger sustained a broken leg.
Passenger fell from raft after it came down a waterfall. She hit the bottom of the river, sustaining a fractured wrist.

Mayday calls were made to both Maritime and Coastguard radio. An aircraft was used to locate two passengers from their vessel. They were found safe and well, they had had trouble maintaining anchorage.
Vessel suddenly dropped rpm as the exhaust bellows failed, allowing exhaust gas and raw water to enter the engine compartment and engine.

Freezer trays stored adjacent to the by-catch plate freezer broke the chain holding them in rough weather. The loose trays contacted one of the plate freezer flexible hoses causing a hole and a liquid ammonia leak. Replacement was required.

Skipper fell overboard, they had been in dingy checking they were attached to the correct mooring. Mayday Relay broadcasts were commenced and a vessel responding located the skipper and took them and the dingy back to their vessel.
Rescue helicopter extracted an individual jammed against a log in the river and transported them to hospital for treatment.
Event Location: Hollyford Track, to the east of Rainbow Lake

Brief Description: Pilot ladder not up to standards. The pilot ladder was not rigged, ready for boarding. Crew were also observed, and it was clear they did not understand correct ways to operate the ladder.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The pilot ladder had not been tested in the last nine years.

Whilst proceeding to the anchorage the starboard engine lost revs, stalled and failed to restart. The engine had lost a considerable amount of oil into the bilge, so the starboard engine was isolated and vessel returned to berth on port engine only.
Pilot report - Unresolved - Pilot ladder, Crew Issue

Engine room informed that the no 6 unit was not firing and they need to proceed with slow speed. They proceeded  with very slow speed and after pilot got off dropped anchor for repair. After repair vessel proceed to the passage to Lyttelton.
Three vessels involved in a near miss after travelling down the same fairway. The vessels were on a collision course, however all three vessels managed to alter their positions to avoid this.
Event Location: Westhaven Marina, between A Pier and Y Pier

Brief Description: Three vessels involved in a near miss after travelling down the same fairway. The vessels were on a collision course, however all three vessels managed to alter their positions to avoid this.
Event Location: Westhaven Marina, between A Pier and Y Pier

Brief Description: Three vessels involved in a near miss after travelling down the same fairway. The vessels were on a collision course, however all three vessels managed to alter their positions to avoid this.
Event Location: Westhaven Marina, between A Pier and Y Pier

Brief Description: Vessel stropped under the hanging tree branch tunnel to show off the feature. The river had risen due to the dam opening and the tunnel was too close to the river bank. The vessel clipped the rear wing on a tree. No injuries or damage sustained.
Medical situation of crew member, suspected perforated ulcer in crew member. Ship's doctor recommended MediVac and contacted RCCNZ who commenced helicopter MediVac
Vessel owner injured as they fell while stepping off jetty walkway onto the boarding platform of their launch.
Event Location: Waikawa Marina, Beach Road, Waikawa, Picton

Brief Description: Two people rescued after their boat sunk on Lake Taupo. They were rescued from rocks which they were stuck on.
Vessel became stuck on the Foxton Bar with 3 passengers on board. Coastguard responded to this incident.
Calls to police and coastguard were made as they responded to a vessel with 5 passengers on board, off the Kapiti coast.

Pilot ladder not up to standards. The manropes where shackled to strongpoints just below the capping on the bulwarks each side of the bulwark opening. The length of the shackle, thimble and splice reduced the effective length of the manropes.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The manropes had eye splice with thimble which was shackled onto stanchion.

While hauling a long line a tangle came up and hauling stopped to clear this. Once done the lever was pulled the wrong way and pulled the teeth of the fish along the back of crews hand causing 2, 3 inch long cuts that required cleaning and stitches.
Event Location: At sea off Greymouth Westcoast NZ

Brief Description: Vessel took evasive action closely avoiding a collision by less than ten meters from another vessels bow. They carried on at speed alongside their partner boat.

Bow thruster tripped whilst coming into berth. Vessel commenced swing for berth at safe speed with tug fast aft. During swing, bow thruster tripped twice. Vessel was controlled throughout, using safe speed, helm, tug and engine. Vessel berthed safely

A range of items were lost overboard, and ship suffered damage. The ship has two mooring winches and one of the mooring winches broke, leading to only 3 of 4 being operational. Docking was not hampered.

Vessel was approaching from behind another vessel at speed, another boat pointed at the launch and yelled due to the large wake it was making. Skipper yelled but they passed extremely close without altering course or reducing speed.
Vessel came into contact with jetty, metal channel made contact with bag and tore it.
Three people were on board the boat when it started taking on water, they were wearing lifejackets and swam to another vessel nearby. The sinking vessel, caught fire.
Valve accidental turned on and quickly turned off while in port. Accident was turned into a drill and the factory was evacuated. This caused a minor ammonia leak on board.
A witness reported a potential marine pollution violation, after seeing a large blue barrel brought up in codend and discarded back to the sea.

Vessel got stuck on Raglan Bar, after getting tide times wrong. The skipper tired to get the vessel free, but rung coastguard for assistance. Skipper got vessel free and headed to sea. Skipper rung coastguard to notify them they no longer needed help

Vessel made contact with a fishing vessel while departing from the port. They made contact around the mid ship on port side. There was no visible damage to the fishing boat and crew were safe. There are some indentations to the other vessel.

Vessel made contact with a fishing vessel while departing from the port. They made contact around the mid ship on port side. There was no visible damage to the fishing boat and crew were safe. There are some indentations to the other vessel.
Retrospective complaint about an injury incurred on a passenger ferry a few years ago. Injured person received a permanent injury after a chiller door slammed on them.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladder was secured with shackles.

A blackout occurred and the emergency generator was used, a small fire was reported on one transformer for breaker switch. Once fire out and power restored, the bridge systems were reset. Vessel proceeded inwards for berth without further issues.
During shifting at berth and with pilot on board , vessel starboard quarter made contact with jetty which caused minor dent on the starboard side aft hull.

Vessel noticed their anchor rope floating in the water and subsequently realised they were being towed by a trawler. The anchor rope broke at the chain connection. Vessel did not pursue after the trawler, due to low fuel.
Event Location: Hauraki Gulf, 5 km north east of Noises

Brief Description: Vessel was proceeding shore side to unload passengers and was given the inner pier port side alongside to berth. A gust of wind drifted the vessel down onto the pilings situated forward of the berth. A small mark was made but no damage to the pier.
While vessel was towing, the starboard trawl block let go as the main pin has sheared off. The pin has since been replaced and safety chains have been put on all blocks.

Boat travelling downstream when the vessel glanced a rock on the underside of the hull on the starboard side. Driver immediately parked boat on shore & contacted shore base for assistance. Passengers transferred to other boats & continued trip.
Passenger fell while exiting the gangway. The passenger was taken to hospital for treatment.
Crew member fell while using the ladder when getting down from bunk. The crew member debarked for medical repatriation requiring further treatment back home.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Water became rough and passengers were thrown around on top level of vessel. They were unable to alert skipper as noise of radio and motor blocked out their screams for help.

Vessel realised they were on wrong side of cardinal mark and immediately pulled power back to neutral. Stern of vessel lifted up but port propeller struck submerged rock. Passengers transferred to another vessel. Port propeller was damaged.
The barge was hung-up on the aft spud. Upon freeing the spud, the barge assumed its normal trim. Inspection showed no ingress of water.

Crew member descended the ramp and lost their footing and fell down and banged their left arm, they felt discomfort to their arm and had to be taken by wheel chair to the medical centre where they received treatment from the ship’s doctor.
Propeller has caught on synthetic rope which was being used to secure floating mooring buoy onto the pier.

Crew member had an upset stomach. Captain and crew monitored, while they rested in the cabin. Arrangements were made for crewmember to be transferred back to port so they could be assessed at hospital.
Crew member was trimming fish when they cut their left Index finger. The skipper treated the laceration with first aid. The vessel then returned to port and medical care was arranged.
While conducting a routine tourist trip up the Dart River, the port engine cut out. The driver switched the engine off and restarted it. Jetboat was driven back to Glenorchy without fault.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The accommodation ladder platform was less than 5m above water.

Pilot ladder not up to standards. The vessel had engines demobilised for repair during stay. The master stopped main engine and advised pilot they need to anchor. Repairs followed and no other issues occurred during outbound.
Vessel was overtaking another vessel, when they switched course they crossed the path of the other vessel very closely. This resulted in a near miss.

During steering tests, steering was not responding. Problem was identified as the micro switch limit for one of the cams, which is connected to the remote control system. This was moved out of position and resulted in the steering to stop working.
Vessel was scratched at the bottom, due to hitting rocks.
Vessel was approaching another vessel on a collision course. The vessel moved away in time so the other vessel crossed their bow and no collision occurred.
Vessel was approaching another vessel on a collision course. The vessel moved away in time so the other vessel crossed their bow and no collision occurred.

Crewmember went to grab the rope off the rock, and the swell lifted the boat up and across the rock. When it slipped off, the pontoon ripped and deflated. They jumped off onto the rock, the boat deflated with one pontoon still inflated.
Vessel was anchored with a large dive flag. Another boat pulled up, then sped off over top of the people in the shallow water.
Event Location: Okorotere Island, Te Whanganui-A-Hei Marine Reserve

Brief Description: Crew observed oil sheen around the barge. The crew arrested a potential hydraulic oil leak. After the potential leak was contained the crew applied dispersant to the sheen. The cause was a crack in an aluminium valve block.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The port side pilot ladder steps were not horizontal from the 2nd last spreader and below.
Whilst berthing, starboard corner of vessel ramp clipped the starboard aft belting of Island Navigator leaving a 9cm x 6cm, tear.

The vessel was still engaged with reverse throttle and the vessel swung in a wide track slowly back towards the beach. Skipper quickly killed the engine, and then jumped over the side of the vessel to prevent the vessel grounding on the beach.
Event Location: Waterfall Bay, Eastern side of Kapiti Island

Brief Description: In the process of the berthing procedure, a vessel began to reverse out quickly. Their stern pulled towards the vessels bow. Anticipating a potential collision, the skipper immediately put the vessel astern to avoid any possible contact.

In the process of the berthing procedure, a vessel began to reverse out quickly. Their stern pulled towards the vessels bow. Anticipating a potential collision, the skipper immediately put the vessel astern to avoid any possible contact.
Vessel struck rocks and sank, six passengers on board were rescued and all returned to shore safely. The boat sunk as a large hole was caused from the rocks.

It was noticed a yacht was sailing in the vicinity of the ship but well clear. Minutes later it was noted that the yacht was out to port and approaching to cross the ships bow. A blast horn was given to warn the yacht.

It was noticed a yacht was sailing in the vicinity of the ship but well clear. Minutes later it was noted that the yacht was out to port and approaching to cross the ships bow. A blast horn was given to warn the yacht.
A lifting strop failure resulted in timber being lifted into the ship falling from height on to wharf.
Crew member slipped on the tail end on the bow rope, rolling their left ankle in the process.
Event Location: Off of Hobson Wharf heading Halsey Street

Brief Description: One of the returning vessels struck a surfer on the head as it passed through a wave.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The accommodation ladder in the combination boarding arrangement was not secured to the ships side.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The accommodation ladder was not secured to ship side.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The trapdoor combination ladder platform looked lower than the required 5m from the waterline.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. This vessel had a potential non-compliant trap door arrangement.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The vessel presented a non-compliant trapdoor arrangement with the ladder suspended from the gangway.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Vessel presented a shell door pilot ladder secured to deck head without stanchions.

Crew reported odour of LPG on the rail deck, the crew slowed down and started investigations. No leak was found. Inspections were made on arrival. No report was received onboard about any leaks. Vessel loaded subsequent cargo and departed.

Pilot ladder not up to standards. The reel had a very loose arrangement for locking the reel and the ladder was secured with relatively light securing ropes which were tied to the handrail and not the strongpoints that were fitted on the deck.
Injury to charterer's ring finger while they climbed over the life-line railings to swim. As they dived their ring finger got caught. There skin was stitched up in hospital.
Injury to skipper's foot due to placing their foot incorrectly on the deck with their toes catching the lip of the gangway.
Kids jumped off the boat ramp pontoon in front of a passing vessel, causing the vessel to take evasive action to avoid them.
Event Location: Inner harbour boat ramp in Gisborne

Brief Description: Pilot ladder not up to standards. Pilot Ladder is connected to the underneath of the trap door and does not continue to connect to the ships side or deck.
Pilot report - Partly resolved - Pilot ladder
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Upon boarding ladder was found to be secured to deck lugs with shackles.

Pilot ladder not up to standards. Pilot ladder requirements sent to vessel by the agent, stating not to use shackles to secure the ladder. They didn't use shackles as instructed, but didn't use anything else either.

Pilot ladder was not up to standards. The ladder was very old and worn and the bottom rungs were at an angle. On deck about four rings from the top of the ladder on the left side one of the main strands appeared partially cut through.

Vessel was on autopilot heading straight, when another vessel went to overtake at a fine angle slightly away from the vessel. They suddenly changed their course and it was now on a collision course. The straight vessel veered to avoid collision.

Vessel was on autopilot heading straight, when another vessel went to overtake at a fine angle slightly away from the vessel. They suddenly changed their course and it was now on a collision course. The straight vessel veered to avoid collision.
The vessel steering failed and passengers were transferred to another vessel. The vessel was returned by using emergency steering.

Master noticed rope attached to the stern while returning to jetty. Actions were taken and attempts were made to remove the rope. All rope was removed, however, fragments of rope had made it past the cutlass bearing. Minor changes were made to SOP
Engineer hit index finger with hammer while conducting repairs.
Passenger tripped on a flight of stairs and fractured their right ankle.
Two people collided into each other. Damage was significant but no injuries.

Passenger boat made contact with rockface, damaging the vessel's rear starboard and injuring four passengers. Vessel was then beached while passengers were assessed and treated by members of the crew.
Crew member accidentally cut their left palm. The wound was cleaned and dressed.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Starboard pilot ladder used for embarkation with bottom steps on an angle.
When overtaking a vessel, a high speeding vessel cut in front of the vessel ahead requiring the vessel ahead to turn hard to port to avoid a collision.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
A vessel was involved in a near miss situation involving a pilot vessel and the tug vessels.
Jet ski collided with a another jet ski which was towing a sea biscuit.

A crane main sheave bearing failed during operation. No personnel were in the vicinity and no weight on the crane at the time of the incident. The failure was picked up by the operator due to a noise coming from the Jib. Operations were ceased.
Vessel hit rock and sunk. Three people were uplifted from on board.
Vessel's starboard PEM had a control fault which was preventing its operation.

Crew member became dizzy and was not feeling well while passing fish into hold for stacking. They continually passed in and out of consciousness and began seizing. Crew member was monitored until paramedics arrived.

Their was a breach of safety operations, due to the skipper testing their engines while still loading cargo without notifying Harbour Control. The vessel surged on the berth causing the terminal staff to have to stop cargo operations.
A mayday call was made from a yacht with 2 passengers on board which had lost steering. A vessel responded and took the vessel under tow.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Vessels starboard side pilot ladders steps were not horizontal and the tripping line was rigged incorrectly.
Loss of port engine due to mechanical issue. Vessel immediately returned to port on 1 engine (starboard). Vessel docked safely. All passengers disembarked. No injuries, no more damage to vessel.

The engine was damaged with a hole which was punched through the intercooler. After being cleared to sail, a drop in power on the port engine was noticed. All passengers were ok onboard and they were returned to the berth under one engine.
Vessel run hard aground, nil injuries reported from the four passengers on board. The bow sustained some damage and took on some water.
Vessel hit a rock, took on water and the boat sunk.
Skipper was coming back upstream in an empty boat from dropping rafters off and ran aground on a shallow sand bar. Boat was recovered and no damage sustained.

Vessel tangled equipment due to weather conditions, while untangling equipment crew member had their left thumb caught in wire. Crew member damaged their left thumb with a cut which received 5 stitches, no broken bones.
Recreational jetboat hit rock in deeper water.
Passenger experienced sharp pains in their chest. A mayday call was transmitted to have them assessed.

The vessel ran aground on the rock wall near Wellers Rock. When they were able to remove the vessel from the rocks, they started to take on water. They vessel headed to the  sand banks, and was patched up to stop the flow.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladder was shackled under the trapdoor with a short ladder above to a frame also located on the trapdoor.
Skipper fell down the hatch landing on the floor in the accommodation due to tiredness, the fall was approximately 3 metres.

Operator made a turn to avoid a patch of seaweed. Crew member went overboard. Boat stopped immediately and turned tiller arm to prevent the prop pulling them under. Crew member came up under boat and brushed the prop guard, suffering minor abrasions
The aft port fender caught flare of transom of an arriving vessel.
Water was found in the fuel line, vessel organised to be towed.
Crew member adjusted the course of auto pilot, and over corrected causing the wire to flick over the side of the vessel and strike a deckhand on their hand.
Boat hit submerged log and damaged prop
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladder was not secured on both sides of pilot ladder to ships hull. The gangway was not secured to ships hull. The tripping line was secured aft of ladder.

Morse cable snapped on starboard engine bucket control whilst approaching ferry berth. Bucket locked in upper position. Vessel was diverted to pilings, secured and shut down engines. Marina tender assisted the vessel to berth, the cable was replaced.
There was reported drug use on the vessel to the point crew could not walk when they were coming off the vessel.

A problem with the starboard engine occurred and vessel pulled back on the power for both engines while  investigations took place. Crew advised to standby anchor. Vessel had sustained broken rocker gear. Vessel berthed with one engine and a tug.
