Uncontrolled gybe caused by wind shift while running downwind in 20 Knots. Problems setting spinnaker caused major distraction. Crew member in cockpit was hit in their chest by main sheet. They broke their ribs and scapula.
Loss of power on the starboard engine occurred. All passengers were informed. Coastguard arrived and towed the vessel back to port.
Skipper navigated the vessel into rocks near the shoreline, dismounting the engine from the vessel. Vessel was towed back to port, no injuries, but damage was sustained to the engine.

A split coolant hose on the starboard engine resulted in an engine overheat and manual shutdown. Vessel continued to marina on port engine. They restarted starboard engine briefly for docking. No damage and no injuries occurred.
A crew member on board suffered a stroke and required immediate medical evacuation.
Medical evacuation requested for a passenger after they became ill.
Event Location: West of Cape Providence, Chalky Inlet

Brief Description: Vessel lost steering, they then locked the engines in a dead ahead and continued at a slower speed. After continuing, the skipper noticed the bilge was half full of water. Propulsion was lost and passengers rescued before the vessel sank.

As the skipper was about to pass, a kayaker decided to pass in front of the vessel with the vessel less than 2 meters away. The skipper had to throw vessel in reverse in order to avoid a collision with the kayaker.
A passenger slipped on a ramp while coming in from the outside deck, and fractured their left wrist.

Port shaft pitch failed while vessel was arriving into port. The turn towards the berth was made without incident. Skipper set the starboard engine to full astern which reduced the speed. The ship was berthed safely, with a tow assisting.
The bolts of the crane's block were broken while the stevedore was loading logs at port. The bolts were replaced by new ones.
Passenger sustained light graze to arm and knee as they missed the step and tripped on the edge of the gangway while boarding.
Vessel was travelling between buoys when a passing vessel intimidated them by driving close and at high speed resulting in a near miss.
Vessel was travelling between buoys when a passing vessel intimidated them by driving close and at high speed resulting in a near miss.
During a lift the flat rack fell from the lifting frame falling into the ships hold. There were no personnel in vicinity of the falling load. There were no injuries to personnel.
Vessel was struck by another yacht at mooring, this caused extensive damage to the forward pulpit and stanchions.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.

Vessel airbags started leaking. As the vessel rolled down the launching ramp and began to swing sideways, the barge ramp connected with a wooden fencepost at the side of the yard and broke it off and damaged a saltwater wash-down pump at that spot.
Vessel hit rocks. Slight steering damage.  occurred, and the vessel was towed to shore.

Vessel was anchored and the wind shifted the vessel causing it to swing and contact some rocks. The skipper boarded the vessel and manoeuvred the vessel off the rocks. Damage was sustained to the false keel.
Event Location: Arid Cove on Arid Island, East of Great Barrier Island, Hauraki Gulf

Brief Description: While proceeding towards port, the no.2 generator shut down unexpectedly causing the ship to black out and lose propulsion
Event Location: Lyttelton main navigational channel between buoys 5 and 8

Brief Description: Skipper smelt a strong smell of oil and looked around the ship, but could not see anything. They were not able to identity any leaks from or around the ship.
Starboard engine stopped as the mooring block was struck with propeller while manoeuvring in between moored vessels.
Witness observed crew onboard fishing charter drinking alcohol.
Vessel with 15 passengers on board was taking on water, pump use caused the water ingress to stop.
Large wave picked tender up and pushed into a vessel which punctured pontoon on tender. No injuries. Minor damage to the vessels outboard.
Main engine stopped going, skipper checked for issues/problems. After discussions, the vessel was towed back to port.
Passenger was trying to secure the boat with a rope as the swell was coming in and their finger got caught in the rope and de-gloved the top of their right ring finger.
Vessel hit a rock, bending the propeller blades. Two of six passengers on board fell over. No one was harmed, skipper replaced prop on outboard.
Event Location: Sarah Cove, Half Moon Bay, Stewart Island

Brief Description: Damage as the gust of wind pushed vessel against concrete fenders and wooden capping while berthing
The master noticed a small vessel in the channel with no navigation lights on. The master reduced speed quickly to avoid collision causing both the engines to stall.
Vessel engine was stopped while the pilot vessel proceeded to clear other boats from the channel.
Event Location: Rangitoto Channel vicinity 1 to A buoys

Brief Description: Two jetboat passengers injured during racing event, sustaining multiple fractures
Injury to crew member's right leg as they cut themselves with their work utility knife while cutting a piece of rope on the deck.
Event Location: Marine Farming area, Koputauaki Bay, Coromandel

Brief Description: Strained back muscle was caused for a passenger as they bounced off the seat due to wave.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The trip line was a manila rope fixed around a spreader with a reasonable large loop causing a significant trip hazard

Alerts were received from a PLB after a person fell from their jet ski. Passengers were floating in an inflatable that was being towed by the jet ski. Coastguard attended the scene and brought everyone to shore safely.
After A PLB went off, six people were retrieved to the coastguard boat, uninjured but cold.
Event Location: Takou Bay, Near Tapuaetahi, North of Bay of Islands

Brief Description: An injury occurred due to the person slipping while standing on top of the lip of the steps.
Vessel was towing north east of Timaru and the deckhand fell asleep, leading to a near grounding
Starboard double bottom tank was found to have accidentally been left open, which caused a diesel spillage (approx. 100 litres)

The ship’s digital rate of turn indicator was lagging considerably behind the ship’s true rate of turn. Once the ordered rate of turn had been held for a period of time - the  digital rate of turn indicator then showed the correct rate of turn.

Loss of propulsion on port side due to main engine shut down. Starboard propulsion and steering were intact and the ship was under command. Main engine was shortly restarted. The reason for main engine shut down was not determined.

Vessel made light contact with the barge. While slowly manoeuvring to go alongside the barge, the vessels bow moved to starboard and caused the vessels starboard shoulder to graze the barge. No injuries or damage occurred.
Crew member slipped and fell, using their hand to break the fall, this resulted in a minor fracture of a finger.
Passenger injured as they tripped on bulk head divider while the vessel was docked.
Main engine stopped without alarm sounding, it could not be restarted. Tug assistance was required and the vessel was safely was navigated in the channel.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The pilot ladder and accommodation ladder were not secured to the ships side.
Pilot report - Partly resolved - Pilot ladder
Crew injured while cleaning a machine as their hand came into contact with the drive sprocket. This caused lacerations and potential fractures to their hand wrist.
Pallet loaded in the tray fell into vessel's fish hold as lifting eye became dislodged from the main hiab hook.

Movement of vessel and farm cages strained mooring ropes and snapped port aft cleat off vessel. Sufficient other lines held boat safely along cage, additional lines were run due to wind speed and sea state. No injuries occurred.
The motors failed to respond to the steering input as the hydraulic ram wasn't moving due to a pin-sized hole discovered in the hydraulic line.

Sudden loss of transmission oil pressure and forward propulsion. The transmission and main engine lubricants and cooling system were all lower than normal operating levels. The vessel was towed back to wharf.

A massive gust exceeding 100 knots hit the boat, a dolav lid snapped, all four tie downs flew up in the air and hit a crew member on the side. They were knocked unconscious, and skipper arranged to meet a nurse at the shore.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
When kayaking and diving, one of the kayaks broke loose while passengers were diving and drifted away.
Close quarters complaint by master after they tried to reach another vessel on VHF but had no response. They had to throttle back to avoid collision.
Close quarters complaint by master after they tried to reach another vessel on VHF but had no response. They had to throttle back to avoid collision.

Vessel got stuck in shallow weather, during bad weather. The four passengers tried to push the boat out, however, this was too hard for them. The water was too cold for passengers to walk to shore so they used their PLB. A helicopter rescued them.
PLB had been used, and four passengers were rescued after their jet boat grounded in the river.
Event Location: Waimakariri River, upstream from Gorge Bridge

Brief Description: Fatal recreational boating accident.
Crew member injured as the lashing wire was broken suddenly and the lashing block hit their right flank.
Event Location: Berth MP1 at port of Marsden Point

Brief Description: While pulling in tuna line crew member sustained a blue bottle jellyfish sting to their eye.
Vessel had a tow rope fail, two people landed in the water and they were retrieved by the jetboat which was on the land. There were no injuries. The rope was replaced.
Skipper had to modify their passage plan when their chase boat had a stern shaft seal failure. The chase boat started to take on excessive amount of water whilst in Kaiarara Bay.
A complaint was made regarding the skippers actions. The skipper took off at a high seed, resulting in a passenger to become airborne and sustaining a fractured heel upon landing heavily.
Vessel had to alter course a few times to ensure they were not in the way of other vessels during a busy time in the channel.

The side ropes were secured with a natural fibre rope approx. 14mm diameter. The securing ropes were tied with two half hitches at either end, made fast to the deck head and the ladder, such that they bore the full weight of the ladder and pilot.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Ladder side ropes made fast to deck head. No stanchions.
Vessel lost power to port engine. suspect electrical issue. Alternative steering was engaged and vessel returned to the viaduct under one engine. 88 passengers were on-board. No injuries.

Flooding in the bow thruster room was discovered. There was a split in the suction line for the freshwater pump. The valves were immediately isolated to prevent any more water entering the space and the split pipe has subsequently been repaired.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Engine cooling failure. Vessel was returned to servicing agent to check fault.
Damage to stanchions on port side due to hitting a boat.

An angler cast a spinner at the rear of the boat. The spinner hooked into a passenger's chest embedding itself there. The skipper broke off the attachment line and emergency services met them at the berth.
Yacht experienced mechanical issues and required a coastguard rescue vessel to tow it back to port.
Yacht experienced mechanical issues and required a coastguard rescue vessel to tow it back to port.
Main engine remote control was not operational as the main engine governor actuator was out of order due to failure of reduction gear caused by damage of radial bearing.
Injury to worker as a result of falling through the open forward port hold. Emergency services were contacted, and the worker fractured their vertebrae in their back.
A piece of timber was found. Vessel was preparing to take cargo and dropped the wood. No personnel in area at time, No injuries.
Boat punched a wave. The force of the wave pushed the boat backwards before capsizing the boat.
Vessel attempted to punch an inshore wave and pushed backwards and capsized.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The tripping line was below spreader and aft. Chocks were missing on side of first spreader. Ladder appeared varnished.
Vessel ran aground on sand bank and injured party hit their head and suffered a small laceration.  Vessel refloated and continued back to ramp.
Skipper had to quickly lift the chute and manoeuvre  out of the way of a passing vessel. This resulted in a near miss.
Event Location: Takapuna Head, North of Rough Rock

Brief Description: Skipper had to quickly lift the chute and manoeuvre  out of the way of a passing vessel. This resulted in a near miss.
Event Location: Takapuna Head, North of Rough Rock

Brief Description: Vessel noticed another vessel approaching them. They yelled out to try get there attention but they weren't changing course. The skipper reversed and didn't have time to lift the anchor but avoided a collision by a few metres.
Skipper accidentally cut right index finger. Surgery was required to repair the tendon.
Passenger's caught underneath seat when a wave caused vessel to shift abruptly. They reported hearing a popping sound, and were unable to move their leg. Passenger was taken to hospital.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Tripping line was rigged below spreader. Vessel had been called up on this in the previous port, but still presented the same non-compliance for the next port.
The starboard anchor winch brake was not functioning causing the chain to run uncontrollably. Port anchor was used instead.
A customer slipped between boat and boarding ramp as ramp had moved during disembarking. The passenger sprained their left shoulder.

When heading to port, skipper spotted a rock head at the last second and rolled engines to neutral and reverse hard. The momentum was too great and they hit the rock. Minor damages sustained, no injuries.
Complaints were made after many near misses occurred with children jumping into the wharf. The vessel had to move around children who had jumped into the water in restricted zones.

The driver got caught between waves and removed throttle to allow the wave to break, wave broke later than expected flipping the craft. No injuries to crew or operator, motor reinstated and back operation with 20 minutes.
A passenger became injured as they tripped and landed heavily. This resulted in a laceration to their lower leg. An ambulance met the passenger on arrival to berth.

The crew used the hose that had been used to empty the bilge to wash down the deck the oily water from the bilge that remained in the hose was discharged onto the deck of the vessel. An estimate of 5 - 10 litres discharged into the sea.

After a locator beacon was activated, a jetboat and helicopter were sent to the location. Three passengers were rescued, one via helicopter. They had misread the channel and been swept into the upper branches of a fallen tree.
Event Location: Whanganui River, Ohinepane Landing - Matawhero Island

Brief Description: The pilot card lacked some basic information: direction of rotation of propeller, astern power, number of consecutive starts of the main engine. The Master was unable to start the bow thruster for the whole berthing operation.
The pilot ladder lower seven steps were on a slight angle.
The port side prop hit a submerged rock and stalled the engine as the rib was backing off the beach. The motor was re-started, damage occurred resulting in a bent prop and a damaged prop shaft.
Ship crew repainted ships name on bow. This was done by using a suspended platform comprised of hemp rope and wooden plank. Harnessed to hemp rope had an unknown anchor point.
Crew went to position a fender to lessen the impact on the boat, their arm got caught between an upright on the wharf, with the crew member sustaining a fractured wrist.
Eight passengers were transferred to another vessel after a fire broke out on their board.
Sailing boat sheeted in and proceeded to run into the starboard shoulder of the vessel at a low speed.
Event Location: Auckland inner harbour - Off Princess Wharf

Brief Description: Sailing boat sheeted in and proceeded to run into the starboard shoulder of the vessel at a low speed.
Event Location: Auckland inner harbour - Off Princess Wharf

Brief Description: The deck securing lugs used to secure pilot ladder with D shackles, was in a very poor and corroded state.
Total Blackout occurred and the emergency generator started . The emergency drop anchor was used.
Event Location: Lyttelton in Vicinity of Pilot Station

Brief Description: Diver surfaced coughing blood. First aid was provided and emergency services contacted. Returned to port and delivered diver to medical services conscious and alert.
Vessel sounded horn as a yacht was passing closely in front. The yacht changed course however, the vessel still had to move to avoid a collision.
While loading logs with crane 4, bearings and pieces of steel fell from the cranes jib tip sheave onto the wharf.

Cargo hose shifted while hoisting hose. Welding of one of the hinges at the base of the pedestal failed, causing the pedestal to tilt. Vessel experienced a series of swells causing a large roll, which is believed to have strained the pedestal.
A rowing skiff containing eight passengers crashed into another rowing boat which had eight passengers. There were no reported injuries to either crews.
Injury to crew member's right thumb as their thumb got drawn into the winch along with the chain while setting up anchor.
Engine exhaust gas boiler high steam pressure alarm was activated that triggered the main engine safety stop event while underway.
Event Location: Between buoy 7 and 9 of Auckland harbour

Brief Description: A gust of wind pushed the vessel towards moored and unattended yacht. Contact between yacht hull and vessels bow anchor was made before motor could be turned back on and vessel safely reversed and extracted from contact.
A rafter fell out of the raft, colliding with the raft guide in the process. This resulted in superficial injuries to the guide.

A vessel had a collision with another vessel while coming out of berth. The vessel made heavy contact with the starboard aft corner of the outboard protection bar. Minimal damage was seen, only paint markings.

A vessel had a collision with another vessel while coming out of berth. The vessel made heavy contact with the starboard aft corner of the outboard protection bar. Minimal damage was seen, only paint markings.

Just before the boat was committed to the bar a series of short swells past under the boat causing it to touch the bottom. Skipper instantly reversed out and clear of the bar to safer water to turn around and head back to the wharf.

Helmsman leant out of window to check rope attachment to other vessel. A swell caused them to be thrown forward onto the throttles. This resulted in a momentary forward thrust causing impact between vessels. The starboard light broke on one vessel.
Capsized while attempting to punch an inshore wave
The pilot ladder was incorrectly secured to the deck using D-shackles to choke the side ropes.
Electrical fire on departure, the fire was put out and returned to marina. One crew member was taken to hospital due to smoke inhalation.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
A person was trapped beneath the raft for around 20 seconds as the raft capsized. The support vessel lifted the person out of the water.
While selecting ahead, gear control had slipped and momentum resulted in a glancing brush with a vessel. Contact made with aft corner while drifting. No damage to plant property or people.
While selecting ahead, gear control had slipped and momentum resulted in a glancing brush with a vessel. Contact made with aft corner while drifting. No damage to plant property or people.

The vessels ECDIS displayed an incorrect position, the vessel was positioned halfway over the wharf when alongside. The vessels AIS has incorrect vessel dimensions programmed in it, which feeds the pilots portable piloting Unit through the pilot plug
The combination accommodation ladder was not secured to the ship's side.
Two vessels were pushed onto a pile and one vessel became trapped and caught under boarding platform due to high tides.

Vessel altered course to starboard to exit the channel at manoeuvring speed. Another vessel was entering on their port side, resulting in a head on situation. Vessel blasted their horn and the entering vessel moved to avoid a collision.
The rear starboard side wing came into contact with some willow branch. No injuries or damage sustained.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
IRB punched a wave. The force of the wave pushed the IRB backwards before capsizing the IRB.
IRB picking up Bouy in wave zone, IRB punched a wave. The force of the wave pushed the IRB backwards before capsizing the IRB.
The skipper noticed another vessel approaching, they were on auto pilot and hit the boat on the stern starboard quarter. Three passengers fell over board due to the collision.
The skipper noticed another vessel approaching, they were on auto pilot and hit the boat on the stern starboard quarter. Three passengers fell over board due to the collision.
Vessel was being driven downstream when the starboard engine cut. The passengers were unloaded in to the spare boat and completed their trip.
The starboard keel became embedded in the mud with being such a low tide. The coastguard was called in assistance and did many trips transferring small groups to the jetty.
Rescue services rescued people from a small boat which overturned.
Kayak capsize as a result of being reversed into by a vessel. Both kayakers swam to shore, no injuries were sustained.
Event Location: Observation Beach (South), Abel Tasman National Park

Brief Description: Kayak capsize as a result of being reversed into by a vessel. Both kayakers swam to shore, no injuries were sustained.
Event Location: Observation Beach (South), Abel Tasman National Park

Brief Description: Fatal recreational boating accident.
Event Location: Clutha River, 2km upstream of Beaumont Bridge

Brief Description: A jet ski did a sharp turn in front of another jet ski, this resulted in a collision. One jet ski towed the other back to shore. No persons sustained any injuries.
A jet ski did a sharp turn in front of another jet ski, this resulted in a collision. One jet ski towed the other back to shore. No persons sustained any injuries.
A jet boat driver drove through a canoe training area at full speed, narrowly missing the canoes and yelled out abuse to the trainees.
A witness complained after a jet boat was going at a high speed down the river.
Vessel hit rocks causing damage to steering and propulsion. Another vessel assisted them back to wharf.
An EPIRB alert was triggered, and a helicopter was dispatched. A vessel was located wrecked on the rocks and one person was retrieved by the helicopter.
Event Location: North of Mercury Bay, Motukoranga Island

Brief Description: Collision between two rowing boats. Crew on one boat injured after contact with the oar of the other vessel
Mooring linesman injured due to whiplash from mooring line when heaving them for the vessel.
Injury to passenger as they fell out onto the back deck while the vessel stopped to view a pod of dolphins.
A yacht had steering and rigging damage which initiated a pan pan satellite phone call. A vessel which assisted had to a tow in outside survey limits.

Skipper stopped the engine for a minute due to excessive revs. Engine restarted and resumed. Vessel continued on dead slow ahead, with revs racing between slow and half continuously. Once vessel passed a beacon, engine stopped to rectify problem.

The vessel was ordered dead slow ahead. The engine failed to start, and this was repeated approx. 6 times to no avail. The tugs were used to arrest the vessel. Main engines took approximately 5 minutes to work prior to berthing.
Injury to crew member as they fell in water while stepping onto the vessel from the wharf. They caught their leg on a ladder and suffered a serious laceration.

While travelling from Matakana Island  a passenger had a epileptic seizure and fell overboard. Crew were instantly alerted and turned around and retrieved them. The patient was transferred to another boat and taken to hospital.
The towed vessel made contact with the port side outboard of another vessel, causing a crack to the cowling of about 8cm.
Event Location: Boat Ramp Halfmoon Bay Marina Auckland

Brief Description: A fuel leak occurred onboard. East deck crew already cleaning up diesel spill from save-alls using absorbent pads after mopping up with the absorbent pads and retain them in fishmeal sacks to be incinerated. Less than 2 ltrs of diesel went overboard.
Water isolating valve was not re-opened after completion of the maintenance.  Skipper realised during passage from Wellington to Picton.
A contractor fainted after sustaining an elbow injury. They were treated on site then taken to hospital.
The pilot ladder was connected to the platform of the accommodation ladder with shackles. An additional length of the ladder was used to extend it to the frame above the platform.

Barge suddenly started taking on water in the starboard section. The 10ft container broke free of its tie downs and started drifting downwind. The vessel towed the capsized barge to the bay and there was no sign of the container.
Crew member's left foot became jammed underneath the pallet of frozen fish as crane driver lowered the load back down. This resulted in a bruised foot.
Event Location: Talleys Wharf, Maitai Basin, Port Nelson

Brief Description: Skipper noticed oil pressure 2.0 bar lower than normal on starboard main engine. The vessel was stopped and excessive oil was found in the bilge. The skipper shut the engine off and returned on one engine.
The vessel had the pilot ladder secured to underside of the trapdoor platform. The ladder was in good condition and transition through trapdoor was better than most, but was not secured to ship.

The telegraph went to stop but failed to go astern. The engine room was informed. The vessel was lined up for berthing so the decision was made to continue berthing on one shaft. Vessel was berthed safely on the port shaft.
After decompression therapy, a diver experienced symptoms consistent with Type 1 decompression illness.
Sludge spilled as the hose connector of waste management technical service disconnected from centre of hose.
While sludge disposal operation was on going, the sight glass of sludge tanker broke and sludge oil came out on berth.
Pilot Ladder not up to standards - the vessels combination arrangement was non-compliant and un-safe for use. The gangway was tied directly to the pilot ladder and was not secured to the hull.
As the crane driver was lowering an empty FEU, the container fell away from the spreader. The cause appeared to be operator error as the container was not locked on adequately.

Vessel secured a tow line to another vessel to pull it clear off rocks. During this, the vessel on the rocks made brief contact with the starboard outboard engine cowling, causing minor impact damage.
Master informed pilot that bow thruster was inoperative. They suspected that the propeller maybe fouled.

The boat overturned due to storm with a sole occupant on board. They became washed up on a beach, and walked to the nearest address to contact the police. No injuries were sustained and the owner assisted the harbourmaster in clearing the debris.
Ship safety standards were not met. All 4 cranes failed survey, the gangway was not safely rigged. Trip hazard were everywhere across the ship .
While attaching a new anchor wire to the anchor winch, the wire became loose on the drum and caught crew member's finger.
When moving wire across deck with crane, the wire hooked on obstruction and became tight. The wire released from the obstruction and hit crew member in the right ankle
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The third to last rubber step was cracked.

Ammonia released into vessels factory when pipework feeding the plate freezer was accidentally dislodged. The factory was evacuated and the leak was promptly isolated and made safe by the vessel engineering department.
Machinery failure occurred, the air rapture disk was broken causing constant air leaking. This resulted in the main air reservoir tank pressure to drop.
Vessel hit the beacon light with the stabilizer arm and broke the light off its perch. No damage occurred to the vessel or to the pylon, the light was knocked into the water but was retrieved.

During unloading, a stack of bins were being lifted out of the fish room and one of the handles on the bottom bin broke off and they tipped over. The bins got restacked and they carried on unloading. No one sustained injuries.

A fuel oil leak spurt out on the main engine fuel oil main high pressure pipe. The engine was temporarily stopped, but the leak could not be controlled. They then left the main engine running until vessel safely anchored, the leak was repaired easily

Vessel came into contact with berth No.3 during berthing operations. The causes were communication not effective as should have been with Master and officer. This lead to a delayed response to bring the vessel ahead at a time when wind was a factor.

While manoeuvring the crane, a bracket broke causing a small leak of hydraulic oil. A few splashes went into the ocean, but were not visible after a couple of minutes. Crane was placed across deck and leak contained and cleaned up. Hose was replaced
Pilot ladder not up to standards - The vessel had an almost 8 metre climb to the deck, and the ladder was held in place by shackles. Thimble eye end of ladder was not secured.

While the vessel was hauling the bag/cod end on board, the strop that was used broke at the hook and sent the cod end back over the stern ramp until the small haul winch took hold. This nearly hit crewmembers, but no injuries were sustained.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.

Someone had been seen paddling a kayak out at sea. Alerts were then received from a PLB. A local boat operator had gone to the area and located the person who had fallen from their kayak after trying to play a large fish.

Fire alarm sounded, and smoke was coming from the exhaust. The port main engine got shut down. The exhaust was found to have a leak and it would take 2hrs to fix. Vessel carried on slowly to berth, temporary repairs led to starting port engine again
Event Location: Cook Strait, South of Sinclair Head

Brief Description: Pilot ladder was not up to standard. The ladder platform was not secured.

While sailing the auxiliary generator shut down, this led to loss of steering for several minutes. Once restarted, it was discovered that is was a push in fuse that had dislodged. Vessel carried on with their trip.
A jiffy moved and caused a stevedores finger to get pinched against a cage. The finger was broken and they were taken to hospital for treatment.

Pilot ladder was not up to standards. The pilot ladder was shackled to underside of platform. No ladder above the platform, just two ropes shackled to an extension frame above the platform. Master was made aware this is not compliant.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The two magnets securing the ladder's side ropes to the hull came away and the ladder swung outboard. This was due to the magnets not being activated.
A crew member came down with heart attack symptoms. They were evacuated from the vessel by helicopter. Crew member was conscious, they had tingling in fingers, pain in the shoulder and was nauseous.

Crew member was removing the hinge pin on the fish pound door half deck. They were levering the pin in its retaining slot with a pinch bar when a piece of steel fractured from the pin and hit them in the left eye. This required surgical removal.
Crew member was cleaning a fish and it slipped from their hand and landed on their left foot. A spike was lodged in their foot which had to be removed once they returned to port.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The tripping line created a possible trip hazard.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladder was secured with shackles, and a tripping line on bottom of ladder. Also the man ropes were less than 28mm.
The gear box broke shaft so vessel was un able to drive, vessel got a tow.

When readying for departure, crew member was caught between top and bottom sections of telescopic accommodation ladder when stowing for sea, resulting in major crushing injuries to both lower legs. First aid was given, and an ambulance was called.

An unlit 5m runabout was spotted in darkness at close quarters on a collision course, cutting across the vessels starboard bow from an oblique angle. Vessel came to a controlled stop, and avoided the collision.
Event Location: Between Bean Rock and No.18 Buoy

Brief Description: Vessel had a wandering gyro. After swinging off the berth and out bound the gyro wandered to 4 degrees high.
Boat rolled over while entering the bar. One passenger was thrown out from the boat and two were stuck inside the cabin. Everyone managed to make it to shore safely.
Due to wind, vessel drifted down onto another vessel making contact between anchor of D1 and port aft sliding door on the other vessel. Neither vessel had passengers on board at the time.
The oil containment boom came free, this was unsighted by crew and became entangled in the propeller. Vessel berthed and divers removed the plastic boom. No damage or injuries were sustained.
A child running aboard vessel misplacing their footing and fell into the small gap between the ferry and pontoon.
Pilot ladder was not up to standards. The steps at the lower part of the starboard ladder were not horizontal. The ropes passed over what appeared to be a sharp edge at the fish-plate.
A vessel sunk with five people on board. A rescue helicopter from was tasked and safely uplifted the party from the remote area and took them to Milford Sound. There were no injuries.

A vessel dropped long lines close to another vessel. They came back to retrieve the lines, hitting the boat on the bow. The skipper pulled their lines through the other lines, tangling them. They cut the line and took the lure.
Deckhand severed top section of the index finger on their left hand while cutting bait. Crew member went to hospital for treatment.
While lifting the trawl door higher to get to the bottom chain. The door swung onboard and hit crew member unexpectedly. No injuries were sustained.

Vessel was leaving the marina entrance when it was stopped due to hitting the sea floor. There was an uncharted sandbar, and the vessel lost steering. Vessel used their port motor to drift away and restarted the starboard engine.
During the discharge of frozen fish from the fishmeal hold a pallet load of cartons was being lifted. A board fell and hit the hand of the stevedore.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The shackles on the side ropes under the top rung were not fastened on the side rope eyes.

An employee was guiding the crane operator to land the container and during the process their arm was caught in-between the moving container and adjacent steel guide beam. The injured person was taken to hospital for treatment and work was stopped.
When exiting, cabin crew member banged their left knee. Later in the day, pain was felt in their left hip. Crewmember required medical attention, and was declared unfit for duty for three days.
Skipper stopped hauling immediately of the nets coming in as a crewmember had a vape hung around their neck. This was outside their clothing and got caught in the mesh. No injury was sustained.
A fire broke out in the vessels store room while the vessel was at sea. The observer and crew evacuated the factory and the fire was put out. Processing in the factory resumed shortly afterwards.

Maritime radio received a distressed call, after a vessel with one person on board lost steering. A vessel nearby responded and assisted the vessel. The coast guard then took over the assist, bringing the vessel back to berth.
Main mast and boom collapsed while fishing. After investigation, weld failure was found on boom.

The jet boat became beached in shallow water. The river channel was too shallow and the vessel became grounded. There were no injuries or damage. Work colleagues were called in for assistance to shift the boat.
Pilot ladder not up to standards - The ladder was patched up and the ropes were not tight to the steps, they were worn and stretched. Steps are tilting when standing on.

A main engine alarm triggered a slow down, which eventually required stopping of engine to reset system. Tug assistance was requested as vessel speed dropped to 4 knts in a 2.5knt flood tide. Once engine reset, vessel proceeded out without any issues

As the heave was lifted over the ships side, it brushed against the bulwarks as it came over, which caused the heave to tilt slightly and several logs started to slide out. The scene was frozen after the driver lowered the load to clear the logs.

Vessel was steaming towards Elaine Bay and an approaching vessel failed to give way and pass port to port. The vessel kept turning to show the vessel their port light but had to reduce speed and pass the vessel starboard to starboard instead.
Event Location: Waitata Reach, off Waitata Bay, Pelorus Sound

Brief Description: Vessel missed the channel and grounded on the sand bar. The trailer was used to get the vessel from the beach. No damage occurred.
Two people were injured after a boat capsized. Emergency services were called, and ambulance officers treated the two individuals.

Outbound vessel lost engines due to burst hydraulic lube oil line on main engine. Vessel dropped anchor and ordered tugs for assistance. Vessel took 30 minutes to fix the problem and then proceeded on their way.
Crew member slipped on deck and twisted their ankle.
While berthing vessel with pilot and tug, the vessel made slight contact with another vessel which was already berthed at the wharf.
While berthing vessel with pilot and tug, the vessel made slight contact with another vessel which was already berthed at the wharf.
Six people were rescued after their waka was submerged by a wave. The passengers were in the water for approx. 30 minutes and were treated at hospital.
An person who made an overnight trip across Cook Strait in a motorised dinghy had to be rescued after breaking down off the Mana Coast.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Vessel had a non-compliant trap door arrangement with the ladder attached to the underside of the platform and not to ships structure.

Crew member was pulling a pot off the freezer hatch, causing the next pot to unbalance, fall and strike them in the head, resulting in a 10mm cut. First aid was administered by the skipper and the crew member was monitored for the rest of the trip.

Vessel was waiting to go to the fuel dock and didn't pay attention to their position, hitting the side of vessel at berth, causing damage. This was witnessed by the vessel on the fuel dock and they contacted the marina to alert them of the incident.
Event Location: Gulf Harbour Marina, End of O Pier

Brief Description: Vessel was waiting to go to the fuel dock and didn't pay attention to their position, hitting the side of vessel at berth, causing damage. This was witnessed by the vessel on the fuel dock and they contacted the marina to alert them of the incident.
Event Location: Gulf Harbour Marina, End of O Pier

Brief Description: The crew were tidying up on board and the crewmate had the fingers of their right hand caught in the net rope, causing injury to three fingers.

Boat took on some water as the stabilizer arm picked up an abandoned mooring chain and wind tipped the boat on it's side. The next day, a pump was used to pump out the water that got in, vessel was dragged to a sand bar to remove the mooring block.

When rounding East Cape the vessel rolled heavily to an estimated 4 - 5m swell set. Crew members lost their balance and fell against bulkheads/deck in their various locations. Four members had minor bruising, and one had a minor abrasion.
Recreational vessel sunk after operator was unable to pump the bilges.
A pile driving barge started to sink during driving operations. Emergency towing operations commenced to remove the barge however, when almost complete, the barge sunk.
An electrical cable on the main engine starter motor shorted out against the starter motor body causing an electrical fire. The crew responded quickly and a replacement part is ordered.

Rescue vessel was towing a vessel, with 3 passengers. Vessel got stuck on the bar due to slow towing speed. The towed vessel was pulled to shore. Boat occupants along with crew, managed to push the other boat into deeper water, and crossed the bar.

Wind picked up early and the vessel was blown into the shoreline and engine dismounted. Occupants safely disembarked. Tug boat lost propulsion when towing the vessel back to Marina. Rescue vessel then towed both boats back. No damage sustained.

Wind picked up early and the vessel was blown into the shoreline and engine dismounted. Occupants safely disembarked. Tug boat lost propulsion when towing the vessel back to Marina. Rescue vessel then towed both boats back. No damage sustained.

Vessel had motor troubles, so the master put anchor down, the anchor rope got caught in the propeller. The boat turned and a wave tipped the boat. All 3 passengers swam to Mana Island and managed to safely wait till they got help.
Vessel was exceeding 5 knots within 200 metres of shore and 50 metres of other vessels. This resulted in a large wake destabilising other vessels in the vicinity

The master misjudged the tide and made light contact with the bowsprit of a moored yacht on the port side. No damage was sustained to the vessel, however, there was minor damage to the bow of the yacht.

The master misjudged the tide and made light contact with the bowsprit of a moored yacht on the port side. No damage was sustained to the vessel, however, there was minor damage to the bow of the yacht.
Vessel capsized during a race, two other vessels immediately went to check on the three crew. An assisting boat transferred the crew back to shore.

Vessels engine failed and stopped just after starting turn. Engine restarted a few minutes later when steady on no.2 reach. Remainder of passage continued without any further problems with crew monitoring the main engine control system regularly.

A burning smell came from the engine room, once the engine room hatch was open, a small fire on port engine behind starter motor was visible. Crew tried to put out with a rag but couldn't, a fire extinguisher was used to put it out.

Pilot ladder not up to standards. The Pilot ladder was secured on deck, with the ladder between the ship's hull and the platform. The ladder combination has been amended to secure the pilot ladder on deck.
The starter motor on the port engine caught on fire. This was put out with an extinguisher. Four crew were onboard, no one was injured and vessel headed back to port for repairs.

A log on top slipped out of heave while crane operator was lifting heave of logs into Hold#2 of the vessel. The load of logs were wet and slippery and the logs were not evenly flushed up on the back of the truck.

Vessel was in the centre of the channel with a fishing boat on course to cross from the port side. The boat continued on the apparent collision course so five short blasts were sounded. The boat passed close down the starboard side of the tanker.

Vessel was in the centre of the channel with a fishing boat on course to cross from the port side. The boat continued on the apparent collision course so five short blasts were sounded. The boat passed close down the starboard side of the tanker.
Master was coming out of engine room and while climbing up ladder, their foot slipped off rung and they fell onto the metal hatch coaming, landing on their chest and fracturing two ribs.
Crew member shut the toilet door on their own finger. First aid was provided by vessel crew. The crew member was transferred ashore for medical treatment.
Handle on crane 1, by the side window dropped off and fell onto stow. Handle fell off due to it being rusted through. No personnel were near where handle fell at the time.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. There was a loop under the bottom step, and loose steps.
The net got caught around the propeller so crew had to cut it free. The skipper and some crew were hostile about having their net cut and were threatening and intimidating to the other crew.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The pilot ladder was fastened by shackles on side rope only. Also, the vessel was involved in a close quarters situation.

When using the digger, the driver lost momentum and the digger fell to the side. After assessing the situation, crew used the crane to up right the digger so the driver could climb out. The driver had a sore rib cage and was medically checked.
An unmarked rock was hit accidently while cod potting. The situation was assessed and returned to port.
Event Location: Hazelburgh Group, South of Ruapuke Island

Brief Description: Crew person struck the top of their head against the passenger side console grab handle, during routine operations.
Close quarters incident between two vessels.
Close quarters incident between two vessels.
Main Engine stopped while on passage from Nelson to Tauranga. After checking and restarting the vessel was full speed away again. Vessel was clear of land and all other traffic at the time.

Vessel went down waterfall, causing four passengers to fall overboard. One individual sustained a suspected dislocated shoulder. Skipper decided to change route to let the passenger get off and be transported to hospital.
Event Location: Okere Falls, Kaituna river, Tutea falls

Brief Description: Pilot ladder not up to standards. Vessel has a trapdoor type combination, the accommodation ladder was not secured to ships side, Ladder not attached to ships side 1.5m above accommodation ladder platform.
Due to steering control issue, vessel coming into berth made contact with two other vessels, resulting in minor damage.
Bosun fell approximately four metres while descending ship's crane. The impact rendered them unconscious for a period of ten minutes. Ambulance arrived and transported patient to hospital.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The vessel had a trap door ladder and the pilot ladder was not secured to the main deck. The non conformity was only observed once up the ladder.

Engines did not start after refuelling the boat. The batteries had no charge to power the Morse controls. The vessel was tied up, and the ferry service commenced on the back up ferry. Battery was then charged up and Morse controls were tested.
Two kayakers were rescued after strong winds tipped them out. They were treading water for approx.. 30 mins before rescued. No injuries were sustained.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The trapdoor type combination pilot ladder does not meet New Zealand standards.
The master and bridge team were not wearing PPE gear, as per the port company standards.

A main engine fuel line issue, lead to shutting down the starboard engine. Vessel aborted channel exit until engine restarted and restored to bridge control. Once in the open, clear of land, the vessel shut down starboard engine to investigate cause.

Vessel had to carry out an emergency tow due to another vessel having a mechanical failure. Spare parts were brought out by another vessel. After seeing these were operational, the vessel carried on their trip.
Passenger slipped while descending the back stairs from the top deck. The skipper assessed injuries and called the ambulance. Passenger walked off the vessel accompanied by ambulance staff.

Main engine failed to kick ahead when backing to berth. The solenoid valve that controlled No.5 unit start air came loose, that caused engine to not respond. Vessel used tugs and anchor to stop vessels stern movement.
Whilst constructing the framing for timber, stevedore leant against some framing that collapsed. The stevedore fell approx. 5-6 ft and sustained a fractured left wrist.

Two kayakers were swept out to sea in treacherous conditions off the west coast were saved. PLB alerts were received and the coastguard rescued the two kayakers. They were cold, but had no injuries. The kayaks were retrieved.

Pilot ladder not up to standards. It was observed that a combination ladder arrangement with the pilot ladder was secured to the ships railings, and it was not using the designated strong points on deck.

The vessel lost engine when returning to port, the emergency stop button was activated. A crew member noticed smoke coming from the engine room stairwell the source of the fire to be the shaft generator. Fire was extinguished, and engine restarted.

After approx. 30 minutes of de-ballasting, an oil sheen was observed in the water on the vessels port side . De-ballasting was stopped as the sheen appeared to be coming from the vessels overboard discharge.

RCCNZ were in contact with a yacht with 5 passengers on board, that had some water ingress, engine difficulties and an injured crew member. Vessel was making slower progress than predicted but was not in immediate distress.

A cargo handler was lashing containers on the ship. A twist lock fell from approx. 8 metres hitting the worker on their hat, before sliding to the bridge of the nose causing a laceration. Crewmember was taken off shore, and had a loss of memory.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The side ropes were not secured to ships hull 1.5m above platform, they were secured on deck with shackles.
At the start of a race, one vessel on port tack collided with another vessel on starboard tack. One vessel took water and sunk.
Event Location: Waitemata Harbour, Westhaven tower, Westhaven Buoy.

Brief Description: At the start of a race, one vessel on port tack collided with another vessel on starboard tack. One vessel took water and sunk.
Event Location: Waitemata Harbour, Westhaven tower, Westhaven Buoy.

Brief Description: Vessel struck a rock, and started taking a lot of water quickly. A mayday call was made, and the two passengers grabbed a few items and hopped into a dinghy. A rescue helicopter arrived and found them on the beach.

While stacking boxes, a crew member got their jacket caught in the conveyor belt. The jacket pulled around the end of the belt, crushing their hand between the belt and roller. Crew member was transferred to another vessel to get checked ashore.
A vessel sunk, and the two passengers were in the water for approx. 20 mins. Fuel was coming out of the boat. Wellington Maritime Police rescued both people, and one person was seen by the ambulance.

The air compressor was being maintained a technician disconnected the airlines and closed the valves. Another engineer did some troubleshooting and reopened the valves. This sent a shot of compressed air down the line it was disconnected. No injuries

During Fast Rescue Craft (FRC) training, boat was lowered and recovered. About 2m after lowering commenced a hydraulic hose coupling blew. FRC continued to be lowered with brake. FRC was taken around to berth. No fluid went over the side.
Vessel was informed tug was closing with the channel side between beacons. The tug made contact with the vessel
Vessel was informed tug was closing with the channel side between beacons. The tug made contact with the vessel
Aquaculture vessel on its mooring made contact with a recreational yacht which was also on its mooring. Neither vessels had crew on board. Damage sustained to yacht only.
Aquaculture vessel on its mooring made contact with a recreational yacht which was also on its mooring. Neither vessels had crew on board. Damage sustained to yacht only.

Motor wouldn't start after numerous attempts. Skipper determined this was due to two flat batteries. Skipper made a call to the owner and another battery was brought down. Once battery was swapped, skipper started boat and returned to base.
Event Location: Deep Water cove, Bay of Islands

Brief Description: While heading out of the channel, the vessel hit a marker pole on the port side and dented the vessel. The skipper wasn't paying attention and was about a boat length away from the pole, the tide was running up the stern so couldn't turn in time.
When coming in to let go of cargo ship, the tug boat got sucked in under the transom on the port quarter. Damage was caused to funnel and funnel casing.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The tripping line was fitted on the bottom rung.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladder was initially secured with shackles but changed to rope prior to disembarking, man ropes initially incorrectly rigged but rectified prior to disembarking.
Vessel had a delay in testing main engine prior to sailing, the cause was unknown.
Crew member slipped on the wet deck, sustaining lacerations above their left ear.

A block of frozen fish was dislodged when being lifted from the hold. The frozen block fell back into the hold, glancing off a pallet standing on it's edge in the hold, striking the stevedore who was waiting for the lift to clear the hold.
When lowering the roller cover the weighted boom caught a D-shackle and built up some inherent downward pressure. The  boom came free, dropping quickly about 4 metres.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladder had been lashed and shackled around the handrails and not secured to the deck eyes - though secured to the base of 2 vent fittings.

Approximately 3 hours after leaving Lyttelton the meal plant was found to have filled with a large amount of water. The vessel immediately deployed additional bilge pumps to divert water from the area. Once water was removed, the vessel carried on.
Event Location: 12 nm off the coast of Lyttelton

Brief Description: As the vessel pulled up to the wharf, the hand of a crew member became caught between the side of the vessel and the wharf, resulting in a hand fracture.

Pilot ladder not up to standards. The retrieval line was affixed to the aft side and below the spreader of pilot ladder, removed by pilot vessel for transfer. The ladder was greater than 9m. Ship is equipped with a combination ladder, it was not used
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The man ropes had knots or splices on ends or in the length of the rope. The accommodation ladder was not secured to the ships side.

Vessel hit rocks at high tide, as the tide started to retreat they were stuck there. A police launch boat was in the area and picked up the people on the boat. Passengers removed the fuel tanks for the outboard from the boat. No injuries sustained.

Vessel broached off the top of a wave causing the vessel to drop sharply to the port side into the wave trough. The next wave tilted the vessel sharp, a person fell overboard. They were recovered back on board quickly, with minor cuts to their hand.
After entering breakwater main engine did not fire astern, due to fuel pump lubrication issues & subsequent starting air failure. No injuries & no damage were sustained.

The skipper saw on the gps that vessel was too close to shore so they reduced engine rpm and turned hard to starboard to steer away. However, vessel keeled over to port hitting partly submerged rock. Once at wharf, water was removed and repairs made.

Vessel had a partial power loss while departing in strong winds. The vessel drifted towards one bank, hitting a channel marker. The chain wrapped around the propeller shaft, causing the engine to stop. Both anchors were dropped and vessel was towed.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The pilot ladder manropes were substantially less than 28mm.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The pilot ladder bottom ends seized together in a loop and a retrieval line was rigged leading aft.

During the early hours of the morning the vessel grounded in Bluff Harbour. The vessel was moored to a mooring buoy in the harbour. From inspection the mooring appeared to have parted at the mooring block end on the sea bottom.
Vessel damage found on starboard aft due to an unknown cause, no one was on board. Possible vessel collision while on mooring.
Event Location: Swing mooring TAB3, Town Reach, Tauranga

Brief Description: Crew member had a hernia and was treated ashore, and returned to vessel after recovery.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The vessel had a non-compliant trapdoor type pilot ladder, the ladder is attached to the gangway instead of the vessel.
Kayaker capsized, and activated their ERIRB. A local ferry located and retrieved a kayaker who had fallen from their kayak, they did not require any medical assistance.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladder steps were uneven or on an angle.
Deck cadet assisting lashing operations tripped over logs, sustaining a sprained ankle.

Pilot ladder was not up to standards. There were shackles, knots and splices in the ladder ropes. The pilot ladder was well secured to the hull of the vessel by magnets and shackled eyes of the ladder were secured well on deck.
The hydraulic hose split in the jet room spraying the vessel with hydraulic oil, causing the steering and bucket rams to seize.
Passenger fainted and fell onto the rear seat, sustaining a fractured nose and a mild concussion. Skipper placed them in recovery position and waited for ambulance.

Watchkeeper alarmed skipper of a vessel with no navigation lights, approaching the port side, on a collision course. Vessel was stuck between two other vessels, so made a decision to accelerate to avoid collision.
Event Location: Approach to Auckland downtown ferry basin

Brief Description: One vessel drifted to the middle of the river and collided with the second vessel. One oar shaft on stroke side in the second vessel was broken but no one was injured.

A vessel with four people started taking on water. A vessel at the scene helped and took three people on their board. They towed the vessel, the skipper stayed on board to monitor the ingress. Coastguard met them, a pump was used to stop the water.

Vessel was approaching the final position, when the skipper asked for dead slow astern, the engine failed to fire. Tugs were used to arrest headway. The cause of the fault was a loose sensor on the main engine which activated a start interlock.

As jetboat driver performed a spin, the throttle pedal stuck, causing the boat to over rev. Driver turned the boat off and popped the pedal back out. While the boat's engine was turned off it drifted and made contact with the race wall
Deckhand was removed from the vessel by coastguard after they experienced severe abdominal pain.
A vessel passed other vessels at high speed between a distance of approximately 5 meters. Both passed vessels were thrown violently around with loss of steerage for a short time.
Fisherman missing while fishing near the shore of Lake Wakatipu at the Buckler Burn river mouth, just south of the township.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The trapdoor type ladder was not secured directly to the ship’s structure, it was secured to the accommodation ladder.
The vessel's gate seal dislodged, leading to water ingress. All three passengers went overboard as the vessel listed. Another vessel passed by and rescued them.

Prior to arrival skipper noted a turbo issue with the main engine and a tug was ordered. When 5 metres off the wharf, an engine alarm sounded. Engine was shut down and tugs pushed vessel, mooring lines were passed to the vessel to berth safely.
Vessel blew its head gasket.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The tripping line was fitted too low, and the accommodation ladder was not secured to the ships side.
The Coastguard rescued two people after their boat got a flat battery and started drifting on the Clutha River.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladder ropes had shackles, knots and slices throughout them. The trapdoor type combination ladder was not secured to ships side.

During discharging of the vessel, an empty reefer has hooked up on another container and fallen into the water, sinking immediately. Personnel on deck were well out of the area at the time, away from any potential for harm.

The Emergency fire alarm was activated due to a fire in the galley. Smoke came from underneath the bratt pan, a dry powder extinguisher was used. The bratt pan had a tiny crack which allowed oil to access the heating element below causing the smoke.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The trapdoor type pilot ladder did not extend to the height of the railings above the platform.
The skipper fell asleep at the wheel, woke up in the middle of a mussel farm. Another boat was taken down and they spent all day untangling the vessel from the mussel farm.
A kayaker capsized in large waves and became separated from their kayak. Coastguard alerted by a witness and the kayaker was brought to shore.
One person from a kayak and one from an inflatable were rescued after spending five hours in the river.
Event Location: Otiria Falls, Otiria Stream, Near Moerewa

Brief Description: Fatal recreational boating accident.

An electrical failure caused bilge pump and bilge alarm to fail and the engine room became flooded due to too much weight aft of the vessel. Mayday calls were made before the vessel went down, and the two crew were rescued.
The boat flipped back as a roll over occurred at the edge of the break zone. The boat was then flipped back over and dragged/pushed back into the break zone to be washed ashore. No injuries occurred.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The combination type pilot ladders lower platform was less than 5m above the sea.

The vessel's steering toggle loosened in its mount and became unresponsive. The rudder went hard to starboard, with the skipper immediately pulling the vessel out of gear. The vessel was then able to hold position using power before being towed back
Vessel was coming into pilotage area, there were large swells. Communication was clear and concise between the pilot and pilot launch which brought the vessel in .
Due to heavy north easterly swells, pilot was unable to board vessel at Pilot station. Vessel was lead in by pilot launch with pilot on board until buoy #9 where pilot boarded.
Pilot boarding considered too dangerous due to heavy north easterly swell and excessive ship rolling.
Crew member tried to hook the chain to the stopper, but the door swung out and the chain moved, catching their hand. The crew member was taken to hospital to receive medical treatment.
After their waka capsized, five people swam to safety. They had been plunged into frigid water.

Barge slowed down to a stop into the deeper water. Vessel went astern on engines to no avail as the barge had sat down on the bank and waited for incoming tides. Vessel reversed back into channel to await more flood tide.
Passenger's foot caught under gangway while boarding. A cold compress was applied and passenger was checked on after a few minutes and reported feeling fine.
The vessel had unsafe safety lines. The safety stanchions' are mounted from the bottom of the lid height which made them ankle height from where the hatch man stands.

Port outboard motor pod failed resulting in port motor, pod and duckboard submerging. Loss of hydraulic steering. A vessel 100m away and took them under tow back to the wharf, disembarked passengers and put vessel on mooring awaiting haul out.

Vessel was coming to anchor at slow speed. When power was applied to co astern a loud vibration was heard and vessel did not respond by slowing down. Propeller was loose on the shaft. Vessel remained at anchor till  it was towed out the next day.

Vessel departed a berth, with no passengers or vehicles onboard. During transit the loading ramp was inadvertently deployed and entered the water while underway. Loading ramp was lost in approx. 15 metres of water. The vessel returned to main wharf.
Ship defect, X band radar was not working, and a technician was arranged to repair.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Vessel was clear of wharf, main engine set to dead slow ahead, engine slow down alarm activated. In safe water, engine stopped on two occasions to allow fault to be rectified though this was unsuccessful. Tug escorted vessel until  clear of channel.
Starboard engine temperature rose over 220 degrees and smell noticed. Engine stopped and returned safely to port. Initial exam of engine suggests 2 cylinders have nipped up.
Pilot Ladder not up to standards. Ladder fastened by shackles on side ropes

The rope bagger frame on the vessel fell out of its bracket, hitting an employee on the top of their head causing a laceration and concussion. Employee was attended by a clinician at hospital in Blenheim.
When the net came up on deck, the cod end slid over the inner bulwark, and one crew member was caught in the middle. First aid was provided to the crew member.
A petrol generator was in the well of the punt and caught fire. The generator was not in use at the time, there was no naked flame. Fire service attended site to assist extinguish the fire.
Vessel lost propulsion due to a net becoming entangled around the propeller. Another vessel towed them to an anchorage, and the net was removed with the assistance of divers.

Once the master had arrived at Mana Island, they circled their vessel and noticed that the dinghy which was attached to the back was missing. The conditions had been rough across the trip, causing the dinghy to become unattached.

The vessel lost both bow thrusters in high wind conditions due to malfunctions of the bridge controller. While attempting to berth, contact was made with a parked vessel causing minor damage. Vessel then berthed with assistance from a local jetboat.

As the vessel was being manoeuvred a surge pushed the vessel towards the vessel slipway. The starboard propeller hit an underwater rail and the motor immediately cut out. The vessel was safely berthed and equipment removed.
Event Location: Erau Moana Lagoon, Port of Greymouth

Brief Description: After coming down from a large swell the main navigation computer lost power.
Allegation that a crew member was seen smoking cannabis onboard by an MPI observer, later recorded in the logbook by the skipper for follow-up action.

Steering command failed after alarm sounded, gyro repeater indication was lost. Crew discovered steering room flooding. All crew started bailing out water, with water coming from a corroded air pipe. Vessel continued using  emergency steering.

Vessel broke its mooring and drifted southeast, the vessel came to rest on a beach at the western side of the bay. The skipper proceeded to secure the vessel and bring it alongside the wharf. No damage was evident, it appeared the mooring rope frayed
Two people spent an hour in the ocean and were rescued as their tinnie was swamped by a wave.

Vessels Main Engine Stopped and Ships Power Blackout. Engine and power was restored within 5 mins. Vessel remained under steerage control in the main channel. Vessel continued to berth. Master was unsure of the cause.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The pilot ladder and man ropes were secured to the ships railing and not the deck.
Vessel struck something hard under the starboard side hull. Crew checked all compartments for any water ingress. All appeared sound and continued passage.
Pilot ladder was fastened with shackles on side ropes.

Skipper was cutting bait on foredeck and noticed too late that a beacon was in the way. This lead to the vessel colliding with a navigation beacon, which then slowly sank creating a hazard, so a temporary marker was installed after.

Ship had a blackout of all electronics and lighting, when attempting to get bow thruster started for berthing. Main engine was stopped. Steering gear was operational throughout. Everything came online in about 3 minutes. Berthed without bow thruster.
Maritime Radio received a call from a fishing vessel with a sick crew member on board.  Another vessel went and transferred the crew member, who was later assessed by ambulance.
Main engine "High water temp and level Main engine" alarm sounded in wheelhouse. Pitch and RPM reduced to zero and 440. The chief engineer investigated and shut down main engine to effect repairs.
Vessel lost power due to contaminated fuel. The local coastguard towed the vessel to berth.
Maritime Radio received a Mayday call from a vessel on fire in the Tamaki River, Auckland. Responding vessels rescued the five people, the fire was extinguished and the vessel was towed ashore.
A vessel was unturned with three people in the water. A responding vessel, offered assistance and deployed lifejackets. Maritime police came and rescued the three people.

Bilge alarm went off due to water. Pump was put onto manual and deck wash pump to bilge. Water level started to lower after a hose from main motor was used. Where the electric bilge pump sits, its caused electrolysis from inside, causing the hole.

Vessel reported that their fire alarm system on board malfunctioned. The fire alarm panel showed fault and the zone indicator lamp were displaying that they were always on. A technician was organised to investigate fault and repair at the next port.
Vessel ran over another mooring vessel while mooring the vessel. Mooring rope jammed the prop and boat stalled. Damage to rudder noted after vessel was removed from the water.
Skipper contacted regarding a net they cut free.
Vessels batteries went flat and engine would not start while out at sea. Coastguard was called and they went and towed the vessel to shore.
Vessel grounded on a flat shoaling rock shelf. The master put the engine astern, but the vessel still grounded lightly. No damage occurred.
Starboard engine cut dead without warning during the trip. Driver pulled up safely and the passengers were transferred to another vessel.

RCCNZ was notified of a vessel at anchor odd Taiharuru Head with engine problems. RCCNZ stayed in contact with vessel overnight, and operations were in place to facilitate the vessel being brought back alongside shore in a timely manner.

Crew member added too much caustic soda and water to the cooker. This caused a reaction and the solution splashed back resulting in light chemical burns to the skin on their shoulders. The medic on board provided first aid treatment.
Surf lifesavers rescued three people from the water after their jet ski broke down two kilometres offshore.
Vessel made contact with a moving vessel while pulling alongside to perform the medical evacuation of an unwell crew member.
Log wire caught plate on the back of bolster on log trailer and caused it to break.

The evaporator unit had become dislodged and this left the freezer coils exposed. They have a heat trace system and ignited cardboard packaging, resulting in smoke filling the freezer room. Fire crew were deployed
Crewmember lifted a large trap, injuring their right shoulder.
While manoeuvring the forward upper portside section of the vessel, it collided with a non-fendered corner of the ‘barge’ resulting in tear/crease to upper portside hull
Pilot disembarked due to strong wind sea conditions that poses high risk of safety to Pilot
The chief cook sustained a burn injury from boiling water. First aid was applied and a call was made for further medical treatment.
Whilst disembarking the vessel a passenger sustained a suspected broken ankle. Paramedics were in attendance, and passenger was taken to A&E.
When removing old pipe work and re-instating new pipe work a substance fell onto the floor near the worksite. All work was halted until substance was checked and confirmed as asbestos.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
Reports were made after a witness noticed windsurfers were breaching covid and speed regulations
Shotover Jet boat and the private boat were in a 'head on' situation while both in the first gorge as private boat entered the concession area
While travelling upstream, the starboard engine lost power twice, and eventually stopped altogether while idling.

The bow thruster failed when departing. Thruster was bought back online, tested and they continued. The thruster failed again and wasn't able to be bought back online. Vessel was berthed and work began to determine the reason for the thruster failure
A crew member's finger caught between the load and crane hook, sustaining a small fracture.
Three passengers were rescued as their vessel hit a whale.
Main engine slow down outbound cutter channel. Tug was on standby.
Pilot ladder was fastened with shackles on side ropes
Port engine overheated and shutdown. Inspected and found clamp had been left off strainer. The engine was refitted and the temperature dropped. The vessel returned to the marina.
A vessel broke their mooring, heading towards the rocks. The vessel then ran aground.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
Four passengers were rescued from a yacht that had caught fire. Another vessel took them ashore.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessel ran aground in shallow water and jet unit became filled with debris. Skipper went to restart engine and the fuel tank exploded, causing significant burn injuries.
A stevedore was struck by a log wire from a crane. The wire struck their hardhat and knocked the stevedore over. They then were taken to hospital to be assessed.

Two people were on board a vessel when it started to sink. They jumped off into their 7-foot inflatable, and sent a message on their distress beacon. A coastguard vessel and transferred the two passengers to shore. No injuries were sustained.

Master noticed that the port rudder indicator was not following the helm movements. Once vessel was in open waters, the steering was tested in all modes, with engineers in attendance in steering flat. Duty engineers stated everything was working fine

Crew member awoke with headache and no appetite, worked on deck for a short time and complained of severe migraine. Their condition deteriorated, a helicopter was sent and a paramedic took the crew member to hospital.
Event Location: Morningstar in Waitata Bay, Pelorus Sound.

Brief Description: Electrician was carrying out a routine check on a set of batteries, the mains were disconnected. When reconnecting the battery terminal of one battery, it exploded. The exact cause of why the battery exploded is unknown.
While carrying out a training exercise there was an accident where the bow door winch failed, causing minor injuries to a crew member.
An engineer tripped on a power cord, falling on their right shoulder and sustaining a minor injury.
While carrying out lashing the pelican hook slipped and made pierced the crew member's hand.
Crew member was performing a planning turn at the base of Huka Falls when their starboard engine cut out. The failure was caused by a faulty fuel pump.
Vessel went over a shallow shingle shelf. A stone jammed the steering nozzle and they were unable to avoid a collision with a tree/bank.

AN engine failure occurred due to a leak in the fuel line as well as a build up of air in the fuel pump. The fuel line has been replaced and the system has been bleed, the engine started running again fine.
The vessel hit a small log and did not notice it. They only noticed when crew took the boat out of the water.
Event Location: Between Tairua bar and Slipper Island

Brief Description: The driver was unable to make a left turn around the marker on the lake and the boat continued in a straight line to come to rest in the grassed margin of the lake area. No injuries were sustained. Two bolts within the steering had sheered off.

An aftercooler pipe had failed at the flange, spraying water over the aft end of the switch board. The vessel lost power from the shaft alternator. This resulted in the ship  "blacking out" and emergency lighting was used.
Crew member was cleaning the screw feeder machine when their finger became caught in the machine. The tip of the forefinger was severed and the crew member was taken to the doctor.

Vessel had reported that the piston rings of main engine No 3 cylinder had worn out, and a decision was made to overhaul main engine No. 3 cylinder before proceeding on voyage. Vessel anchored to complete the overhaul.
Whilst hauling the sweeps onto the net roller, crew member's hand became caught between the winch and wire. Coastguard arrived and evacuated the crewmember to receive medical attention.

While ambulance were on board treating a crew member for an injury, the skipper noticed that the starboard aft section of the sponson bag was flat. The master determined that it was safe to run the vessel in the conditions.
Event Location: The mouth of the Manawatu River

Brief Description: Vessel's forward crane housing collapsed while under load. No injuries sustained and the scene was frozen immediately.

While the stevedore was coming up on the hook of the crane, the grab chain snapped causing the grab to be hanging by only one chain. The product was released back into the hold and the grab was taken to the wharf to be inspected.
Vessel was entering Gisborne harbour at night and was unaware a logging vessel was exiting the harbour. . The vessel was flagged down by the pilot vessel. This resulted in a near miss.

The vessel hit the sandbar and became stuck. Skipper tried to reverse but was hit by a wave, causing the boat to fill with water and capsize. All four crew had lifejackets on and evacuated the vessel. The boat was retrieved the next day.
Crew member was hit on the jaw by a gantry hook when lifting backbones.

A crane driver lowered the lift down the starboard side coaming about 2m and one of the log wires broke. The heave fell about 6m onto the stow. The broken wire and the other wire were both changed for new ones immediately. No injuries were sustained.
The captain was contacted about a passenger on board with suspected appendicitis.

Skipper complained regarding a near miss incident. The vessel turned towards their vessel and nearly hit them. They had to turn sharply and almost run aground. They yelled at the boat but they shrugged it off and kept going.
Vessel was rounding a point and hit a rock.
Maritime Radio received a distress call from a vessel off the Northland coast which was taking on water and sinking. A vessel responded to mayday calls and picked up all four people from the water.

A series of distress calls were received by Maritime Radio stating that a vessel was on fire. Fire crews responded, but some fire crews were hampered by limited road access and poor weather. Fire was eventually extinguished and no one was hurt.

When approaching the jetty, skipper compensated for a North Westerly wind and took a wide angle. The skipper didn't notice the tug wash and made contact with a tug boat. No passengers were affected and minor damage was seen to the vessel, not the tug
Lightening strike hit the mast above bridge causing issues with fishing monitors and sensors only. All other vessel operations were not affected, and no injuries were sustained.
Pilot ladder not up to standards - the ladder was not secured to deck as per guidelines but spreader was resting on stanchions.
A crew person rolled their right ankle once in the wheel house then outside again when setting the pots.
