The boat lost power and was drifting down stream. The anchor was deployed but the shackle broke so vessel drifted further. Skipper got the vessel to the river bank, and the clients got off. The boat was towed back and the vessel was assessed.
Passenger slipped on bottom stair inside the main cabin while descending. Crew checked on the passenger and no injuries were sustained.

While backing down the inner viaduct to moor at the visitor’s berth, vessel got blown too close to the moored yachts on the Northern side of the inner viaduct and caught their keel on another vessel's ground line (mooring line).

The boat had moved a little from where first anchored. Half the anchor chain was up when the conditions got worse, causing the chain slip on the winch, the hydraulic motor gave out. The anchor was lost.

Yachts were crossing and impeding ship during a race. One yacht sailing close to quarter waved away restricting ability to turn ship. Engine was stopped and steering was lost moving through fleet. Whistle sounded numerous times and no action taken.
Vessel hit a rock on the prop at low speed entering the main channel. The vessel still worked and made it to shore.
Crew member placed their right foot on the forward section of the floorboard. As the bow of the IRB hit the wave, it folded at the junction of the floorboard. This resulted in a fractured leg.
IRBs flipped while partaking in a training exercise. No injuries were sustained.
Alerts were received from a PLB after a jet boat accident. A helicopter was tasked to attend the scene. A passenger sustained injuries.
A crew member was evacuated for medical treatment ashore as they had severe back pain.

Whilst preparing to deploy fishing gear, the main engine unexpectedly shut down. The 'overspeed alarm' triggered the automatic shutdown. The main engine was then restarted and after thorough testing, no further fault was found.
While positioning a 7 m Senator runabout under a barging situation, this vessel came into contact with the end of the ramp pontoon.

Officers were alerted to someone waving a yellow flag on a boat some 250 metres off West Beach, Waitara. The tide was low and the boat was unable to get back in near the Waitara bar. Another boat towed the vessel back, no one was injured.

After vessel completed annual maintenance at the mooring buoy during the early hours of the morning it broke clear of the mooring. It was returned to its position by pilots, no apparent damage and no injuries.
At main deck access to combination ladder there is a wire rope at head height, creating a hazard for disembarking.
Oil pressure dropped on port engine. After investigating crew saw that oil was in the bilge. The vessel came home on starboard engine.
Injury to crew member as their head made contact with the top of the hatch causing a cut on top of their head approx. 2-3 cms.
Vessels barge temporarily left the channel whist inbound to the wharf. This occurred after steering change-over from the wheelhouse to the top console.

The vessel took a while to respond to helm orders. The wheel turned promptly to order, but the rudder angle indicator responded extremely slowly. Two tugs were kept on standby while the vessel set sail back to port. The reason of problem was unclear.
The starboard engine revs went to zero. Pilot communicated to tugs that one engine had been lost, the manoeuvre continued with one engine and the tugs.
Outboard engine cut out due to water in fuel, water sensor in engine fuel filter shut down engine. It restarted and the mechanic replaced the filter once back on shore.
Vessel hit rock wall as the navigation system failed.

The vessel began to yaw stern to port without sufficient power to maintain steerage. The stern was being set towards the bridge pylons, the port side outboard engine struck a submerged object near the bottom of the pylon stalling the engine.
Police advised that a yacht with four people on board had sunk in Tennyson Inlet, Pelorus Sound.  A local vessel responded and rescued the crew from the water.
Pilot slipped from ladder whilst boarding vessel, landing on their back and injuring their left shoulder.
A kayaker was found 15km offshore, after strong winds blew them out to sea while diving near Gisborne. The anchors had failed due to the wind dislodging them.
While passengers were safely disembarked from the vessel, the port propeller picked up a mooring line that had been dislodged from its secured position causing the engine to stall.

Awaiting vessels to depart and clear. Vessel made a turn and sounded a few blasts as astern propulsion engaged. Backed into berth and punt impeded approach to a berth by moving to construction zone despite vessel manoeuvring.
The starboard side outer life raft was deployed due to the heavy wind and big waves. The combination dislodged the life raft.
Electronic controls got stuck in gear while reversing vessel into berth, leaving small scratch in vessel next door. No passengers on board and no major damages occurred.
A diver entered the water between the berthed tugs to do berth fender work. While in the water the adjacent tug's engine was started.

Vessel had no forward or reverse on starboard engine. They re secured the vessel to the dock and still had no response from starboard. Throttles were used to rev engine out of gear in neutral. They re-engaged controls and it worked fine.
The vessel struck rocks hidden at high tide at approx. Two locals in the immediate area came to the rescue and towed the vessel off before the tide receded to safe mooring.

Skipper used the port engine to bring the vessel in, crew took longer than expected to get the bow line on, as a result the bow drifted to the right and skipper countered this by touching ahead on Stbd. - Stbd engine stalled. No damage was found.

The vessel was having an issue with their voyage data recorder, it was showing an alert message that their was an error. It did not affect nor compromise their safety in navigation. Necessary arrangements to rectify the fault in the VDR were made.
The pilot ladder step chock and clamp were missing, causing tilting step.
A compression fracture on the mast was found and the vessel was returned to berth.
Kayaker capsized in a grade 2 rapid, after failing to right their kayak. They hit a submerged rock and their shoulder was injured (dislocated).
A vessel struck a whale and sustained damage to their stern drive and required assistance back to Napier.

The platform structure sat flush against the hull over the pilot ladder (secured on deck). The beam of the platform had to be negotiated around, with hand holds on the pilot ladder transferred through the trapdoor.
Pilot ladder not up to standards - The construction did not meet current SOLAS standards.
Collision with another Boat during racing. The masts got tangled, no contact with the hull was made.

The angle of approach was too shallow and the bow of the vessel got pulled into the stern wake of another vessel. This caused the bow of the vessel to contact the boarding platform. To minimise the impact, the engine was put into neutral the astern.

The angle of approach was too shallow and the bow of the vessel got pulled into the stern wake of another vessel. This caused the bow of the vessel to contact the boarding platform. To minimise the impact, the engine was put into neutral the astern.
Vessels watchkeeper sighted a small tender heading in the same area of the vessel. This was watched closely and the master slowed down after seeing it had passed astern.
Passenger fell down stairs while disembarking. The passenger was initially rendered unconscious, and later reported lower back pain. Medical services were called to assess the passenger.
The vessel went up against rocks and took on water as they were on way back to port. Crew were keeping vessel afloat with pumps.

The vessel was scheduled to drift outside so another vessel to depart. After drifting and proceeding to the wharf, the forward tug was made fast. While assisting and shifting to push the bow of the vessel to berth, the forward tugs line broke.
At the northern entrance of the Queen Charlotte Sound, two vessels were involved in a close quarters situation.
Vessel was pulled to port by the outgoing tide, hitting its port stabiliser on a submerged rock on the Quarantine Island side of the channel.
Event Location: Between Goat Island and Quarantine Island

Brief Description: The ladder was not rigged per the current SOLAS regulations.

Vessel props picked up buoy and line. The buoy rope was removed from vessels port prop but still had rope around Stbd Prop. When vessel was released from buoy rope the vessel was then manoeuvred down and made secure. Crew dived and removed line.

A skipper's finger was crushed under a rope turn on the surge drum after lifting cod end of net aboard in moderate to rough seas. The boat pitched, propelling the skipper toward winch. They reacted by putting their hand out to halt their momentum.
Crew member injured their knee and was transferred off the vessel.

Vessel was on outward bound course and slow ahead when main engine failed, with no clarification of why main engine failed. Control was shifted to local controls and outward course resumed with forward tug attached and aft tug trailing close behind.
The skipper alerted their PLB, after running aground. A local vessel responded and towed the vessel off the shore. No damage was evident.
A person fell overboard and was safely recovered, sustaining only minor bruising.

An Electrical Solenoid controlling the Jack up Barge spud leg ram malfunctioned causing the barge to lean on one corner during pre loading procedures. The problem was found and rectified and barge was re levelled. No damage to barge or equipment.
Vessel failed to start main engine on departure. The ships electrician had somehow disabled it after repairing the bow thruster which had failed on arrival.

When manoeuvring into position for berthing there was a possible control transfer issue. No response port engine. The takeover button was pressed and control recovered. Minor damage to gel coat. No passengers aboard at the time of injuries.
Boat was found high and dry on the sand bar.
A powerboat traveling approximately 20 knots crossed in front of another vessel bow with no navigational lights.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Passengers sustained a back injury after the boat hit a rogue wave and lurched heavily.
Vessel approached a small vessel, the passengers started yelling abuse and then their vessel capsized. All three were retrieved from the water by another passing vessel.
Vessel presented a stretched ladder with the bottom rungs and spreader at approx. 30 degrees to the horizontal.
Vessel capsized and was in the surf still at anchor after being left overnight. The cause was unknown, potentially from a dragged anchor.

Boat lost engine power, and called on radio to a friend in front. They came over and attempted to throw a rope to them, strong incoming tide pushed the bow into their starboard side causing a dent in top side of their boat.
The combination ladder on the starboard side had ladder rungs not horizontal.
When untying from the wharf the stern got blown off the wharf and toward a gravel spit, the engine was in gear and rudder hard over. No damage to the vessel.
Event Location: Ships cove wharf, Queen Charlotte Sound

Brief Description: Vessel struck by wave, causing two passengers to fall overboard. They were quickly recovered from the water, with no injuries sustained.
The spinnaker got caught on a buoy. The spinnaker was cut to release from buoy. No discernible damage to buoy.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Moored vessel untied by unknown people, drifted in the marina until it ran aground, causing minor rudder damage.
Crew member's finger caught in a filleting processing machine. The crewmember was taken to hospital for treatment.

The main engine failed to go astern when berthing. Vessel was stopped using tug and berthed fast alongside No.5 wharf without incident. Master advised that the cause was a start air distribution issue. An engine test was issued before next departure.
The pilot ladder had not been secured by rope or shackles.
The pilot ladder man ropes had seizing's every 50cm which made them unsafe to use.

Skipper was awoken by the smell of smoke and called a crewmember. They went down to vessel were they proceeded to find the source, which was smouldering wood located between deck and exhaust. They doused with water until fire was extinguished.
Boat had overturned and was towed to shore by an assisting vessel which was alerted from a MAYDAY call. Three people were uplifted and transported to the nearby car park without injuries.

Symptoms indicated the skipper had suffered a stroke. They had to be air lifted off the vessel, the other skipper took over and another crew member was brought to the vessel by coastguard. The skipper was taken to hospital to be assessed.
Pilot ladder was secured to gangway not the ship.
Worker was pinned between two trucks while loading cargo, resulting in two broken ribs.
Pilot ladder was secured with shackles with a single step taking the weight of the ladder.
The pilot ladder had loose whipping on ladder, allowing steps to tilt.
A vessel was trying to avoid contact with a jet ski, however, the jet ski and vessel made contact. The collision caused a large hole in the boat, but it did not sink.
Kayakers decided to go for swim and started cramping up, they called for help and a boatie close by called the police. The kayakers were transferred, and taken back to the beach base.
Jetboat fuel surged and engine cut out for a short period of time, then rolled over some debris while drifting in current
A boat capsized and emergency services were called. Two of its four passengers were airlifted to hospital. The boat was recovered a short time later.
Vessel got caught in bad weather, and the engine stalled. Two waves came over stern and they started to sink. The two passengers had life jackets and swam to shore.

Skipper shot away the first net and the cod end took control of the helm in the winch station, and accidently put the vessel astern instead of ahead. This wrapped the net around the vessel prop. Divers were able to remove the netting from the prop.

Vessel started taking on water at the stern of the vessel. After initiated bailing, the motor and stern of the boat were flooded. The crew all evacuated, a nearby vessel picked up the passengers and the boat capsized. The vessel was towed to shore.
Jet ski operator sustained a fractured leg after jet ski flipped during turn.
Vessel landed slightly off parallel during final berth approach with two fender piles aft touching slightly before the rest. The hull plating set super close alongside each of the first two piles.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The manropes were rigged from deck level and not through the top of the stanchion. Incorrect diameter, two thin ropes were lashed together at intervals.
Master recovered two kite surfers which were in difficulty in the water and delivered safely to terminal with their gear.
Event Location: Beam rock light house, Auckland harbour

Brief Description: Two participants fell from a towed inflatable, one landing on top of the other. One sustained an injured shoulder as a result.

Vessel noticed a yacht coming towards them at speed. The vessel didn't have time to move and the yachts anchor and prow hit them and scraped down the port side of the vessel. The vessel raised the anchor and headed back to port, no injuries occurred.

A wet log slipped from the heave when being loaded into the hold and struck the rear of a digger. The log was forced from the heave due to the heave slowly rotating and making contact with the combing of the vessel. The lift was on a slight angle.
The pilot ladder had manropes with knots.

Boat was lifted into water to be used as a safety boat. The boat was taking on water and the outboard submerged. The boat was removed from the water to find the bungs had not been put in. The boat was taken to the mechanic and flushed with no damage.

Vessel had an over rev as the gear was engaged to pull in to the jetty. Skipper pulled the boat to starboard and ended up running the bow straight into the side of the jetty tearing the plastic on the jetty. No injuries or structural damage occurred.
Jetboat driver's hat flew off and struck a passenger. Passenger received a graze to the forehead.

The vessel was struck by two large waves in quick succession. This caused the ship’s skiff to lift out of its rails, despite it being well secured. This caused damage to the stern above water line, bending frames under the skiff ramp.
A passenger being towed behind powerboat received abrasions on their leg from the tow rope after passing over vessel's wake.
Event Location: Finlay Park Adventure Camp, Waikato river

Brief Description: Pilot ladder not up to standards - The rope ladder had a side which was damaged.
Vessel had a loss of gearbox selector control(ahead/neutral/astern) for the starboard transmission.
Pilot ladder not up to standards - The man ropes had knots and splices on the ends and in the length of the rope. A new ladder was replaced and rigged.
Pilot ladder not up to standards -  the ladder had unusually long tails on the ladder with an extra crimp in them.
The pilot ladder was uneven at bottom and appeared to have repairs to side ropes. The tripping line was in the wrong place and the ladder secured by shackles.  A new ladder was rigged for sailing.

A boat entered an active racecourse which had jet skis racing at high speeds. The jet boats had to take evasive action to avoid the vessel. The situation lasted about 20min before the vessel turned around and exited the race course.

The bridge rudder angle indicator was not responding and the readings were inaccurate. Engines were put to stop and tugs in escort were called in for assistance. After a re-check the vessel continued to proceed, likely cause was a mechanical failure.

Main engine shut down twice due to problems with high oil mist concentration. With permission, the anchor was dropped to investigate the main engine. No problems were seen so the vessel proceeded and it was thought to be malfunction of equipment.
Vessel Gyro was defective due to unknown causes, the Cargo hold number 5 forward stanchion ladder was broken during loading in overseas port.
The master reported that the gyro was not working, and one steering pump was operating very slowly which does not meet the SOLAS requirements.
A trawler passed behind another vessel, becoming tangled in their fishing gear. They continued with the gear tangled for about twenty minutes and did not acknowledge they were aware of the situation.
A trawler passed behind another vessel, becoming tangled in their fishing gear. They continued with the gear tangled for about twenty minutes and did not acknowledge they were aware of the situation.
Crew member knocked unconscious after being struck by boom while executing jibe. Crew members contacted police for help ASAP. The crew member was transferred to the police boat and taken to hospital.
Pilot ladder not up to standards - On departure the vessel presented a combination ladder with the platform only approx. 3m above the waterline.
When skipper went to start the port engine the starter engine did not work. They drove back to berth on starboard engine. The mechanic assessed and it needs to be reconditioned (new brushes).
Vessel hit rock, no injuries were sustained. Vessel damaged crash bulkhead with no danger of sinking. Temporary repairs were made to get the vessel back to a better area to receive help.
Vessel exploded when passengers turned on the BBQ, igniting leaked fuel. Passengers uninjured and taken to shore by another vessel. The boat was destroyed with some petrol leaking into the water.
Event Location: Hen and Chicken Islands - Hauraki Gulf

Brief Description: A wave hit the boat smashing the front windscreen and a large amount of water entered the vessel.
Passenger lost their footing and slipped while entering their cabin, sustaining a grazed nose and bruises to their lower shin. First aid was administered.

A crew member was helping guide the line onto the drum and signalled to the winch to be slowed, but the signal was interpreted incorrectly, pulling the line in, causing the crew member holding the line to incur injuries to the face, chest and hands.

A large group of passengers were intoxicated. Skipper gave a safety briefing and stopped many times to reiterate. People threw one member overboard, vessel stopped. After the person swim to shore, the vessel carried on and contacted the police.

When retuning to Picton, two passengers from a charter group jumped overboard. They had been told no, after asking the skipper numerous times. They disobeyed clear instructions and jumped. Both individuals were talked too after vessel safely berthed.
Vessel rescued kayakers following the capsize of their kayak. Vessel managed to return the individuals and the kayak back to shore.

The engine room fire alarm activated when the vessel was returning to berth after completing a swing of the compass. The chief engineer investigated and found steam entering the engine room. The main engine was shut down as soon as vessel anchored.
Person found after missing from their empty dinghy
Kayak capsized after going down a rapid at speed, and passenger hit a rock with their lower right thigh above the knee. They were carried out and transported to hospital by helicopter.

Outbound vessel did not exit the channel as instructed and at the same time the inbound vessel did not maintain its position after weighing anchor. The inbound vessel proceeded towards the main channel resulting in a close quarter situation.

Outbound vessel did not exit the channel as instructed and at the same time the inbound vessel did not maintain its position after weighing anchor. The inbound vessel proceeded towards the main channel resulting in a close quarter situation.
After rowing skull became swamped with water, rowing coach instructed the crew to jump out of the boat and reboard nearby rowing boats.

During berthing of the vessel a missed telegraph movement allowed the vessel to move ahead of it's berthing position. This caused the vessel to stop within 2metres, a close proximity of the vessel ahead.

Without warning or communication one vessel closed the distance between the two vessels to less than 50m. The other vessel took evasive action to avoid any chance of collision by immediately tuning to starboard and reducing their speed.

Without warning or communication one vessel closed the distance between the two vessels to less than 50m. The other vessel took evasive action to avoid any chance of collision by immediately tuning to starboard and reducing their speed.
While performing lashing on cargo hold no. 1, a crewmember lost balance and fell into the water. The crewmember reboarded and reported pain to their right shoulder.
Jet boat collision with kayak. The kayaker was flown to hospital.
Jet boat collision with kayak. The kayaker was flown to hospital.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Combination pilot ladder with trap door was non compliant as per requirements

A yacht with one passenger on board was drifting out to sea with a broken engine and not able to use the sails. RCCNZ tasked helicopter and managed to winch them off the vessel and took them back to safety.
A child fell from the vessel, and their father leapt into the water to recover them. They were both swept away by tide, and rescued by passing vessels. The two were taken to hospital.
While stevedores were loading cargo on deck, the ship's stanchion fell onto the wharf. Ship's staff investigated the area and found the ship's stanchion locking pin was bent. No one was injured.

Alarm was heard then smoke was noticed from the cabin. Motors were shut off, then turned off power at batteries. The auto extinguisher in forward cabin activated putting out the fire. Once safe,  power was on and returned to shore.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. No chocks above and below rubber steps. Certificate for ladder had expired and ladder was over 4 years old.
A vessel entered the lake at 25 km/hr creating a substantial bow wave. Wake rocked the reporter's boat, causing a foot injury to one passenger.
An 8 Person Rowing Skiff became swamped. Occupants disembarked into other vessels and skiff towed back to boat ramp.
Deckhand fell into the water and immediately swam under the wharf and climbed up the ladder. No injuries.
Kayakers fishing line got tangled with a vessel, the line snapped. The kayaker capsized and the vessel assisted in getting them back to shore safely.
Vessel dragged anchor and was washed onto beach.
Two missing boaties were spotted after lighting a fire on the beach as their small boat broke down due to fuel problems.
Event Location: Taranga Island, Hen and Chicken Islands

Brief Description: While conducting man overboard training, vessel lurched and two people lost balance, falling to the vessel deck.

Engine was blown by air and tested on fuel oil while moving ahead - in that time no alarm was raised. The raised ME injection quantity piston then failed. Controls were changed to ECR and engine again started. When re-checked no failure found.
The tug boat was leaving the channel, and changed their course which was then onto the same course as another vessel. The skipper made evasive action to avoid a collision.
The tug boat was leaving the channel, and changed their course which was then onto the same course as another vessel. The skipper made evasive action to avoid a collision.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The ladders had long tails and knots at the end of the man ropes, some of the steps were loose.

The crew were at stations preparing the vessel's ramp for berthing. The safety snap hooks were removed and made ready for lowering the ramp, when lifting and lowering STB chain, it parted causing the STB side of the ramp to drop into the water.
The tripping line was not secured to the bottom on the ladder.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Combination was less than 5m above sea level.  Vessel was turned to reduce sea & ladder raised enough for safe access.
Vessel was located aground on rocks with two passengers on board. Both were rescued by the use of a helicopter and a coastguard vessel.
During training, the driver entered into a wave bow-first resulting in the crewperson taking the force of the impact. Crewperson dislocated their shoulder as a result of impact.
Deckhand dislocated left shoulder attempting to secure the stern line while berthing.
Three people were missing after falling from the raft. All rescued by police helicopter.
Passenger experienced a medical event on board the vessel. A helicopter was called to transfer the patient to the hospital.
Event Location: Te Pukatea Bay,Torrent Bay, Abel Tasman

Brief Description: Two jet skis collided. No body was hurt. One jet ski suffered top deck cracks.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The side ropes were cut and crimped above the bottom step.

While proceeding into harbour, there was an audible alarm on the bridge and engine room indicating that No 1 & 2 steering pumps were overloaded. Berthing was aborted. Hydraulic control valve block on steering gear pump no.2 was the cause.
While canoeing, the canoe had a near miss with another vessel. The other vessel allegedly cut across the bow.
While canoeing, the canoe had a near miss with another vessel. The other vessel allegedly cut across the bow.

A rope was wrapped around the propeller causing a loss in steering. The boast was positioned bow onto the beach, while trying to find a solution to get this off.  Coastguard were contacted for support.

Stevedores observed some metal pieces falling down from jib end area while Cargo operations were in progress. Crane was stopped immediately, while it was investigated. A bearing of one of the luffing wire sheaves on jib end had failed.
Vessel grounded after skipper fell asleep. The vessel was put into astern, and they waited for the tide to rise before they started moving again. No damage occurred.

Vessel dragged mooring in strong winds and ran aground on local beach. No damage to vessel and remained ashore bow first for a period of approximately 10 minutes. Vessel was towed off and removed from the bay by trailer and inspected.

The skipper felt a thud from underneath the vessel. When heading into the bay and the vessel started shuddering quite violently. A diver found damage to the hull and rope wrapped around the prop and rudder which was cut away.
While in a lake with choppy waves a participant fell off vessel awkwardly head first into the water.

Minor incident during the starting of a yacht race where two yachts rigging got entangled. No significant damage or injuries. One yacht retired with suspect rigging damage. Second yacht carried on racing with minor damage to the paint on the boom.
Skipper adjusting harvest gear, crew was told not to turn hydraulics on. Crew turned hydraulics on. On/Off valve was off. Nothing was activated because correct safety procedures had been followed.

Vessel hit a submerged rock and lost drive to the stern leg. The motor was still running. Upon raising the stern leg there was damage to one of the propellers and a mark on the bottom of the stern leg. Vessel was towed back to shore.
Event Location: South East corner Kawhitu (Stanley) Island, Whitianga

Brief Description: After lifting starboard side galley/engine room hatch lots of smoke has poured out. Immediately engine was shut off as well as fuel, fans, and air dampers, and the emergency anchor dropped. Starter motor was the issue and mayday calls were made.
Mayday call was received by RCCNZ. A person had swallowed water after jumping in for a swim, was unconscious with intermittent breathing.
The anchor rode parted due to a worn chain. The chain was retrieved, and no other problems occurred.
Yacht ran into harbour rocks. The yacht was towed off the rocks, and the crew made it back into the Ahuriri harbour under their own power.
All emergency services were on standby as there were reports of leaking carbon monoxide on board. The leak turned out to be nitrogen from a pressure valve. Workers fixed the problem.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. A tripping line was fitted to the bottom of the ladder, or was rigged not in accordance with regulations.

A vessel crashed into a bridge after losing control. The vessel filled up with water and broke. Life jackets were thrown to the rowers and safety boats picked up all the crew. Retrieval of the boat commenced once all rowers were safe.
Event Location: Waikato River at the Mercer Bridge

Brief Description: The fuel pump shaft was wobbling when main engine was running, exerting strain on the shaft bolts causing it to fail. This resulted in main engine fuel pump shaft bushing failure.

Tug was assisting vessel during berth and requested to come in to retrieve tow line. Whilst positioning tug, ship interaction caused the stern of the tug to move under the soft chine of the vessel. Made contact with port deck rail and top of bulwark.
Event Location: Inner Waitemata Harbour - Captain Cook wharf

Brief Description: Two people were rescued after being thrown from a jet ski into near Petone beach. The two people were forced to swim 1.5km to shore. They both had life jackets on.
All three occupants were safe and rescued after their vessel capsized.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

As the cargo net was being lowered into the hold, the plywood sheet within the net caught the rungs of the escape ladder. Once released it dropped free and the net assembly impacted a contractor on the head, knocking them unconscious.

Maritime Radio advised RCCNZ that two people were stuck inside a sea cave. A helicopter and rescue swimmers responded. The two people were successfully retrieved from inside the sea cave and returned to their vessel.

Failure of the shackle moussing wire, caused the shackle pin to loosen and release the mooring line. The vessel was free of mooring and aground. The vessel re floated and moored to alternative mooring buoy.
Event Location: Fly Point, Half Moon Bay, Stewart Island

Brief Description: The pilot ladder bottom two steps were damaged and loose.
Due the swell conditions and size of trawler the pilot disembarked the trawler prior to leaving the harbour.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
A vessel was approached at by another at high speed. Evasive action was taken, and the vessel turned to avoid collision.
A vessel was approached at by another at high speed. Evasive action was taken, and the vessel turned to avoid collision.
A vessel started to converging on another vessel, and crossed the bow with less than 20m to spare. The vessel was required to reduce power and go hard astern to avoid collision.
The spring line of the tug parted and snapped back, striking the right hand of crew member and injuring their thumb.
Crew member injured while pulling in the top of the grab to secure the hook.

Crew member was cleaning the outfeed conveyor to the heading machine. Their hand was drawn into the gap between the conveyor belt and roller and the stationary outfeed conveyor. This resulted in a fractured forearm.
Light contact was made while coming alongside vessel during a bylaw patrol. A gust of wind caused the bow roller to make contact with the bow railing.
Light contact was made while coming alongside vessel during a bylaw patrol. A gust of wind caused the bow roller to make contact with the bow railing.
During routine unman to manned period checks, crew observed that EGCS system PLC had been frozen, sea water pump stopped and funnel damper positions changed to atmosphere without given any alarm
Boat sank at anchor, probable cause is a failed bilge pump.
Pilot ladder not up to standard. The ladder appeared well-used and the chocks and steps were loose.
Crew member fell approximately 2.5m from the bow of boat. They were taken to hospital where surgery was required.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
The boat 'dug in' before popping over the wave. This caused a jolt as the crew member's foot caught in foot strap, causing crew member to sustain a fractured foot.
Vessel struck by a large wave in bad weather, causing a box pallet to slide across the deck, striking a deckhand and fracturing their ankle.

When leaving berth, Chief Engineer called to bridge to ask if engine could be stopped due to an issue with a pipe. Vessel could not be stopped, and proceeded at a slow speed. No conclusion was found from the issue regarding the pipe.

A hatchman was working the vessel, while looking up at a container stack, leaned back against a handrail, which broke through. The handrail was rusted through and had not been maintained to an adequately safe standard. No injuries were sustained.
Extremely bright white light was seen. Officer approached that vessel and skipper stated they were still getting used to their boat and they didn’t think the radar was working very well.
A rescue operation was launched after a boat capsized off the South Taranaki coast and three people were thrown into the water.
Master was relieved of command. Chief Officer took command and indicated indisposition was for the influence of alcohol.

While manoeuvring the hatch, crew member misplaced their foot and fell into the engine room. This lead to them injuring their hip, ribs and back. The ambulance took them to the hospital for treatment.
A large vessel raced at very high speed causing damage to a boat which was tied to the wharf.

On hauling an approximately 60 ton cod end onto the vessel, one of the strops that was used to drag the cod end onto the deck of the vessel snapped, smashing the bridge window facing the stern of the vessel. No injuries occurred.

Vessel struck an unknown submerged object while travelling at approx. 20 knots. After hearing a bang, they slowed down and checked for visual damage and water ingress. Damage was noticed to the strut on the foil between the two hulls.
A large fire aboard a ship at Napier Port forced the evacuation of crew undertaking their 14-day Covid-19 isolation period.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The pilot ladder was  not affixed to ship's side 1.5m above the gangway.
Vessel was going in at 5 knots, 50 to 60 metres from shore and a passenger chose to dive in from vessel and swim to shore, closely monitored by the crew.

A commercial vessel attempted a dangerous overtake manoeuvre on another vessel before clearing the rock wall while exiting Picton marina. Vessel ended up overtaking just past the rock wall, causing a near miss.

A commercial vessel attempted a dangerous overtake manoeuvre on another vessel before clearing the rock wall while exiting Picton marina. Vessel ended up overtaking just past the rock wall, causing a near miss.
Fishing charter passenger collapsed in warm weather. Crew placed them in a shaded spot at the front of the boat and provided them with cold water.
Vessel passed at speed, causing a dangerous wake. Damage was seen to at least two boats tied to their mooring on the river bank.
Vessel hit a boat that was tied to the pontoons. No one was at the boat and they were unaware of and damage caused.
A yacht moored close to a beach at Le Bons Bay sunk. It was unknown what caused the yacht to sink.
Three people aboard a boat were rescued after they got into trouble off the coast of Dunedin
Vessel was fumigated and after 8 hours found leakage of gas from Hold no. 5. Ship crew managed to control the situation by sealing leakage areas.
Witness reported an unattended vessel which was grounded on the beach.
Skipper lost board control in the surf break. When trying to recover their board, a wave pushed the board into their forearm, causing an injury.
Assistance received and safe transfer was done after a vessel was located aground with two passengers on board.
Shore breaking wave caused the vessel to flip. No injuries, the engine was reinstated and working fine.
A report was made after a couple of people were swimming in the river near the boat ramp in Ngaruawahia when a jet boat came too close and too fast to them in a 5 knot zone.
Reports were made after a vessel was engulfed in fire and expected to sink. The cause was unknown and no people were onboard.
Event Location: Moturua Island, Motukiekie, Bay of Island

Brief Description: Crew member leant into a fishing rod and got a hook stuck in their forearm. Skipper stopped the vessel and cut the line that was attached to the hook. They were taken to the medical centre.

A call was received for a vessel with four people on board that lost the use of one engine while in Cook Strait. They briefly struck rocks but became free without sustaining obvious damage, but needed navigation assistance. The vessel was towed in.

The skipper encountered steering failure on the outboard engines as they were reversing. Hydraulic oil leaking from port engine ram fitting, with a split in the hose to the port engine steering ram. Vessel was anchored and then towed back to berth

Skipper failed to notice foul ground ahead approx. 1.3 metres underwater which was marked on the chart. Vessel rode up onto the submerged foul ground and settled slightly nose down. The vessel waited for the tide to rise until it could float off.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Pilot ladder was secured to ships structure independently from lower gangway platform, however the pilot ladder and gangway were not secured to ships side.

The coach boat propelled forward and crashed into two of the rowing skiffs damaging both skiffs. All rowers were unharmed and safety flotation devices were utilised to ensure rowers were safe before two were pulled onto the coach boat.
Event Location: Matapihi rail bridge on the Memorial park

Brief Description: While disembarking a passenger fell between the vessel and pontoon and then into the water. Passenger received minor bruises from this incident.
Skipper's thumb sustained deep laceration after their hand was caught in the boat trailer's winch. The first aid kit was used to clean and bandage the wound.
Jetski passenger suffered a fractured wrist following a heavy impact crossing a boat wake at high speed.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. The tripping line fitted on bottom spreader by means of permanent splice. The tripping line was facing aft.

Skipper left the tiller briefly to grab some sunblock, upon returning, it was too late to prevent a collision with a small moored yacht. The gunnel board was fractured.  No injuries or other people were involved.
Pilot ladder not up to standards. Bottom four rubber steps deteriorated and in poor condition.
Kiteboard operator's kite lines became tangled with fishing lines being flown by drone out to sea, requiring the kite operator to cut their lines free
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessel collided with submerged rock, damaging the bow and bow thruster. Propeller and rudder were undamaged and vessel was able to return to port for repairs.

Engine room reported an issue with the port main engine. Engine shut down as a precaution, and vessel proceeded to its destination on starboard engine. Vessel berthed without incident and port engine repaired.
Event Location: Marlborough Sounds rounding Ruamoko (Heaphy) Tory Channel

Brief Description: Pilot ladder was not compliant with  SOLAS standards, with the pilot ladder and gangway not properly secured to the ship's side.
Jet ski rolled, causing passenger to fall into the water. Passenger assisted from the water by tour guide PWC, with the capsized jet ski towed back to base.
Unruly passenger assaulted crew and caused damage to vessel. Passenger was restrained by crew until vessel arrived at destination, where they were met by police
Commercial fishing vessel collided with moored workboat. Commercial fishing vessel sustained a 20cm gouge to its hull, with no damage to the workboat
Event Location: North Eastern of Moturua Island, Bay of Islands

Brief Description: Commercial fishing vessel collided with moored workboat. Commercial fishing vessel sustained a 20cm gouge to its hull, with no damage to the workboat
Event Location: North Eastern of Moturua Island, Bay of Islands

Brief Description: Jet boat was making a tight turn in a narrow river channel when the rear of the boat made contact with the river bottom, breaking the steering assembly. The vessel then launched off a sand bank and collided with two individuals on a nearby river bank
Jetski operator capsized and was unable to right vessel. Coastguard assisted passenger back to shore and towed jetski

Water taxi preparing to depart wharf was approached from behind by passenger ferry.  Ferry continued to close distance between the vessels, preventing the water taxi from safely departing, before eventually backing away and allowing taxi's departure.

Water taxi preparing to depart wharf was approached from behind by passenger ferry.  Ferry continued to close distance between the vessels, preventing the water taxi from safely departing, before eventually backing away and allowing taxi's departure.

Ferry watchkeepers observed racing yacht approaching. Master placed ferry into neutral as yacht's course changed into a direct bow to bow heading. Yacht advanced at 40-50 knots before altering course at the last moment, narrowly avoiding collision

Ferry watchkeepers observed racing yacht approaching. Master placed ferry into neutral as yacht's course changed into a direct bow to bow heading. Yacht advanced at 40-50 knots before altering course at the last moment, narrowly avoiding collision

Fishing vessel was proceeding eastward on auto pilot with master leaving wheelhouse unattended when it collided with another vessel in the fishing grounds. Both vessels failed to maintain watchkeeping procedures ahead of the collision occurring

Fishing vessel was proceeding eastward on auto pilot with master leaving wheelhouse unattended when it collided with another vessel in the fishing grounds. Both vessels failed to maintain watchkeeping procedures ahead of the collision occurring

Passenger jumped off vessel deck's starboard side, landing in the water approximately 6 metres away from the hull. The passenger then began swimming towards the shoreline and was picked up by a passing boat.

IRB was travelling southward in rough conditions, running parallel to the surf when a large wave struck and capsized the vessel. IRB master and crew were able to right the vessel and manoeuvre it back to shore

Near miss with passenger ferry as both vessels began to simultaneously depart from wharf. With a collision imminent, the skipper became conscious of their proximity and turned hard to port, narrowly avoiding a collision.
Spreader buckled during the unloading of bulk steel. All stevedore staff were located in their safe zones at the time of the incident, with no injuries recorded
Fishing line dislodged and recoiled across the deck of the vessel, with the line's brass lure striking a crew member in the head.

Vessel tied alongside dock and was unloading passengers when it was approached on its port side by a passenger ferry. As the passenger ferry swung into dock, its stern made contact with the bow of the docked vessel.
Passengers on board charter fishing boat, believed to be intoxicated, were disruptive and abusive to occupants of a nearby recreational vessel.
Passengers on board charter fishing boat, believed to be intoxicated, were disruptive and abusive to occupants of a nearby recreational vessel.
Passed too close to harbour pile marking the edge of channel. Rigging became entangled in the pile, snapping the mast
Rescue vessel's hull made contact with the seabed while attempting to tow a grounded yacht.
A lead weight placed on top of a pallet of equipment rolled and fell 2.5 metres after the pallet shifted during loading, landing on the deck of the vessel
During the release of a mussel float, a metal ring on the pulley clamped onto a the skipper's hand and drew it into the pulley, severing the first joint of their thumb.
Crew member's hand became entangled in fishing line and pulled into vessel's power block, severing their middle two finger tips
Crew member slipped on the vessel's factory floor, twisting their ankle. First aid was provided on site before the injured person was transferred ashore for further treatment
Jet boat had a near miss with a dog, which had entered the waterway ahead of the approaching vessel. Jet boat operator slowed and swerved, managing to avoid a collision.
Pilot ladder was not secured to the side of the vessel and not compliant with current SOLAS standards
Rescue helicopter responded to PLB beacon activated after vessel capsized. Both passengers were found sitting on the hull of the upturned vessel and were transported to hospital for treatment

Collision with a rock after the skipper misjudged the vessel's position, with strong tidal flow also a contributing factor. Mayday call was issued as the boat was taking on water. Coastguard responded to tow the vessel and assist in bailing water
Surf lifesaver struck on the back of their head after losing control of their rescue board, sustaining a mild concussion.
Main engine high temperature pump motor failed. Second pump was operational, and vessel was able to proceed to port and have replacement pump fitted
Vessel overloaded with gear was sitting low and began to take on water. The bilge pump then failed, and with the vessel becoming flooded, the skipper beached the boat so water could be bailed out.
Contractor was cutting out an inspection hatch & ignited insulation foam residue. The ship's crew engaged the fire protocols & the source of ignition was quickly extinguished.
Vessel tender collided with marina, causing one passenger to be knocked overboard.
Jetski hit by swell while it was being loaded onto trailer, scraping against rocks around the boat ramp
Vessel's hull made contact with the seabed while travelling in the harbour transit lane.
Serious engine malfunction disabled vessel, which drifted for several hours until responding vessel arrived to assist in towing back to port
Inbound ferry clipped vessel berthed at wharf. Ferry sustained superficial damage, with no apparent damage to the vessel at berth
Inbound ferry clipped vessel berthed at wharf. Ferry sustained superficial damage, with no apparent damage to the vessel at berth
IRB operators misjudged wave during training exercise, resulting in one crewperson becoming airborne and landing badly on their right foot, spraining their ankle.
Near miss between dinghy and a fishing charter vessel - charter vessel passed within an estimated distance of 10 metres at high speed.

Vessel experienced loss of engine power and radioed for towing assistance. After receiving no response, the vessel's GPS location was established and a patrol boat was dispatched to tow the vessel back to port.

Racing yacht damaged during race. No injuries were sustained but the vessel experienced flooding, though was kept afloat through assistance provided by other competitor vessels and coastguard, before being towed back to base
Windsurfer observed struggling in rough conditions rescued by patrol vessel and taken ashore
Two boxes fell from a container vessel during the unloading of cargo at berth.
Vessel exceeding 5 knots on departure, created a sizeable wake which posed a risk to other vessels at berth.

Vessel was struck by a large wave, sending a passenger overboard. While in the water, the vessel spun, catching the passenger's leg in its propeller. Emergency services were contacted, with the passenger airlifted from the scene and hospitalised.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessel on departure under pilotage collided with a channel marker on the western side of the channel.
Tug shuddered during outbound transit, with suspected contact with underwater obstruction.
Crew were altered by the vessel's fire suppression system low battery warning. While having the unit inspected, the system accidentally discharged, expelling fire suppression gas into the atmosphere
Blade of angle grinder jammed while in use, causing it to forcefully recoil. The operator lost control of the grinder and sustained a large gash on their lower leg
Unsecured hatch door closed as crew member was exiting the vessel's aft hold, striking their head
While berthing, a wind gust caused vessel to shift sideways, making contact with the wharf and floating pontoon. No serious damage to the vessel was observed during a subsequent inspection

Engines failed and were unresponsive while exiting marina. Skipper used the emergency bypass system to navigate away from breakwater and was then able to restore normal operation using the wheelhouse helm controls
Passenger dislocated their shoulder after jumping from the side of the vessel into the water.
Yacht collided with vehicle ferry in harbour. Yacht failed to give way as required and did not heed warning sirens issued by the ferry as it approached

Jetski operator lost orientation when coming back into the beach. They came into the wrong area and when they realised their error, proceeded to travel parallel to the shore in the direction of the beach, hitting submerged rocks and damaging the hull
Broken connecting rods caused port engine to fail during trip. Vessel navigated back to base using starboard engine
Crew person's foot caught underneath the vessel's fuel bladder when the vessel was struck by a wave, fracturing the crew member's ankle.
Near miss in marina as charter fishing boat approached recreational vessel on a collision course, with the recreational vessels taking evasive manoeuvres to avoid a collision
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessels collided while engaging in fishing activities. Neither vessel maintained watch keeping at the time of the incident, with both vessels sustaining significant damage
Vessels collided while engaging in fishing activities. Neither vessel maintained watch keeping at the time of the incident, with both vessels sustaining significant damage
Shore lifting wires parted while loading logs onto berthed vessel, with four logs falling onto the wharf. Incident occurred in the safe zone of the wharf, with no individuals harmed
Vessel partially flooded due to a combination of strong winds, tide and other vessel wave wake. Excess water removed manually by occupants, and towed back to boat ramp

Vessel experienced problems with its main engine during departure from harbour. Engine revs restricted, with tug kept in attendance until the engine issues were remedied and the vessel cleared the channel
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Group of kayakers, including several young children, encountered strong winds, blowing them approximately 700m from shore, and causing the kayaks to take on water. Jet boat operator navigated to the group and assisted them ashore
Loss of steering during departure from marina. Vessel secured to the wharf, passengers disembarked and marine mechanic called to repair
Propulsion failure while en route to check cray pots. Coastguard contacted, who towed vessel back to mooring
Jet boat collided with partially submerged log. The log breached the hull under the chine and tore through the hull to the transom, flipping the vessel.
Passenger attempting to board ferry preparing to depart berth climbed on vessel's belting. The passenger's foot then became trapped between the ferry and the wharf, resulting in a crushing injury.
Vessel experienced control failure and powered ahead, colliding with the marina pier and several other vessels at berth, causing substantial damage to the pier and all involved vessels.
Vessel experienced control failure and powered ahead, colliding with the marina pier and several other vessels at berth, causing substantial damage to the pier and all involved vessels.
Vessel experienced control failure and powered ahead, colliding with the marina pier and several other vessels at berth, causing substantial damage to the pier and all involved vessels.
Collision with channel marker. Vessel had turned off roof mounted lights, with channel marker also unlit. Vessel was gouged on starboard side, with occupants sustaining minor bruising.
Vessel at anchor involved in collision with yacht. The involved yacht was operating on autopilot at the time of the incident, with the master below deck.
Vessel at anchor involved in collision with yacht. The involved yacht was operating on autopilot at the time of the incident, with the master below deck.
Charter vessel grounded on submerged rocks, damaging the propeller and drive shaft.
Pilot vessel in near miss with recreational launch. Launch did not respond to the sounding of pilot vessel's horn or alter course, and pilot vessel reduced speed to avoid contact.
Pilot vessel in near miss with recreational launch. Launch did not respond to the sounding of pilot vessel's horn or alter course, and pilot vessel reduced speed to avoid contact.

Close contact with launch, which travelled at high speed between reporter’s vessel and another small fishing boat at anchor. The wake wave caused the reporter to lose balance and fall, and flooded the fishing boat at anchor.
Vessel experienced issues with starting air capacity on departure from berth. Issue was resolved and vessel departed on schedule.
Deck hand sustained cut to hand while gutting fish.
Loss of steering while exiting harbour. Vessel safely returned and berthed by skipper and crew. Cause determined to be a blockage in the contacts that control the hydraulic steering.

Magnet holding portside combination gangway failed during pilot disembarkation. It failed for a second time after being reattached. It was swapped with a pilot ladder magnet, which then also failed during pilot’s descent
Passenger's hand caught between the dock line and hand rail, resulting in a bruised finger

A passenger being towed on a sea biscuit became entangled in a tow rope and was pulled into the water. The boat skipper then reversed the vessel, at which point the propeller struck the passenger in the water, causing lacerations to their legs.

Centre engine shut down by vessel master following the sounding of a warning alarm and the detection of smoke inside the engine room. An examination of the engine revealed holes in the sides of the engine block.
Vessel's hull hit the seabed in shallow water adjacent to the wharf. Skipper manoeuvred the vessel into deeper water, pulled alongside the wharf without the use of lines, and disembarked passengers

Amid heavy congestion in Waitemata harbour between inbound and outbound vessels, passenger ferry made a turn to port without communicating their movements to vessels in the vicinity, resulting in a near miss with an outbound vessel.

Amid heavy congestion in Waitemata harbour between inbound and outbound vessels, passenger ferry made a turn to port without communicating their movements to vessels in the vicinity, resulting in a near miss with an outbound vessel.
Main engine failed while berthing. Engine restarted after approximately one minute, and berthing completed with assistance from tug vessels.
Vessel sunk 2 nautical miles offshore with four passengers on board. Emergency distress call was made, with a responding rescue helicopter successfully winching aboard all passengers.
Vessel driving dangerously overtook sailing boat at close proximity and at high speed, almost causing an accident
Sternline became entangled in propeller and pulled on a crewperson's arm as it became taut, causing minor ligament damage.
Port engine failed during commercial trip
While responding to a fire aboard a construction barge, rescue vessel impacted bow of barge, resulting in a dent to the bow and scratches along port hull.
Yacht grounded on a sandbar in harbour and remained aground for approximately 40 minutes until assisted by Coastguard.

Small recreational boat with two passengers on board sunk after capsizing in heavy swell. Passengers were able to make an emergency phone call, and were rescued by a recreational boater responding police had asked to assist.

Pilot ladder was shackled to the underneath of the accommodation ladder platform with a separate length of ladder used to extend the ladder to a frame 2m high above the platform. The ladder did not reach the main deck.
Collision between sailing yachts in marina, with both yachts sustaining hull damage above the waterline
Starboard engine overheated, producing smoke and igniting a small fire. The fire was extinguished within thirty seconds and the vessel withdrawn from service
The pilot ladder was being hung from the main deck by a single rope.
Vessel struck a submerged rock during harbour transit, sustaining damage to its starboard propeller

While manoeuvring into the berth at Picton Harbour, vessel's rudders became unresponsive. The second officer was able to re-establish steering control at the centre console and manoeuvre the vessel safely into position.
Door that was not properly secured closed on hand of crew member, injuring their finger

Vessel experienced propulsion failure upon departure from berth.  Chief engineer reported the cause as an electrical failure of the vessel’s control system. System was fully functional following retesting, with no further incidents.

Vessel drifted in river current after experiencing engine failure, grounding on flat rocks six inches under the surface of the water. Vessel was refloated after dam operators added more flow to the river and engine restarted
Vessel operating at night at high speed, without navigational equipment and in low visibility, collided with land mass, seriously injuring both vessel occupants.
Event Location: Take in Bay, near Portage, Kenepuru Sound

Brief Description: Vessel on autopilot lost heading and collided with the side of the fjord, cracking the bulkhead and flooding the vessel. Skipper beached the vessel and pumped excess water out
While stowing fishing gear, crew member's hand was caught between vessel's stern and fishing net wires, resulting in minor bruising to their fingers.

Minor injury sustained aboard race marshalling boat. In the course of intercepting a launch approaching the course boundary, a hard turn to starboard resulted in a crew member losing balance and overextend their arm trying to hold onto the vessel.

Vessel being towed to marina was noted to be low in the water and with pump running continuously. Inspection detected substantial water ingress, overwhelming the water pump. Tow line was cut and vessel proceeded to sink within half an hour
Explosion of air compressor due to an ill-fitted oil filter, resulting in superficial burns to the vessel master

While at berth, vessel was caught in wake from a passing commercial fishing vessel. The wake pitched the port side of the vessel against the wharf, shattering the safety glass of the port side front windscreen.
Vessel experienced a loss of control inside marina while attempting to berth and collided with passenger ferry, resulting in minor damage to the ferry's upper belting
Vessel experienced a loss of control inside marina while attempting to berth and collided with passenger ferry, resulting in minor damage to the ferry's upper belting

A heat cover became dislodged and came into contact with the exhaust stack for main engine. It then began to smoulder and ignited. Crew removed the burning heat cover onto deck and extinguished the fire.

Workboat’s anchor wire caught while replacing navigational beacon, with tension on the wire pulling vessel’s bow and causing it to list and be pulled through the water. Crew were able to release the bridle shackle, after which the vessel stabilised.
Empty cases placed on a steel tray shifted as vessel slewed toward wharf, sliding from the tray and landing on the deck and wharf

While aboard a barge and removing a series of aquaculture posts, unexpected movement of the vessel caused a post to fall and land on the hand of a crew member, resulting in an injury to one of their fingers.

Recreational catamaran failed to give way to power boat, resulting in a near miss. Power boat came to a stop to avoid collision and attempted to establish radio contact with catamaran to advise as to collision regulations
Recreational vessel ventured into yacht racing course area and had a near miss with a race marshal vessel that had approached in an effort to halt its advance into the race course.
Recreational vessel ventured into yacht racing course area and had a near miss with a race marshal vessel that had approached in an effort to halt its advance into the race course.
Passenger ferry departing marina at night and with low visibility experienced a near miss with small recreational boat, passing at speed within 10m of the ferry’s starboard side.

Following an altercation between the skipper of a passenger ferry and a jetski operator, the individual on the jetski approached the ferry at speed, spraying the ferry and its passengers with water and causing partial flooding of vessel decks.

During a pilot transfer to a large fishing vessel, pilot vessel sustained minor hull damage, with water ingress via a small perforation. The vessel was docked and repairs undertaken before being relaunched later the same day.
Stevedore fell from height while working aboard container vessel, sustaining serious injuries

Recreational vessel responded to another boat that was drifting, having experienced engine failure and lost its anchor. In the process of affixing a tow rope, the two vessels made contact, resulting in damage to the engine of the responding vessel.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessel hull hit submerged rock, imperceptible from the surface
Vessel collided with a submerged vehicle that had been driven into the waterway the previous day. Area had been marked with dive floats but no VHF navigational warnings were issued

Fishing vessel approaching wharf requested another berthed vessel reposition to allow access for unloading. Vessel at berth then moved forward before crew on board could secure mooring line, resulting in a collision and minor damage to both vessels.

Fishing vessel approaching wharf requested another berthed vessel reposition to allow access for unloading. Vessel at berth then moved forward before crew on board could secure mooring line, resulting in a collision and minor damage to both vessels.

Vessel grounded after water ingress from holes in the ship’s hull. After vessel’s bilge pumps failed, ship crew grounded the vessel on a nearby beach. The holes in the hull were subsequently patched and the vessel towed for repairs
Event Location: Big Bay, North end of Fiordland

Brief Description: Rescue vessel made inadvertent contact with a vessel at anchor while rendering assistance, resulting in minor damage to the stern of the anchored boat.
Free diver became separated from dive boat. Search and rescue effort was undertaken, with diver located unharmed the following day

Steering gear failed en route to destination. After multiple attempts to restart steering, vessel was anchored until repairs could be conducted the following day. Following repairs, the vessel continued on voyage without further incident
Bilge alarm sounded, with water found to be entering the engine room. Engine was turned off and sea cock closed, vessel returned on one engine. Oil cooler tail found to be corroded.
While performing deck replacement operations, crew member sustained a laceration above their right knee after dropping an angle grinder

During pre-departure engine testing, propulsion was applied by the vessel for a longer duration than normal, resulting in loading of the stern lines. A stern line parted and rebounded towards the vessel.

Jet boat travelling at speed around left hand turn impacted with rock on the river bank before colliding head-on with a rockface further along the river bank.  Vessel driver and single passenger injured and transported to hospital for treatment
Two vessels each carrying an individual passenger got caught in a whitewash, both being pushed and subsequently rolling. Both crewmembers rolled under the vessels but no injuries were sustained.
Vessel experienced engine failure during arrival at berth.
Passenger's hand slipped off handle and lost their balance, the opposite handle catching their forehead as they fell, resulting in a laceration above their right eye.

A passenger missed a step while descending vessel's upper deck stairs, falling and sustaining a head injury. Passenger was attended to by first aid trained crew and a nurse who was also a passenger on the day.

Master of the vessel was intoxicated and had trouble manoeuvring the vessel, when returning to harbour the vessel struck the berth and a chase boat. A passenger then fell overboard whilst coming into berth.
A vessel was seen exhibiting dangerous behaviour, including excessive speed and close contact with other vessels.
The pin broke on the vessel's crane, resulting in the attached cargo falling inside the cargo hold. Crane's sheaves and wire damaged in the incident, with loading operations stopped immediately.
Skipper shut down engine after feeling vibrations through the vessel and witnessing smoke emanating from the engine room. Smoke vented from the engine room and vessel towed to nearby wharf

Offending vessel approached and did not slow or alter course. When close, offending vessel moved slightly to starboard, placing the vessels on a collision course. First vessel turned to starboard for clearance and other vessel slowed, turning to port
Crew were caught off guard by strong winds while attempting to berth, with the vessel drifting toward, and making contact with, another vessel at berth
Crew were caught off guard by strong winds while attempting to berth, with the vessel drifting toward, and making contact with, another vessel at berth

Vessel's throttle jammed while trolling 20-30 metres from the shoreline, running into shallow water before launching into a bank, with two passengers onboard sustaining concussion, cuts and impact injuries.
Collision between two racing boats, resulting in injuries to two individuals involved in the incident
Dredge pipe separated during dredge operations
Vessel glanced off a semi-submerged object, causing the vessel to veer into a bridge pile. Both passengers collided with the boat windscreen, causing lacerations requiring medical attention.

Vessel lost steering due to a servo motor failure. Vessels speed was reduced and steering was switched to non-follow up mode, which resolved the issue. Vessel proceeded up the channel at reduced speed as a precaution

Vessel experienced port engine failure after mooring of container ship. Due to the loss of power, the tug veered and made contact with the stern of the berthed vessel, resulting in minor cosmetic damage to the tug

Vessel experienced port engine failure after mooring of container ship. Due to the loss of power, the tug veered and made contact with the stern of the berthed vessel, resulting in minor cosmetic damage to the tug
While completing a turn to starboard the clamp to the engine bracket on the outboard motor sheared and motor fell into the ocean.
Two vessels had a near miss incident. Vessels were on a collision course before passing port to port within approximately one metre of one another. No contact was made.
Two vessels had a near miss incident. Vessels were on a collision course before passing port to port within approximately one metre of one another. No contact was made.

During departure from inner harbour, engine was increased from slow to half speed. Main engine alarm then sounded but revs were maintained until the vessel was in safe waters, with tugs organised to escort vessel past port limits.
Two jet boats collided in a T-bone type crash, resulting in injuries to passengers of both vessels. Two seriously injured passengers were flown to hospital for treatment.

Vessel alarms sounded to indicate water was being pumped out. Vessel had flooded, and with bilge pumps overloaded, the skipper proceeded back to shore, grounding vessel on boat ramp to avoid risk of sinking

Gear selector cable on port engine snapped while approaching berth. With vessel stuck in gear, port engine was shut down and vessel slowed with starboard engine. Vessel made minor contact with other vessels at berth, with no damage sustained
Coming into the berth behind another vessel, skipper accidently leant on the throttle, which thrust the vessel forward and into a collision with the vessel in front

Forestay base plate snapped unexpectedly, with the mast falling to leeward, clear of all crew. Mast and boom retrieved aboard. Crew transferred to safety boat, and vessel motored back to base for repair.
Event Location: North West of Pareanui beach, Northland

Brief Description: Vessel was returning down river at speed when a fuse to the power train unit failed and power to engine was cut. The vessel crashed and driver was knocked unconscious. One passenger received facial fractures, other passengers suffered minor injuries.

Concerns were made regarding the standards of the pilot ladder. Ladder was not sufficiently tightened in place so steps were easily twisted. Additionally, the combination ladder was too low which could have impeded the pilot boat.

Inbound bulk carrier sighted fishing boat in the middle of channel and on a collision course. Skipper sounded series of horn blasts with no response from the fishing boat. Bulk carrier moved out of channel, fishing vessel passed at distance of 25m

Inbound bulk carrier sighted fishing boat in the middle of channel and on a collision course. Skipper sounded series of horn blasts with no response from the fishing boat. Bulk carrier moved out of channel, fishing vessel passed at distance of 25m
Crew member emptied a pot of hot cooking oil out on the deck into the wind. This caused the oil to blow back on them, burning their right arm.
Gearbox failure occurred. A call was made to another vessel owner who in turn came out to tow the vessel back. Coast vessel assisted in berthing the vessel.

As passenger stepped through the door, wind or the motion of the vessel caused the door to close on their foot, with the passenger sustaining lacerations to their ankle. Vessel proceeded back to port for the passenger to receive treatment.
Crew member was hauling pot on board when it swung and hit them in the right hand side of their chest.
Vessel hit by a 1.5m wave during bar crossing. One of the passengers lost their grip on railing as the wave struck, falling to the floor of the boat and injuring their shoulder and hip.

Vessel struck by series of waves in rough conditions. Passenger was thrown forward, hitting their head on the front step and rendering them unconscious. Vessel proceeded to shore, with the passenger treated by attending paramedics
Vessel lost main engine while transiting out of port. Engine power restored via emergency local controls.

Near miss with dinghy, which failed to register on radar and with visibility poor due to rough weather. Vessel was doing engine instrument scan and looked up to see dinghy 60-70m ahead, altered to STB, passing safely but within 50 metres.
Recreational vessel capsized after taking water on over the bow whilst crossing bar. Four persons on board – all wearing life jackets and recovered by other recreational boats in vicinity

A crew member on board suffered an arm injury after being struck by a cable. The injured person required a winch uplift and to be taken to hospital. Vessel was unable to do this at night so a helicopter met them at a set location at daybreak.
Deckhand sustained a broken leg after being struck by a float that was caught on the outside of the trawl deck when shooting the trawl gear.

Recreational vessel lost power after being struck by lightning in rough weather. Skipper contacted police, who arranged a nearby fishing vessel to assist. Upon its arrival, the recreational vessel had regained power and was escorted back to port
A vessel had a mooring line fouled in its starboard propeller shaft. Divers attended and removed the line.
The vessel's main engine shut down due to failed high pressure injection fuel pipe. After replacing the pipe the vessel was restored to full operation
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
Crew member fell through the corroded hatch cover of centre walkway ladder, sustaining bruising and a sprained ankle

Controls did not engage when master attempted to shift vessel into reverse gear on approach to wharf. Vessel, in neutral and at a speed of approximately 1/2 a knot, made contact with the wharf, causing minor damage to the bow of the vessel.

During passenger boarding of a recreational vessel, nearby ferry’s bow thruster was engaged, creating a wash that caused the recreational vessel to be pushed onto the ramp, damaging its outboard motor and causing occupants to lose balance
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Jet boat right hand spin caused passenger to shift violently inside the vessel, banging their head and sustaining a cut to their eye.
Unsafe behaviour observed from individual operating a jet ski. Jet ski narrowly avoided collisions with multiple vessels while operating vessel at high speed and in reckless manner
Sailing yacht hit a rock while departing an anchorage under motor, with speed estimated at between 3-5 kts. Skipper backed off to clear water, with no significant damage detected upon inspection
Two jet skis operating at high speed lost sight of one another, leading to a collision and a serious injury to one of the vessel operators.
Load of 7.7 metre logs being lowered into cargo hold by mobile harbour crane collided with the side of a digger operating inside the hold
During vessel maintenance, worker dropped a hand tool. The tool fell approximately three metres into the vessel's freezer hold, narrowly avoiding workers present in the hold unloading product.
While shifting ladder in the vessel's cargo hold, the ladder swung, crushing bosun's fingers between the ladder and fixed stanchion.
Crew member tripped and fell while performing pre-departure checks on the vessel, landing heavily on the deck. MRI scans revealed no major injuries with crewperson subsequently returning to duty

Crew member tripped and landed heavily on their left knee on the edge of the step leading from the working area to the main deck. After their knee was bandaged the injured party was taken to Nelson hospital for surgery
Boat grounded on sandbank while negotiating a channel. The impact of the grounding was minimal, but sufficient to cause one crew member to slip and fall, sustaining a small cut to their head.

Aquaculture vessel minor collision with jet ski. Fisherman on board jet ski was fishing within 5m of aquaculture vessel, with contact between vessels occurring as the aquaculture vessel was manoeuvring from a mussel line
Vessel crossed bar with multiple people sitting on the bow, and with the vessel traveling more than 5 knots.
Rowing boat struck by quad rowing skiff, piercing its hull and shearing off part of the boat's front section. Quad crew departed the scene and the rowing boat was towed to shore
Rail operator was coupling rail wagons to the starboard rake of wagons on board the ferry when their leg was caught between the two rail wagons, injuring their calf.
Grounding on island following navigational error. Deckhand on watch was not trained in proper use of navigational aids and failed to record island’s location
Vessel lost propulsion after running out of fuel. Nearby vessels contacted to provide tow to port
Fatal recreational boating accident.
In low light, vessel misjudged their approach and collided with the harbour entrance wall, causing minor damage to the vessel.
Passenger slipped on deck, spraining their knee.
Passenger tripped and fell while disembarking. They sustained a cut above their eye and bruising to their leg, with first aid administered on the scene.
Walkway gave way underneath a lasher unlashing cargo. The lasher suffered a minor twisted ankle.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.

Strong winds forced vessel free of the pontoon it was moored alongside. Crew were able to secure the vessel before it could damage any other vessels moored nearby and with its engine inoperable, arranged for a tug to shift the vessel back to berth
Main engine stopped when lifting off berth. Chief engineer determined that the issue was a stuck exhaust valve. After being reset, vessel resumed its departure with no further issues.
Crew were walking the vessel along a mussel line when a float pin broke, causing a mussel float to strike a deckhand in the left forearm, resulting in a minor laceration.
Passenger on board ferry experienced a medical event. Passenger was treated by emergency services, who attended the scene to render assistance
Operational concerns raised against fishing vessel, including operating outside of its operational limits, discarding rubbish at sea and leaving bridge unattended while not at anchor
Vessel struck submerged concrete pile, approximately 10cm below the surface of the water. Vessel was placed in dry dock and inspected, revealing damage to the port side hull

Collision with submerged and abandoned launch, puncturing the vessel's hull and leading to flooding of the engine room. Coastguard responded and were able to pump excess water from the vessel and assist it back to port
Fire alarm sounded from a manual call point in the engine room. Engineers inspected the cause of the alarm and determined that the call point was faulty
