Water sprayed on electronic engine components, after which the main engine failed to start. Another vessel in the operator's fleet was contacted and towed vessel back to port

Vessel's coolant tank over pressured and overfilled. In the course of draining excess fluid from the tank, vessel's engineer ingested a small quantity of coolant fluid. The IP reported to hospital and was discharged after a period of observation
Crew member working in engine room collapsed and lost consciousness for approximately ten seconds.

Charter vessel departed jetty on trip after a passenger failed to arrive by the scheduled time of departure. Approximately 400m from jetty, passenger approached at high speed on a small motorboat and forced entry onto vessel via locked boarding door
After the pilot ascended the combination ladder they discovered that there was only one magnet fastening one side rope of the vertical ladder section and the magnet was not properly secured.
Dinghy caught by a change in swell and wave height. Vessel took on water until it foundered and passengers had to abandon the vessel.
Engine went into limp mode. Skipper manoeuvred to a nearby beach and transferred passengers to back up vessel
Passenger suffered a medical episode on board vessel. Crew provided assistance to the injured party before medivac arrival and passenger transfer to hospital

During bar crossing, a large wave over bow of the vessel destroyed forward facing windows. Emergency services were advised and a pilot rescue board attended the scene to pilot vessel back into harbour

While descending a set of stairs, a passenger slipped, hitting their head and rendering them momentarily unconscious. Crew attended but did not report incident to Master.  Incident was reported by victim 3 months later.

Vessel experienced a dynamic position run off event. The vessel recovered and manoeuvred away from other ships in its immediate vicinity. Following extensive testing of its systems, the vessel was restored to full operational capability
Fishing line wrapped around propeller,  resulting in temporary interruption to propulsion.
Crew member fell down an internal staircase and sustained grazes and bruising. After resting, they continued to feel unwell and transferred to hospital for treatment.
Crew member's arm crushed between wharf and vessel when attempting to grasp mooring line.

While attempting to effect a rescue of operator of a wind foiler with a broken boom and board, pleasure craft passed at high speed within 30 metres of the vessel, creating a substantial wake that impeded rescue efforts.
During removal of boiler safety valve, chief engineer's thumb was caught between spanner and the valve housing, resulting in a crushing injury

Recreational vessel observed sailing boat approaching from opposite direction of channel failing to give way, forcing vessel to the extreme left hand side of the channel. Sailing boat did not alter course, and a collision was very narrowly avoided

Recreational vessel observed sailing boat approaching from opposite direction of channel failing to give way, forcing vessel to the extreme left hand side of the channel. Sailing boat did not alter course, and a collision was very narrowly avoided
Workboat was assisting mooring operations for an inbound tanker when its mast became caught in another mooring line causing damage to the mast and fittings.
Crew member standing in wheelhouse turned to move out on deck and strained and dislocated their knee
Crew members observed discarding nylon fishing lines, snood, plastic corner bags and cigarette butts from the ship into the sea during fishing voyages
Yacht hull touched the bottom of river bed while transiting channel

Smoke observed emanating from the dryer vent ducting while the vessel was alongside wharf. The vessel was evacuated and Fire Service attended. It was found that the In-line vent fan had failed and overheated, causing accumulated lint to combust
Passenger fell overboard while disembarking vessel, with the vessel surging against the wharf. People on the wharf and a nearby vessel helped recover the passenger from the water without injury.

Vessel made contact with a submerged rock, damaging the propeller and causing structural damage to the hull at the point where the strut supporting the propeller shaft had been pressed into the hull, leading to minor water ingress
Yacht crew member hit by the vessel boom. The crew member fell and landed in the cockpit, injuring their hip, back and knee.

Vessel involved in low speed collision with piles at ferry ramp. Skipper was away from the wheelhouse fixing a generator issue. Upon returning, the vessel was adjacent to the berthing area at a low speed drift and made contact with the outer piles
Port engine began to lose RPM before failing altogether as the vessel pulled into a bay. Passengers disembarked and were transferred to another vessel
Crew member suffered a broken tooth after being struck in the mouth by a grapple thrown by another crewperson while unloading gear.
Medical event at sea as passenger became increasingly unwell while fishing. They were attended to by other staff and passengers before being transferred to an ambulance once vessel arrived at shore
Starboard throttle control was unresponsive. Engine restarted twice, and revs raised from 650 to 700, at which point throttle response returned
Individual suffered suspected stroke aboard vessel, with police coordinating a rescue operation.
Vessel was underway on auto pilot at night, when an auto pilot error steered the vessel to port and caused it to run aground.
Ferry crew member tripped on gangway at the ferry terminal, sustaining a swollen ankle.

Truck on board passenger ferry leaked approximately ten litres of toxic fluid. In consultation with the international code for the maritime transport of dangerous goods, crew in protective clothing were able to stop the leak and wash liquid overboard

While hauling the fishing net in rough weather, the net unexpectedly traversed the deck and struck a crew member in the chest, knocking them off their feet. The crew member sustained multiple injuries and was transferred to hospital

Crew member accidentally dropped berthing line into the water, where it was sucked into the thruster, stalling one of the main engines. Vessel was secured with spare lines and commercial divers were able to clear the fouled lines

Hoisting wire of ship crane was stuck in a sheave, and after attempts to free it, it was decided to replace the wire. Lashing used to secure crane’s hoisting wire during its replacement broke, causing the wire and block of crane to fall into the sea
Crew person cut index finger with fishing knife, requiring five stitches

Recreational vessel broke free from its mooring, drifted and collided with two other moored vessels. Two of the involved vessels then drifted and grounded on rocks in the vicinity of the mooring area.

Inbound vessel observed outbound vessel positioned in centre of the channel without running lights. Attempts at radio contact were unsuccessful, and skipper was preparing to take evasive action when the outbound vessel turned abruptly to starboard

Inbound vessel observed outbound vessel positioned in centre of the channel without running lights. Attempts at radio contact were unsuccessful, and skipper was preparing to take evasive action when the outbound vessel turned abruptly to starboard
Fishing vessel entered a Marine Exclusion Zone around port and narrowly avoided a collision with working tug vessel.
Fishing vessel entered a Marine Exclusion Zone around port and narrowly avoided a collision with working tug vessel.

A boat that entered into an exclusion zone around a marina under construction had its propeller entangled in a winch line. Winch line was cut and freed from the propeller, with the vessel sustaining only minor cosmetic damage
Bulk carrier inbound to port encountered a recreational vessel anchored in the pilot boarding area. Bulk carrier manoeuvred around the boat with a clearance of approximately 250m
Bulk carrier inbound to port encountered a recreational vessel anchored in the pilot boarding area. Bulk carrier manoeuvred around the boat with a clearance of approximately 250m
Small vessel passed approximately 20-40m ahead of inbound container ship while approaching breakwater.
Small vessel passed approximately 20-40m ahead of inbound container ship while approaching breakwater.
Pilot ladder was not compliant with SOLAS standards; ladder was on a significant angle and had loose treads.
Staff member walking topside on partially loaded log ship in low visibility tripped and fell on an exposed lug, injuring their hip.
Event Location: Beach St Wharf, Port Chalmers, Dunedin

Brief Description: Observer noted multiple rescue craft operators thrown from their vessels after hitting waves at incorrect angles during training exercises

Crew member on rescue vessel sustained a head injury after slipping while cresting a wave and hitting the knee of another crew member. The injured party was assessed by another lifeguard and advised to see a doctor should their condition worsen
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
During commercial driver training, skipper ran aground and became stuck on a sand bar at the river entrance.
Crew member was leaning against handrail when it collapsed, causing the crewperson to fall and sustain a fractured ankle.
Worker was cutting fish when the knife slipped, causing a deep cut between their thumb and first finger.
Observer noted that a sailing boat that was moored below their property had sunk overnight, with only the mast visible above the waterline
Barge was being utilised as a work platform. A hole developed in the forward section of the barge, which allowed the ingress of water

Kayak operator entered marine construction site and intentionally obstructed the movement of vessels within. Workout was placed in reverse to back out to a safe distance, with the resultant prop wash pushing the kayaker away from the vessels.

Kayak operator entered marine construction site and intentionally obstructed the movement of vessels within. Workout was placed in reverse to back out to a safe distance, with the resultant prop wash pushing the kayaker away from the vessels.

Kayak operator entered marine construction site and intentionally obstructed the movement of vessels within. Workout was placed in reverse to back out to a safe distance, with the resultant prop wash pushing the kayaker away from the vessels.

Kayak operator entered marine construction site and intentionally obstructed the movement of vessels within. Workout was placed in reverse to back out to a safe distance, with the resultant prop wash pushing the kayaker away from the vessels.
Pilot ladder arrangement not to SOLAS standards. Steps loose and not parallel, and the platform at bottom of the gangway not level. Pilot requested that the ship master remove ladder from service

Skipper of fishing charter boat reported a near miss with a passing service vessel while at anchor. They reported that the wake wave created by the passing vessel necessitated taking evasive action to avoid possible swamping

Skipper of fishing charter boat reported a near miss with a passing service vessel while at anchor. They reported that the wake wave created by the passing vessel necessitated taking evasive action to avoid possible swamping

Recreational vessel involved in near miss while entering harbour. Water taxi heading in opposite direction in exit from harbour was on direct collision course, forcing skipper of recreational boat to swerve hard to port to avoid a collision
Barge turned on its deck due to taking on water during severe weather. Barge was on mooring at the time of incident, and subsequently returned to base for repairs.
Mechanical and electrical power black out
Jet ski towing a skier without an observation person on board, navigated over a flooded jetty, which had been partially submerged after heavy rain, narrowly avoiding a collision.

While at anchor, in calm weather and with good visibility, a vessel glanced the side of anchored vessel, resulting in a fouling of its rigging in their vessel's port course yard brace. The vessels were separated without sustaining any visible damage.

While at anchor, in calm weather and with good visibility, a vessel glanced the side of anchored vessel, resulting in a fouling of its rigging in their vessel's port course yard brace. The vessels were separated without sustaining any visible damage.

Vessel collided with an uncharted sunken rock at low speed while undergoing fishing operations. All crew uninjured, vessel hull undamaged, but rudder rendered inoperable. Vessel delivered back to port for repairs under tow.
While manoeuvring channel, pilot noted a significant error in vessel's gyro compass. The ship's master switched to a second gyro compass, and vessel proceeded to berth without further incident.
Trip rope under tension parted and snapped back, striking crew member on the middle finger of their right hand.
Crew member slipped on some frozen squid bait while crossing the deck. No Injury sustained
Small electrical fire occurred in the engine room. The fire was confined to the block heater and was quickly extinguished with CO2

During log loading cargo operations cargo crane failed to luff up when directed by the operator. Once crane was safe, crew carried out inspection and found spring holding the luff wire tensioner in place had become dislodged

The accommodation ladder platform was too low - not 5m above the water. Ladder was inspected, crew were advised to raise the ladder 2m in order to disembark. The ladder was raised, re-secured and vessel departed safely.

When lowering the vessel into the water with two crew aboard, it was hit by swell causing the vessel to partially capsize. One crew member climbed atop the hull, the other became separated from the boat for a short time before being recovered.
While approaching the south side of the berth, sudden wind gust blew the vessel off into shallow water. No apparent damage to vessel.

Vessel rolled 30 degrees in rough conditions, causing crew member to lose their balance and hit their heat against the bulkhead. Incident reported to master and second officer, with no sign of concussion observed.

While approaching berth, gearbox failure caused vessel to advance astern despite attempts to bring vessel to a stop. Vessel impacted wooden fender piles at the end of the berth, causing two piles to fracture.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Whilst carrying out hatchman duties on the vessel, crew member was struck by a lashing turn buckle and sustained facial injuries including a fractured nose.

While undertaking training exercises, a vessel operator became unbalanced and fell from the vessel. While in the water, a wave hit the vessel, causing it to capsize. Lifeguards provided assistance, righting the vessel and avoiding further incident.

Crew member noted the port motor had developed a concerning exhaust noise. Upon return to base two holes were noticed in the plastic motor cover. Following the removal of the cover by crew, a crack in the exhaust housing was discovered.
Vessel tugging barge into harbour when struck by a large wave, causing stress on the stern line and resulting in a fracturing of the vessel's stern line bitts.
Vessel tugging barge into harbour when struck by a large wave, causing stress on the stern line and resulting in a fracturing of the vessel's stern line bitts.
On returning to port, approaching from NE at approximately 7.5 knots, vessel collided with a buoy. Crew recovered the damaged buoy and proceeded to berth.
Skipper injured while offloading bins on vessel. Skipper was standing atop a stack of bins when it tilted, caused them to fall and land on the deck.

Pilot ladder inspected prior to pilot disembarkation and determined that it was improperly secured. Pilot instructed crew to fasten ladder with shackles and noted that once this was performed the ladder was made safe for use.

While undergoing loading operations, foreman reported a broken hoisting wire on vessel's crane. Loading was stopped and crane relocated to a safe location on the vessel's port side, with no reported injuries or damage to either vessel or pier.

Reefer experienced near miss with an stationary, unlit vessel. Pilot launch approached immobilised vessel and was informed by its skipper that their boat had lost power. With help from the pilot launch, vessel was able to restart their engine.

Reefer experienced near miss with an stationary, unlit vessel. Pilot launch approached immobilised vessel and was informed by its skipper that their boat had lost power. With help from the pilot launch, vessel was able to restart their engine.

Gearbox failure during docking operation. Vessel secured to wharf and passengers disembarked. Inspection revealed a detached actuator cable from gearbox. New part fitted, with regular operations commencing thereafter.
Anchor was sucked into vessel's jet unit. Vessel secured with emergency anchor until towed by coastguard.

Ship crane power failure while lifting a scrap bin. Hoisting brakes failed to halt the uncontrolled descent of the bin, which landed on the ship's coaming before coming to a rest in the bottom of the vessel's hold.
During hauling one of the crew fell overboard and was not wearing a lifejacket. Crew member was swiftly pulled back on board vessel
Low knots and high running river caused dredge to shear, impacting mid tide wall & grounding on lower river section, causing damage to plating on starboard and portside keel.
Vessel dragged anchor resulting in a close quarters situation with another vessel.
Vessel dragged anchor resulting in a close quarters situation with another vessel.

Crew member tripped on the vessel cabin door sill, hitting their head heavily on the engine cover. After first aid was performed onsite, an ambulance was arranged for transfer of the crew member to hospital.
Concerns were raised regarding the safety of the pilot ladder arrangement. No stanchions rigged on vessel at embarkation deck and no stanchions brackets welded on main deck.
While assisting an inbound container ship, tug vessel master lost control of the stern of the tug, leading to a rotation of the vessel with the towline running off the winch.
While assisting an inbound container ship, tug vessel master lost control of the stern of the tug, leading to a rotation of the vessel with the towline running off the winch.

Vessel transferred control to bridge wing, bridge control appeared to be functioning normally. Dead slow ahead ordered but control was unresponsive. Control was moved back to the bridge and normal operations resumed after a short delay
While rowing at night in low visibility, operator experienced difficulty steering to bow side and made contact with the oars of another boat travelling in the opposite direction.
Machinery malfunction while performing de-rusting aboard vessel at berth, resulting in a minor abrasions to the operator.

Members of the public entered the water in and around the work site, obstructing vessel movement and operations. One threw a rock at crew members performing construction operations abroad a barge. Authorities and police were notified.

Members of the public entered the water in and around the work site, obstructing vessel movement and operations. One threw a rock at crew members performing construction operations abroad a barge. Authorities and police were notified.
Vessel grounded following the parting of its mooring. The vessel was refloated the following day

During disembarkation, pilot noted that the pilot ladder was affixed to an air vent and railing, not the deck. Man ropes were attached to the railing, not the deck. They were informed that they are to be fixed prior to the next arrival of the vessel.
Event Location: Pilot boarding grounds, Port of Tauranga

Brief Description: A crew member working inside the hauling room was struck by a wave that entered the space, knocking the crew member down and causing injuries including broken facial bones, lacerations and a broken tooth.
Vessel sank at its moorings with no passengers were on board. It is believed the vessel had not been managed or maintained in some time.
Boat capsized at mooring, with no passengers on board

On a long route, vessel got caught in a heavy swell and its over speed trip was triggered. The engine was restarted approximately six minutes later and the vessel resumed course on reduced pitch and with the addition of 320 tonnes of ballast.
Individuals trespassed into marina construction site and impeded the operation of a construction barge
Individuals trespassed into marina construction site and impeded the operation of a construction barge
Individuals trespassed into marina construction site and impeded the operation of a construction barge
Crew member sustained injury after another crew member accidentally closed a hatch on their foot, causing lacerations, bruising and a fracture.
In strong winds, vessel dragged anchor in mooring area, drifting across and into other vessels moored in its vicinity.

During marina construction works, two swimmers entered the work site, swimming underneath a vessel involved in construction operations, impeding its ability to function and preventing works from continuing.
Engine failed to fire astern on approach to berth. Tugs held vessel mid channel until engine fired astern. Berthing completed without further incident.
Skipper of vessel reported close quarters with another fishing vessel, which approached from one mile away to a distance of less than 250 metres and obstructed their fishing operations.
Skipper of vessel reported close quarters with another fishing vessel, which approached from one mile away to a distance of less than 250 metres and obstructed their fishing operations.

Fisherman standing on river bank experienced a near miss with a Jetboat which narrowly avoided them at high speed. The vessel operator's spotlight was focused on fish they were pursuing and as such failed to immediately sight the fishermen
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Loss of engine impaired vessel's ability to navigate a series of large waves and caused the vessel to overturn.  All passengers were uninjured and able to swim to the shore along with the boat.
Skipper reported that a crewperson appeared unsteady on their feet while walking on deck and advised other crew members to observe them.

Vessel captain noted smoke emitting from the engine room. Captain activated the fire alarm and engaged fuel stops. Engineers closed vents to the engine room, extinguishing the fire, and crew applied firefighting foam to the area as a precaution.

Passengers aboard their yacht berthed in a marina experienced a significant wake wave, sufficient to dislodge items from their yacht's shelving, suspect caused by a ferry exceeding the harbour's speed limit. Found to likely be two wakes combining.

Passengers aboard their yacht berthed in a marina experienced a significant wake wave, sufficient to dislodge items from their yacht's shelving, suspect caused by a ferry exceeding the harbour's speed limit. Found to likely be two wakes combining.
Crew member person sustained cuts to their hands while handling fish.
Contractor fainted while descending a flight of stairs, rendering them unconscious for a period of approximately one minute.
Vessel lost engine power due to a suspected electrical power failure. Vessel was towed back to port with assistance from coastguard
Failure of manual spring start mechanism on Emergency Generator (backup start failure).
Leak discovered on the vessel's port side plate freezer. Crew removed from factory area as a precaution, with engineers determining a faulty flange connection was responsible for the leak
Person slipped while entering excavator onboard logging vessel, suffering a minor head injury.
Fishing boat capsized during bar crossing. All crew were wearing wetsuits or lifejackets and were able to safely reach shore. The vessel hull was salvaged the following day.
During marina construction, a number of swimmers entered the work site and positioned themselves underneath the marina construction barge, halting construction operations
Dinghy swamped in rough seas. Two passengers on board the dinghy were recovered by a responding vessel, with the dinghy then towed to marina.
Crew member lost their balance when vessel was struck by a large wave in rough seas, causing them to fall and sustaining superficial head injuries.
An individual sustained a sprained neck and wrist after vessel collided with them in the water

While transiting inbound under pilotage, vessel's engine failed without warning. Engine restarted after approximately two minutes, with the remainder of the arrival transit proceeding without incident.
Diesel overflow from the starboard fuel tank, with spillage out onto the main deck from the tank’s breather. Engines stopped and fuel cleanup commenced

Vessel allegedly suffered a control fault when berthing, causing the vessel to impact heavily against the wharf, resulting in passengers being knocked off feet and a crew member sustaining a minor injury.
Vessel duty officer's fingers caught in the hatch cover of manhole while securing the hatch.

Leaving Tamaki Marine park for Tryphena. Vessel was difficult to manoeuvre into mooring position and found significant list on starboard side. Found starboard pontoons rear tapered end-cap had split from pontoon.
Rescue vessel flipped during training exercise. No injuries or vessel damage was sustained in the incident

Bow thruster failed to respond during final approach into port. Vessel held in position while issue was investigated, with the cause determined to be low oil level. Thruster became operational after refilling oil levels, and berthing continued.
Pilot ladder not in line with SOLAS standards. There were shackles, knots and splices in ladder ropes. Steps uneven gaps and or on angle, loop at bottom of ladder, tripping line fitted on aft side.
An IRB had a roll-over at a controlled IRB training at Waihi Beach. Conditions was a medium onshore wind, 1m-1.5m swells. The roll-over was due to an engine failure in the break zone.
A bulk bag with harvested rope fell when being shifted from bagging frame to forward deck. No injuries or damage to vessel.
Crane brake has failed as the operator maneuvered to pick up lifting equipment from the wharf.
Tug collided with inbound cargo ship. Tug sustained damage, including shattered fly bridge windows, with no apparent damage to the cargo vessel
Tug collided with inbound cargo ship. Tug sustained damage, including shattered fly bridge windows, with no apparent damage to the cargo vessel

Vessel's hull grounded on river bottom. It is reported that low lake levels and deferred dredging and desedimentation maintenance caused the grounding. Skipper ceased operations until the lake rose to a safe operating level
Crane Hook came unclipped when hoisting load. Hook repositioned to avoid injury to crew.
Worker fell approximately 4 meters from ladder, breaking their leg on impact.
Skipper fell asleep and awoke to vessel running aground on cliff side rocks. Vessel was anchored and crew disembarked onto shore where they were recovered by a rescue helicopter
A port-side combination ladder was rigged after the starboard side ladder was unable to be used due to winch issues.
Engine failed and could not be restarted. Skipper contacted coastguard, who towed vessel back to port
Passenger tripped over the rear door sill while boarding. During the trip the passenger's condition worsened and an ambulance was called.
Flames and smoke observed coming from vessel's funnel. Repairs undertaken by crew on board to the air/oil distributor restored vessel to good working order.
Crew member sustained cuts to their fingers while handling fish.
Crew member jumped off truck deck, landed badly and twisted their ankle.
During log loading operations, stevedores aboard vessel noted issue with crane hoisting, which upon inspection was shown to be caused by a damaged jib end sheave bearing.
Passenger lost balance and fell while descending stairs on charter vessel in heavy swell.
Event Location: North Eastern of Tarpeka Point, Bay of Islands

Brief Description: Kayakers and swimmers entered work site via surrounding waters, positioning themselves between vessels engaged in construction work and disrupting operations. In the course of the incident, a protestor's paddleboard was destroyed.

Kayakers and swimmers entered work site via surrounding waters, positioning themselves between vessels engaged in construction work and disrupting operations. In the course of the incident, a protestor's paddleboard was destroyed.

Kayakers and swimmers entered work site via surrounding waters, positioning themselves between vessels engaged in construction work and disrupting operations. In the course of the incident, a protestor's paddleboard was destroyed.

Kayakers and swimmers entered work site via surrounding waters, positioning themselves between vessels engaged in construction work and disrupting operations. In the course of the incident, a protestor's paddleboard was destroyed.
Reported use of force by operators of several vessels inside construction site in the course of apprehending an individual who had trespassed into the site.
Vessel experienced main engine failure while navigating out of berth. Tugs held vessel in position for two minutes until there was enough starting air to restart the engine.

Vessel lost steering and control of winches, suspected to have been caused by a broken coupling between engine and hydraulic pumps. Vessel towed to berth by another fishing vessel and tugboat in the area.

During replacement of vessel's echo sounder transducer, controls to prevent water from entering vessel's void space failed, resulting in an ingress of water. A mobile pump was used to remove water from the void space.
Starboard wire parted while hauling gear.
Pilot ladder construction failing to meet SOLAS standards, with an apparent angle greater than the 55 degrees listed against the vessel's operating guidelines
Steering failure during transit to Halfmoon Bay from Auckland. Vessel returned to berth in Auckland with maintenance crews determining a relay contact failure the likely cause of the incident.
Jib end outer sheave bearing failure during cargo operations. Crane removed from service following incident.

Unsafe trapdoor ladder arrangement,  accommodation ladder not secured to ship's side. Pilot ladder secured to ship's side with magnets and to the frame fitted to the lower platform and not to the ship.

During scheduled maintenance while at berth, a minor electrical fire was started in the course of load testing of the vessel's generator. The unit was shut down and isolated, with dry powder fire extinguisher discharged into the unit as a precaution.
Crew member's thumb injured after the release of slack while guiding fishing wire onto reels.
Pilot ladder not rigged to a safe standard.

Lifting wire parted while loading logs which resulted in the heave being spilled on the side deck and wharf with logs also falling in between the vessel and the berth into the water. All staff were in their safe zones at the time of the incident.
Bottom pilot ladder rungs not horizontal, stretched on one side and with retrieval line rigged too low. Pilot requested master to obtain new ladder.
A piece of decking fell into the hold, where two stevedores were working. No injuries were reported, with damaged bolts affixed to the decking the suspected cause of collapse.
While raising anchor, crew member's hand became caught in anchor winch, resulting in a partial amputation of the thumb.
Pilot ladder appeared well worn and potentially out of date. Age of ladder could not be accurately determined against ladder certificate due to badly corroded manufacturers plate on pilot ladder.
Vessel lost control while performing right hand spin, with boat's stern and starboard making contact with tree branches on riverbank. No injuries or damage to vessel occurred.
Vessel grounded on reef after helmsman altered course at the southern edge of the reef. No significant damage to the vessel or injuries were sustained in the incident
Worker injured while operating a grinder in the course of performing vessel maintenance. A small metal fragment passed between the worker's safety goggles and struck their eye.
Vessel's starboard propeller hit object floating near surface. Vessel then proceeded slowly back to marina under power of port engine.
Crew member's hand caught in rope while launching fishing net, sustaining a strained arm.
Pilot noticed helmsman having difficulty holding ship steady and observed gyro wandering five degrees either side. No deficiencies declared before docking at port.
Handholds were not securely fastened to the ship's bulwarks to enable the pilot to step safely and comfortably from the top of the ladder on to the ship's deck.

The ladder was rigged incorrectly. The manufacturers plate under the top spreader was corroded. Pilot could not determine the age of the ladder or whether it matched the certificate presented by the ship.
Pilot ladder not rigged in keeping with the ship's standard procedures, meaning the setup was not fit for purpose and able to comply with regulations.

Vessel master was fitting fender strops to the vessel. Assistance from tug boat was requested to push fendering to secure fittings. Master's hand was then caught between the two vessels, resulting in a serious injury to two of their fingers

Vessel master was fitting fender strops to the vessel. Assistance from tug boat was requested to push fendering to secure fittings. Master's hand was then caught between the two vessels, resulting in a serious injury to two of their fingers
The pilot ladder combination was unsafe; Man ropes only 22mm. Master advised on required size and said they would rectify as soon as possible
Accommodation ladder not secured to ships side. Ladder not attached to ships side 1.5m above accommodation ladder platform. Accommodation ladder secured with same magnet as pilot ladder.
Container vessel contact with wharf. Vessel making final approach to berth when vessel's starboard shoulder landed heavily on wharf.
Excessive winch tension caused tug lowline to snap, damaging the tug's window when it recoiled.
The main engine stopped due to mist detection in the crankcase. On inspection there was scuffing to the piston liners. The vessel ran on auxiliary generators to its destination
Starboard cargo resistor box overheated and began to smoke. The ship's engineer isolated power to the unit and crew used a powder extinguisher to extinguish the fire.
Collision between fishing vessel and container ship 70 nautical miles offshore. Fishing vessel sustained minor damage, with no injuries recorded in the incident.
Collision between fishing vessel and container ship 70 nautical miles offshore. Fishing vessel sustained minor damage, with no injuries recorded in the incident.
The pilot ladder rigging was unsafe. Ship's combination ladder and pilot ladder was secured with one magnet. Ship had no bits on the side to secure it.
While heading outwards from boat ramp, recreational power boat collided with a moored line fishing vessel, resulting in damage to the port bow and trolling motor of the power boat.
While heading outwards from boat ramp, recreational power boat collided with a moored line fishing vessel, resulting in damage to the port bow and trolling motor of the power boat.
While undertaking maintenance on the main engine, a piston hit a crew member in the leg. Vessel anchored and the crewperson was transferred to hospital for treatment

Vessel struck by wave while crossing Whakatane river bar, causing four passengers to fall overboard. Life rings were deployed, and with assistance from other boats in the vicinity, the passengers were able to be safely recovered from the water.

After launching its tender, the vessel's hydraulic cradle was not fully raised, resulting in damage to the cradle after passing over a wave. Water pressure on the cradle caused a small split in one of the cradle's ram hoses, rendering it inoperable.

Vessel struck by wave while crossing bar, with the impact causing both passengers to be thrown overboard. Both were able to re-board vessel, with no injuries or damage to boat as a result of the incident.
Vessel's keel made contact, then rested on sea floor during slight swell. Vessel reversed into open water with keel to be inspected by divers for damage.
Vessel capsized during driver training as operator misjudged approach to oncoming waves. No injuries reported during the incident.
Capsize
IRB operator misjudged approach to oncoming wave, flipping the vessel on its starboard side.
During strong winds, two ketches observed drifting onto rocks and grounding.
Crew member's clothing became caught in deck machinery, pulling their arm into the machinery. The injured person was freed and provided first aid by crew on board before being airlifted to hospital.
Vessel operator was unable to release tender from berth on account of protestor obstruction of mooring line. Vessel operator was able to cut the mooring line.
Main engine failure while berthing. Control was changed to the engine side and an additional tug was recruited. Vessel then berthed without further incident.
While loading a cargo of containers, a bar fell from the vessel from a height of 10-15 metres, narrowly missing a maritime officer on the wharf below.

Port engine failed to move from astern to ahead. Engine shut down with remainder of vessel operation completed using the starboard engine. Cause of port engine failure appeared to be a broken or disconnected gear selection cable.
While shooting the fishing gear the helper winch rope slipped off its drum causing the lazy wire to drop onto crew member's hand. Crew member taken for medical attention.

Drop unit fell while loading vehicles, rupturing its fuel tank and causing a diesel spill from the vessel ramp into the harbour. Deck crew deployed oil spill equipment to prevent further spillage, and no injuries were reported.
Crew member fell into portside hosing connection, sustaining bruises to their head.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
MPI observer reported a violent dispute between two crew members on board vessel.
Starboard pilot ladder old and in poor condition. Steps rotated under foot as chocks were loose. Needs to be condemned and replaced with new ladder.
The ship dragged anchor in heavy weather close to shore off the Gisborne coast resulting in a near miss.

Whilst raising No. 5 starboard side collapsible stanchions the hoisting wire loop parted within the wire clips. Stevedores were ashore crew standing in their safe zones. No damage occurred as the stanchions fell.
Crew member's hand dragged into and caught between rope and cleat, resulting in a minor injury
Vessel ran aground due to crew member falling asleep. Vessel got off rocks and proceeded to Oyster Bay, Port Underwood. Three POB. No injuries. No water ingress. No oil leaking.

As the vessel approached Rawene the electronic steering controls faulted to its back up control and the control alarm sounded. Control of the bow was lost, and made contact with the handrail on the wharf, damaging the top rail and 2 stanchions.

During re-stow, logs slipped and a chemical drum with hydrochloric acid (200 litres) broke. Fire brigade was called out. 150 litres  spread on starboard side and crew completed cleaning up the chemicals on the deck.
Boat contacted river bank coming to a halt about 20 metres downstream of initial contact point

When approaching the wharf at Walter Peak gusting wind in the bay caused the steam ship to alter position near the wharf. Vessel made low speed impact with a section of wharf and port propeller subsequently touched sea-bed.
Ladder not rigged adequately. Crew failed to use heaving line as explained to the Master, which resulted in tug needing to abort connection to vessel.
During swing on departure, Master reported main engine issue that required vessel to be at the berth. Returned vessel to berth with existing tug assistance.
Vessel undertaking long line fishing operations near to shore involved in a near miss with a kayaker.
Vessel undertaking long line fishing operations near to shore involved in a near miss with a kayaker.

As approaching a boat on a straight wide piece of river the jet boat has come into contact with the wake with a bang. This released the STBD side reverse lever and caused a hard right turn into tree line. Abrupt stop, passengers fine.
The pilot ladder running through the trapdoor pilot boarding arrangement was not resting firmly against the ship's side but rigged over the rear horizontal beam of the trapdoor.
Investigating vibration from the vessel's no.2 engine, a piece of timber was discovered lodged in the propeller. Debris was cleared, with a fault in the vessel's steering subsequently discovered.
While berthing at No.1, bunker MDO overflow from No.3- FOTk (P) and spillage on main deck.  Unstable supply pump pressure and suddenly increasing rate reported to be the cause of incident.

Vessel rolled with deckhand's arm caught between vessel gantry and trawl door, resulting in a fracture of the deckhand's arm. First aid administered on the scene, before the injured party was transferred to hospital for treatment.
Coastguard vessel ventured 6 NM outside of certification limits for a period of one hour and twenty minutes while responding to a vessel experiencing mechanical issues.

Recreational vessel collided with navigation marker, with vessel operator sustaining head injuries. Passengers aboard vessel were taken to a nearby boat ramp to await ambulance, with vessel then towed to shore by police.
Pilot ladder not rigged to current SOLAS standards.
Pilot ladder construction not compliant with current SOLAS standards.
Crew member collapsed on harbour approach. Injured person was admitted to hospital and diagnosed with an arteriovenous malformation on their right frontal lobe.
Vessel made contact with port lateral pole while inbound.
During unload of cargo onto vehicle on wharf, crane operator error resulted in cargo colliding with the vehicle and breaking its rear window.
Whilst loading logs, a stevedore fell approximately 2 metres from hatch lid on deck at the aft end of the vessel, resulting in knee and back injuries.

Genset shut down. Master and crew member checked the fuel, oil, water and strainer and was clear. Master noticed smoke and an orange glow coming from alternator when starting it. Back up genset was used for the remainder of the trip.
Third officer sustained an injured finger while preparing gangway after mooring operations.
A crew member got their right thumb caught between the mooring line and the vessel bollard while attempting to untie the vessel.

Fire alarm alerted crew to smoke emitting from refrigeration plant. While investigating the unit, the control panel ignited. The fire was promptly extinguished and the unit isolated before the vessel returned to port for repairs.
Hatch closed on the hand of crew member, resulting in cuts and two fractured fingers.
Vessel experienced RPM fluctuation and a subsequent stalled engine during departure from harbour. Engine restarted after two minutes and passage resumed without further incident.
Pilot ladder not compliant with SOLAS standards; Trapdoor combination type pilot ladder with the ladder section only secured to the accommodation ladder.
While attempting to board pilot from pilot vessel onto cargo ship, swell caused the ship to roll, making contact with the pilot vessel and shattering two cabin windows.
While attempting to board pilot from pilot vessel onto cargo ship, swell caused the ship to roll, making contact with the pilot vessel and shattering two cabin windows.
Container dropped from spreader while discharging cargo at berth.
Vessel made contact with beacon on port approach. Vessel continued to berth with no damage reported.
Vessel became entangled and lost manoeuvrability.
While preparing stabilisers for operation, safety bar swung and struck crewperson, resulting in a minor cut to the top of the forehead.
Crew member suffered suspected stroke aboard vessel. Emergency services were contacted and a rescue helicopter extracted the crew member and delivered them to hospital.
Inbound pilot spoke with master about loose chocks on the pilot ladder. On departure the pilot spoke to master and noticed that the ladder provided still had loose chocks.

Members of public reported oil slicks on water near Mariners Cove, Algies Bay. Council compliance team attended the area and communicated with the locals but could not identify the source. Harbourmaster Office made effort to identify vessel.
Crew member's finger was caught in a skid on the side of the vessel, resulting in a minor abrasion.

Pilot ladder arrangement not compliant with SOLAS standards. Main engine failure when transiting inbound and was without propulsion for 15 minutes. After changing oil filters, the vessel proceeded on route without further incident.

Vessel's tender struck an uncharted rock 100m from shore. No injuries were reported, with tender able to continue its operation. Subsequent investigation of the tender revealed external damage to its outboard motor.
Starboard engine failure. Portside engine engaged to navigate away from shoreline and passengers transferred to a backup boat.

Vessel capsized on the Kaituna Bar with three people overboard. All were wearing life jackets and were picked up by a nearby vessel. Persons were then transferred onto Coastguard rescue vessel and taken ashore
Recreational vessel grounded after wind changed during the night while at anchor. Second vessel also grounded while attempting to assist.
Recreational vessel grounded after wind changed during the night while at anchor. Second vessel also grounded while attempting to assist.

While piloting vessel, another vessel approached the course taken to berth 4. Contact made via VHF. Vessel continued at 8.6kn on a course between our bow and the wharf. Vessel had to be stopped by pilot.

While piloting vessel, another vessel approached the course taken to berth 4. Contact made via VHF. Vessel continued at 8.6kn on a course between our bow and the wharf. Vessel had to be stopped by pilot.
Tow line snapped as tug was guiding vessel to berth. While pulling astern at 350 (full power) this occurred. Vessel berthed safely.
Tow line snapped as tug was guiding vessel to berth. While pulling astern at 350 (full power) this occurred. Vessel berthed safely.

Departed Days Bay Wharf with two passengers and two crew at 1729. At beam Point Halswell the deckhand came downstairs to let the Skipper know she could not find one of the passengers onboard. Passing passenger vessel found passenger and rescued.
After transmitting an emergency mayday call, two fishermen were rescued from their vessel, which had taken on a significant amount of water and begun to founder.
Crew member stepped off the gangway onto uneven pavement, fell and injured their leg.
Vessel's bow thruster fouled by mooring lines. Initial efforts to free the line were unsuccessful, with divers deployed to assess the situation.

Master was completing the last spin of the trip. As the boat spun the port engine cut out and would not restart. Idled back to the jetty on STBD engine. On further inspection it was found that the port engine had seized.
Jet boat driver swerved to avoid wildlife, causing the vessel to make contact with tree branches on the riverbank. One passenger sustained minor scratches to their face.

Party of four paddling the "release" (planned release of water from nearby dam or spillway). Hastings SAR helicopter uplifted a patient with suspected broken ribs and delivered them to Taupo Hospital for treatment.
Event Location: Tree Trunk Gorge Bridge, Waipakihi River

Brief Description: Crane slippage while unloading cargo resulted in a 25 tonne load falling 4-5 metres. Crane operator unable to restart crane following incident.

Approximately 50 metres from the beach the engine stopped. Coast Guard called for assistance and vessel towed to Kapiti Island. Engineer starts diagnostic test. It was revealed the fuel shut off valve was in the closed position.
Propulsion failure during departure from berth.
Following engine failure and loss of control of vessel, occupants abandoned vessel. Passengers reached shore without any reported injuries and have arranged recovery of the vessel.
Boating down stream, encountered railway irons across the channel path. Evasive action to avoid irons resulted in boat beaching and flipping.

Jetski collided with marina berth and continued out of the basin, where it ran into the stern ramp of another vessel. Jetski sustained damage to its bow. Driver reported to be under the influence of alcohol.

Jetski collided with marina berth and continued out of the basin, where it ran into the stern ramp of another vessel. Jetski sustained damage to its bow. Driver reported to be under the influence of alcohol.
Vessel ran aground, taking on water through the bow area. Vessel came off and then foundered enroute.  Another vessel responded to distress call and rescued all three passengers on board.
Event Location: South East Bay, Great Island, Three Kings Islands

Brief Description: Vessel was enroute to join inbound cargo vessel. The vessel was momentarily disorientated in heavy fog condition and ran aground between #6 and #7 beacons. Was able to move from grounding under its own power. No damage to vessel.
Crew member went out to check and secure gear, pulled on rope and felt a sharp pain in their chest, rested for the night with no signs of improvement. Was taken to shore to receive medical treatment.
Hook from lifting gear slackened, swinging and striking the head of crew member. First aid was applied on site.
Vessel passed at speed and at close proximity, creating a significant wake and causing the vessel to roll. Master injured with cuts and bruises.
Crew member sustained a fractured wrist while attempting to refloat a partially submerged mussel line.
Vessel was heading into the entrance of a harbour towing a 16-foot aluminium Dingy. Vessel reported to have a near miss of the Port hand marker buoy.

Jetboat struck a submerged rock, resulting in serious injuries to three passengers, and minor injuries to a further three. Emergency services attended the scene, with the seriously injured parties airlifted to hospital
Passenger aboard vessel lost balance and fell, sustaining a fractured wrist.
Master loaded passengers on boat and went to start the boat but it would not start. Replaced starter Relay and boat started.
Crew member experienced a medical event as a result of a pre-existing condition. The vessel returned to port where the injured person was treated by medics.
Tug lost main engine cooling during ship arrival. Ship forced to complete berthing with use of remaining tug and ship's anchor.
Report from crew member on board vessel regarding the emptying of bilge tanks in potential violation of MARPOL conventions.
Near miss between kayak and recreational fishing vessel. Fishing vessel crossed over kayak's anchor line and created a wake wave that nearly capsized kayak.
Near miss between kayak and recreational fishing vessel. Fishing vessel crossed over kayak's anchor line and created a wake wave that nearly capsized kayak.
Vessel lost control in marina, colliding with the hull of a sailing boat berthed in the marina.
While securing cargo, lashing bar fell and struck the head of crew member. Crew member and was taken to a medical centre for assessment.
Jetski operator observed to appear to exceed speed rule and narrowly avoided contact with a swimmer.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Skipper was motoring down harbour, when lowering light got too close to a moored vessel. Their bowsprit caught vessel's push pit as a wind gust hit.

Two crew where on top of a pot clearing it of fish. The pot fell over board and both crew landed in the ocean. No one was injured, both crew retrieved using life rings and were brought back onboard safely.
Faulty gyrocompass

Ship engineers shut down ammonia line due to the ammonia sensor alarm. Engine room was vented, and engineers repaired the faulty valve, with loading operations recommencing following the vessel captain issuing an all clear.
Equipment Failure - Hook Lever came loose causing an emergency shut off.

Vessel approached another vessel when it was trawling off the port. The skipper of the vessel tried to raise the ship on a number of different channels with no response. Original vessel made a late manoeuvre to avoid the fishing vessel.

Vessel approached another vessel when it was trawling off the port. The skipper of the vessel tried to raise the ship on a number of different channels with no response. Original vessel made a late manoeuvre to avoid the fishing vessel.
Vessel was departing from wharf when it experienced a loss of propulsion. Upon examination, the skipper determined the drive line had sheared.

When loading containers on to a vessel, two containers fell onto the lash platform on the berth. There were no injuries during the event however there was a breach of the exclusion zone which had the potential to cause harm.

Kayak operator caught in sailing vessel's fishing line. The sailing vessel initially refused to stop or render assistance. When subsequently approached, the sailing vessel's skipper was uncooperative.

Kayak operator caught in sailing vessel's fishing line. The sailing vessel initially refused to stop or render assistance. When subsequently approached, the sailing vessel's skipper was uncooperative.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Vessel had to abort port entrance as not able to heave-up starboard anchor. Vessel superintendent agreed to swap electric motors between W1 (burnt) and W2 (operational) to allow pick-up anchor and bring vessel to operation.
Tied vessel to mooring. The next morning after a windy night, the vessel had sunk with just the bow sticking out of the water.
Fuel sensor fault occurred during commercial trip. Skipper pulled to shore and was towed to boat trailer by another commercial vessel

Operator error led to the grapple digger toppled during log loading. The ship's crane was employed to partially lift the digger to allow the operator, who sustained superficial injuries, to be extracted.

Strong gust caught the bow just before berthing, followed by a large swell line which pushed the vessel on to the fender of the wharf. Impact resulted in minor damage to port bow high above waterline.

Pilot noticed that the speed appeared to stall and heading wasn't responding as expected with helm order. Confirmed with Captain that there was a Main Engine issue, and had failed. After 5 minutes Main engine was back online.

Line handler letting a ship line go from a bollard became entangled in a part of the line resulting in the line handler's left leg being placed in tension. Unknown musculoskeletal injuries to knee, hip and ankle of left leg.
Ladder supported from frame on gangway in contravention with MNZ rule 53.

Low insulation alarm sounded followed by steering gear number one motor alarm stop and no voltage. The motors insulation were found to be very low. For safety reasons, could not use. Steering gear motor number one was not operational.
Launch came out at speed close to shore creating a wake that hit the eight on the bow. The wake caused the boat to snap in half tipping eight people on board into the sea.
Launch came out at speed close to shore creating a wake that hit the eight on the bow. The wake caused the boat to snap in half tipping eight people on board into the sea.
Vessel flipped while navigating waves during training exercise, resulting in all three passengers being ejected into the water. All passengers uninjured and able to return to shore
Passenger ferry sighted the bow of a sunk dinghy and shortly thereafter two people in water wearing lifejackets.  People were recovered with the assistance of a second passenger ferry.
Passenger tripped while boarding vessel, suffering minor injuries.
Concerns raised due to boarding arrangement not compliant or safe.
Jet ski observed to be travelling in excess of 5  knots and within close proximity of swimmers and kayak operators.
Vessel drifted onto rock while at anchor and was later refloated at high tide.
Vessel made contact with landing companionway while berthing, resulting in damage to the access platform and ladder
The vessel's number two and three cranes malfunctioned during log loading.
Vessel experienced engine failure and drifted onto rocks.
The vessel diver recall system cable got caught in propeller, resulting in minor damage to the port engine's inside cavitation plate.
Crewperson fell overboard while securing vessel to wharf. Crew member was able to swim to vessel's dinghy and was pulled back aboard
Fire incident on board vessel while getting battery checked at an authorised dealer.
Cargo handler sustained a foot injury while loading cargo.
Boat dragged anchor until it was nearly under a bridge. The owner wants to upgrade mooring to a screw anchor system.

Lost use of the port engine when vessel was leaving with customers aboard. It was diagnosed as a throttle issue due to the pin slipping out. The engine was still running, but throttle was not functioning.
Engine failure resulted in master losing control of the vessel. Unable to navigate oncoming waves, crew were knocked overboard.
Following a training exercise, a canoe crew member reported a back injury sustained while paddling the canoe.
Vessel turned sharply to port in shallow water. Crewperson was ejected from the vessel, impacting heavily on the sand.
Ladder was not rigged per current SOLAS regulations.
Crew member departed vessel and attempted to swim to shore, spending 23 hours in the water before being located and transferred to hospital for treatment
Steering jammed in rough conditions. Unable to free steering, vessel operator anchored and transmitted a call for assistance. Coastguard arrived and towed disabled vessel to nearby harbour

Skipper left vessel at anchor and returned to shore via dinghy and was later informed that vessel had dragged anchor in strong winds and grounded. Once winds had subsided the vessel was successfully refloated at high tide.
Issues with main engines. One blanked off for service.
Found small crack on port side tank. After consultation repaired by shore contractors. Repair found to be watertight and no sign of leakage.

Hoisting wire broke on the vessels crane four while loading. The crane operator had lowered the bin into the hatch and started to lift the bin to tip out the scrap metal then the wire let go. All Cranes except crane one were condemned.
Three kayakers were on the water outside of the buoys marking a construction zone and were protesting. Reported that a vessel aimed for them, causing swells and pushing kayakers back in water.
Three kayakers were on the water outside of the buoys marking a construction zone and were protesting. Reported that a vessel aimed for them, causing swells and pushing kayakers back in water.
A passenger became unresponsive. Passenger was assisted off boat and transferred to waiting ambulance.
Crewperson overboard during training exercise. No injuries reported, with crewperson able to re-board vessel.
While attempting to secure recreational vessel to wharf, strong outgoing currents forced it into the rear of a fishing boat, damaging its outboard motor
While attempting to secure recreational vessel to wharf, strong outgoing currents forced it into the rear of a fishing boat, damaging its outboard motor
Vessel hit tree on the front port side bow, ramming the log up into the chime. Master checked over the side and saw indent in hull.

Stanchions not secured by pins near the base. Pilot discovered deficiency after climbing the ladder and reaching the deck level. Captain sought and this was repaired before mooring men used the ladder in basin.

Radio charging station in vessel's bridge caught fire during the night. The fire eventually self-extinguished and was discovered by crew the following morning, with significant damage to wiring, bridge dash and a broken wheelhouse window.
Passenger lost balance and slipped while disembarking. No injuries sustained
Quad rowing boat struck kayaker causing kayak to capsize. Quad boat was travelling at speed at the time of the collision
Quad rowing boat struck kayaker causing kayak to capsize. Quad boat was travelling at speed at the time of the collision
Inbound vessel's approached inshore from pilot boarding area about heading toward navigational beacon. Vessel was approached by pilot and was able to correct course to harbour approach.

Crew responded to smoke alarm sounding in the vessel. Upon investigation, it was determined that the onboard watermaker system had malfunctioned and discharged water through the plant room, short circuiting some electrical equipment.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessel featured trapdoor type combination, with the ladder not attached to ship's side 1.5m above accommodation ladder platform.
Skipper detected smoke from engine exhaust and a small fire after lifting engine hatch. Fire was extinguished, with vessel towed back to home port thereafter for repairs.
Vessel's crane hoisting wire snapped while unloading cargo, resulting in cargo falling approximately 10 metres into vessel's hold.
Vessel landed heavily after cresting wave. Crew person dislocated shoulder and was returned to shore.
Vessel's engine stalled after being hit by wave. While attending to the engine, a second wave struck and swamped the vessel. Occupants transmitted an emergency call and were rescued by police
Both engines failed during sea trial due to an electrical fault.
Crew member slipped on deck, resulting in ligament and lumbar strains
Vessel collided with 5 knot marker in harbour
Pilot advised Master to swing to starboard 80° but overswung past 90°. Vessel delayed turning to port and came into close quarters with pleasure vessel.
Pilot advised Master to swing to starboard 80° but overswung past 90°. Vessel delayed turning to port and came into close quarters with pleasure vessel.
Vessel foundered at berth in marina. Booms were deployed to limit spread of a fuel leak, before the vessel was refloated with diver assistance and towed to a dry dock
Rescue boat towing another vessel and made contact with a speed marker on approach to boat ramp. No damage reported to either vessel
Vessel hit by large wave in training session, resulting in crew member injuring their ankle.
Vessel lost propulsion at sea. An inspection revealed the propeller was no longer affixed to prop shaft. Vessel was able to sail to port and attach replacement propeller.
Minor injury to stevedore worker.
Wind gusts spun vessel, causing anchor line to become caught in vessel's propeller. Skipper reversed vessel to dislodge rope, before returning to port to allow divers to inspect propeller for damage.
Crew member tripped on vessel, resulting in a fractured arm.
Vessel struck submerged object, leading to failure of starboard engine.

While approaching the berth the vessel started to get pushed down onto a moored vessel. Master made adjustments but was unable to bring bow around, hitting inside pole of a vessel and ripping off tire fender.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Passenger fell overboard while performing Man Overboard training. Vessel safely recovered passenger with no injuries reported
One of the main ropes had a broken rope strand. This was shown to the Second Officer and deck crew at the ladder and they were asked to replace it before visiting next port.
Master heading in shore. Master occupied and did not see recreational boat. Boat had to move and crossed vessels bow at starboard side.
Master heading in shore. Master occupied and did not see recreational boat. Boat had to move and crossed vessels bow at starboard side.
Vessel  lost propulsion and began drifting.
Vessel failed to keep clear of pilot boarding area
Jetski hit by another jetski at 80km on the side. Jetski went up and over the ski and injured driver's back.
Driver broached on a turn, after encountering an unexpected wake. Boat did a capsize barrel roll, throwing driver from the boat.
Small boat crossed in front of another vessel.
Small boat crossed in front of another vessel.
Wind gust caused vessel to flip while cresting wave
While placing a mooring, vessel's gearbox experienced a mechanical issue, resulting in the vessel colliding with the wharf
Vessel made contact with a rock ledge. Vessel's tender deployed to inspect for damage and subsequently confirmed as a minor graze to the vessel's keel bar.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Moored vessel began capsizing about 50 yards off the jetty
Vessel collided with hull of another vessel while securing tug line, resulting in the vessel's mast detaching from the wheelhouse.
Vessel collided with hull of another vessel while securing tug line, resulting in the vessel's mast detaching from the wheelhouse.
Crew member slipped and struck their head on a basin, resulting in a laceration above their right eye.
Crew member's hand caught in fishing wires, sustaining superficial injuries

Skipper of fishing vessel contacted coastguard to report vessel's engine failure. Upon arrival of coastguard, skipper was discovered in the water away from the vessel, requiring rescuing.  Fishing vessel secured and anchored
Crew member sustained a torn achilles tendon in the course of performing duties
Passenger fell from sea biscuit being towed by motorboat and the tow rope wrapped around their neck. Passenger was pulled underwater and dragged by boat.
Boat grounded on rocks with stern submerged. Minor injuries to two passengers
Rescue vessel exceeded 5 knot speed limit within 200m of shore in the course of executing a rescue operation

Launch anchored in Channel and outbound vessel was required to alter course to pass the pleasure craft safely. Radio requested to know the vessel name when Pilot Boat got back at Berth due to slight radio interference.

Launch anchored in Channel and outbound vessel was required to alter course to pass the pleasure craft safely. Radio requested to know the vessel name when Pilot Boat got back at Berth due to slight radio interference.
Tug Master advised of an unsafe mooring arrangement for their towline using a shackle.
Harbour Control requested that vessel enter an area and advise a small pleasure craft that they were in a restricted area. Contact was made during this operation.
Harbour Control requested that vessel enter an area and advise a small pleasure craft that they were in a restricted area. Contact was made during this operation.
Crew member removed a sight glass from the separator oil feed tank while the machine was running, causing hot liquid to spray onto the crew member's arms, neck and chest.

Vessel presented a combination ladder which was rigged less than 5 mtrs from the waterline making it unsafe to use. A straight ladder was instructed to be rigged instead. Pilot ladder was rigged but crew then rigged the retrieving line below the last
Vessel collided with an uncharted rock, causing crew member to fall and hit their head. Crew member sustained a concussion, and was taken to hospital for treatment.
Motor cut out in set of waves. The next set of waves came through and rolled the boat.
Skipper attempted to free a foul around the propeller. The vessels ladder slipped and fell overboard making it difficult to get back on board.
Inspections caps of jet units removed following repairs to the vessel and not detected by crew until the vessel was launched, resulting in flooding to the vessel engine bays.
Electrical fault caused a fire inside the crane. Fire extinguisher pin was jammed. Crane operator put out fire with water.

Engineering crew detected smoke on board vessel. Fire alarm sounded with crew deploying fire suppression procedures. Upon investigation, cause determined as exhaust smoke caused by incomplete combustion of the main engine, with no evidence of fire.
Passenger accidentally cut index finger. Wound was flushed and dressed.
Two uninflated life rafts deployed inadvertently. Vessel slowed to retrieve rafts, with crew noticing upon arrival at port that only one had been retrieved.
Skipper dropping off two passengers who had been rescued from cliffs to be assessed by ambulance. While alongside the wharf, the vessel rolled and the window on the port side of the cabin smashed.
Pilot ladder combination rig was positioned too low, 5m from the waterline.
Skipper sustained fractured ankle while operating vessel

Whilst setting the gear, crew member got their leg tangled in the backbone as it was streaming overboard. Vessel was pulled out of gear and the other 3 deckhands came to their assistance to prevent them being pulled overboard overboard.
Vessel operator mistimed approach to wave and vessel capsized. Crew member and driver were thrown from the vessel. No injuries to either crew or driver.
Stevedore was standing on vessel hatch cover when they fell backwards over a safety rail and landed on a ventilation box.
Vessel crested wave at low speed and at an angle, resulting in the vessel flipping and ejecting the operator
Stevedore was assisting in the loading of containers when a container swung, crushing the injured person between the containers and lashing bars.
Vessel tied up in an area without permission. It was reported that water had been pumped over the port side. Water flowed from the vessel between 10-15 litres per minute.

While attempting to remove an obstruction that was preventing it from retracting, crew member's ankle became trapped and crushed by the vessel's telescopic gangway. Injured crew member was transported to hospital for treatment.
Passenger experienced medical emergency and was airlifted to hospital by rescue helicopter.
Boat turned around. Went hard over to starboard and Master put engine into gear and throttled up to 1000rpm. Rudder stock broke.

Whilst carrying out a training drill, vessel transited over the wake of a nearby boat at speed, causing crew on the vessel's fore deck to lose balance and impact heavily on the hull/bulkhead of the vessel.
Fishing vessel operating outside of operating limits
Passengers onboard vessel at berth assaulted by a group of individuals on the boat ramp.
While alongside assisted vessel hooking up Tow & Raising Anchor, vessel drifted back & touched an underwater rock. No damage or injury to vessel.
Steps/spreader not horizontal at boarding point. Master advised and promised to replace ladder prior to departure.
Operator misjudged wave, causing vessel to flip, ejecting occupants. No injuries to vessel occupants, though vessel engine was damaged
Swimmer struck with rowing blade. Swimmer did not respond to attempts at engagement with vessel master, continued swimming and did not appear to be injured.

Second gear motor failed while running. Vessel completed successful pre-arrival checks as per NZ requirements. On inspecting the motor a burnt smell was found and casing of motor was hot, 110 degrees.
Vessel was operating close to shore break when tower called on radio. Shore break wave became large in front of craft and tipped vessel
Reported damage to the starboard side front of no.5 cargo hold fire hydrant by stevedore during loading of logs.
Crew member was pulling net chains when the chain hooked on their knife holder, releasing their knife and causing a piercing injury to their lower back.
Crew member's face accidentally splashed with diluted chemical cleaning agent. First aid was applied and crew member was taken to hospital for further treatment.
Stevedore slipped on a step on board vessel and scraped their thumb on a grate. They were taken to hospital for treatment.
Vessel struck side on by wave. Crew member sustained an injury to their right ankle.

While berthing vessel alongside another vessel at berth, the vessel starboard quarter which was in way of the aft tyre fender made hull to hull contact with the other vessels port quarter. Small paintwork damage.

While berthing vessel alongside another vessel at berth, the vessel starboard quarter which was in way of the aft tyre fender made hull to hull contact with the other vessels port quarter. Small paintwork damage.
Master was driving upstream when a duck flew into the windscreen cracking it.
As vessel was berthing and the bow thruster shut down. Berthing was aborted and vessel returned to centre of harbour until fault was found. Repairs were made and vessel berthed as normal.
Operator sustained dislocated shoulder while launching vessel
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Passenger experienced serious medical event on charter vessel. The incident was radioed in and the passenger was airlifted to hospital
Upon tow back to port a small hole (approx 8mm) was discovered in hull below forward boiler, port side. Surveyor notified and approved temporary fix. Long term repair to occur.
Passenger fell backwards, hitting their head against their seat. Crew rendered aid as the vessel returned to base where the passenger was transported to hospital.
Passenger's finger trapped in hole in plastic seat. Vessel returned to shore, where emergency services were able to free the passenger
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Skipper reporting back and hand pain from driving the vessel.
Near miss with recreational vessel which approached on a direct heading, requiring ferry to take evasive action to avoid a collision
Cargo dropped onto vessel deck due to crane operator error. No vessel damage or injuries reported
Crew member sustained minor injury to elbow during hauling.
Contact occurred between vessels while at berth resulting in superficial damage to vessel hull
Contact occurred between vessels while at berth resulting in superficial damage to vessel hull
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.

Boat pulled into shallow waters to allow passage of canoes. Once clear, skipper determined the water was too shallow to safely restart engine, so vessel was pushed by crew into deeper water. Trip continued without incident
Deck hose pump seized starting a fire which burned onto main engine causing damage. Fire was put out. Anchor deployed and vessel was towed back into port. No POB injured.
Vessel passed in close proximity and at high speed, ignoring attempts to flag skipper
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Vessel was at anchor when a yacht collided with the vessel, damaging its gunwale and shattering its windscreen, with one of the passengers sustaining minor lacerations from the shards of glass.
Vessel was at anchor when a yacht collided with the vessel, damaging its gunwale and shattering its windscreen, with one of the passengers sustaining minor lacerations from the shards of glass.
Vessel on collision course with another vessel. Skipper got the attention of oncoming vessel and boat turned port side, nearly hitting bow of the other vessel.
Vessel on collision course with another vessel. Skipper got the attention of oncoming vessel and boat turned port side, nearly hitting bow of the other vessel.
The raw water pump failed
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
Boat motor cut out during bar crossing, resulting in the boat flipping.

Two vessels were at idle facing upstream. Skipper was passing car keys over to person in other vessel. As they moved apart one turned starboard and the other turned to port. The two port stern corners touched. Small dent on one vessel

Two vessels were at idle facing upstream. Skipper was passing car keys over to person in other vessel. As they moved apart one turned starboard and the other turned to port. The two port stern corners touched. Small dent on one vessel
Crane boom made contact with head of crew member. First aid was provided to the crew member, who was cleared to continue work later the same day.

Sailing at approximately 9 knots in 20 knots of wind when approached from astern by another recreational vessel. The approaching vessel did not alter course, and with a collision imminent, skipper steered to starboard to avoid an impact

Sailing at approximately 9 knots in 20 knots of wind when approached from astern by another recreational vessel. The approaching vessel did not alter course, and with a collision imminent, skipper steered to starboard to avoid an impact
Passing vessel's engine caught a diving line, dragging diver at speed. Vessel ignored instructions to avoid dive flags in the vicinity prior to the incident
Passing vessel's engine caught a diving line, dragging diver at speed. Vessel ignored instructions to avoid dive flags in the vicinity prior to the incident
Vessel towing ski biscuit swerved to avoid a person in the water, causing ski biscuit to swing and collide with a vessel at anchor.
Vessel proceeding northward at 7.5kt when a fishing boat, travelling southward, collided with the vessel's port bow, sustaining extensive damage to its port side
Vessel proceeding northward at 7.5kt when a fishing boat, travelling southward, collided with the vessel's port bow, sustaining extensive damage to its port side
Jetski was towing children in a ski biscuit when black smoke began to issue from under the driver's seat. Driver jumped into the water before the jet ski burst into flames and sunk.

Sailing vessel experienced a near miss with a parasailing operator that overtook it at speed, with the sailing vessel having to take evasive action to avoid contact between their mast and the parasailing line

Sailing vessel experienced a near miss with a parasailing operator that overtook it at speed, with the sailing vessel having to take evasive action to avoid contact between their mast and the parasailing line
Yacht crossed very close under the bow of outbound tanker, requiring vessel pilot to take action to avoid a collision
Yacht crossed very close under the bow of outbound tanker, requiring vessel pilot to take action to avoid a collision
During IRB driver training vessel positioning errors when crossing breaking waves resulted in the ejection of crew from the vessel.
Charter vessel impacted heavily by waves while traversing harbour bar. Two passengers injured as a result of the impact
The vessel was observed to carry a non compliant pilot ladder arrangement.
Vessel capsized during bar crossing
Passenger aboard passenger ferry injured after slipping on stairs
Crane operator error resulted in container being dislodged from vessel deck onto wharf
The pilot ladder was secured by one piece of rope, which was in poor condition.
Charter passenger sustained serious lacerations after their hand was caught between anchor winch and chain.
Passenger sustained a dislocated shoulder after falling over on board vessel.

Vessel's engine failed during bar crossing. Another vessel arrived to assist, before also experiencing engine failure. Both vessels were grounded and as they began to flood from incoming waves, occupants abandoned their vessels
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Fire on board vessel after a weld on exhaust pipe failed, causing gases to ignite.
Large swell caused vessel stern to dip, with propeller making contact with reefs
Event Location: North Reef, Goat Island Marine Reserve
