Brief Description: Near miss with dinghy while rowing tender back to main vessel. Dinghy did not appear to be aware of their trajectory until tender operator called out, at which point the dinghy diverted course, narrowly avoiding a collision

Near miss with dinghy while rowing tender back to main vessel. Dinghy did not appear to be aware of their trajectory until tender operator called out, at which point the dinghy diverted course, narrowly avoiding a collision
Jet ski capsized. Both passengers picked up and returned to shore by assisting vessel
While exiting harbour, vessel moved out of channel to allow transit of incoming tanker and was drifted into shallow waters by high winds, grounding vessel. Successfully refloated at high tide
Engine overheated after water cooling hose became dislodged
Passenger fell from jetski, sustaining a broken arm.
Lost throttle control on Port engine. Master stopped engine then switched control to manual and back to remote, which reset the fault.
Near miss with jet boat driver that was reported to have been driving erratically
Pilot ladder not properly secured, resulting in pilot falling into the water while disembarking
Boat backed into another vessel, resulting in minor damage to the housing of its motor
Electrical fault caused echo sounder to lose display
Empty fish bins fell while being loaded in the hold, striking the head of a crewperson, who sustained a concussion and cranial laceration
Jetski with two passengers on board capsized 400m from the channel entrance of Lake Taupo.
Combination ladder ropes fastened with single overhand knot
Vessel fishing at anchor when another vessel pulled along starboard side of boat. Reported to have made contact, leaving scratch marks.
Vessel fishing at anchor when another vessel pulled along starboard side of boat. Reported to have made contact, leaving scratch marks.
Vessel grounded after attempting to manoeuvre around a group of canoes
Outboard motor combusted in flames upon ignition of the engine. Extensive damage was caused to the vessels transom and both the main and auxiliary outboard engines.
Notified of fatality on board vessel outside of NZ waters
Vessel hull contact with reef/rocks on the southern side of Bean Rock Lighthouse, damaging the propeller and skeg.

Grounding while coming into Waikawau boat ramp north of Thames 90 minutes before low tide. Reports that ramp website states the river is dredged on a regular basis to allow access for boats up to 5 metres at, or close to, low tide.
Extreme vessel movement in rough conditions resulted in minor injuries to two passengers
Passengers fell from hired jetski. Both passengers were picked up by responding vessel and returned to base
Jet ski collided with the side of recreational vessel
Jet ski collided with the side of recreational vessel
Pallet broke while being loaded onto vessel, resulting in several oil drums falling into water. Crew retrieved drums and initiated ship oil pollution emergency plan clean-up.
Jetski capsized, leading to near drowning of a passenger. Passenger was brought back to shore and resuscitated, then taken to hospital
Passenger injured after they fell from sea biscuit and were struck by tow vessel, which had turned to retrieve them from the water.
Container vessel's approach to port was obstructed by fishing vessels in harbour channel, requiring vessel pilot to manoeuvre around them
Vessel nose dived while sailing, causing crew member to cut their hand on the back of the vessel's windward foil.
Winch failed while lowering roller guide, falling onto the foot of crew member.

A powerboat towing a water skier passed between two rowing boats in close proximity to one another. As the power boat passed, the rope towing the water skier made contact with the head of one of the rowers, causing concussion.

A passenger jumped into the sea from the observation deck while the vessel approaching Halfmoon bay ferry terminal. The vessel's loading ramp was lowered as a platform to retrieve the person in the water
Boat made contact with rocks, resulting in superficial damage to the vessel's port side hull
Pilot ladder steps were not horizontal and unsafe to use. A second ladder was rigged following pilot's refusal to board vessel, with master advised not to use original pilot ladder rigging in future.
Tug made fast to starboard quarter of inbound vessel when suction force dragged tug into the hull of the ship. Funnel made contact with the corner of vessel stern, denting tug's funnel
Tug made fast to starboard quarter of inbound vessel when suction force dragged tug into the hull of the ship. Funnel made contact with the corner of vessel stern, denting tug's funnel
Passenger injured and IRB capsized when cresting wave
Jet skis exceeding limit in speed restricted area
Yacht grounded after it dragged anchor and drifted into shallow water.
Jet boat engine failure. Passengers disembarked and were transferred to another of the operator's vessels
Engine failure on harbour approach. Cause determined to be a faulty engine governor. Following its repair the engine was restarted and the vessel proceeded without further incident
IRB landed heavily after cresting a large wave, with a crew member spraining their ankle in the impact.
Vessel inbound to Havelock made contact with a submerged object near the beacon between Shag and Cullens Points. No damage to the vessel.
Jet Ski passed another jet ski and stopped. Overtaken jet ski could not avoid collision and hit them on the left back corner of their ski.
Deck hand testing pilot ladder fell from height onto deck of pilot launch
Deck hand testing pilot ladder fell from height onto deck of pilot launch
Passenger slipped when boarding, landing on the deck of the vessel and sustaining a minor leg injury.
Vessel under pilotage collided with beacon at port entrance. Poor visibility, tide and strong winds noted as causal factors
Stevedore injured after falling through booby hatch on vessel at berth.
Vessel experienced engine issues, including shuddering and a loss of revs. Returned to berth with assistance from marina tender
Alarm sounded on bridge during departure from berth. Cause determined to be an electronic communication error between the engine room and bridge
Collision between two boats rowing on the Avon
IRB flipped when hit by large shore break after driver mistimed the entry into the water

Vessel came in to berth at Stanley Bay wharf to unload passengers. Whilst tied up and unloading passengers, a member of the public jumped on to the bow of the vessel and then proceeded to jump in to the water.
Collision between two recreational vessels, with one sustaining a cracked hull
Launch ran aground and began taking on water. Two people disembarked into kayaks and were retrieved by a passing vessel.
Five people were rescued from the sea and taken back to shore after their vessel capsized.

Main engine automatically shut down due to an oil mist detection alarm. Chief engineer performed an initial investigation and found no obvious damage. Vessel proceeded to port under auxiliary propulsion for further examination
A log struck a drum causing it to leak hydrochloric acid. The vessel was evacuated and situation managed by the fire brigade.
Digger driver was stowing logs on 5 deck at the aft end when the stow tipped forward into the crossdeck.
Owner towed barge out to a borrowed mooring and secured it, and was later notified that the barge was sinking.
Event Location: Opposite Opononi Boat Ramp, Hokianga Harbour

Brief Description: Experienced engine failure during arrival, suspected to be a starting air issue. Vessel manoeuvred to the berth with tug assistance.
Propulsion engine shredded fresh water pump belt and the hydraulic pump belt.  Vessel idled inshore while replacement belts were fitted, before returning to port on reduced revs
Vessel skipper slipped on stairs, sustaining an injured hand.
Port employee suffered multiple leg fractures and an ankle dislocation after slipping while descending from vessel's hatch lid access point to the main walkway.
Pilot Ladder not secured to ships side 1.5M above Accommodation Ladder Platform per SOLAS regulations
Multiple ladder steps were loose. This allows steps to rotate under foot and could result in a Pilot falling.

Hydraulic hose of excavator on board barge ruptured and hydraulic oil spilled onto the wharf and into the harbour. Spill was contained, wharf cleaned with de-greaser and crew deployed oil spill kit to capture the oil in the water
Winching cable came loose under tension, striking the hand of vessel skipper, who sustained a fractured knuckle.
Pilot ladder stretched on one side causing bottom steps to sit at an angle.
Near miss as kite surfers crossed vessel's bow at close quarters

Starboard engine smoke alarm sounded. Upon investigation, the cause was determined to be a broken fuel line. Passengers were transferred to another service, and vessel was able to return to port for repairs using alternate engine.
Miscommunication when berthing vessel resulted in vessel drifting across berth and making contact with another vessel, with minor damage sustained by both vessels.
Miscommunication when berthing vessel resulted in vessel drifting across berth and making contact with another vessel, with minor damage sustained by both vessels.

IRB operator attempting to guide vessel onto trailer collided with guide poles, puncturing the vessel's starboard side. Operator inexperience and an outgoing tidal flow at right angles to the trailer were contributing factors in the incident
Recreational vessel caught in commercial fishing vessel's lines, resulting in minor contact between vessels. No significant damage or injuries reported in incident

Recreational vessel anchored in channel. Investigating pilot launch found recreational vessel's battery had died and couldn't restart engine. Pilot onboard outbound tanker determined there was sufficient space to navigate around recreational vessel
Vessel foundered in Oneroa Bay with three persons on board. Passengers recovered by Coastguard
Crew member slipped and fell, hitting their head and experiencing disorientation. Treatment was provided on board the vessel before the crew member was brought to shore and transported to hospital.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Yacht grounded upon entry into river bar, and was subsequently destroyed.
Hire and drive PWC damaged in collision with another operator's PWC. Damaged PWC was struck in the rear port side while idle

Jet boat operator misjudged spin manoeuvre and made contact with overhanging lakeside vegetation. A check revealed that no damage to vessel or injuries to passengers were sustained in the incident, with vessel continuing operations thereafter
Vessel caught by a wind gust while attempting to berth, causing vessel to collide with the pontoon. Vessel sustained a small puncture on its port aft quarter and was removed from service for repairs
Fishing vessel lost power to both engines. Neighbouring vessel was contacted for assistance. Crew were transferred to responding vessel and fishing vessel towed back to base
Passenger suffered medical emergency. Skipper provided first aid and contacted emergency services before proceeding to shore, where the  passenger was taken to hospital.
Vessel's pilot boarding ladder was in poor condition, not compliant with SOLAS standards and represent a hazard to pilot boarding
Pilot ladder was in poor condition and represented a safety concern for pilot boarding
IRB experienced engine failure while returning to shore. Vessel occupants disembarked into the surf, and while pulling vessel back to shore, IRB was struck by a wave and capsized.

Vessel lost steering control and requested assistance. Coastguard attended to tow vessel to harbour. Due to rough conditions, vessel tow proceeded cautiously, taking approximately 15 hours, with conditions prohibiting the possibility of crew change
IRB struck by wave and capsized during IRB training exercise
Yacht skipper lost control of vessel and collided with another yacht at berth
Yacht skipper lost control of vessel and collided with another yacht at berth
Vessel anchored in shallow water ran aground at low tide
Vessel grounded on entrance to Ramanui rapid in the mid reaches of the Whanganui River. Initial hull inspection check showed no significant damage.
Passenger slipped on steps, hitting their head and sustaining a laceration. Crew called an ambulance and administered first aid while awaiting its arrival.
Vessel ran aground in low visibility
Water level of river very low, leading to grounding of vessel
Gearbox cooler seawater line ruptured, spraying main switchboard and causing an electrical shortage in the main switchboard
A number of serious defects noted with the vessel's pilot ladder arrangement, representing unsafe conditions for pilot boarding
Vessel observed operating in excess of 20 knots within 10 metres of moored boats in marina
Manrope broke while being revved through eye of sanction. New manropes fitted immediately.
After cresting a peaking wave, a crew member lost balance, causing them to fall and hit their head on the vessel's engine.
Inflatable support boat rolled in waves, with all 3 occupants thrown from the boat. One passenger was struck by the propeller, sustaining minor injuries.
Starboard bridge wing engine RPM indicator not working. Also had a tripping line attached to the bottom step of pilot ladder leading aft.
Crane spreader failed to release, lifting containers as well as the hatch. Foreman jumped out of the way, injuring their knee.
Traveling downstream, river flow pulled boat off line on entering a rapid, causing starboard midships to ride over large boulder. Skipper and passenger ejected from vessel and thrown into water

Recreational boat anchored inside shipping channel, impeding departure of pilot vessel. Recreational boat operator refused to reposition their vessel, with pilot then manoeuvring around boat and proceeding to pilot boarding grounds

Recreational boat anchored inside shipping channel, impeding departure of pilot vessel. Recreational boat operator refused to reposition their vessel, with pilot then manoeuvring around boat and proceeding to pilot boarding grounds
Reported instance of contacting an object which has resulted in significant repairs to vessel.
Salt water cooling pump failed, resulting in water ingress into the main engine. Assistance requested from Coastguard, who towed the vessel back to port
When making the vessel fast, the rope that was thrown down to the tug struck engineer's right shoulder.
When making the vessel fast, the rope that was thrown down to the tug struck engineer's right shoulder.
Near miss with a kite surfer who had fallen from their board. Vessel stopped to avoid them, and crew checked on the condition of the surfer
Near miss with a kite surfer who had fallen from their board. Vessel stopped to avoid them, and crew checked on the condition of the surfer
Crew member fell through galley hatch, sustaining a laceration to the head
Crew member experienced medical event on board vessel. Crew member was transported off the boat and taken to hospital.
IRB ran aground on the West Side of Clark Island.
IRB flipped in surf by a large wave
After transferring pilots to the inbound ship, a crew member climbed to the bottom of the pilot boarding ladder without safety equipment or life jacket.
Vessel flipped by large wave. No injuries were sustained.
Vessel propeller struck object/obstruction and vessel subsequently lost propulsion. The skeg/propeller suffered impact damage and the vessel was towed back to berth.

Kayak operator fell from kayak and became separated from the vessel. They were later spotted by a fishing vessel in the vicinity, picked up and taken to shore, where they were attended to by emergency services
Fishing charter vessel capsized. Coastguard arrived and found one person on the upturned hull, three persons in the water and one on rocks. All 5 POB were accounted for and brought ashore
IRB made contact with a board rider, knocking them from their board. The board rider went under the port side pontoon of the IRB before resurfacing on the starboard stern quarter.
The vessel hit a breaking wave and crewperson slipped and fell to deck of the vessel. In trying to break their fall the crewperson sustained a fractured wrist.
Yacht broke free of mooring and collided with moored fishing vessel
IRB rolled in surf while attempting to crest wave. Rough weather and winds noted by vessel skipper as contributing factors in the incident
Vessel struck and flipped by a wave after experiencing engine failure in breaking surf. A subsequent examination revealed a loose engine cowling cover, which may have allowed water ingress
Vessel was travelling parallel to shore and was struck from the side by a wave, flipping the vessel. Passengers were uninjured and able to right the boat and proceed to shore
Large wave and wind caused the vessel to be lifted from the surface of the water, causing both occupants to be ejected from the vessel

Pilot ladder arrangement was not compliant with SOLAS regulations. Vessel's combination ladder has solid beam across lower embarkation platform, thus impeding clear easy access through trapdoor to reach gangway platform.

Concerns were made about the pilot ladder arrangement, including loose steps rotating under foot, lower section of ladder not level and  man ropes appearing worn. Vessel master advised that the ladder should be replaced immediately and not used again
Launch caught fire approximately 1 nautical mile from shore. Police vessel attended and rescued all four passengers, returning them to shore for medical treatment.
Vessel lost propulsion due to a fault with the throttle system. Port engine was shut down and the vessel proceeded to berth on single engine to discharge passengers.
Vessel lost propulsion while operating after running out of fuel. Skipper contacted coastguard, who were able to provide assistance
Ship crewperson observed testing pilot boarding arrangement on the ship's hull without appropriate safety gear, including a tether, harness or lifejacket.
Pilot ladder non conformity, requiring pilot to transfer  at deck level to a small platform aft of the ladder in order to access the deck

Outbound container vessel encountered a recreational craft with engine failure anchored about half way in the channel at Tanea. Resulted in a close quarter situation (20m) on the starboard bow before the craft was towed away.

Outbound container vessel encountered a recreational craft with engine failure anchored about half way in the channel at Tanea. Resulted in a close quarter situation (20m) on the starboard bow before the craft was towed away.

Skipper failed to observe vessel's trajectory toward a moored yacht while passing through harbour. Upon realising that a collision was imminent, the skipper attempted to reverse but was unable to prevent their vessel colliding with yacht's hull

Skipper failed to observe vessel's trajectory toward a moored yacht while passing through harbour. Upon realising that a collision was imminent, the skipper attempted to reverse but was unable to prevent their vessel colliding with yacht's hull

Engine failed to fire astern when ordered. After multiple attempts the engine fired, though after a substantial delay. This also occurred in two subsequent engine orders. Captain confirmed that the bridge telegraph was prone to malfunctioning

Party of kayakers encountered another kayaker in distress. The injured person was suffering from cold water immersion, and a PLB was activated. A rescue helicopter arrived and transported the injured kayaker for treatment.
A group of divers displaying a dive flag with orange floats in the water. Approaching vessel failed to observe distance from the dive flag and made contact with a diver. No injuries
Event Location: Ngunguru reef, south of Tutukaka entrance

Brief Description: A group of divers displaying a dive flag with orange floats in the water. Approaching vessel failed to observe distance from the dive flag and made contact with a diver. No injuries
Event Location: Ngunguru reef, south of Tutukaka entrance

Brief Description: Vessel ran aground on a reef just south of Lushingtons Bay with 16 people on board
Crew member overbalanced and fell overboard from a vessel at berth, sustaining minor bruising.
Crane spreader malfunctioned while lifting containers from cargo vessel hold, with one side of the spreader becoming detached, dropping both containers into the stow.

Passing vessel collided with a surfacing diver, causing a substantial laceration to their head. Individual was assisted onto the deck of the dive vessel and treated by passengers on board, before being taken ashore and driven to hospital.

Passing vessel collided with a surfacing diver, causing a substantial laceration to their head. Individual was assisted onto the deck of the dive vessel and treated by passengers on board, before being taken ashore and driven to hospital.
Charter fishing vessel impeded passage of container vessel throughout transit into Port of Tauranga. Vessel failed to move to the side of the channel and failed to maintain a radio listening watch.
Charter fishing vessel impeded passage of container vessel throughout transit into Port of Tauranga. Vessel failed to move to the side of the channel and failed to maintain a radio listening watch.
Jet boat crashed and rolled while participating in an organised race event. Both passengers were injured, one seriously, with both parties transported to hospital by helicopter
Jet boat rolled after hitting a pressure wave at speed, resulting in injuries to the driver and navigator.
Fishing vessel hit a submerged object, possibly log. Following this, vessel was taking on water.
The vessel was engaged in fishing activities when it lost propulsion. On inspection noticed that the propulsion shaft had disengaged from the gear box.

Sailing at approximately 6 knots towards Rakino when another recreational vessel approached at approximately 20 knots. Master of yacht required to take evasive action after realising the approaching vessel was not going to alter course.

Sailing at approximately 6 knots towards Rakino when another recreational vessel approached at approximately 20 knots. Master of yacht required to take evasive action after realising the approaching vessel was not going to alter course.
Cargo shifted during unloading, crushing the palm of the left hand of cargo surveyor.
Vessel sustained engine failure after its main engine turbo charger broke down
Jetboat engine failed suddenly without sounding an alarm or warning light. Boat planed for 35m then drifted to the true right where it ran aground on the side of the river.
Event Location: Wilkin River at Kerin Forks Flat

Brief Description: During a mooring operation at Marsden Point, a ship's mooring line became snagged underneath another vessel.

Engine alarm sounded on entering Cutter Channel. Captain advised dead slow restriction and possible engine stop. ME #4 unit had been overhauled and engine immobilized during its most recent port visit

The rowing skiff made contact with a noted marker buoy, the coxswain could not see the buoy due to their position. The skiff sustained significant bow damage and two rowers were taken aboard the safety boat which was nearby. No injures were sustained
Vessel was crossing a channel when two small vessels appeared. Skipper of the large vessel had to do an emergency manoeuvre to avoid contact with the two small vessels.
Pilot ladder not compliant with SOLAS standards
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
Support vessel for a swimmer crossing the Cook Strait made a mayday call after the swimmer collapsed on board the vessel following the conclusion of the swim.
Passenger fell from the stern of vessel after being hit by a wave and received lacerations from the vessel propeller.
Pilot ladder not compliant with SOLAS standards, with multiple loose steps, representing a safety concern for pilot boarding
Jetski severely damaged after collision with object in the water, causing jetski to founder

Multiple operational concerns noted, including poor condition of pilot ladder, failure to advise port authorities of ME restrictions and crew members observed on deck of vessel, outside of safety barriers and without harnesses or safety gear
Person fell overboard during attempted rock landing
Steering cable failed while travelling down river. Vessel broached hard to starboard, with the vessel operator sustaining injuries including bruising and a concussion
Fishing vessel made contact with another vessel while reversing out of its berth at Havelock marina
Both vessel's engines failed repeatedly. Vessel restricted to inner harbour operations until engines inspected and repaired
Ship pilot ladder combination not compliant with SOLAS standards; accommodation ladder less than 5m above sea height.

Outbound container ship lost power. Ordered both tugs to be on standby on port side ready to push vessel away from another vessel in harbour. Engine power returned and proceeded passage without further incident.
IRB crew member sustained a fractured ankle after the vessel landed heavily after crossing a wave at speed during a race event.
Passenger had an asthma attack resulting in a cardiac event. Another passenger assisted with medical attention. Vessel organised a medivac for passenger and vessel returned back to berth.
Fishing vessel reported near miss and threatening behaviour from another unidentified vessel
Vessel operator error caused all three occupants of IRB to fall overboard. No injuries were sustained and all three were returned to shore.
Vessel sunk off Catlins Coast. RCCNZ coordinated a response with another vessel in the vicinity, and a rescue helicopter rescued one adult and child onboard.
Engine failed and would not restart due to an electrical fault
Main engine failed to start head due to lack of air after departure. Aft tug used to stop astern movement and hold position in basin until sufficient air pressure.
Main engine stopped twice during a short transit from the berth outward bound while running at dead slow ahead. It was a problem with the charge cool air. The engine restarted on both occasions.

The vessel had an exhaust problem with unusual emissions of black smoke every time the engine started. Also the vessel was loaded with logs which were making it hard for crew to access the foredeck and unsafe. Crew didn't have appropriate PPE gear on
Fishing nets became tangled in strong winds and fouled propeller
Vessel radioed for assistance after losing propulsion. The vessel was found anchored in water and another vessel went to assist with a tow.
Shortly after departure, crew reported that there was a strong smell of petrol onboard. Crew turned off all equipment and the vessel was towed back to port
Main engine disabled due to problems with the turbocharger.
Vessel ran aground at a speed of approximately 8.5 knots after skipper failed to observe port marker.
Crew member's hand caught in pot hauler while hauling line, causing a crushing injury to their finger.
Chief engineer detected a drop in steam pressure from the boiler burner. While changing the fuel nozzle and electrodes, some fuel combusted, with the engineer receiving burns to their arms and neck.
Large swell snapped vessel's starboard mooring line, causing vessel to ride against its port pile, sustaining damage to its bulwark

Vessel had reduced power after prop bush failure. Skipper attempted to contact Coastguard via VHF radio but was unsuccessful, so they called Coastguard via cell phone, who then deployed their vessel for a tow.

Vessel was cruising steadily when another vessel passed in front and the wake immediately hit the vessel hard. The second vessel made no attempt to slow down or adjust there course as allegedly they seemed to be chasing another vessel out ahead.

Vessel was cruising steadily when another vessel passed in front and the wake immediately hit the vessel hard. The second vessel made no attempt to slow down or adjust there course as allegedly they seemed to be chasing another vessel out ahead.

Crew member's finger stuck in between the door and the frame. First aid was given immediately, an ambulance was arranged and temporary treatment given by the shore doctor before being transferred to hospital.
Crane dropped load of logs approximately 5 metres from truck trailer.
Propeller fouled with rope. Skipper entered the water and was able to free the rope from the propeller
Vessel was swamped by a wave.

Passenger charter near miss with recreational yacht. Yacht passed within 30 metres at a speed of approximately 20 knots. The wake caused a passenger on board the charter vessel to fall and sustain bruising.

Passenger charter near miss with recreational yacht. Yacht passed within 30 metres at a speed of approximately 20 knots. The wake caused a passenger on board the charter vessel to fall and sustain bruising.

Transitioning from a calm area to fast flowing water the vessel slewed, ejecting the skipper. No injuries were sustained and crew member swam to the bank. The vessel continued downstream into a dredge and when recovered, damage was visible to vessel.
Pilot ladder retrieval line was crimped around the bottom spreader so that the eye rested on the step, representing a tripping hazard
Pilot ladder secured to hand railings on deck. Pilot ladder advised chief officer/crew to secure ladder using the dedicated securing lugs welded to the deck
Noncompliant pilot ladder arrangement - man ropes were not of adequate diameter. Pilot requested larger diameter ropes but the crew failed to produce any

While unloading cargo, crew member lost their balance, twisting and injuring their ankle. Crew member was assessed by the ship doctor before being transferred to hospital with a suspected fractured ankle.

Vessel was disabled after its propeller became entangled in rope and netting. A passing boat was contacted for assistance and helped tow vessel to a nearby bay, where divers were able to clear the netting from the propeller.
During berthing, vessel's reverse gear was selected but didn't engage. Vessel continued to drift and made contact with the marina pier.

Passenger fell overboard, was unconscious and had sustained an arm injury. Another passenger on board activated a PLB, and a rescue helicopter was dispatched, with the passenger taken to hospital for treatment.

Jet ski operator proceeded around a river bend on the right hand side when a jet boat approached from the other direction. Jet ski driver attempted to steer clear, but was unable to avoid a collision.

Jet ski operator proceeded around a river bend on the right hand side when a jet boat approached from the other direction. Jet ski driver attempted to steer clear, but was unable to avoid a collision.

Jet ski rounded corner of river on right hand side as a jet boat approached from the opposite direction. Both vessels slowed, and jet ski steered toward the river bank, but was unable to avoid a collision with the jet boat.

Jet ski rounded corner of river on right hand side as a jet boat approached from the opposite direction. Both vessels slowed, and jet ski steered toward the river bank, but was unable to avoid a collision with the jet boat.
When returning to port the vessels port engine experienced erratic RPM. The port temperature alarm sounded and high temp of 110 degrees found. Vessel returned to berth safely on one engine.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
Dinghy skipper reported harassment from two individuals on jet skis, who allegedly attempted to sink the vessel and ran into it at the rear.
Dinghy skipper reported harassment from two individuals on jet skis, who allegedly attempted to sink the vessel and ran into it at the rear.
The skipper turned off and unplugged the shoreside power box. When checking that the neighbours power did not switch off too, the skipper received a moderate electric shock - no injury sustained.
Pilot ladder not compliant with SOLAS standards. Combination platform was less than 5 metres above water at the draft.
The vessels trapdoor combination pilot ladder arrangement not compliant with SOLAS standards
A technician slipped while completing maintenance on a filleting machine. Their finger became trapped in a blade resulting in a cut and suspected tendon damage.
Hatch was accidentally closed on the hands of stevedore, with the stevedore transferred to hospital for treatment.

Master ordered vessel astern on approach to berth, however, engines were put to ahead, resulting in the vessel moving past the berth and grounding on sandy beach. Vessel was then able to move astern and berth, with no apparent damage to the vessel.
Injection quantity piston failed during testing of main engine. Tested engine again and found satisfactory.

The dinghy was appearing to have trouble. Overloaded boat, under powered, no tiller, 2 passengers on board were manually steering. The dinghy took on water, went ashore, then went back out, took on more water and capsized. Wind blew them ashore.
Deckhand sustained mild electric shock after attempting to switch off power at shore based power box
Crew member slipped on deck, landing heavily and sustaining a sprained wrist.
Vessel struck the wharf pile light while berthing.
Aft spring line parted. Upon inspection of line, damage to mooring line strand was noted.
A fishing boat collided with sailboard while entering the harbour. The person on board the sailboard was not injured but the board was damaged.
Pilot ladder arrangement was not compliant with SOLAS standards and NZ Maritime Rules. Ladder lashed to steer bar on deck of vessel rather than to a certified strong point
Pilot ladder in very poor condition. Steps were found to rotate under-foot, and were loose with large gaps between chock and steps.
Vessel was caught by the outgoing tide made contact with rocks on the opposite bank. Vessel was able to clear the rock, no damage or injuries sustained.

Jetboat was proceeding through a narrow river passage when a kayak approached on the right hand side. The jetboat moved left to pass, and as they closed distance, the kayak drifted to the centre, forcing jetboat onto the river's extreme edge.

Jetboat was proceeding through a narrow river passage when a kayak approached on the right hand side. The jetboat moved left to pass, and as they closed distance, the kayak drifted to the centre, forcing jetboat onto the river's extreme edge.

Recreational vessel was proceeding through channel when ferry approached in the opposite direction. As they closed distance, ferry altered towards the recreational boat, forcing it to turn to port, narrowly avoiding a rock formation.
Pilot ladder was in poor condition; loose steps and fibre fraying from rope. Overall condition very poor and noted by pilot that the ladder should not be used again.
Vessel with six passengers on board ran aground in low tide, with one passenger sustaining injuries. Coastguard assisted passengers to shore, with the injured party taken to hospital for treatment.

Ship struck by a large wave while raising anchor, causing vessel to pitch heavily and damaging its windlass, in turn affecting its ability to heave up anchor. The anchor was released and the position was marked for future recovery.
Main engine lost power, due to the quick valve of fuel system not having been reset after previous testing. After a reset the engine was restarted, vessel then made its way back to berth.

Main engine automatic slowdown triggered following sounding of engine's exhaust gas temperature alarm. Following speed reduction, the temperature of the exhaust gas remained high, with the cause determined to be gas leakage from the exhaust valve.
Pontoon deflated at the bow of the vessel after traversing across multiple large waves, the impact of which was believed to have forced air out of the pontoon
Crew member injured after a fall of approximately 2m on board vessel
Pilot ladder combination was in poor condition and not compliant with current SOLAS standards, with recommendation from the pilot to the master for the ladder to be replaced immediately

Pilot ladder arrangement was not compliant with SOLAS standards; ladder steps and spreaders not horizontal, steps rotate underfoot and the ladder is of generally poor quality. Master advised to replace the ladder immediately.
Pilot ladder of poor quality and not compliant with SOLAS standards, representing a potential hazard for pilots boarding vessel.
Passenger slipped and fell while boarding jet boat, sustaining minor injuries

Vessel encountered three swimmers in distress, one of whom was non-responsive. Vessel occupants entered the water and assisted the injured party to shore and administered oxygen from vessel's emergency oxygen unit to aid their recovery.

Individual swimming from beach to 200m marker buoy noticed a power boat heading in their direction. Operator appeared distracted and did not notice the individual in the water until they were approximately 30m away, at which point they swerved away.
Pilot ladder was not compliant with current SOLAS regulations; ladder fastened to deck with 8mm white cord and insufficiently secure to allow safe pilot transfer.

On entering into Stella Passage basin, the engine of container vessel failed to start astern when requested. The vessel was then stopped with tugs and about 2 minutes later engine reset without any further problems.
Pilot ladder combination not compliant with SOLAS standards.
Yacht club training vessel capsized in severe weather, with with one occupant in water for an hour before being rescued.

Cargo Vessel inbound to ferry terminal at Hamer street. Numerous yachts were observed and monitored. 150m ahead they tacked to starboard crossing bow. Cargo Vessel had to sound horn and stop all engines to avoid collision.
Crane wire snapped while offloading cargo onto wharf. No injuries or damage to wharf reported.

Vessel proceeding northward through channel when yacht observed approaching on a collision course. At a distance of approximately 20m, the yacht altered course and motored alongside vessel. After a verbal altercation, the yacht slowed and cut behind.

Vessel proceeding northward through channel when yacht observed approaching on a collision course. At a distance of approximately 20m, the yacht altered course and motored alongside vessel. After a verbal altercation, the yacht slowed and cut behind.

While at anchor on the edge of channel a yacht collided with the port side of the vessel. The bow sprite went through the screen and canopy, making contact with the head of the vessel master. Both vessels were damaged in the incident.
Event Location: Whangarei Harbour, just north of Northport

Brief Description: While at anchor on the edge of channel a yacht collided with the port side of the vessel. The bow sprite went through the screen and canopy, making contact with the head of the vessel master. Both vessels were damaged in the incident.
Event Location: Whangarei Harbour, just north of Northport

Brief Description: Tow rope locker hatch closed on the hand of crew member, causing a laceration to their thumb which required eight stitches.

Vessel with two passengers on board flipped after accelerating over cresting wave. Both passengers were able to get free of the capsized vessel and were treated by emergency services personnel, with the capsized boat towed to nearby boat ramp.
Construction did not meet current SOLAS standards, knots on the end of the manropes. The vessels crew were advised about this.

Vessel was anchored, with three people on board. Another vessel approximately 40 metres long was heading towards the vessel at a high speed. The vessel was very close before they altered course but did not slow down resulting in a near miss.

Operator of jet ski swerved to avoid another jet ski, but was unable to change heading due to wake from nearby boat, leading to a collision between the jet skis. One jet ski operator seriously injured in the incident and transferred to hospital.
A small scaffolding plank dislodged from fitting in the vessel engine room, causing a shackle to be dislodged. The shackle fell 1.5 metres onto a worker below, causing a minor cut to the forehead.

The vessels engines were not syncing. The port engine had smoke, the skipper turned it off, anchored and tried to extinguish the fire. Another vessel helped, extinguishing the fire. The vessel was towed to berth, and assessed by the fire department.

Skipper in training mistook the direction and made contact with log. The log was submerged and not visible. The vessel stopped and skipper ensured both the vessel and passengers were fine before continuing.
A single-masted yacht seemed to have slipped its mooring and beached itself at the mouth of Hellyers Creek opposite the Beach Haven Ferry terminal.
Passenger reported loss of movement of legs. Doctor on board confirmed medical attention was required. Emergency call made and assistance requested to evacuate passenger to Invercargill Hospital.

During fishing operations it was noted that there were drip marks in a localised area on packaged product in the freezer hold. The liquid was identified as Ammonia. Total quantity estimated to have been lost from the bulkhead is under 200 ml.
Pilot Ladder Standards were not met. Upon disembarking it was noticed that the upper wooden treads of the ladder rotated under foot slightly, and the lower rubber treads were badly perished.
Tug vessel involved in turning cargo ship at berth approached to push near port bow and collided with the cargo vessel, denting its hull.
Tug vessel involved in turning cargo ship at berth approached to push near port bow and collided with the cargo vessel, denting its hull.
On delivery voyage from Tauranga to Marlborough Sounds vessel has broken down and has made a distress call to RCCNZ.
Vessel had a mechanical issue with gearbox. Was pulled out of the water to remove leg, collar and gearbox for inspection and repair.
Worker unlashing a 3 high bar let go of the bar after unlocking it from the turnbuckle. The bar dislodged from the container and landed on the lasher, who sustained a fractured collarbone.

Vessel's pilot ladder was not compliant with current SOLAS regulations with safety issues including missing a bottom step, ropes under bottom step lashed together, damaged rubber steps, gaps between chocks and tripping line incorrectly tied.
Passenger was feeling sea sick and fainted.
The vessel arrived to port with no safe crew access to foredeck.
Deckhand received an electric shock from marina's shore-based power box when attempting to switch off shorepower. This was the third incident involving the electrical unit.
Pilot ladder in poor condition and not compliant with SOLAS regulations.

Vessel's pilot boarding trapdoor arrangement inner beam restricts access to vertical pilot ladder section, with use requiring extreme caution. Master advised pilot in attendance that a replacement modification was on the way.

While welding a small hole in a reducer on an ammonia pipe, residue oil ignited in a small explosion. No injuries occurred, and the area was evacuated as a precaution before the chief engineer investigated and approved work to continue.
Pilot ladder not compliant with current SOLAS standards - accommodation ladder not secured to the side of the ship.
Landing barge cut across the bow of pilot vessel transiting through Otumoetai channel. Pilot vessel reduced speed to avoid potential collision, with the barge passing within 100m.
Landing barge cut across the bow of pilot vessel transiting through Otumoetai channel. Pilot vessel reduced speed to avoid potential collision, with the barge passing within 100m.
When hauling Starboard anchor after leaving berth for shipping movement, the anchor was coming home and an open link in the chain failed, dropping the anchor to the seabed.

After scheduled maintenance smoke was observed from the bottom of the turbo. The vessel was stopped and engine shut down, a small fire was extinguished. It's assumed the source of the fire was degreaser residue that had not evaporated away.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Vessel touched a rock, damaging the Port Aft Chine. The driver was attempting to drive centre river as trained, though recent rock removal work meant their line bought the vessel close to a previously hidden rock.
Collision between jetskis travelling at speed, resulting in injuries to two jetski passengers.

As vessel was returning to berth, engine failed to fire astern due to a fault with the forward/reverse control of the vessel, resulting in its bow sliding under the jetty. No passengers were injured nor damage sustained by the vessel in the incident
Repatriation of a crew member from ship's anchorage back to the Marsden Point tug jetty for medical treatment. Reported that the crew member had sustained burns to both of their legs.
The starboard trim tab contacted an underwater shelf which damaged it, when performing a planned stop in the stop sign hole. The planning stop manoeuvre was approximately one metre out of place.
A stevedore fell and sustained injuries.
Client on Jetski fell off and could not get back on. They called base on VHF and rescue vessel located clients unharmed and not in need of any medical attention.

Vessel had decided to wait by Tanea number two buoy when large vessel was rounding Tanea. This was the wrong position in the channel. Master has been advised to report intentions and avoid waiting off a crucial turn at Tanea.

Vessel had decided to wait by Tanea number two buoy when large vessel was rounding Tanea. This was the wrong position in the channel. Master has been advised to report intentions and avoid waiting off a crucial turn at Tanea.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Vessel grounded on Whakatane bar. Gear and equipment shifted across the vessel due to the impact of the grounding, with passengers on board experiencing distress and potential injuries during the incident.
While loading vessel, ship's number two crane failed, dropping four pallets onto the deck.

Police had tasked vessel to conduct a search pattern that was going beyond the Territorial limit. Unit Support Manager was informed that the vessel may be going beyond the Territorial Limit during a search pattern.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.

Concern raised regarding fouled anchor with a 1.5 inch wire of unknown length, picked up at anchorage, laying over both flukes. Operation was carried out with a risk assessment and operated a clear distance from the foul.

Passenger drove on the vessel ramp, and when only the front two wheels where on the ramp, the ramp started raising and the vessel was leaving. The car reversed back to the terminals tarmac and the car plummeted from 1m, damaging the car.
Main engine failure occurred due to coolant water in the engine.
Event Location: 172 nautical miles south east of Napier

Brief Description: Vessel was anchored. Skipper awoke to their vessel starting to drag anchor. They turned the engine over to retrieve and reset the anchor and the propeller touched the rocks. There was damage to the propeller but vessel was able to return to base.
The accommodation ladder was not lashed to ship side, man ropes were not tucked in and the retrieval line was above the spreader and facing aft instead of forward.

While boarding at Days Bay Wharf a passenger was making their way downstairs from the top deck and the back of their calf made contact with the non-slip stair nosing, causing a graze and moderate bleeding. First aid was administered.
The skipper was washing down the top deck of the boat and slipped on an edge. The fall caused bruising to the left side of their ribcage and to their right thigh.
Driver of vessel was assisting unwell passenger when the passenger lost their balance, and both persons fell overboard. Paraflights were there to offer assistance and take them safely to shore.
Hydrostatic release of 25 man SOLAS B life raft on the top deck port side failed, causing it to be deployed over the side. The casing was unable to be recovered.
Bow line of moored vessel tampered with and tightened, so that vessel became grounded in low tide.
A passenger collapsed and was breathing but unresponsive. Met an ambulance at Ruamahanga Boat Ramp where the passenger was transported to Thames Hospital.

All crew were on deck working port side, hauling vessel when another vessel crossed the stern at distance of 150-180 metres. Their track line indicated no sign of deviation from vessels position which resulted in a near collision.

All crew were on deck working port side, hauling vessel when another vessel crossed the stern at distance of 150-180 metres. Their track line indicated no sign of deviation from vessels position which resulted in a near collision.

During departure, the vessel engine was not able to reach required RPM, so pilot ordered the vessel to stop to rectify issue. During the stopping of vessel the engine was fired astern, which managed to fix the issue, which was a stuck inlet valve.
Non compliant pilot ladder arrangement. Combination ladder was less than five metres to the waterline.
Two recreational boats collided during a race event, causing one boat to capsize and multiple passengers across both involved vessels were injured and transported to hospital.

Pilot ordered vessel dead slow ahead on approach to berth. Several attempts were made from centre console with no response from the main engine. Berthing was completed with main engine in local control.

While loading passengers, charter vessel was alleged to have been deliberately rammed by another vessel in the marina, with the skipper of the offending vessel proceeding to then verbally harass the occupants of the charter vessel.

While loading passengers, charter vessel was alleged to have been deliberately rammed by another vessel in the marina, with the skipper of the offending vessel proceeding to then verbally harass the occupants of the charter vessel.

On departure, when outbound off the refinery the engine was put on half ahead but failed due to sensor issue. Aft tug was used to push at the transom and speed close to 7 knots was achieved. Vessel negotiated the turn without problem.
While driving into the lake via the boat ramp the vessel became stuck in soft sand approximately  eight metres from shore and required a rescue tow to refloat. No damage to vessel.
Fatal accident during a commercial operation.
Vessel's pilot boarding arrangement in poor condition; loose chocks and lashings and steps rotating underfoot.
Event Location: Port of Tauranga Pilot Boarding Area

Brief Description: Jet boat proceeding upstream when starboard engine lost power. Skipper manoeuvred the jet boat into the mid stream and radioed for assistance from a back up boat.
Pilot boarding ladder poorly maintained; steps loose that rotate underfoot, securing ropes thin and not sufficiently robust and in poor overall condition.
Event Location: Port of Tauranga Pilot Boarding Area

Brief Description: Passenger lost balance and fell on vessel deck, sustaining a fractured leg. Vessel operations were halted and a medevac was arranged to transfer passenger to hospital.

Vessel turned from the main shipping channel into a cross channel marked with red and green channel markers. The first red marker was unlit, causing vessel to drift off course and ground on the edge of the channel.
Accommodation ladder not secured to ships side, but secured to pilot ladder. Pilot informed Master, who reported they had a magnet securing item onboard to secure accommodation ladder.
Oyster barge collided with a navigation marker located in the inlet between Cowan Bay Rd and Pakupuka Rd, breaking the post.

Pilot ladder in poor condition; Multiple loose chocks and steps which rotate underfoot. Pilot notified vessel master that this ladder must be replaced, and would not be used by Port of Tauranga pilots.

Vessel towing two parasailing passengers struck by unexpected gust of wind, causing parachutes to roll and parasailers to rapidly lose elevation and land heavily in the water, with one sustaining minor injuries.

Vessel signalled distress in the early morning with water ingress via a hole in the hull. An hour later, the bilge pump failed and vessel began to sink. Coastguard arrived and uplifted single vessel passenger. Vessel sank with 1000L of fuel onboard.
Chief Engineer noticed a smell of Freon (refrigerant gas) coming from the engine room. The Chief Engineer tightened the isolation valves to stop the leak and called a contractor back to the vessel.

A worker has reported a serious near miss as a wharf based crane was moving a load of fish from the vessel to the wharf. While the load was being moved horizontally the strop broke which caused the load to shift and the crane to wobble dramatically.
Event Location: Bledisloe North East (B2), Port of Auckland

Brief Description: Charter vessel moved ahead of passenger ferry coming into berth. Ferry sounded several warning  blasts before swinging hard to port to avoid a collision.
Charter vessel moved ahead of passenger ferry coming into berth. Ferry sounded several warning  blasts before swinging hard to port to avoid a collision.

Jetboat got towed by another jetboat, until they got stuck downstream. The towing jetboat attempted to nudge the other vessel clear, but rode up on back of the vessel, flipping the jetboat and trapping a passenger underneath for a short period.

Near miss was recorded between a large vessel and a yacht. The vessel blasted their whistle to alert the yacht, no action was taken. The vessel had to slow down and alter course to the edge of the channel to avoid contact.

Near miss was recorded between a large vessel and a yacht. The vessel blasted their whistle to alert the yacht, no action was taken. The vessel had to slow down and alter course to the edge of the channel to avoid contact.
Passenger stepped backwards and fell down a stairwell resulting in them requiring medical attention.
Collision between two rowing skiffs, with one passenger requiring treatment at hospital for a minor injury.

Vessel was on course, doing a port to port pass when another vessel altered their course. No warning or contact was attempted by them. Vessel had to take sudden action by slowing, to avoid collision and they passed at approx 40-50m down stbd side.
When disembarking, the pilot ladder had multiple loose chocks and the steps rotated under foot. A replacement is recommended.
A crane had a failure at the port and a load of logs fell over the vessel. No injuries.
Passenger fainted and became unresponsive. Coastguard assisted in evacuating them from the vessel. They were taken to shore to receive medical treatment.
Vessel lost power to the starboard engine. Skipper drove boat back to the workshop jetty with port engine. Swapped boats out and continued trip. Cause was a blown fuse.

Vessels main engine stopped due to low lube oil pressure to camshaft. Occurred when vessel was entering the channel. Master was pilot training under supervision. Two tugs were secured and the tugs escorted until vessel was back.

A valve was inadvertently knocked and this caused a dead head of the main starboard winch. Then the hydraulic winch motor fractured causing oil to flow onto the deck. The winch system was stopped and approximately 20 litres of oil entered the sea.
When set for departure,  main engine failed to start due to an issue with the start air system. Sailing was aborted, lines re-run ashore, tugs let go and gangway re-rigged.
Manropes were in poor condition with damaged fibres in strands. Master advised to replace them and the next port pilots were advised too.
Inflatable rescue vessel struck by large wave, twisting the craft seaward and resulting in the vessel operator sustaining a fractured ankle.

Bulk Carrier inbound under pilotage when a yacht involved in a race cut across the bow of the ship. Vessel sounded several blasts that were not heeded by yacht, before ship made small course alteration and brought engine back to slow ahead.
Non compliant pilot ladder arrangement; ladder in poor condition, with multiple loose steps.
Event Location: Port of Tauranga Pilot Boarding Area

Brief Description: A call from the shore reported that smoke was near Whirinaki. This was investigated and two people onboard were located. They had an engine room that had been extinguished. Coastguard took them under tow to Napier Harbour.
Second engineer was performing maintenance on galley air conditioning unit when they slipped and caught their finger between the drive belt and pulley, crushing one finger of their right hand.
PLB activated following jet boat crash with four passengers on board. Two passengers were airlifted to hospital for treatment, while another sustained minor injuries and was treated on the scene.
Noncompliant pilot ladder arrangement. Pilot ladder rigged less than five metres to the waterline.
Crew member suffered a medical emergency on board vessel. Coastguard notified, who uplifted the injured party and transferred them to shore for ambulance pick up.

Pilot ladder rigged with man ropes. When the pilot vessel crew performed durability checks on the pilot ladder, one of the man ropes parted. Upon inspection, the man ropes were found to have rotted and were in urgent need of replacement.

Ferry caught by a gust of wind while exiting marina, pushing the vessel sideways. Port window of the ferry made contact with the anchor of another vessel at an adjacent marina berth, causing the ferry's window to break.

Crew member experienced medical episode during race event. The vessel slowed down, and beached the boat. Other lifeguards and emergency services came and attended to the crew member. She was airlifted to hospital.
Rudder failure on passenger ferry while berthing. No damage sustained by the vessel or wharf.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
After a wave hit the side of the vessel causing a sudden roll, crew member's fingers were caught between door and the frame.

Broken skin fitting flooded the back lazarette. The crew member notified shore contact, and Coastguard. They turned on emergency pumps, used a pump from Coastguard to pump and sped up pumping of water. Found broken skin fitting and plugged the hole.
Man ropes had knots or splices on the ends or in the length of the rope.

When moving off berth the vessel caught the wind and contacted the floating pontoon causing a jolt. The wind pushed the vessel onto the wharf as it was going astern. A small puncture of the superstructure approx. 1.5m above the waterline was caused.

When changing trawl doors, a crew member used a pipe to apply more leverage to the lever. When the lever released, the pipe struck their jaw, causing an injury to their tongue and a brief loss of consciousness.
Lasher dropped a 3-high bar, hitting the lasher below.
Report from Marlborough Marine Radio that the vessel had grounded.
Event Location: Greville Harbour, Rangitoto ki te Tonga / D'Urville Island

Brief Description: The ladder was fixed to deck with only shackles around the side ropes. After departing the vessel, a ship's crew member was seen climbing down the ladder to re secure the messenger, without either a safety harness and line or lifejacket.
Port worker slipped while unloading cargo and suffered a broken ankle.
The AIS system failed, resulting in no AIS information being transmitted to other ships.

Water entered onto the boat, when the driver dived into the water and didn't latch the canopy properly. A mayday call was made, and life jackets were put on. Another vessel transferred the passengers to land, and the boat was towed to shore.
Vessel blown by winds during berthing. Crew could not get bow line on before boat drifted off on the ramp/rocks.
Vessel lost propulsion  and was drifting 16 miles offshore due to a failure of the propeller shaft sealing system. Tugs were dispatched and vessel proceeded under tow to anchorage in New Plymouth.
Collision between aquaculture vessel and yacht.
Stevedore got trapped between ship and container – crushing their helmet. No injuries reported.
The step-chocks were loose on multiple steps. The steps rotate under foot and present a risk of pilot falling from the ladder.
Crew member sprained their shoulder while lifting a pot onto the vessel's top deck.
Crew member was being taught how to guide in pots by the skipper and was struck on the head by a pot.

When flushing the outboard, two wires on the base of the vessel outboard leg were noticeably warm. Battery was isolated and contacted Suzuki agents the next morning. This symptom is suggestive of a wiring earth issue on the boat.
The lowest 2 rubber steps are deformed and present a risk of pilot slipping. The crew were informed that the ladder must be replaced.

Crew found water ingress in the bilges under the main engine and began to pump out the water. Divers found the hold quickly and put a piece of wood in the hold to stop the leaking. They pumped for 40 minutes and brought the leak under control.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
Crew member's hand stuck in the plate freezer resulting in a crushing injury to their fingers.
Ballast water treatment system reactor shutting down.

All rudder angle indicators stopped reading except for one. An engineer was on standby in the steering flat to verify actual rudder angle and take steering if needed. One rudder angle was used in passage. Loose wire connections were the cause.
Deckhand sustained an injured knee while working aboard vessel.
Vessel collided with an anchored vessel at approx 0400. They both made their way safely to Marsden Cove Marina. There was some debris left in the water.

In a rough sea state, a crew member fell forward, landing head first in the scuppers. The bang caused them to briefly lose consciousness and sustain a cut to their left ear. Coastguard removed them from the ship and they spent the night at hospital.
Event Location: Hauraki Gulf, east of Motuketekete Island.

Brief Description: Allegations reported about several issues on board with the equipment, which is unsafe and could result in injury.
While handling fish product, a fish spike become lodged in the hand of a crew member, requiring surgical removal.
When using crane 1, the conduit pipe fell from the crane jib approx. 18 metres. No injuries occurred, and operations were stopped while the crew assessed the situation.
Passenger tripped while disembarking the vessel, grazing their left knee and palm.
Crew member on fishing vessel had a hatch lid close on their hand, crushing their wrist.
The pilot ladder was observed to be at an angle, with the steps not horizontal. The Master and crew were advised, and will replace the ladder prior to departure.
Jet ski rolled after cresting a wave. Driver landed awkwardly and sustained two fractured vertebrae.
Crew member collapsed while fishing and struck their head on the boat as they fell.
The pilot ladder was not secured to the ship’s side 1.5m above the boarding platform. Master was advised of this and that magnets should be used as there were no securing point in the hull.

The weight of the pilot ladder was carried by the spreader which was resting on the lower platform, with the side ropes above being slack. The master was advised of this, and asked for it to be correct at the next port.

During a race a competitors steering wire snapped resulting in the boat taking a hard right turn at 100kph (mechanical failure). The boat was towed to shore. Ambulance escorted one person to hospital, ad the other person sustained minor injuries.
The boat caught some waves while rounding a buoy, causing the occupants to be ejected. Other boats picked up the occupants and took them back to shore.

The ships boom extension hydraulic rams separated with part of the ram striking the deck. The crane was not under load at the time of failure. Spilled hydraulic oil onboard was cleaned up and appropriately disposed of.
Main winch started while crew member was splicing wire, briefly trapping them between the trawl wire and the spare trawl door storage rack.

A leak developed in an oil capillary line on the main engine. When oil capillary line was isolated to address the leak, the engine registered low oil pressure and shut down resulting in the vessel returning to Port for repairs.

When departing, a dead slow ahead was ordered. Engine was only able to produce 1.5 kts headway. Master informed that the vessel was manoeuvring on low sulphur fuel and they needed to switch over to Diesel, whilst vessel was exiting the Basin.

The launch caught the bottom of the Pilot ladder and the ladder parted from below the bottom spreader. The lack of ladder wasn't observed until launch. The ladder was used in conjunction with manropes for departure. A lee was given for disembarkation
A yacht was in the middle of shipping channel while container vessel was inbound. When avoiding the yacht the vessel came close to grounding on Matakana Island.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.
Liquified gas and carbon dioxide in a 33 litre container leaking on to the vessel. The vessel has isolated the area of the ship. The ship is docked at the Wharf Five Port of Napier.
Vessel with passengers on board declared a pan pan, due to a fuel issue. The vessel would not make it back to land so another vessel assisted with a tow back to shore.
Vessel with passengers on board declared a pan pan, due to a fuel issue. The vessel would not make it back to land so another vessel assisted with a tow back to shore.
Ladder had been secured by a steel rod between ladder side ropes and also lashed to a nearby pipe. Current method shows crimps adjacent to chocks loosening from taking load of ladder.
Stevedore suffered a crushed finger injury while loading containers aboard the vessel.

The Navigation light was hanging by just its wiring. The mounting bracket appeared badly corroded. The vessel moved astern so that the Navigation light was no longer directly above bollard which aft springs were on.

When the anchor was freed and the main engine was engaged there was contact with another vessel. The stabiliser arm made contact twice, but no damage evident. The lack of full main engine power seemed to be a contributing factor.

When the anchor was freed and the main engine was engaged there was contact with another vessel. The stabiliser arm made contact twice, but no damage evident. The lack of full main engine power seemed to be a contributing factor.

Vessel lost power to port side when returning to wharf. The power was reduced to starboard side and pointed downwind to maintain steerage and weather helm. The vessel proceeded back to berth cautiously at reduced power.
Crew member slipped when handling and filleting fish. The knife pierced their glove and cut their little finger.

High load and black smoke were observed on the starboard and port main engines. At idle speed 650RPM and 0 pitch, the engine load increased slowly up to 100 percent that lead to the main engine failure.
Vessel's ballast water treatment system not operating properly.
Vessel grounded in Arkles Bay. Anchor rope and anchor attached.
A leaking CO2 container on the container ship. A 250 meter exclusion zone had been put in place around the vessel. At 08:25 the CO2 container ceased venting.
The vessel lost steering and started drifting, with 23 passengers on board. The vessel was towed by another vessel and offloaded the passengers at the passage, before it was towed back to Picton.
Crane 4 had an empty 40ft reefer on its hook and was coming out to the wharf. The container free fell for a few metres before the brakes kicked in. No injury or equipment was damaged.
While picking up a sunk line the crew threw a hook and the vessel drifted over the rope and the propeller became entangled. The vessel then hooked up to the line and contacted shore person.

While crew were discharging an ISO tank, a 6m steel rail detached from the tank and fell onto the deck of the ship. Initial investigations suggested that a weld on the aft end of the tank failed. No personnel were injured in the incident.
Old yacht dragged its mooring. Found on rocks near Fisherman's Wharf.
Event Location: South side of Little Shoal Bay

Brief Description: While enroute to the city, port engine alarmed for high temperature. Skipper reduced revolutions, checked engines and found a lot of steam and coolant pooled on top.
Vessel lost steering due to a damaged rudder after a collision with an object in the water. Vessel towed back to port by another fishing vessel in the vicinity.
Event Location: 15nm NNE of Gable End Foreland, East Coast

Brief Description: Fatal recreational boating accident.
After vessel stalled, driver restarted engine in gear, leading the vessel to launch forward, colliding with trees on the riverside and flipping.
Pilot ladder not secured properly.

Crew member was setting line between pier and vessel at aft port side. Vessel pulled away from the pier to starboard as the mooring line was being set on the deck mounted bollard, causing laceration to the thumb of the crew member.

Non compliant pilot ladder. Ladder stretched resulting in steps no longer horizontal. Vessel owner/master informed by port authorities that the ladder must be replaced and will not be used by port pilots again.
Member of the public released the bow line of water taxi at berth. While recovering the situation, the skipper broke the vessel's starboard bow rail.
Fatal medical event during a commercial operation.

A combination ladder was requested by pilot during transfer. During rigging, crew appeared unfamiliar with equipment, with accommodation ladder not secured, and the pilot ladder not adequately secured.
Vessel capsized while performing 'donut' manoeuvres in calm conditions. All five passengers on board were recovered from the water by nearby vessels, with capsized vessel towed to nearby beach.

Engine vibrations and fluctuating RPMs experienced while exiting port. Cause believed to be RPM setting initially set too close to critical RPM's on the B/W telegraph and not adjusted when command transferred to bridge control.
Fishing vessel lost power on approach to berth due to a loss of hydraulic pressure, drifting toward and making contact with another vessel at berth, resulting in damage to both vessels.
Fishing vessel lost power on approach to berth due to a loss of hydraulic pressure, drifting toward and making contact with another vessel at berth, resulting in damage to both vessels.
Vessel tied up on the upsteam mooring at Tieke at 1630. Vessel checked at 0745 on the 22nd no boat and only rope attached to the pole. 0845 vessel found in backwash at Ngaporo rapid. No damage.
Aquaculture vessel observed moored and loaded with aquaculture product. The following day, the vessel was found grounded at low tide, having flooded at some point in the preceding 24 hours.
While preparing pilot ladder rigging, crew member's hand caught between winch line and sheave, resulting in a serious laceration and possible dislocation of one of their fingers.
Pilot ladder station had no deck securing points. No manrope stanchions. Whole arrangement was secured ad-hoc.

Vessel experienced steering gear failure during departure from Port Chalmers.  Rudder was stuck at hard to starboard, with steering unresponsive to attempts to alter steering. Vessel held in position by tugs, before returning to port for assessment.
Passenger experienced medical event on board vessel. CPR was administered by ship crew before the passenger was transferred to a medical facility.

Vessel broke down with two parasailors in air. They drifted down and water landed. The crew of nearby vessel offered to pick up the 12 passengers and was towed by chase boat of Bay of Islands Yacht Club to Paihia.
Passenger on dive trip exhibited symptoms of decompression sickness. Diver was transported to medical facility for treatment.
Vessel's engine stalled causing it to collide bow first into the stern of another vessel. Minor damage done to Trawler. Vessel speed was less than 5 kn.

Skipper berthed vessel and was notified early the following day that the vessel had sunk at its berth. It appeared to have become stuck underneath the wharf, where the rising tide listed the vessel, allowing water ingress through the open aft hatch.
Crew member tripped over hatch, landing on hand and sustaining a fractured finger.
Propeller damaged after colliding with an underwater object. Vessel returned to base on port engine and placed in dry dock for repairs.
Assault onboard vessel. Person had concussion symptoms and was assessed as requiring medical attention. Ambulance service notified RCCNZ for MEDEVAC co-ordination.
Crew person was drilling holes through the fenders and panels when their glove caught the chuck. This twisted their finger, requiring medical treatment.
Crane grapple malfunctioned and partially opened while heaving logs, resulting in two logs falling from height into the ship's hold.
Equipment failures: MF/HF radio not operational due to a failure of the antenna tuning unit. Air compressor not operational.
Members of ship's crew observed walking on the outer edge of the bulwark without harnesses or safety equipment.
Vessel experienced main engine failure during departure from Auckland harbour. Tugs were deployed and pilot remained on vessel until it reached anchorage.
On departure from Wellington harbour, vessel's main engine failed.  Ship was brought to anchor with tug support and experienced ongoing engine issues before returning to berth.

Non compliant pilot ladder; during disembarkation, pilot noted that the steps were loose and rotated underfoot, in generally poor condition and in contradiction to the vessel's signed VAIS stating the ladder was in compliance with SOLAS standards.

Non-compliant trapdoor type pilot ladder arrangement, with the ladder not resting against the ships side. Pilot discussed with master and provided copies of regulations and solution used by other vessels with similar arrangements.
While unhooking the hook and chain from the cranston on the wharf apron, the cranston has dropped which was attached to the ships crane severing stevedore's thumb.
Heave of logs slipped while being loaded onto the vessel, hitting a digger operating in the vessel hold. No injuries were sustained in the incident.
Vessel capsized after being struck by swell while making a tight turn into Te Matuku bay.

Fishing vessel operating in the middle of channel entrance, obstructing passage of large vessel traffic. Inbound ro-ro vessel sounded horn to alert fishing vessel, before it passed within 20m of the vessel's port side.

Fishing vessel operating in the middle of channel entrance, obstructing passage of large vessel traffic. Inbound ro-ro vessel sounded horn to alert fishing vessel, before it passed within 20m of the vessel's port side.
Vessel declared mayday advising of a fire in the engine room before downgrading alert to urgent. Vessel was then towed to harbour by another vessel in the vicinity.

A hose blew on the gearbox when the vessel was coming into Havelock wharf to unload. The anchor was readied for deployment, but another vessel came along side and manoeuvred the vessel into the wharf where the hose was fixed.

While loading logs using a log lifter, the lifter released wire ropes with lift approximately 2 meters above cargo on ship. There were no personnel in the area when the event occurred. Lifter was replaced and operations resumed.
Crew member reported chest pain. Crew member was evacuated from the vessel and taken to hospital for further observation.
Incinerator not functional. Spare parts ordered for arrival in Auckland.

Vessel's anchor became caught on the seabed, causing the bow to dip below the waterline with the rising tide. Vessel skipper activated an EPIRB and set off a smoke flare, with coastguard arriving to cut the anchor chain and free the vessel.
Stevedore tripped and fell on open grating sustaining minor injuries.
Crew member slipped on bulwarks while boarding the vessel at wharf.
Skipper noticed Russian vessel approaching and ordered deck boss to haul in gear. Reported that vessel hard to turn starboard to avoid collision.

Heavy leaking from scrubber pipes during departure from port Napier. Scrubber pipes were temporary repaired by crew but with no success. Request to use non compliant fuel while in NZ territorial waters.
Pilot Vessel made contact with vehicle carrier, with suspected damage to one of the propellers. Pilot Vessel was lifted out of water for inspection.
Pilot Vessel made contact with vehicle carrier, with suspected damage to one of the propellers. Pilot Vessel was lifted out of water for inspection.
Vessel hit rock in Breaksea Sound. Was not taking on water, extensive damage to bow and bulwarks. Made temporary repairs to bow and then sailed for Bluff.
The bottom of the motor and propeller guard sustained damage from striking a clay reef.
Jetboat was heading downstream on the Shotover River close to the trailers corner when the starboard engine suddenly stopped.
During final stages of berthing in Ports of Auckland, vessel's main engine failed to fire astern, due to a failure of the engine's starting air compressor.
Main gyro and all bridge repeaters not stable when underway.
Gyro error aboard vessel and excessive trim after 12 hours of loading.
Non-compliant pilot ladder; loose steps that rotate underfoot, and with steps no longer horizontal due to the ladder having been stretched.
Vessel reported to pull out in front of private boat while leaving wharf, causing severe movement to passengers.
Helmsman error in course direction when coming into port.

Starboard side ladder in poor condition. One side rope stretched to the extent that the steps in the lower half of the ladder were not horizontal and were loose. Pilot requested the ladder be replaced prior to sailing.
Crew person's hand caught between the skid and the trawl door, sustaining cuts and bruises.
Ladder ropes not rigged correctly. Pilot supervised re-rigging of ladder to meet compliance before departure.
Master only qualified to operate vessel during daylight hours. Mechanical issue and resultant delay in returning to base lead to master operating outside of these hours.
Issue with releasing the towline from towed vessel resulted in eye of tow line dropping in to the water and getting sucked in to the jet intake.
Issue with releasing the towline from towed vessel resulted in eye of tow line dropping in to the water and getting sucked in to the jet intake.

Non-compliant pilot ladder. Steps loose and rotate underfoot and in generally poor condition. Pilot in attendance inspected a second ladder held in storage in better condition and advised vessel master to use this ladder instead.
Securing rope for pilot ladder thin and of poor quality, and with the ladder itself in poor condition. Pilot advised master that the ladder is to be replaced prior to its next arrival at port.
Crew member sustained an injured finger after it was pierced by a hook while setting the vessel's longline.

Vessel suffered failure of its main engine turbo.  Discussed at ADT-2978. 6 studs broke on air cooler mounting box, and 8 more were found to be loose. All replaced with OEM parts. Instruction issued to fleet to check at 24000 hours.

During trip, master was alerted by a loud bang followed by the failure of the port engine. Vessel unloaded passengers before returning to base on single engine. Inspection subsequently revealed a missing blade on port engine propeller.
