Ferry on route when engine shutdown. Bilge and fire alarm sounded. Passengers returned safely to berth.
While responding to a rescue, the patrol IRB vessel hit a wave unexpectantly and a crew person was airborne and ejected from the vessel.  No injuries.
During maintenance in the plant room, ammonia was released via the thread on a partially unscrewed jacking spindle cap. The refrigeration engineer re-secured the cap to make the area safe.
Luff wires went slack resulting in the crane jib free falling 2 metres.

Jetski with sled attached ran aground on a sandbar. This caused the master to fly over the handle bars and onto the front of the craft, hitting their head. The crew member on the sled fell forward hitting the jetski, receiving moderate injuries.
Event Location: Opoutere Beach, estuary at southern end, Whangamata

Brief Description: During a grid search for missing person, a Rescue Water Craft (RWC) has cut across bow of IRB. To avoid collision IRB turned into wave and this resulted in vessel being swamped.  No injuries.
Two teenagers jumped off the back of the vessel after it entered the inner harbour. They swam to No.2 Wharf and climbed up. Vessel turned around and picked them up to return to Lyttelton.
The pilot ladder was non compliant.

Vessel owner was unable to make contact with couple on hire vessel. Vessel had rolled over on beach and passengers set off EPRIB.  Owner dispatched another boat to retrieve passengers and take them to the boat ramp.
Hydraulic oil leak from deck hydraulic oil cooler. Less than 500ml escaped into sea.
Vessel capsized after being struck by a wave.
A wave hit the stern causing the vessel to flood and capsize.
The customer hit the harbour bridge pile at low speed. No injuries occurred.
Collision between two jet skis. One injured person transferred to Takapuna for medical treatment.  Harbour master towed vessel back to berth.
Crew member was hit on the head by the vessel boom. The vessel returned to shore where an ambulance took the crew member to hospital.

Waves began to spill over the boat stern. The boat capsized and four passengers fell overboard. One child was trapped under the vessel. Police met the boat and passengers at the shore and the child was rescued. All members had life jackets on.
Whilst standing on the foredeck of vessel, passenger lost footing, fell backward and knocked back of head on handrail/bulwarks. Due to age of passenger, ambulance was called to meet at wharf.
The vessel was sliding freely with the slipping cradle to the water after the cradle wire rope failed. The anchor was dropped to save the ship.
Crew member slipped from the weather wheel, injuring their lower and middle back. They returned to shore, where the crewmember was taken to hospital.
Passenger's hand became caught in the mainsheet, injuring two of their fingers. They were taken to the Medical Centre for treatment.
Vessel surged forward with increased throttle, and an unsecured crew member lost balance and fell, striking their head on towing post. Crew member was taken to hospital by ambulance.

The incoming tide caused the barge to list heavily. Water entered the starboard engine via the wet exhaust causing internal damage. Water also entered the starboard engine bay via the engine hatch, submerging the engine and gearbox.
A broken mayday call was made in the area, where someone had fallen overboard. Many boats responded, the person was in the water for about 30 mins before they were picked up.
Main engine (ME) developed water leak from a connection on a cylinder head. ME was shut down and repairs made. No damage and hauling fishing gear resumed.

A large wave caused the front windows to break which lead to the boat filling with water and capsizing. The two crew members got out after a few attempts and made it to the life raft that had deployed. The vessel sank within five minutes.
Cruise ship passenger fell down steps, injuring their left forearm and shin.

The forward spring mooring line parted while the vessel was at berth. The officer on watch initiated the mooring lines parting procedure. Emergency mooring operations, propulsion and thrusters were requested. The propulsion and thruster came online.
The vessel lost power and propulsion in rough conditions, with wind pushing vessel toward the shoreline. Both anchors were used to prevent the vessel drifting ashore and grounding.
The vessels anchor started to drag due to high winds. Tugs were called and contact with land was made to avoid grounding.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

Crew member was putting the ladder up to exit the fish-hold and knocked the aluminium board which consequentially fell down and crushed their thumb. This resulted in a fracture to the tip of their thumb.
Jet ski caught the edge of shallow mud flat and stopped suddenly, ejecting the operator off the vessel. No injuries to person or damage to  jet ski.
The vessels VDR was reporting an error code which was believed to be capsule (float free). The vessel had a defect as per SOLAS V.
Jet ski - support search and rescue of 12 people after report of sinking waka. Jet ski motor sucked in loose rope from vessel. Life guard unable to clear so jet ski towed back to beach by Coastguard.
The pilot ladder was poorly constructed and there were loose chooks on the lower spreader.

The operator swung the load of machine lifted packs of timber around and the weight of the load tilted the machine badly lifting a set of wheels off the ground. The load was placed on the ground and discharge stopped. No injury or damage occurred.
Boat passenger sustained superficial injuries after falling over on the vessel.

When leaving berth, the vessels engine kicked ahead and stopped. This happened several times, pilots used tugs to keep the vessel safely in the gap. After a couple of minutes, the vessels engines ahead movements were steady and vessel proceeded.
Master was stung on the hand by a bee and was admitted to hospital after experiencing a serious reaction.
Vessel impacted side of wharf after failed attempt at securing mooring lines.  This resulted in 150mm fracture in aft port side of hull.   No injuries.
Close quarter situation with an out-bound tanker after pilot had disembarked, requiring course alteration to avoid collision.
Anchor became stuck on the seafloor. On the final attempt the swell caused the vessel to rise and the bow roller unit was wrenched off the woodwork.
A minor leakage of exhaust gas occurred from the main engine unit. The exhaust gas pipe flange gasket ruptured. Repairs occurred.
Stevedore dropped lashing bar, hitting their forearm and resulting in a fracture.
Grounding - hit uncharted submerged rock.
Off the beach in an IRB conducting event guarding. Crew hit a wave and capsized the vessel. Life guards thrown from vessel. No injuries.
Jet ski capsized while operating in big waves and rough conditions.
While undertaking a rescue, due to swell, one vessel came down on top of the other vessel.  No injuries and minimal damage.
Event Location: Bay of Plenty (north of Motiti Island)

Brief Description: While undertaking a rescue, due to swell, one vessel came down on top of the other vessel.  No injuries and minimal damage.
Event Location: Bay of Plenty (north of Motiti Island)

Brief Description: Sailing yacht coming from astern. Began to pass on port side (leeward) and master lost control of their vessel. It cut across bow of another vessel and was struck amidships. They were at 20knots.
Near miss between outbound log carrier SOLAS vessel and small fiberglass vessel anchored in shipping channel in Port of Tauranga.  Pilot reported to Harbour Master for action.
Near miss between outbound log carrier SOLAS vessel and small fiberglass vessel anchored in shipping channel in Port of Tauranga.  Pilot reported to Harbour Master for action.
Moving bulk vessel from one berth to another to resume loading. When running stern mooring lines, lines were caught in propeller wash and fouled the propeller. Engine stopped immediately.

Wave formed on right side of IRB. This wave was not running parallel to the shore. Turned craft to left causing right side to rise. Two crew on left pontoon and one crew person on right fell overboard. No injuries.
Vessel master discharged waste at wharf after having forgotten to perform the process at sea.
During IRB training session, operator opted to head straight into the wave to avoid the  break. Vessel went vertical and landed heavily, with one passenger sustaining a fractured foot.
Vessel crossing the bar when the boat was capsized by a wave. Both occupants were not wearing a lifejacket.
The wave size and force was stronger than the master anticipated, resulting in the craft striking the wave head on and flipping over. No injuries or damage occurred.
Main rudder indicator stuck on Starboard 10. Pilot unable to communicate with ship master or crew. Unable to hold a spring line or run mooring lines safely.
Vessel reported damage to their gangway due to movement of another vessel at the same berth.
Vessel reported damage to their gangway due to movement of another vessel at the same berth.
A passenger fell in the cabin toilet and suffered a fractured arm. They were treated by they ship's doctor before being transferred off the vessel.

As part of pre departure preparations, fuel was shifted between internal tanks. During this process a tank overflowed through a breather and overboard. Approximately 42 litres of diesel was lost overboard.
Crew member hit on the head by the vessel trap door while setting fish traps. The skipper provided first aid.
Non compliant pilot ladder. Multiple loose chocks and spreader bowed. Tripping line below lowest spreader.
Side ropes were worn with loose chocks and treads.
Passenger fell in internal stairwell and was transported by helicopter to hospital.
Crew member sustained a cut on their toe after dropping a knife on their foot.
Dragged anchor while moored during snorkelling trip.
Jet boat missed turn and ran aground. Passengers transferred to other vessel and continued journey. No injuries.
The pilot ladder was in poor condition with loose chocks.
One side of the pilot ladder was stretched so the first few metres of steps were no longer horizontal.
Steaming at cruising speed when main engine shut down leaving vessel adrift.  Detected a blocked fuel intake - was unblocked and engine started.  Steamed to port. No injuries.
Main engine failure requiring tug assistance requested by pilot.
Attempting a sharp turn, jet boat knifed, pulled out of manoeuvre and grounded in shallow water. Tried to rock boat to refloat but unsuccessful. No injuries.
Event Location: Dart River, upstream of Beansburn river

Brief Description: Vessel grounded and passengers transferred to other vessel.
Event Location: Dart River, between Routeburn and Paradise

Brief Description: During approach to island in extreme weather, pallets of ship's spares broke free and went overboard. Two box spare parts, one lifebuoy and five 25 litre cleaning products spilled on deck.
Jet boat hit submerged object. Passenger was thrown forward, sustaining spinal injuries. Passenger was airlifted to hospital for treatment.

After inspection it was found that the fire pump number 2. was found insufficient. It was later found to have electrical cabling around the impellor. Temporary repairs were effective, and a new pump was ordered.

Temporary loss of propulsion outside Tory Channel mouth. Diesel generator #2 overloaded and tripped other generators. Both propulsion drives shutdown with fault being isolated to an electronic or software failure in diesel generator #3.
Vessel has grounded after the skipper has tried to navigate a shallow channel in the Otago Harbour to avoid an inbound tanker. Miscommunication on timings between the vessel and Harbour Control.
Vessel missed turn and ran aground.

The engine cut out and the skipper attempted to restart the engine while a crew member put down the anchor. The engine did not start and the boat then got hit by a wave and flipped over. The fuel bayonet was not attached and caused the flip.

A deck hydraulic hose failed on the deck. Work was stopped immediately. Oil was sprayed over two crew members. SOPEP absorbent pads were quickly placed on deck around the affected area and all oil was retained onboard. The hose was replaced.
Vessel sunk at mooring after being hit by a cyclone.
Konsberg Digital LTU Soft Button System on bridge failed and unable to take control of vessel from the bridge.
The combination ladder had a stretched pilot ladder. The rungs at deck level were horizontal, but at 2m above the water the rungs were at an angle of approx. 30 degrees.

The vessel's engineering staff called the bridge to request stopping the starboard main engine due to the turbo unit overheating. Vessel proceeded out to sea on one engine and took the longer route for safety precuations.
The pilot ladder was secured to the deck strongpoints with lashings of insufficient diameter. It was considerably less than the ladder side ropes.

Vessel had main engine slow down alarm in the fairway. Tug was called to standby until vessel clear of the sharp turn. The vessel proceeded to open water for reboot of main engine control. System was working after reboot, vessel continued voayage.
Jetboat passenger sustained injured ribs after sliding to the side of the vessel during a spin.
Diver failed to surface after a dive. Their body was subsequently recovered from the seabed.  Refer to full description for analysis review.
All lower rungs of ladder were loose and rotated under foot. One chock was broken, and the lowest step was perished.
The pilot ladder was in poor general condition. There were multiple loose steps and ladder stretched and not horizontal.
The pilot ladder was in worn condition with multiple loose steps.

Crew shut the main engine down due to a failure of a cooling fan on the engine electronics power supply. The shutdown prevented any damage to the engine. Repairs to the fan were effected and fishing operations were then resumed.

A vessel began taking on water. The amount of water taken on board exceeded capabilities of bilge. The boat capsized and two crew members swam to shore to alert emergency services. Three crew were rescued as they were unable to swim to shore.

A fresh water cooling hose had failed resulting in a loss of coolant. The standby generator was started and put online. Main engine was shut down to allow replacement of the hose. The cooling water was then replenished. The engine was restarted.
Steam engine sprung a leak causing loss of power.  Wind and tide carried vessel under a mooring line of a bulk carrier, grazed aft canopy and snapping flag pole.  No Injuries.
Pilot ladder standards - steps had uneven gaps and were on an angle.
A passenger collapsed onboard the vessel. Crew decided to turn the vessel back around and the passenger was transported to hospital.

Crew observed water leak from main engine #2 economiser. The impact of the leak was affecting exhaust temperatures of main engine. Vessel was capable of sailing using port engine and lower RPM on starboard.
The pilot ladder was stretched. Steps were no longer horizontal and multiple rungs had loose chocks.
Passenger fell overboard. Life ring was deployed and the skipper entered the water to assist.
The pilot ladder had shackles, knots and splices in the ropes.
Stevedore lost their footing on a ladder, releasing their hold on the hatch lid, which came down on their finger and causing a crushing injury.

The fan on auxiliary blower #1 found to have slipped and become misaligned on the shaft, not sitting properly in its housing. The fan was electrically isolated and tagged-out at its supply breaker on the main switchboard. It will be removed.
The engine RPM reduced back while vessel was moving through the channel. The engine did not stop, but was significantly slower. Tugs were called to assist and be on standby.

There was reduced power from the vessel and the starboard engine stopped running. The engine would not restart. A spare boat was sent to retrieve the passengers. It was found that the starboard engine had no spark. The vessel was repaired.
Vessel struggled to hold the ships bow due to strong tidal flow. Prolonged pushing at high RPM caused port main engine to fall into reduced power mode.
Crew member's hand crushed while stowing equipment on vessel. Their hand was bandaged, with only minor injuries sustained.
The pilot ladder had loose chocks allowing steps to rotate under foot. Tripping line was rigged lower than the lowest spreader.
During training session vessel (RIB) hit large wave and capsized.  No injuries.
Lifting gear failure resulting in logs dropping.

One person was crushed between two trucks on the main vehicle deck, receiving injuries to their wrist and ribs. They were removed from the vessel by ambulance and the scene was frozen pending an investigation.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Grounding - hit rock while trawling for kingfish.
Grounding - Jet boat undertook a spin and landed on beach. Unloaded passengers and pushed vessel back in to the water. Continued journey with 14 passengers.
A passenger tripped while descending set of stairs and sprained their ankle.
Passenger tripped on a lashing point on deck, hitting their face on side of the vessel's rail wagon. Injuries included cut to the right eye, broken nose and loss of two teeth.
Catamaran dragged anchor under wind gusts of over 35Knts.  Vessel grounded and could not move till high tide at 1230 hours. No injuries.  Vessel sailed to lift out facility at Gulf Harbour.
Equipment failure - master told pilot that he was not sure about reliability of remote controls on bridge wings so returned to bridge.
Vessel passed a large log off Devonport coastline that could be a navigational issue.
Stevedore removed the pin of a protection guard that was obstructing a lashing bar, causing the bar to fall and strike the stevedore. Went to hospital and was diagnosed with concussion.
IRB landed heavily after cresting a large wave. Vessel operator fell to the deck, sustaining multiple foot fractures.
Injury sustained by pilot boat crew member whilst trying to board cruise ship.
Injury sustained by pilot boat crew member whilst trying to board cruise ship.
Electrical power failure - passengers transferred and vessel towed back to base.
Vessel made contact with debris and lost power in drive train. Safely returned on one engine.
The wave on the sandbank stacked up quicker than the master anticipated causing the vessel to capsize. No injuries or damage occurred.

A passenger missed their step and fell backwards, hitting their lower back and causing a laceration on the back of their head. First aid was given on board and they were transported to hospital once on shore.
The Fast Rescue Craft (FRC) self righting arrangement was damaged due to heavy weather.
Medical event requiring emergency evacuation - coordinated by RCCNZ.
Injury - crew member struck on face with clip from buoy cutting cheek.

Vessel came through breakwater and was ordered engine dead slow astern. The engine indicator showed ahead. The vessel requested to stop engine and ordered astern again. The master was told to start astern to stop the ship.
Ferry collided with wharf while departing.
Equipment Failure - trip hazards and ladder without protective frame.
Log Handling - gear failure resulting in logs dropping (no injuries).
Equipment failure - old lashing wires entangled on port anchor.
Medical event - crew member unable to swallow food or drink.
Vessel struck log and damaged propeller of starboard hand outboard. No injuries or further damage.
Propulsion failure of main engine.  Requested anchorage to effect repairs.
Multiple injuries sustained by crew members after vessel was struck by a series of large waves while crossing the Greymouth bar, causing the vessel to roll violently.
Propulsion failure - portside gearbox shaft seal alarm after vessel came alongside.
Close quarters - confronted by IRB in a dangerous manner during a regatta.
Another vessel ran into the back of the vessel, causing minor damage to the rails.
Equipment failure - crack found in bottom of stern ramp.
Propulsion failure on port engine. Ferry completed journey on starboard engine.
A mechanical failure of the crane resulted in drop of electric motor onto vessel. No injuries occurred.
While alongside pumping sludge into tanker, the tanker overflowed.  No oil spilled into the water.
Collison between tug and cargo ship causing damage to hull of cargo ship.
Collison between tug and cargo ship causing damage to hull of cargo ship.
Vessel tied up at wharf overnight.  When engine started next day, slack mooring line had gone overboard and got sucked in propulsion unit causing engine to stall.
Electrical power failure resulting in complete shutdown in operations while at berth.
The pilot ladder steps were not level.
Testing new motors with new steering. Made sudden turn to port manoeuvre. Master was not braced and hit their shoulder on the starboard side.
Equipment failure - replacement part not working.  Reverting to supplier with additional order.
The pilot ladder was in poor condition with loose chocks and stretched side ropes.
Customer sustained a dislocated shoulder while climbing dive ladder.
A swell caused the boat stern to rise and bow to lower and the ladder disconnect from the vessel after making contact with the ground.
The skipper sustained a shoulder injury after repeated pull starts of outboard motor experiencing engine trouble.
Charter vessel with passengers on board unable to start engine. Radio called to another vessel for a tow and safely returned to port.

Whilst picking up the net, the tide pushed the vessel over their gear and propeller tangled up their net, stalling the main engine. Vessel was towed to a bay and anchored overnight. Divers cleared fouled propeller and assessed for damage.
Passenger knocked off their feet by a gust of wind. First aid was administrated on board.
Wind gusting 50kts caused vessel to come off berth about one metre and one mooring rope (breast line) parted at the aft mooring station.
Due to high swells spring line strands broke and rope protector hit crew member's feet. This caused them to stumble and fall, though the crew member did not sustain any injuries.
Electrician received an electric shock while repairing refrigeration unit.
While discharging cargo, noted water in #1 cargo hold. No bilge alarm sounded. Found water seeping from ballast tank into cargo hold.
Passenger tripped on high lip on entry door, sustaining minor injuries.  Weather was calm. All door entries have hi-vis tape and passengers told to be weary of high lips around doorways.
Collison between two jet skis at boat ramp while avoiding log, resulting in serious injuries to one person.
Crew member tripped over mooring lines of adjacent yacht, fell forward and fractured arm.

Three SUP users were seen struggling to make their way to shore. A kayaker went out and started towing them back to shore, but struggled due to the condition. Coastguard and Police were called to assist. The police boat towed everyone back safely.

The driver misjudged the wave and got pushed off the jet ski. When swimming back to the jet ski another wave caused the jet ski to capsize. The driver then re-righted the jet ski, started the craft and continued operations.
The boat was heading out to sea, hit a wave and stalled. The crew could not get it restarted in time as a second wave approached and flipped the boat.

A vessel with three people on board lost propulsion and an aquaculture vessel responded to rescue crew and tow back to port. While being towed, the vessel hit the hull of the aquaculture vessel, causing its windscreen to break.
During emergency generator routine testing there was an explosion of #1 cranking batteries. No injuries occurred as all the staff were outside at the time of the explosion.
During national competition, vessel was hit by heavy surf and capsized. Two minor injuries.
While trying to put the vessel onto the cradle at Nelson Slipway, wind pushed fishing trawler into three other berthed vessels.
While trying to put the vessel onto the cradle at Nelson Slipway, wind pushed fishing trawler into three other berthed vessels.
While trying to put the vessel onto the cradle at Nelson Slipway, wind pushed fishing trawler into three other berthed vessels.
While trying to put the vessel onto the cradle at Nelson Slipway, wind pushed fishing trawler into three other berthed vessels.
Pilot ladder standards - side ropes stretched and ladder not horizontal. Lower rubber rungs deformed and chocks are loose, allowing steps to rotate.

The vessel struck a sunken rock at a speed of approximately five knots. They manoeuvred into clear water and inspected the vessel for damage. Damage had occurred to the internal grid structure but no water came in.
Both crew members knocked overboard by waves. The vessels throttle was stuck and kept heading out to sea, and was later recovered washed ashore approximately 20km to the south.

The vessel bumped the fixed navigation marker at the entrance to the river on the port side of the vessel. No passengers were on board, and no physical harm occurred to the people. A minor dent was sustained on the vessel port side.
Two members of the public fell from floating pontoon into the Kaiapoi River between passenger vessel and berthing face of pontoon. Rescued by two bystanders.
Commercial trawling vessel approached stationary recreational fisherman in a stabicraft vessel.  No one could be seen at the helm of the trawler and had to move to avoid collision.
Commercial trawling vessel approached stationary recreational fisherman in a stabicraft vessel.  No one could be seen at the helm of the trawler and had to move to avoid collision.
Two vessels collided with each other after they were heading in opposite directions down the river. Minor damage occurred.
A passenger was unsteady on their feet before collapsing,  hitting their head on the door frame. The patient was taken to hospital by a rescue helicopter.
A crew member tripped and fell on the ships rail deck, injuring their right arm. An ambulance attended the scene and they were taken to hospital.

The air starting valve of the main engine malfunctioned. The pilots were immediately informed, and the vessel dropped anchorage. The air starting valve was replaced. The engines were tested and worked. The vessel carried on their voyage.
The vessel lost propulsion and was blown to another Bay. Anchor was readied for deployment and a call was put out for help. Another vessel came and towed the vessel back for repairs.
The generator shut down, as well as the engine. The anchor was dropped, and the vessel dragged due to the anchor not holding. The vessel was towed back to the marina for repairs.
Capsize of IRB whilst training.  No injuries.
Near miss with ferry causing launch to collide with a pile on the wharf.
Near miss with ferry causing launch to collide with a pile on the wharf.
Poor quality pilot ladder with multiple loose chocks.

Passenger disembarked the vessel during a 1.5m to 2m swell. They slipped while attempting to exit and fell onto the bow pontoon hitting their head. The passenger was returned to shore immediately and treated as a suspected spinal or neck injury.
Vessel motor kicked out resulting in loss of stability.
Pilot Ladder standard - in poor condition with multiple loose steps. Must be replaced.
Jet ski made collided with a buoy at speed, resulting in significant injuries to the operator.
Vessel propeller struck unknown hazard. Limited visibility prevented crew from spotting hazard in advance or identifying it following contact.
A crew member was pinched between the wharf and handrail of the vessel, sustaining head injuries. They were taken to hospital for treatment.
Electrical power failure resulting in reduced power.
Wind gusting to 60knts caused break in mooring lines. Gantry crane jib came into contact with ship unloader and damaged it.
Pilot Ladder in poor condition and requires replacement.
Failure to give way resulting in a near miss with other vessel.
Failure to give way resulting in a near miss with other vessel.
Pilot Ladder in poor condition and in need of replacement. Loose trends and rotates under foot.

A digger was on fire in the cargo hold. The digger was extinguished by the crew using fire pump and hoses. The fire was caused from a mechanical issue and removed from the vessel. No injuries or damage occurred to the vessel.

The vessel came into contact with the edge of a small shoal, clipping the tips of starboard propeller blades. The vessel carried on due to no immediate damage. A full inspection was made and two of the three propeller blades were damaged.
Dive charter and was unable to restart engine. Coastguard called to tow vessel back to port.
Newly installed AIS set up incorrectly, giving no ship location data.
The pilot ladder bottom steps were placed at an incorrect angle.
Vessel made contact with the a channel marker beacon while trying to avoid two inbound pleasure crafts that had turned to port instead of passing port to port.
Tug came into contact with container vessel. Minor damage to tug.

Tug came into retrieve line and hit the stern of the vessel with it's port side, and slid under the cutaway. This resulted in damage to the tugs handrail and bulwark. No damage to the departing vessel. No injuries.
The ship had lost main engine power and requested a tow to harbour. The vessel was picked up for tow a few hours later and then brought into the channel where tugs took the vessel to berth.
Port side main engine went on automatic shutdown. Continued on one engine for 35 minutes until repair made.
Scull travelling parallel to beach accidentally struck the head of a swimmer with their oar.

The vessel was assisting another vessel and as they approached the other vessel they dipped below their gunnel. The gunnel came into contact with the vessel and damaged the navigation light and front grab rail.
Event Location: North West off Great Mercury Island

Brief Description: No response from the port side propeller and the bow drifted towards the pile on the berth. The ramp of the ferry settled on the pile. Another vessel assisted in getting the vessel off the ramp. Everything was then offloaded to be assessed.
A loud bang was heard and it was apparent that the boat had hit the river bed. The boat continued to operate satisfactorily. The boat was checked with no significant damage observed.
Loose treads were on the steps of the pilot ladder. The steps also rotated under the foot and a number of chocks were loose.
Governor failure on main engine whilst on route to New Zealand.
On voyage from Sydney to Wellington main engine stopped and vessel was brought to a safe anchorage.
Vessel had three events - lube oil low pressure, anchor fouled and main engine overspeed.
Propulsion failure. Restarted engine but error remained. Returned to ramp. Went into reverse causing boat to turn 10 degrees and missing trailer. Maneuverered by hand onto trolley.
A crew member was climbing down the back hatch when the wind caught the hatch and blew it shut, landing on their hand.
While lifting the engine room hatch to reattach hinges and struts, the engineer stumbled and one foot slipped down in to the engine room causing a torn ligament in their knee.
Pilot ladder stretched and incorrect type of rope.
A crew member fell during a large roll in heavy weather. They were taken to hospital and diagnosed with fractures to their hand and neck.
Yacht got caught in storm. Vessel rolled and was de-masted. Skipper rescued from vessel by nearby trawler.
The pilot ladder was in poor condition with loose chocks and steps.
On departure, main engine only able to operate on dead slow ahead.
While securing vessel to wharf, wake of another vessel caused it to move and a person went overboard.
The vessel took a wrong turn to avoid another vessel and became beached. All passengers on board were uninjured.

The operator was caught off guard when the crew let out a loud shout. The operator looked back to see the issue while taking off throttle. This caused the sled of the jet ski to catch an edge and stop. The operator was ejected from the jet ski.
Vessel ran out of fuel. Anchored while Coastguard delivered extra fuel. Returned safely to shore.
SOLAS vessel anchored above fishing ropes that could have caused entanglement. No response to VHF 16 calls to vessel.
Contact with another vessel while reversing out of berth. No injuries.
Contact with another vessel while reversing out of berth. No injuries.
Whilst at sea on route to port, malfunction reported on No. 1 D/G engine. Other two are operational.
Taking a lift of 12m logs from trailer. Logs almost fell out due to being lifted up on an angle.
Passenger had an allergic response to food consumed on board vessel. Skipper returned to wharf and the passenger was transferred to ambulance for treatment.
Pilot ladder had loose chocks and steps. Recommended replacement.

The river sea swell moving up river caused a gaffe to become dislodged from bow area.  Crew went to retrieve as vessel went over training wall.  One of the stern drives connected with wall causing motor to lift.
On lake found capsized trailer sailor (CAT) with person sitting on hull. Tried to tow back to berth but unable due to weather. Righted vessel and it sailed safely back to berth.
Pilot ladder in poor condition.  Multiple steps rotated underfoot.
Crane struck other crane while loading cargo.
Main Engine slow down alarm activated on first start.
Pilot ladder poor quality with very loose chocks allowing treads to rotate.
Inflatable vessel hit by wave and flipped.
AE fuel module pressure dropped and RPM decreased, causing vessel to lose power.
Ammonia leak occurred in the vessel ammonia plant room. Room was evacuated. Source of leak identified as a fitting which had been replaced by engineering officers. No injuries.

After casting off from berth, main engine failed to fire ahead. Held vessel in tide with tugs. After 15 minutes decided to re-position vessel to another berth to allow other terminal shipping to continue.
Yacht hit rock and sunk. Three people rescued from rock.
Launch passed yacht between 20-40 metres at high speed causing yacht to roll and mast to snap.
Launch passed yacht between 20-40 metres at high speed causing yacht to roll and mast to snap.
Crew member slipped onto a gunnel impacting right side of their ribcage.
Vessel hit by wave from side and rolled over.
Charter vessel departing wharf with eight customers heading out of harbour at 17 knots. Hit a submerged log. Headed back to wharf to off load passengers and check vessel.

Near miss with recreational vessel which was anchored in the middle of the channel. After repeated short blasts and verbal warnings, turned to starboard and passed recreational vessel 3-5 metres off port side.

Near miss with recreational vessel which was anchored in the middle of the channel. After repeated short blasts and verbal warnings, turned to starboard and passed recreational vessel 3-5 metres off port side.

Near miss with recreational vessel which was anchored in the middle of the channel. After repeated short blasts and verbal warnings, turned to starboard and passed recreational vessel 3-5 metres off port side.
Vessel tethered to a pile. Pile suddenly snapped and fell, hitting side of the vessel.
While departing wharf, fishing vessel has side swiped a passenger vessel resulting in crushing of dingy hoisted on a davit on port side.  No injuries and minor damage to tender.
While departing wharf, fishing vessel has side swiped a passenger vessel resulting in crushing of dingy hoisted on a davit on port side.  No injuries and minor damage to tender.
Jet boat beached after driver missed downstream turn.
Collision between recreational vessel and passenger ferry, resulting in one passenger overboard and the ferry skipper sustaining serious injuries.
Collision between recreational vessel and passenger ferry, resulting in one passenger overboard and the ferry skipper sustaining serious injuries.
Near miss. Fishing vessel bearing down on cargo ship. Tugs and cargo ship sounded horns and fishing vessel altered course.
Near miss. Fishing vessel bearing down on cargo ship. Tugs and cargo ship sounded horns and fishing vessel altered course.
Pulling string of cray pots, crew member got leg caught in rope, causing a  crushing injury to their calf muscle.
Passenger vessel off course and without propulsion. Another ferry in the vicinity approached and provided assistance, transferring passengers across and returning them to port.

Fisheries officer knocked their head on the roof of wheelhouse of a fishing vessel while transferring from patrol vessel. Following the incident, the individual reported experiencing signs of concussion.

Fisheries officer knocked their head on the roof of wheelhouse of a fishing vessel while transferring from patrol vessel. Following the incident, the individual reported experiencing signs of concussion.
Vessel struck submerged object while traveling at 20 knots.
Passenger was moving their pipe cot when it accidentally fell on a crew member below.

The vessel departing harbour experienced a power failure to all generators and main engine. The vessel began to drift in rough weather conditions before conditions stabilised and the vessel was towed into sheltered waters.
Anchor winch failed and released the chain causing vessel to go sideways, get stuck and then swamped by waves.

Whilst holding position off the barge ramp to allow another barge to complete loading operations, the starboard quarter made contact with channel marker. Red light was still operational. No damage to vessel.
Engine issue led to the boat contacting an underwater rock. No injuries and minimal boat damage occurred. The boat returned to jetty under its own power.
Stevedore suffered injury to leg while trying to remove a stuck twist lock.
Passenger was on the bow when rough weather hit, causing passenger to lose balance and fall over.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
While on kayak padding trip, one tourist began to have a seizure.
Vessel rolled whilst hauling gear. Deckhand put out their hand for balance but their hand was crushed against the gantry.
Ammonia leak in engine room. Returned to port.
Crew told deckhand that the master would wake them for the final watch keep. The master fell asleep and ran the vessel aground.
Slowed passenger vessel to allow barge to pass, then attempted to put port engine back into gear and engine stalled.
Jet boat turned wide and stern was caught in the shallow water. No injuries.
Charter fishing vessel hit large swells and passenger went overboard. Was rescued with only minor cuts sustained.
Oil spill from aft seal tank. Isolating valves closed preventing further loss.
Vessel started flooding and was necessary to ground vessel. Once on shore checked and found entry of water was due to no bung. Reinserted bung, bilge pumped water out and resumed activities.
During a jet boat spin, passenger shifted heavily in their seat, making contact with another passenger and sustaining a shoulder injury.
Two jetboats collided during race event, causing injuries to three occupants.
Hydraulic hose split and approximately 100ml of hydraulic fluid went overboard.
Motor came off the back of IRB but not lost due to safety strop. The momentum of the Inflatable Rescue Boat (IRB) stopping caused the crew person to fall out of the IRB.

Strong winds dragged anchored passenger vessel closer to shore. While trying to manoeuvre vessel tender away from the rear of the boat, it swung on its stern line, making contact with the vessel and causing minor damage to the tender fuel pump.
Vessel contacted by Coastguard to look out for two people in a small kayak.  Found them and returned them to shore.
Report of a jet ski collision.
While transiting inbound through Baywaters Channel, vessel responded to person in the water under distress. Made rescue and returned to marina.
Loss of propulsion due to uninitiated manual shutdown on No. 2 main engine on starboard side. Able to continue with safe passage.

Skipper anchored vessel and went for two hour walk. When they returned, the tide had gone out and the vessel was grounded.  Next high tide was not until 2345, so Coastguard returned them to shore. Owner collected vessel later.
Coming into the marina, 15-20 knot winds caused vessel to drift towards jetty.  Eventually berthed successfully with no damage or injuries.
Forward draft incorrectly informed to pilot as 9.6m was actually found to be 10.4m.
While crane was lifting logs off trailer some fell onto wharf. No injuries or damage.
Pilot ladder - pilot noticed large gaps between chocks on several steps. Informed master of need for replacement.
Laceration to right wrist with arterial bleed.
Crew member experienced chest pains. Coastguard retrieved crew member and returned them to shore.
Close quarters - several incidents involving recreational vessels failing to observe Maritime Rules Part 22.
While inspecting cargo hold vent flap, the securing hook released and the vent flap closed on the fingers of crew member.
New pilot ladder with aluminium crimps. Loose chocks causing lower section of steps to be loose and rotate under foot.
While retrieving port anchor, bolt on engagement gear sheared. This caused the anchor to free fall out to nine shackles.
Vessel left marina when inner tub front bag deflated with loud bang. Returned to the marina for repairs.

During training session involving four Inflatable Rescue Boats (IRBs), one of the IRB's has approached a stationary IRB at speed and failed to see the vessel resulting in a collision. Two crew members in stationary vessel received minor injuries.
Prior to pilot board, main engine of vessel failed so returned to anchor and rectified the issue. Again main engine failed on departure from the terminal.
Vessel broke free of mooring in 40 knot winds making contact with another vessel and coming to rest in mud at the edge of an oyster farm. Refloated and hauled out of water for inspection.
Log handling - logs dropped into ship hold. Digger operator was in safe zone.
Crew member reported feeling unwell. Support vessel arranged to collect them and transfer to hospital for treatment.
Pilot ladder had a number of loose chocks and treads that rotated under foot.
Near miss between two commercial vessels.
Near miss between two commercial vessels.
Crew member slipped on wet deck and injured knee.
Crew member entering incinerator room placed their hand on the sea door framing. The door swung closed catching their fingers between door and frame.

Crew member checking cleanliness of a moving belt when their glove was caught by a conveyor roller, pulling their arm into the conveyor framework. Laceration to right arm treated and returned to work.
Pilot ladder stretched and in poor condition.
Deploying vessel stabilizer arms as vessel was pitching side to side. Vessel rolled and rope looped around thumb of crew member removing the tip of the thumb.
Vessel engine remained in the critical revolution range instead of increasing through. This resulted in the engine having to be stopped during pilotage.

Vessel was berthing at loading wharf. The tide was lower than expected and the vessel settled onto the muddy bottom as the tide was ebbing out. The vessel was refloated on the next tide. Sea trials confirmed no damage occurred due to the event.
The pilot ladder lower spreader was bent and the ladder had multiple loose chocks.
Propulsion failure on sailing yacht. Returned safely to port under sail. 25 passengers onboard and Coastguard was called to be on standby and track voyage.

Vessel's engine failed to start astern when pulling up off the berth with little clearance ahead. Pilot ordered dead slow astern to stop vessel on berth. Engine did not fire. Pilot ordered tugs to lie back to arrest vessel as engine had failed.
Yacht collided with the port side of anchored charter vessel causing superficial damage to the weather dodger and belting of the vessel.
Docking training at disused fuel jetty resulted in deflated port bow pontoon after making contact with the wharf.
Logs dropped four metres from ship crane. No injuries occurred. Minor damage to hand rail on vessel.
Crew member cut end of their thumb while cutting bait.
Back spring mooring lines on vessel moored to CTS jetty parted. Master called harbour radio requesting tug assistance to re-secure new mooring lines.
Vessel drifted into open ocean and capsized in rough weather. The four occupants were rescued from the water by a rescue boat and taken to hospital for treatment.

Alarm raised and crew evacuated following ammonia leak. Freezing plant shut down and freezer water spray operated after ammonia dispersion. Investigation revealed pin hole in hose on freezer. Hose replaced.
Main engine failed in rough weather (8m swells). Vessel made contact with RCCNZ with PANPAN requesting assistance. Vessel was outside NZ 12 nautical miles. Concerns about containers going overboard.
The low pressure fuel supply line flange leaked due to vibration and loosening of flange nuts. Main engine was stopped and nuts tightened to stop the leakage.
Propulsion failure while coming into harbour requiring support from tug boat.
While loading logs using ship crane and shore excavator, a log has fallen and hit life raft and life raft rack at forecastle deck.
Moving to pilot station vessel lost main engine power. Vessel anchored to resolve issues. Pilot boarded and took ship out on sea trials prior to bringing vessel into port with no further incident.
Passenger ferry entered shallows to avoid passing speedboats. Grounding averted, though the seabed was disturbed by the vessel engines.
Wastage through the main deck by a lashing pot. Water from the lashing pot seeped under the coating and caused the wastage. Doubler plate installed over area after lashing pot removed.
Jet boat rolled over on the Rangitata River causing five injuries. Two in a serious condition. All were flown to hospital by Emergency Medical Service helicopters.

Vessel fishing at anchor when another vessel approached at approximately 10 knots with no indication of attempt to deviate. Passengers prepared to jump overboard as no one at helm. Last minute deviation by the approaching vessel prevented impact.
Bridge relaying control to engine control room not operating. Master failed to notify or declare issue to pilot. Issue was rectified prior to departure on 14 May 2023.
Private launch ran aground at base of Mount Maunganui. Vessel was refloated and proceeded to anchor.
While lasher was lashing a container, a bar from another container fell and landed on their hand, crushing their fingers and causing moderate injuries.
After break in crane runner wire, stevedores requested inspection of other ship cranes. Crane No. 1 and No. 3 failed.
Crew member leapt from vessel to wharf. Vessel lost control, turned sharply and struck the wharf.

Dive vessel left berth to head out. Half hour into trip smoke starting coming out of engine vents. Engines were stopped, Mayday call made and everyone put on life jackets. Inspected and confirmed it was steam by a burst hose from the water cooler.

Brand new ladder as a replacement following previous Port of Tauranga Limited visit. Ladder is an aluminium crimp style with loose chocks. Data plate covered with sticker and different manufacturer name.
Net wrapped around propeller. Could not move forward or backward. Coast guard towed vessel back to slipway.
Grounding - hit submerged rock but no damage whilst close to shore.
Pilot ladder standards - combination ladder with lower platform approximately 3m from the water - IMO standard is 5m. Due to calm conditions, pilot boarded with care.

Pilot was descending pilot ladder when due to an unexpected swell, pilot kicked off using manropes. Landed on pilot boat and fell on their knees and side. Their lower back heavily struck the bollard located in the middle of the foredeck.

Pilot was descending pilot ladder when due to an unexpected swell, pilot kicked off using manropes. Landed on pilot boat and fell on their knees and side. Their lower back heavily struck the bollard located in the middle of the foredeck.
Pilot ladder standards - combination ladder had a stretched ladder. The bottom rungs of ladder were at an angle of approximately 30 degrees.
Pilot Ladder Standards - gangway too low (less than 2m above base of ladder) and ladder being hit by waves making it wet and dangerous.
Yacht got swamped by big waves and ran aground. Master was rescued by Coastguard. Secured vessel to mooring until owner could arrange salvage.
Propulsion failure - pilot ordered dead slow ahead to reduce the speed and assist the swing with the rudder. The engine failed on multiple occasions.
Pilot ladder standards - numerous steps rotated underfoot due to loose chocks.
Non compliant pilot ladder.

Starboard main engine lube oil balance line snapped. Oil pressure dropped causing the engine to shut down. Engineers identified the issue and proceeded to repair the pipe. Starboard engine restarted and operational at 1513hrs.
Passenger slipped on tiles in central stair well and twisted their knee. Ambulance met vessel at port.
Pilot ladder standards - ladder stretched and steps rolled under foot due to loose chocks.
Commercial diver sustained lacerations to the head after being struck by the vessel's propeller. They were taken to hospital in a critical condition.
While undertaking sea trials, master heard a loud noise, after which vessel lost propulsion. Did a dive to check and observed serious damage to propeller. Slowly returned to port for repairs.
While lifting dead float (float full of water) strops attached to backbone broke and flew up into skippers face resulting in cut lip.
Near miss of yacht with passenger vessel within harbour bridge precautionary area. Passenger ferry had right of passage and had to pull engines out of gear to avoid a collision.
Factory hands were feeding a belt onto a conveyor. Hydraulics started and conveyor moved suddenly causing laceration to thumb. Taken to A&E for stitches then rejoined the vessel.
While off loading persons to beach, swell surge caught stern turning vessel side on and causing it to ground. Vessel was refloated. No injuries or damage.
Grounding  of vessel. Assisted by another to tow off beach at high tide and proceed under their own power.
Jet boat grounded during training with vessel driver and trainer. No damage or injuries.
Vessel returning over bar broached and swamped.
While tug was towing 180m SOLAS vessel, small pleasure craft did not respond to sound signals. Master had to take evasive action to avoid a collision.
Report to RCCNZ of propulsion failure 14 nautical miles from North Cape. No visible signs of damage to main engine. No immediate danger from proximity to land.
Master was reaching around ladder to open crossover valve and equalize rudders when their foot slipped off main bearer. Their foot became stuck in bilge, causing their knee to twist.

Bulk carrier inbound under pilotage sounded five short blast to catamaran yacht that was heading for a close quarters incident. Yacht was contacted on radio and said they would clear channel but did not alter course. Bulk carrier altered course.

Bulk carrier inbound under pilotage sounded five short blast to catamaran yacht that was heading for a close quarters incident. Yacht was contacted on radio and said they would clear channel but did not alter course. Bulk carrier altered course.
Low tide and vessel grounded at edge of channel becoming stuck on sandy bottom. Vessel was recovered and returned to port.
Pilot ladder in poor condition with multiple loose chocks.
Coming alongside the berth, main engine failed to start and tugs had to berth vessel.  Also noted the pilot ladder has multiple loose chocks and needs to be replaced.
Pilot ladder with bowed spreader and rusting steel. Ladder was in poor condition. Master informed and stated ladder would be replaced immediately.
Pilot ladder in poor condition.
Vessel ran aground on beach. Was able to be refloated. Five persons onboard and no injuries.
Engine room fire on vessel at wharf. Extinguished by 7:54 pm. No one on board at the time.
Main engine was unable to start due to an issue with a jammed starter valve. Vessel remained at anchorage for 2.5 hours until repair was carried out by ships engineers.
On retrieval of gangway, wires parted causing gangway to fall between wharf and vessel into the water. Hoisted back onto vessel and not usable until repaired and checked by approved person.
Oil spill while transferring engine room bilges into 20 litre plastic containers. Spill contained on board vessel.
Propeller fouled by fishing net.
During a rescue of crew from a 37 foot yacht in severe weather, rescue vessel had a collision with the yacht. All personnel returned safely to shore. Minor damage to rescue vessel.
During a rescue of crew from a 37 foot yacht in severe weather, rescue vessel had a collision with the yacht. All personnel returned safely to shore. Minor damage to rescue vessel.
Hydraulics stopped working. Cameras were checked in wheelhouse and saw smoke over hydraulic engine. Identified small fire which was extinguished. No injuries.
Pilot ladder had loose chocks on some steps and wear in vicinity of the crimps. Master stated intention to replace.
Pilot ladder standards - man ropes were too small in diameter and need to be replaced with SOLAS defined ropes.
While returning to port, deck hands alerted tug master to close proximity of a waka to the bow. Tug immediately stopped engines and waka passed around 50m off the port bow.
While returning to port, deck hands alerted tug master to close proximity of a waka to the bow. Tug immediately stopped engines and waka passed around 50m off the port bow.
On passage to next port, the vessel experienced heavy weather. Crew checked deck equipment and noted that port side anchor had gone overboard.
Vessel fire whilst moored. Extinguished by fire service and vessel towed to marina for removal. No oil spill or injuries.
While coming into harbour, the helmsman applied port helm resulting in swing towards outbound ferry. Master replaced helmsman with another.
Crew member fell three metres into the cargo hold. Severe injuries, with crew person taken to hospital.
Near miss with a recreational vessel that was coming towards commercial jet boat on the wrong side of the river. Jet boat had to take evasive action by conducting an emergency stop.
Lifting gear failure - hoist wire on crane number 2 snapped inside hull. No injuries or loss of cargo overboard.
Steward fell on gangway while offloading bags of laundry, hurting their back.
Requested whistle blow due to recreational fishing vessel being anchored in channel. Whistle did not work. Had to alter course around recreational fishing vessel.
Close quarters as car carrier made 90 degree turn to port, putting vessel in direct collision course with ferry.
Close quarters as car carrier made 90 degree turn to port, putting vessel in direct collision course with ferry.
Port shaft tripped and as a precaution, vessel was diverted into open water.
Vessel steering pumps not operational when testing steering before departure.
Jet boat driver training on river when vessel ran aground. No injuries or damage.
Starboard (stbd) engine was shut down due to stbd shaft alternator dropping out. Returned to berth.
Pilot ladder had numerous loose chocks and treads. Ladder needs replacement.
Passenger vessel near miss with another vessel due to AIS not working. Evasive action taken to avoid collision.
Passenger vessel near miss with another vessel due to AIS not working. Evasive action taken to avoid collision.
Charter vessel returning to port hit submerged object, damaging the stern leg of the outboard motor.
During inflatable rescue boat driver training, driver turning close to shore mistook a wave and fell overboard. No damage or injuries.
Vessel presented with a combination ladder arrangement. The accommodation ladder platform was low, approximately 2.5m above the water.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Main engine could not be started at berth. Pilot ordered check as the response time to start and stop was significant. Departure cancelled and sailing resumed ten hours later following repair.
Pilot ladder non-compliant due to accommodation ladder being a couple of metres above water. IMO requirement is 5m.
During driver training, instructor was driving with two passengers and made a fast turn, resulting in both passengers going overboard.
Crew member sustained thumb injury while manually handling a CTD carriage into position through the cutaway on the trawl deck.

During driver training, crew were simulating patient pickups when vessel turned into wave but failed to accelerate resulting in a capsize. Vessel uprighted and returned to shore. No damage or injuries.
Internet went down and was unable to get updates from electronic publications. OneOcean system was removed but unable to reinstall due to weak internet connection.
Pilot ladder had unsafe rigging. Was lashed to deck with rope and webbing type strop.
Mooring bowline slipped off cleat and boat lurched forward two metres down pontoon coming into contact with bollard on pier 6. Slight dent in ramp. No injuries.
While boarding vessel, passenger slipped on internal staircase and twisted ankle.
Pilot ladder retrieval line rigged aft and below spreader. Pilot ladder secured with small rope.
Crew member in freezer hold carrying a box of frozen fish. They slipped and landed on their hand, resulting in a cut to their right finger and a possible fracture.

Yacht caught in heavy seas suffered a rudder malfunction, then lost its anchor and began to drift toward the rocky coastline. A nearby fishing vessel responded to the stricken yacht and rescued the two passengers.
Near miss between two jet boats due to faulty radio.
Last spreader on pilot ladder was bowed. Rest of ladder in good condition.
While performing repairs, a large tool used to apply torque failed and a piece of the toll jaw broke off, falling from height off the working platform to the moon pool below.
Lost power to port shaft while berthing at Picton.
While crew were working to pull up collapsible stanchion, the ship rolled, causing the crane block to swing and hit a crew member. Injured crew member was transported by helicopter to hospital.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
Inflatable rescue boat was driven over a broken wave and hit by another, resulting in master and crew persons going overboard. No injuries.
Master appeared to misjudge a turn in the rigid inflatable boat (RIB). Their attempt at correcting course by rapidly changing direction resulted in crew member falling overboard.
Recreational boater rescued after becoming stranded on an iceberg in a South Island lake after their inflatable boat was damaged.
During testing of the ships bilge system, the system was found to not be fully operational. Class has been contacted.
Gangway on vessel damaged at aft end and not fit for use. Has raised edges.
Skipper of fishing vessel cut hand on board, this injury led to septicemia, resulting in several other serious medical conditions.
Crew member presented with shortness of breath and pale appearance. Vessel diverted to Tauranga and crewperson transferred to hospital.
While completing a mooring inspection, one yacht mast stay got tangled with another moored yacht, breaking the mast.
Vessel exceeded 5 knot rule during attempted rescue of two individuals swept out to sea.
Pilot ladder had a number of loose chocks and treads turned underfoot.
Contractor dropped spanner into ship freezer during unloading. No injuries.
The pilot ladder had loose chocks, the steps were rotating and not parallel.

When driving the boat downstream through the channel, the driver went wide on the corner and caught the stern of the boat on a gravel bar. This caused the boat to spin around and get stuck on a gravel bar.
The driver attempted a planned u-turn, the boat dropped off the plane and beached. There were no injuries or damage.
A worker was pushing a freezer tray when the vessel rolled,  causing the trays to slide out, crushing their leg. The master arranged a medvac for the injured worker from the ship.

A bow securing alarm sounded, crew members checked the PLC. There was no influx of water or failure. It was determined that a junction box had come loose resulting in loss of connection to the cleat sensor.
During voyage it was reported that the Ballast Water Treatment System was defective and unable to be used.

The bow blew off causing the vessel to turn sideways into close proximity to other vessels, lines in water and the wharf. When turning to clear the area the vessel hit the stern of a moored vessel with their Starboard stern. Minor damage occurred.

The bow blew off causing the vessel to turn sideways into close proximity to other vessels, lines in water and the wharf. When turning to clear the area the vessel hit the stern of a moored vessel with their Starboard stern. Minor damage occurred.

Training exercise involving the winching of a patient from deck of vessel. While attaching winch hook, vessel was buffeted by a wave causing the hook to make contact with the patient, chipping their tooth.
During training exercise, RIB vessels approached another vessel too fast, causing a collision which punctured the front bag of the RIB. There was no damage to the other vessel.
The vessel was fixed tight to berth when the tide withdrew, causing substantial damage to the vessel. The vessel was taken out to be serviced. No damage to the wharf occurred.
When the vessel was coming into the channel, they made contact with a newly developed sand bar. The vessel was able to move back to deeper water and return to shore. No injuries or damage occurred.

A submerged log was seen in front of the vessel. The skipper made a call that the vessel could not turn safely, the log went under the hull and struck the skegs at the rear. The engines were turned off, the bilge pump was checked. No damage occurred.

When passing a marker the wind and tide pushed the vessel into the marker pole at midships contacting the belting. As a result the marker pole was left on an approx. 30 degree list. No injuries or damage occurred. The harbour aster was notified.
The jet boat grounded while attempting to perform a spin.
Wire parted while crew were securing accommodation ladder for sea passage which resulted in ladder dragging through the water. No crew were harmed.
Engine failed to fire astern and ahead on multiple occasions when approaching and berthing vessel. It was also ‘slow’ to start when engine did fire. Tugs utilised to slow vessel and berth safely.
Vessel caught side on by wave, rolling the vessel.
Crew was pulling in fish, the hook came out of the fish and hit them in the eye, sustaining bruising.
Jet boat lost control during a turn, resulting in a beaching.

While receiving a sunken line of mussels, a bent hook pinged off the line and hit the crew member on their forearm of left hand resulting in a deep gash to their arm. First aid was applied and then they were taken to hospital for further treatment.
Staff member slipped on vessel stairwell, sustaining a fractured ankle.
MPI issued notice of redirection to vessel due to ballast water treatment system malfunctioning.

Crew member fell from the landing to the deck below (approx. 1.5m height), striking their head on the closed door. The crew member was stabilised in position and an ambulance was called. They were taken to hospital for tests and x-rays.
Master informed that there was a leak in a pipe in the engine room and the main engine needed to be stopped. Anchor dropped and repairs were conducted
Starboard motor lost RPM. Engine room was checked and fault unable to be identified. Steering was unavailable due to starboard motor running steering pump. The vessel was towed to port

The ship was notified of a crew member with suspected appendicitis who was requiring urgent attention. Ships agent notified RCCNZ who arranged for a rescue helicopter to transport the patient to hospital.
Jetboat grounded on riverbank. Passengers were transferred to another boat.
Vessel ran out of gas in the harbour shipping lane and was assisted by Coastguard.

Vessel dragged anchor due to wind strength and made contact with river mouth. The sips engines were restarted, crew mustered and vessel moved clear back into deeper water. The vessel re anchored, there were no injuries or damage.
Crew member grabbed a rope, pulling the front of their finger into the winch. This resulted in the crew member sustaining a finger injury.
Fatal recreational boating accident.
The pilot ladder was in poor conditions with numerous loose chocks causing rotating treads.
Navigational equipment faults reported by pilot.
Fuel was smelt from in the vessel, and was noticed on the floor. The vessel was striped down to find the leak. There was a crack in the top which was repaired.
The pilot ladder was in poor condition with numerous loose chocks and the steps rotating.
While emptying the codend of fish, a crew member's leg was caught between the hatch and the codend which resulted in a crushing injury.
Pilot ladder was in poor condition with numerous loose chocks and steps rotating under foot.
Pilot ladder lowest spreader had loose chocks.
On the way into port, the echo sounder equipment was not powering up. The vessel made it safely into port with pilot onboard. A technician was booked to make repairs.
Vessel was not under operation and separated from mooring line causing it to hit the wharf, damaging its outboard motor. No injuries were sustained.
Pilot ladder was worn and had multiple loose chocks.

Skipper on board passenger vessel in transit to berth heard a bang and felt vibrations. Revs were dropped on the main engine but vibration persisted. Vessel continued to port on minimal RPMs on port main engine.

During process of ordering counter helm to bring vessel back towards the channel centreline a loud bang was heard and vibration felt on bridge. The vessels handling became sluggish. Anchors were deployed and then recovered, tugs assisted the vessel.
Vessel experienced propulsion failure after departure from port. Vessel held fast with support from two tugs. An engine test was undertaken and vessel had a successful engine restart.

There was an escape of ammonia gas from a pinhole leak in compressor discharge line in engine room. Automatic ammonia detection alarm sounded and crew were evacuated. The compressor line was closed down and the area ventilated. The pipe was replaced.
An injury occurred to the crew member's hand, requiring two stitches.
Fatal recreational boating accident.

A jet boat was coming down the river when they clipped a tree protruding from the bank. This caused passengers to collide with one another, and knocked overboard. Injured passengers were medical evacuated to hospital.
Pilot ladder was substandard with steps rotating under foot.
Vessel collided with a swimmer, causing a 18cm scrape to their hip.
Fishing halted due to heavy weather. A large wave broke off the vessel's paravane boom causing it to fall overboard. Vessel returned to port to check for damage.
CCTV footage identified a vessel leaving the port leaving a spotted slick behind the vessel. Port staff responded by deploying two vessels to disperse the substance.
Vessel had just started trawling when a large rope became entangled in the propeller. This caused them to stop instantly.
Vessel made an urgency radio broadcast that they had lost all power. They reported needing a tow if they couldn't get the switchboard working.
Vessel just cleared harbour limits when main switchboard insulation alarm appeared on the IAS. An inspection showed a burnt transformer. Repairs were undertaken and the journey continued.

Fishing vessel broke away from mooring and washed up on the beach. While being towed backwards the vessel made contact with the wharf at Golden Bay due to poor weather conditions and loss of thrust and steering.
Vessel was undergoing planned maintenance when smell of ammonia was detected. As a precaution vessel alarm sounded and crew evacuated.
Hazardous material spilled on the foot of a crewmember, causing chemical burns.
Skipper suffered a medical event and fell, striking their head. RCCNZ were contacted and medvac arranged.
Vessel hit an uncharted rock in the bay, while in gear at idle speed.
While departing the wharf the main engine lost oil pressure and shut down. Vessel was approaching shoreline so anchor dropped. Main engine restarted and vessel continued without further problems.
The crewmember was pulling a pot they were struck in the eye by a loose wire. Basic first aid was applied.
Vessel grounded momentarily while crossing the river bar. There were no injuries or significant damage to the vessel.

The vessels starboard engine lost oil pressure. Engine was shut down and the vessel was returned to port under steam using the port engine. With limited manoeuvrability,  vessel made contact with another vessel at berth, sustaining minor damage.

The vessels starboard engine lost oil pressure. Engine was shut down and the vessel was returned to port under steam using the port engine. With limited manoeuvrability,  vessel made contact with another vessel at berth, sustaining minor damage.
Pilot reported an error with remote piloting, resulting in a near grounding.

Steering issues arose when auto pilot failed, causing vessel's starboard rudder to go hard to starboard. The auto pilot went into alarm and master was unable to regain manual control. Engines were shut down and rudder control was re-established.
Deck channels that containers lock into as door stops failed and containers fell into the sea.

Worker was removing floats from the backbone line during mussel harvesting operations. During this process, the worker cut the back of their left hand with their knife. First Aid was applied onboard, and the worker attended the emergency department.
Contact occurred between cranes two and three. Crane two luffed down onto the back of crane three. Crane limits changed since original inspection before loading commenced.

Vessel misjudged tide inside marina resulting in collision with poles on pier. The skipper struggled to manoeuvre the vessel in the confined space but eventually managed to get off the poles without any further damage to the vessel or marina.
Local wastage and holes found in the web of longitudinal I-beam of the accommodation ladder. The ladder was removed for repair.
Pilot Ladder - multiple loose chocks and stretched ladder.

Vessel was heading to Waiheke Island and was struck an object in the water. They raised PANPAN as the vessel started taking on water. Rescue boats came and helped pump out the water and they then headed back to harbour under tow.
Crew member grabbed anchor chain while it was being hauled. Their fingers were crushed between the roller and chain causing a laceration and bruising.
Logs slipped from deck stow. There was no risk to staff and minor vessel damage occurred.
Ladder secured with small ropes of insufficient diameter.

A recreational vessel failed to give way to passenger vessel. The master of the ferry avoided a collision by making an evasive manoeuvre to starboard. The recreational skipper accepted responsibility for not keeping a proper watch.

A recreational vessel failed to give way to passenger vessel. The master of the ferry avoided a collision by making an evasive manoeuvre to starboard. The recreational skipper accepted responsibility for not keeping a proper watch.
Pilot ladder was stretched and the rungs at bottom of ladder were sloping 30 degrees.
Lower end of handrail on shipside collapsed. Repaired by crew on board.
During driver training, jet boat hit gravel bar and ran aground. They were recovered by a tractor tow.
A passenger from a jet boat tour collapsed on the jetty after the trip. Ambulance were called and the person was taken to hospital for further assessments.
Trainee driver flipped IRB and had to return to shore to reinstate the motor.

The boat was moving slowly, the crew said their engine wasn’t operating correctly. They were told to come back to shore so it could be assessed. On their way back in the engine cut out and they were capsized. Both crew and the IRB were recovered.

While pot hauling, pulley got jammed and wind caused vessel to drift and make contact with a submerged rock. The line was released and the starboard engine was used to turn away from the headland. Minor damage to hull was sustained.

When trying to close the bow door, locking indicator lights did not indicate door closed. Heavy weather damage from sea state on the previous crossing had caused bent gussets and misaligned locking pin.
Pilot ladder was stretched on side so no longer horizontal and there were numerous chocks loose.
Vessel was passing through a channel and made contact with a submerged rock, sustaining minor scraping down the port side of hull.
About halfway into the voyage the ferry came off the plane and an engine issue was reported. The vessel continued on with one engine.

Stevedore identified failed access safety structure on the cross decks and lashing bridges. The terminal amended the stowage plans to a max of two boxes high which did not expose the stevedores and lashing gangs to the failure areas.
Propulsion failure of starboard main engine turbo.
The pilot ladder was poor quality with loose chocks causing rotating under foot.
The combination ladders lower stanchion was rigged inboard and no stanchion was rigged outboard or appropriate rope barrier to prevent a fall from heights.

A vessel was leaving the berth and noticed a vessel not under power or anchor. They changed their direction to ensure they passed via the stern to avoid any windage issues. Two divers appeared and the vessel stopped suddenly to avoid contact.
Passenger attempted to jump aboard departing ferry and fell into the water. No injuries were sustained.
Structural failure of an onboard ladder, a hole was found in the web of the longitudinal I-beam ladder. The ladder was removed from the service until repairs were made.
Vessel reported a failure of its communication system

Scaffold decking was being loaded onto a cradle. The punt was listing slightly towards stern. The punt was moved by hand and the cradle began to slowly move towards the stern. This increased the cradle displacement and caused the punt to capsize.

Scaffold decking was being loaded onto a cradle. The punt was listing slightly towards stern. The punt was moved by hand and the cradle began to slowly move towards the stern. This increased the cradle displacement and caused the punt to capsize.
Manropes on pilot ladder were less than the minimum diameter.
Pilot ladder lower trends were not horizontal and had loose chocks particularly on bottom spreader. The tripping line was incorrectly rigged.
While reversing off the ferry loading ramp, bus made contact with the ramp causing a small amount of oil to leak onto ramp. No oil entered the water.

The steering failed in the pilotage area. The master dropped the anchor and called for help to try and fix the issue. They engaged the emergency steering and made their way back to port with another vessel escorting them.
After just boarding ship, passenger tripped, falling and fracturing leg.

During the running-in process for the overhauled diesel generator at 80% load, the engine failed and the piston and conrod of the cylinder were ejected through the crank cover. No injuries were sustained.
Pilot ladder was stretched on one side resulting in the steps sitting at an angle. One of the manropes had a knot at the bottom.
Prior to departure and during main engine warm up, smoke and a small fire was discovered due to faulty alternator. The fire was extinguished immediately.
Cargo ship was on a collision course with another vessel and made no attempt to alter until radioed. They then altered course to port.
Cargo ship was on a collision course with another vessel and made no attempt to alter until radioed. They then altered course to port.

Port bridge wing rudder indicator showed 'hard a port' when 'hard a starboard' had been ordered. The Master declared a defect, that it was not working and claimed that a new one was on order for delivery and fitting the next day.
Pilot ladder was in poor condition with loose chocks and worn ropes.
While retrieving a jet boat from the river, the vessels engine failed and it drifted downstream. A second jet boat provided a tow back to jetty, there was no injuries or damage.
A derailment of first rake of wagons occurred while they were being pushed onto the vessel resulted in wagons entering the water. No spillage or injuries occurred.
While loading stabiliser arm into water, crew member wrapped rope around their hand this resulted in crushing and degloving of the index finger. They were taken to hospital for treatment.
While on passage to New Zealand, vessel lost depth sounder functionality. The depth sounder was not producing an appropriate picture and struggling to stabilise itself in auto mode.
IRB capsized during training exercise, resulting in injuries to four passengers.

Vessel touched the bottom and throttled back and let the vessel settle on the soft sand bottom approx. 40m inside the river entrance. They stopped both engines and deployed an anchor. They refloated and then went back to sea, before crossing the bar
Rogue wave crashed over fishing vessel and pushed crew against the port side shelter wall. One crew member sustained a sprained ankle, and another a broken tooth.

When entering berth and while in close proximity to other vessels, the vessel lost power to main engine and bow thruster. Smoke and ash emitted from the funnel resulting in the blackout. Tugs were used to safely bring dead vessel to berth.
A strong river current  pushed waka toward buoys, becoming tangled in cables. The crew were brought to shore by coastguard.

While winching boat onto trailer, another boat came from the other side of the slipway and struck the side of the vessel, pushing it into the slipway poles and leaving gouges out of the side that was hit.

Dinghy was struck by wave after its motor stalled, resulting in substantial flooding of the vessel. Vessel occupants evacuated the craft and swam to nearby rocks, after which ocean currents took the vessel out to sea.
While taking on a wave, IRB was pushed backward and hit crest of the wave, ejecting crew and capsizing boat.

While manoeuvring to berth the main engine failed to start, berthing continued with help of tugs. A strong leakage of air from valve was observed and once berthed, crew dismantled the valve and found the gaskets from the piston damaged.
Vessel was seen anchored in the shipping channel with no lights and no reply on channel 16.
During driver training, vessel ran aground while performing a planned turn.
EPIRB accidently activated after being immersed in water. Contact was made via VHF, confirming that it was an accidental activation.
During berthing of the vessel while under control of pilot and two tugs, the vessel made hard contact with the wharf causing large scrapes and dents to the hull.
A near miss occurred when a recreational vessel cut across the ships bow. The vessel blasted their horn five times and attempted to get the attention of the skipper but was ignored.
